threats: Molur et al. (2003) list the following threats: mining, firewood and charcoal collection and production, timber collection, and land distribution (resettlement) for landless people. Loss of habitat, urbanization, and electrocution by power lines are other threats identified for this species. More recently, human-langur interactions are on the increase, resulting in persecution in addition to unscientific and improper translocation.
population: The population numbers are not known. The species is observed to have declined through many parts of its range and it has a very patchy distribution due to human settlements and habitat loss. A continuing decline has been observed in area and quality of habitat, and a decline is inferred in the number of threat-based locations and mature individuals. The population is considered to have declined by 20-25% over the past three generations.
range: This species occurs in Bhutan, northern India (Haryana, Punjab, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, and West Bengal), and Nepal. It is found in the Himalayan foothills from Rajaji National Park (Uttarakhand) in the west to near Pankhabari (southwestern Bhutan) in the east, and throughout in between (Brandon-Jones 2004).
useTrade: The species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species is listed on CITES Appendix I, and the Nepal National Park and Wildlife Conservation Act (1973) lists it as a common animal (Molur et al. 2003). Occurrence in protected areas and in captivity are difficult to determine, owing to taxonomic uncertainty (M. Richardson pers. comm.), though it is known to occur in Rajaji National Park, Valmiki Tiger Reserve (A. Chhangani pers. comm.) and Corbett Tiger Reserve. Molur et al. (2003) list the following areas as in need of research: taxonomy, life history, survey studies, and limiting factor research. The following management actions are also needed: habitat management, wild population management, monitoring, and public education.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern as the species has a relatively wide distribution, is common, and the threats that it is facing are probably not resulting in a significant population decline.
habitat:
This species inhabits subtropical to temperate broad-leaved forest, pine forest, riparian mountain forest, riverine forest, rocky outcrops, and scrub jungle (Molur et al. 2003). A. Kumar (pers. comm.) has observed this species at 3,500 m, but has reports of its occurrence above this elevation, and it may be present up to 4,000 m. It is diurnal, terrestrial, arboreal, and folivorous. It is a diurnal and mainly terrestrial species, but may prefer arboreal canopies to flee from danger. Individuals are sometimes known to prefer barren rock cliffs for warmth. 

Langurs inhabit semi evergreen Sal (Shorea robusta), and alpine cedar forests. They could range as high as as 3,500-4,000 m and could well survive harsh winters and rainy summers in July-October and an annual rainfall as high as 2,500 m. Most of their diet is composed of leaves (40-60%), and the rest of  fruits (20%), ripe, unripe, herbaceous fruits. Other constituents are seeds, storage organs, roots, flowers, cambium, bark, twigs, coniferous cones, moss, lichens, epiphytic fern, young bamboo shoots, rhizome, grass and invertebrate animals. They prefer young leaves of broad-leaved deciduous trees than of evergreen trees. Seasonal variation in food preference is well pronounced. In spring and summer, when their diet is diverse, they feed on leaf clusters of Zanthoxylem nepalense, young leaves and bark of Jasminum humile, acorns, young deciduous leaves, and pine cones. In monsoon, feed on young deciduous leaves and fruits, while in autumn consume unripe fruits, seeds and fleshy ripe fruit, herb leaves and fruit, fleshy plant tissue, cultivated potato Solanum tuberosum. In winter, leaf buds, fruits (ripe) of Cotonester frigidus, Berberis aristata, leaf buds of Sorbus cuspidate, herbs and pinecones.

Birthing is concentrated between late winter to early spring and most mating happens between July-September. This arrangement allows for the langur infants to grow strong to survive their first winter. Besides, winters also mean migration down hill and the independent mobility of infants allows for easy migration for the both the mother and the infant. The inter-birth interval is usually 25 months, until the female gets pregnant and when she weans her infant. Inter-birth intervals are shorter when the infant dies and the female becomes receptive to mate again.

Like other Himalayan species, this species lives in multi-male, multi-female groups. Group sizes range between 4-47 individuals with 1-4 adult males and the female sex ratio 1-1.5-1.7. Larger groups may split while maintaining contact through intermittent call by males. The annual home range is 1,275-12,700 ha due to seasonal migration up and down the mountain. The call of dominant males is a ‘Wao’ or ‘Ua’ and these langurs don’t woop like the southern Indian or plain dwelling langurs. No infanticide during troop takeover was observed, despite 32 months of observation in Junbesi-Ringmo between Kathmandu and Nepal-Sikkim Border.
threats: The taxon, although widely distributed across the Himalayas, is subject to various threats from human interference including logging, habitat loss, fires, human habitations, expansion, developmental activities, encroachment, and war, which makes it susceptible to declines in areas subject to such threats (Molur et al. 2003). Hunting is an important threat in China (Z. Yongzu pers. comm.); this species is used in traditional native “medicine” in Tibet. This species is a dry meat delicacy in Nepal.
population: Global population numbers are unknown, although the species is generally common. The species is suspected to have declined in its range.
range: This species occurs in the monsoon forests of North Western Frontier province of Pakistan, through the high Himalayan elevations (1,500­-4,000 m) of India, Nepal and up to the Sankosh River in Bhutan.
useTrade: The species is occasionally hunted for meat and for 'medicinal' purposes in some parts of its range.
conservationActions: This species is listed in CITES Appendix I. The species is found in at least 10 protected areas in South Asia: Chail WS, Changthang WS, Dachigam NP, Hemis NP, Kanchanjunga NP and Karakoram WS in India; Langtang NP, Makalu Barun NP and Everest Nature Reserve in Nepal; and Manshi WS in Pakistan (Molur et al. 2003).

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened as, although the species is safe in a few habitats in Karnataka and Tamil Nadu, it is in significant decline in Andhra Pradesh and Sri Lanka. This is due to widespread habitat loss, hunting, and persecution through much of its range, but the rates of decline for this species are not yet high enough to qualify for Vulnerable.
habitat: This species is found in tropical dry evergreen forest, riparian, dry deciduous forest, coastal forest, gardens, around temples in Sri Lanka and cultivated areas (Molur et al. 2003). It is found in India up to 1,200 m and in Sri Lanka up to 500 m (Molur et al. 2003; A. Nekaris pers. comm.). It is arboreal, semi-terrestrial, folivorous and frugivorous, and diurnal. In southern India, these langurs are not very commensal with humans (M. Singh pers. comm.) except in areas like Doddabetta-Cauvery Wildlife Sanctuary, Bandipur, Horsley Hills, Tirupathi, Kurnool, and Chinnar. Interestingly, troop size in these areas are high exhibiting multi male societies (Chetan Nag, in litt., 17 December 2019). The Sri Lankan population is restricted to the dry zone in the north.
threats: Hunting and habitat loss are the major threats to this species(Molur et al. 2003). Hunting is rampant in the Eastern Ghats and the forests of the eastern coast, and common in some areas near national parks, for example, Ruhuna National Park (Molur et al. 2003). The habitats are highly vulnerable to human activities, and very few places are protected. Human-animal interactions in Andhra Pradesh and Sri Lanka are a big concern, and other threats include capture for pets. Persecution is one of the biggest threats to the species in India and Sri Lanka.
population: The global population size is unknown. There is a continuing decline in habitat in Andhra Pradesh that suggests a decline in population, but the rates are unknown (A. Kumar, M. Singh and S. Molur pers. comm.). In Sri Lanka, there has been a drastic decline in habitat (>50% in the last 30 years), and there has been more than a 50% decline in the population over the last 3 generations (Molur et al. 2003; A. Nekaris pers. comm.).
range:
This species is widely distributed in southern India (eastern side of the Deccan plateau, Eastern Ghats, Western Ghats east of Moyar River, eastern slopes of the southern Western Ghats and the plains of Tamil Nadu) (Nag et al. 2011, 2014) and Sri Lanka.

S. p. anchises occurs in a small patch of the Deccan plateau south of Krishna (Kurnool in the north to the plains of Cuddappah in the east, in Andhra Pradesh, and south to Tumakuru in Karnataka).

S. p. priam occurs south of Cuddappah in Andhra Pradesh to Kanyakumari in Tamil Nadu including the southern parts of the Eastern Ghats, eastern parts of northern Western Ghats, eastern slopes of the southern Western Ghats, and the plains of Tamil Nadu south up to Kanyakumari; rarely found on the east coast of southern India. The forests of the Eastern Ghats are not contiguous, have highly degraded dry deciduous forests, and are for the most part scrubby. The ratio of extent of occurrence to area of occupancy is very high (A. Kumar, M. Singh and S. Molur pers. comm.).

S. p. thersites is restricted to Sri Lanka in the northern dry zone.
useTrade: It is hunted for food in some parts of its range, and caught live for the pet trade.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on CITES Appendix I, and is on Schedules II, Part I, Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972 amended up to 2002 (Molur et al. 2003). In Sri Lanka, it is included under the Fauna and Flora Protection Act number 2 (Molur et al. 2003). It occurs in several protected areas throughout its range in India (Sri Venkateshwara National Park, Nellapattu Sanctuary, Bandipur National Park, Biligiri Rangsweamy Temple Sanctaury, Mudumalai Sanctaury, Chinnar Sanctuary, Neyyar Sanctuary, Peppara Sanctuary, Parambikulam Sanctuary, Shendurney Sanctuary, Grizzled Giant Squirrel Sanctuary, Indira Gandhi Sanctuary, Kalakad Sanctuary, and Mundanthurai Sanctuary), and in Sri Lanka (Knuckle Range Forest Reserve, Ampara Sanctuary, Buddaragala Sanctuary, Kanthale Naval Sanctuary, Wilpattu National Park, Ritigala Strict Nature Reserve, Angamedilla National Park, Flood Plains National Park, Giritale National Park, Moragaswawe National Park, Somawathie National Park, Wasagamuwa National Park, Uduwalawe National Park, Bundala National Park, Lunugamvehera National Park, Madura Oya National Park and Ruhuna National Park).

Molur et al. (2003) suggests research on taxonomy, man-animal interaction, more surveys, as well as habitat management, wild population management, public education, and monitoring.

rationale: Semnopithecus ajax is listed as Endangered as the population is very small, estimated to be less than 1,500 mature individuals in 15-20 subpopulations with no subpopulation having more than 150 mature individuals. Previously, the species was thought to be restricted to Chamba Valley with an extent of occurrence (EOO) smaller than 5,000 km², and an area of occupancy (AOO) smaller than 500 km². However, the populations in Jammu-Kashmir fit into the morphological and behavioural patterns of the type locality population, thereby these are now included within the S. ajax assessment. This additional range has increased the EOO and AOO for the species, but the number of mature individuals within the known distribution is still restricted and declining.
habitat:
This species is found in pine, moist temperate and alpine cedar forest from 1,300 to 4,000 m. It is folivorous, diurnal, and mainly terrestrial (Molur et al. 2003).

Multimale-multifemale type social organization. Unimale-multifemale and all male bands have also been observed. Typically, these langurs are found in groups ranging between 25-40 individuals. But occasionally, as in one case in Chamba, they numbered over 100 individuals. In Dachigam, groups of over 500 individuals are seen together in congregation for a brief period during winter, after which they disperse into smaller groups (Mehreen Khaleel pers. comm.). Seasonally variable diet but often found feeding on Rhododendron arboream, Aesculus indica, Quercus leucotrichophora, Pyrus pashia, Berbers asiatica, Rubus spp..,Urtica spp., Abies pindrow and crops like Zea mays (Maize), Pyrus malus (Apple) and Raphanus sp. (Radish) (Vishal Ahuja pers. comm.). In Dachigam, they have been found feeding on bark/peel of Ulmus villosa and Ulmus wallichiana. They also feed on seeds of Rhus succedanea and Pinus wallichiana in winters. Walnut (Juglans regia) also forms a large part of their diet in the months of August-September. They also known to lick mud and rocks. Cultigens are a substantial part of the diet. They are primarily arboreal but also spend a good part of their time on the ground. Infants with a more dark, brown fur were observed around March/April, so birthing could be around this time. In Dachigam, the greatest number of infants were found during Jan-March. Very little inter-group or intra-group aggression, if any, were observed. During the months of Nov-March when the groups fuse together, behaviour such as aggression (showing of teeth), chasing away the male, and mating take place. The animals, unlike their lowland congeners, do not vocalize the characteristic langur whoop but rather have a deep, grunt like bark. In Chamba they range from about 1,300 m to 3,000 m in sub-alpine cedar and oak forests (Anandam et al., pers. obs.). In Kashmir, they range from about 1,600-3,000 m and prefer broadleaved deciduous forest habitats, one or two solitary males were found at 3,500 m during summer.
threats:
Molur et al. (2003) list the following past threats: overgrazing, building roads through forests, logging, deforestation, agriculture, and fire. Present and future threats include agriculture and development (Molur et al. 2003).

The booming tourism industry around prime habitats like the Khajjiar-Kalatop Wildlife Sanctuary is a serious threat. Unregulated tourism has ushered in some unwelcome practices such as non-biodegradable garbage disposal, tourist resorts and food-stalls or Dhabas, and loud vehicles through the park. Other such places around the state are now being identified as tourist hotspots therefore the threat is spreading to places new and far. Logging and lopping are other activities in the region but the impact of such activities on the population has not been assessed (Anandam et al., pers. obs.).

Crop foraging is a growing threat across Chamba. In the 2012-2013 survey, 76 of the 244 sites surveyed across the district reported agricultural crop foraging and about 25% of the respondents expressed negative attitude towards langurs (Anandam et al. 2013b). In Kashmir, villages nearby Dachigam, Overa and Hirpora WS reported negative intraction in the form of crop foraging during winter (Dec-Feb) and early spring (March-April). Survey conducted from 2015-2017 in eight districts of Kashmir namely; Pulwama, Srinagar, Anantnag, Shopian, Ganderbal, Bandipora, Budgam and Baramulla reported crop foraging in 7 out of 87 villages. In places close to Dachigam, people retaliate by throwing stones to shoo away the langurs back to protected area.

Due to change in land-use, people have started to grow apple orchards and vegetable farms in villages close to protected areas. This can be considered as a growing cause of crop raiding in places close to Dachigam. For the past three years, villages in Kangan area (District Ganderbal) in Kashmir have reported solitary males foraging on apple and walnut trees. These are usually single males or two. People show neutral attitude towards their presence as no large-scale damage was reported. Only 5% people reported conflict in the entire valley and shoo away monkeys from their fields.
population:
Molur et al. (2003) estimated a total population of this species as fewer than 500 individuals (250 mature). The valley where it lives is surrounded by snow peaks and therefore it has remained isolated from other langurs, and the population is very small (M. Singh and C. Groves pers. comm). With the recent information from Dachigam National Park and other places within the Kishtwar Valley of Jammu-Kashmir indicating the population to be S. ajax, the numbers are estimated to be less than 1,000 mature individuals in the Kishtwar Valley. Dachigam holds the maximum number of mature individuals whereas, at other places the average troop size was found to be around 20-25. The total number of mature individuals is estimated to be less than 1,500 in number. Decline in the past is not known but it is predicted to decline by less than 10% in the next 10 years (Molur et al. 2003).

There are very little data available on the population in Chamba, owing primarily to the steepness of the terrains and shyness of the langurs. But given the many developmental activities in the region, the consequent pressures on the forests, increasing negative interactions with humans, and increasing attacks of the langurs by dogs, one could safely presume that the population is threatened and potentially decreasing (Vishal Ahuja, pers. comm)
range:
This species is reported as occurring in northwestern India in Himachal-Pradesh and Jammu-Kashmir (Groves 2001). It is claimed by Brandon-Jones (2004) that this species occurs in Melemchi, Nepal. Morphological and behavioural studies indicate its occurrence is restricted only to the Chamba Valley in Himachal-Pradesh and Kishtwar Valley in Jammu-Kashmir. The species range is restricted (<10,000 km²), and therefore also its area of occupancy (<2,000 km²).

Following Pocock's (1928) description, the species is identified only from Chamba (Groves and Molur 2008). All the other populations are considered under the plausibility of variation and hybridization and therefore cautiously await taxonomic scrutiny and verification. Groves (2001) suggests a wide distribution range for the species, from Dehra Dun in the Doon Valley of Shiwaliks to Pakistani Kashmir. But Groves and Molur (2008) restrict the species to Chamba. The report of the species in Machiara National Park in Pakistan by Minhas et al. (2011, 2013) requires verification for species identity. Recent reports of the species from Dachigam National Park in Jammu-Kashmir in India (Mir et al. 2015, Mehreen Khaleel pers. comm., Junaid Shah pers. comm., P.O. Nameer pers. comm.), confirm the identity of the populations to match morphologically with the Chamba Sacred Langurs. The Dachigam population also lack whooping calls, exhibit grunts and teeth grinding like that of the Chamba Sacred Langurs (Mehreen Khaleel, pers. comm.). Therefore, the distribution here is restricted to Chamba and Kishtwar Valleys in western Himalaya. Based on photographs and direct sightings, the langurs from these places in the Kashmir Valley match morphologically with S. ajax: Wangat-Naranag CR, Kazinag NP, Rajparian NP, Overa WS, and Tral CR, all within Jammu-Kashmir.
useTrade: The species is not used for any purpose.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on CITES Appendix I, and Schedule II Part I, of the Indian Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 amended up to 2002 (Molur et al., 2003). Except for Khajjiar-Kalatop Wildlife Sanctuary, its occurrence in other protected areas is difficult to determine owing to taxonomic uncertainty. The following areas are in need of research: taxonomy, life history, survey studies, limiting factor research, behavioural ecology. The following management actions for the conservation of this species are needed: wild population management, monitoring, public education, and limiting factor management (Molur et al. 2003).

The Himalayan Langur Project, established in 2012, is working across Chamba, with local communities and other stakeholders to establish a holistic conservation program and research on the langur. At present, the project is working with farmers around the Khajjiar-Kalatop Wildlife Sanctuary to establish sustainable, non-lethal crop-raid deterrents and crop protection strategies (Anandam et al. 2013b).

In Jammu-Kashmir, the species occurs in the following protected areas: Dachigam NP, Wangat-Naranag CR (District Ganderbal), Kazinag NP (Baramulla District), Rajparian WS (Anantnag District), Overa WS (Pahalgam District), and Tral WS (Pulwama District).

rationale: The species is listed as Critically Endangered under criterion A4cd. A population reduction of more than 80% over three generations (39 years) is estimated, including a period of four years in the past and projected forwards for the next 35 years, due mainly to a decline in habitat quality as well as unsustainable levels of exploitation. The total population size was estimated between 260 and 330 individuals, which, according to new data from China (Long et al. 2012; Guangsong et al. 2014), is probably an underestimate. Based on the interviews with hunters (Momberg et al. 2010), at least 13 Burmese Snub-nosed Monkeys were hunted during 2009. It is predicted that hunting pressure on the Myanmar side (directed and undirected) is likely to increase considerably in the next few years as new dam construction and logging roads invade the distribution area of this species.
habitat:
The distribution area is mountainous, and slopes are very steep in most places. The main forest types in the range of the Snub-nosed Monkeys are cool temperate rain forest and mixed temperate forest. Silver fir forest occurs at elevations of 2,745-3,660 m (conifer zone). There is no information how high up the mountains the monkeys go, but the highest mountain in this range is 3,660 m. According to local hunters, Snub-nosed Monkeys spend the summer (i.e., the snow-free times from May to October) mostly at higher altitudes, in mixed temperate forests and conifer forests. In winter, however, when snowfall probably restricts the availability of food, the monkeys descend to lower elevations and may be found closer to villages.

Yang et al. (2019) identified 14 plant species and four lichen species consumed by Rhinopithecus strykeri. In addition, two captive individuals of this species were provided with a cafeteria diet composed of > 600 wild-collected plant species that were gathered from known R. strykeri habitats. This exercise was conducted to determine which plant species and food items were considered palatable by this species. The captive monkeys freely consumed a variety of plant products including young and mature leaves, fruits/seeds, buds, flowers, twigs, and bark from 170 different species of trees, bushes, and herbs representing 76 genera and 41 plant families, as well as 15 species of lichen. Both the wild monkeys and captive monkeys preferred and consumed the same food items. 

Food plants consumed by R. strykeri are mainly found in intact subtropical evergreen broadleaf forests and hemlock-broadleaf mixed forests at an altitude of 2,200–3,000 m (Yang et al., 2019). Known to feed on bamboo shoots. Diurnal, arboreal and terrestrial in habit. Sympatric with various macaques, Shortridge’s langur (Trachypithecus shortridgei), Bengal Slow Loris (Nycticebus bengalensis), and Eastern Hoolock Gibbon (Hoolock leuconedys). Known to prefer elevations of 2,600-3,100 m of conifer and mixed conifer broad leaved forest between 2,600-3,100 m (Chi et al., 2014).  

The study by Ren et al. (2017) showed that R. strykeri appeared to inhabit a range from E98°20′–98°50′, N25°40′–26°50′, including high quality habitat at 1,420 km2, medium quality habitat at 750 km2, and low quality habitats at 1,410 km2.  In China, only 21.1% of the total habitat for R. strykeri falls within protected areas. And out of the total habitat, approximately 2.6% has been lost in the past 15 years, 96% of which has been in Myanmar.
threats:
Snub-nosed Monkeys are threatened by direct and indirect hunting pressures. Animals are hunted and trapped for their bones and heads, but most often monkeys are unintentionally trapped in iron traps that are set to trap deer or wild pigs to supply the local bush meat trade (this has been confirmed by local hunters and there is camera trap evidence of the monkeys travelling on the ground where traps have been set) (F. Momberg pers. comm. 2012). Already with the still limited construction work camps, commercial bush meat demand has increased sharply over the last two years (2010-2011) and is set to accelerate (F. Momberg pers. comm. 2012). Monkeys may also be caught in traps set for bears (T. Geissmann pers. comm. 2012).

Habitat degradation, due to the creation of roads and other infrastructure is rapidly becoming a major threat. Logging roads have now been built into all the areas occupied by this species since 2009 (some are within 200 m of the camera traps) (F. Momberg pers. comm. 2012). With the increased access, the influx of Chinese workers to the area as part of the logging and dam building operations is accelerating and it is expected that when the dams reach the full construction stage there will be at least 10,000 workers employed in this area (F. Momberg pers. comm. 2012).

Habitat loss due the impacts of logging is very serious due to large scale mechanical logging (blasting of logging roads, use of heavy equipment and winches, reaching ridges and even peaks) taking place, especially as the largest part of the range area is conifer forest and during the snow-covered winter months the Snub-nosed Monkeys (just as R. bieti) depend on lichens for food (F. Momberg pers. comm. 2012). As the logging is effecting most mature conifer trees, food sources especially in winter are becoming scarce. The logging practices are causing serious destruction because logging takes place at high altitudes and even on slopes with more than 70 degrees slope inclination (these areas are accessed using winches and roads are blasted through cliffs). Land slides are becoming increasingly common as a result of the loss of tree cover. The  lower mountain broad leaf forest is also impacted by logging (targeting hardwoods) and landslides caused by logging roads. Shifting cultivation reaches from the N'mai Hka river valley up to 2,000 meters, flooding following dam construction will displace shifting cultivation areas in the valley bottom to higher areas, increasing the pressures on the Snub-nosed Monkey habitat (F. Momberg pers. comm. 2012).

At present, the conservation status of the monkey in China remains unclear. Hunting remains a threat as understood from the hunting tools in use in the community around the habitat. In one instance, R. strykeri was reared as pet.

Given the various projects coming up in the species’ range, and based on the ongoing (over the last 10 years) and increasing levels of hunting and habitat loss, it is suspected that the species will undergo rapid declines of over 80% in the future, especially then next 30-35 years.
population:
Geissmann et al. (2011) estimated that there are approximately three to four groups of Burmese Snub-nosed Monkeys, which occur in three distinct parts of the distribution area around Maw River. The first group, distributed north of the Maw River, contains approximately 60-80 individuals; the second group, south of the river has about 80-100 individuals; and a group of about 150 animals appears at the foothills of the snow-capped mountains above the Chichitago village. The total population size was estimated at 260-330 individuals. Yang et al. (2018) found a breeding group of > 70 individuals on the eastern slopes of the Gaoligong mountains in the Salween River Basin.

The generation length of Snub-nosed Monkeys is unknown, however, Geissmann et al. (2011) used the age at first reproduction as a minimum estimate of generation length. In other species of Snub-nosed Monkeys, the average age at first reproduction is 4–6 years in females and 6.5–7 years in males (Li et al., 2003; Liang et al., 2000; Quan and Xie, 2002, cited in Liu et al., 2009; Zou, 2002, cited in Cui et al., 2008). The generation length is derived as 13 years for the species.

After two years of field work in this area the only direct encounters with this species were by local support staff (twice) and not by any scientists and the presence of the species in the wild was only confirmed through camera traps (one group of eleven including three mothers with infants, and two individual animals on three camera traps in total) over a nine-month period (F. Momberg pers. comm. 2012). 

Recent interview surveys by Chi et al. (2014) suggest 10 groups of the species between Salween and bordering with Myanmar, numbering to a total population of 490 to 620 animals. New studies indicate that the population to be less than 950 individuals (Yang et al. 2018).
range:
The trapping locality of the holotype was determined as 26.431011°N, 98.388941°E (elevation 2,815 m) in the Maw River area, northeastern Kachin state, northeastern Myanmar. Preliminary surveys and notes on habitat associations indicate that the range of the new species encompasses the mountain forests in the watershed area of the Maw River, a tributary to the N'mai Hka River, and forests across the range to the east above the village of Chichitago. The species therefore appears to be limited in distribution to a small area of the SalweenN'mai Hka divide in northeastern Kachin state, northeastern Myanmar. The coordinates of the distribution area are 26.31–26.51°N and 98.34– 98.61°E.

The species is also reported from China, where the main distribution area of the species is in the eastern slopes of Gaoligong Mountains Range, Lushui County, Yunnan Province. This range is located ~25.96-26.32° N and ~98.59-98.81° E (Ma et al., 2014), bounded to the east by the Salween River. Ma et al. (2014) estimated a total of ten groups. It is also found in Gaoligong Mountains National Nature Reserve in China (Yang et al. 2018).

Rhinopithecus strykeri is distributed in the mid and southern most segments of the Gaoligong Mountains, covering an area of 3,575 km2. Currently, only about 13.9% of R. strykeri's highly suitable habitat is present in the Gaoligong Mountains National Nature Reserve (Yang et al., 2019). The mid- and southern parts of the Nujiang Grand Canyon National Park contains the remaining major population of R. strykeri in China (Yang et al. 2019).
useTrade:
The species is hunted for its bones and head (skull and brains) presumably for medicinal purposes. The bones and heads are sold to Chinese workers at the nearby road construction and logging camps, as well as to wildlife traders in Kangfang, the nearest town on the Chinese border (Meyer et al., 2017; T. Geissmann pers. comm. 2012). It is also hunted for its fur. A bag made out of the skin of a juvenile Snubnosed Monkey was obtained from a hunter from Htantan on 23 February 2010. Snubnosed Monkeys are threatened by direct and indirect hunting pressures. Animals are hunted and trapped for their bones and heads, but most often monkeys are unintentionally trapped in iron traps that are set to trap deer or wild pigs to supply the local bush meat trade (this has been confirmed by local hunters and there is camera trap evidence of the monkeys travelling on the ground where traps have been set) (F. Momberg pers. comm. 2012).

Already with the still limited construction work camps, commercial bush meat demand has increased sharply over the last two years (2010-2011) and is set to accelerate (F. Momberg pers. comm. 2012). Monkeys may also be caught in traps set for bears (T. Geissmann pers. comm. 2012).
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species. The area is not yet under Myanmar government control (it is within the ceasefire area with the National Democratic Army of Kachin), there are no border controls, no presence of enforcement agencies, and no rule of law. It is not known if the species is present within any protected areas. There is an urgent need to maintain areas of suitable forest within the range of this species.

rationale: Although there are indications of a population bounce-back in the recent years in the southern parts of its distribution range, Rhinopithecus bieti is assessed as Endangered because its population is currently smaller than 1,000 mature individuals, occurring  in fewer than 20 subpopulations, with no subpopulation having more than 100 mature individuals. The species underwent rapid declines in the past suspected of at least 50% over the last three generations (39 years), due mainly to a decline in habitat quality and high levels of unsustainable exploitation. It is presumed that the population is not currently declining.
habitat:
This species is found in high altitude evergreen forests, both the lower (about 3,000 m) and upper (about 4,700 m) limits of its known ranges (Long et al., 1996) are the highest recorded for a primate. It prefers fir larch forest between the Yangtze and Mekong Rivers (Long et al., 1994). At Bamei, in northern Yunnan Province, it was found to live primarily in cypress forests (Zhong et al., 1998). It is mainly folivorous, though Kirkpatrick et al. (2001) report that lichens are also an important part of its diet in the northern part of its range. It is semiterrestrial and diurnal (Wu and Xian, 1994).

Temperate, montane evergreen broadlead deciduous and conifer forest and known to prefer fir larch or cypress forests and bamboos. Highest living primates with ranging altitudes peaking to 4,700 m but are known to use lower altitudes (3,000 m) during winter. In the lower altitudes, they are sympatric with Rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta).

Leaves, lichens, fruits, bark, berries, grasses, nuts, moss, seeds, shoots, acorns. Lichens make up the most of the diet (67%) but in Jinsichang, bamboo leaves make the most of the diet. The diet is variable through the seasons and these monkeys are known to feed of bird nestlings and clay as well (described as geophagy).

Mating peak season (August-September); birthing (March-May). Gestation: 189-198days. In captivity, the monkeys have a birth interval of c. 2 years. Infant mortality in the first ‘harsh’ winter is 55-60% as also reflected in the high female-infant ratio. Males were more terrestrial than female (Xiang et al., 2009). Females spend more time feeding (44.8%) than males (39.5%), juveniles(39.1%) and infants (14.2%). (Li et al., 2015).Scavenging and begging thereafter was observed in Yunnan,China. Two females of a habituated group was food biting and tearing in freshly killed birds (Ren et al., 2010). Grueter et al. (2012) reported altitudinal range use in Samage Forest, Baimaxueshan Nature Reserve, Yunnan, PRC and found that the monkeys ranged from a maximum of 3,550 m in July to 3,060 m in April. The monkeys were seen to exploit high altitude lichens during extreme winters when high nutrition food was lacking (Grueter et al., 2012).

Diurnal, arboreal and terrestrial. They are known to use dark conifer forests, higher up the valleys over consecutive nights. Snow storms in 2008 destroyed such large trees most preferred by these monkeys while killing a few juveniles in Samage Forest in the Baimaxueshan Nature Reserve (Li et al., 2012).

Multi-male, muti-female bands, of unimale-multifemale and all male groups. Band sizes could size between 24-370 individuals and in ranges between1000-4000ha.Mean daily travel distance c.1,300 m. shorter in winter than in summer. Home range of Rhinopithecus bieti in Tibet of the one group observed 16.75 km2 in summer, 10.50 km2 in winter, and 21.25 km2 total over two years. Daily travel length of 765 m (350-3,500 m). Population density was thus calculated 9.1individuals/km2 (Zou Fu et al., 2013).
threats:
The major threat to this species is hunting, often as a non targeted species caught in snares set for musk deer. A preliminary PVA using Vortex found that five smallest subpopulations are at risk of declines and extinction in the next 100 years from effects inbreeding and poaching, while five largest subpopulations were considered more secure (Xiao et al. 2005). The species is also threatened by habitat loss, especially from logging. Since 1999, when a ban stopped most commercial logging in the region, habitat loss has slowed, but it is still a large potential threat in the future. Clearing of forest land for summer grazing pasture had decreased suitable habitat for the monkeys by 31% between 1958 and 1997 (Xiao et al. 2003). In addition, fires set for agriculture are a threat to some of the areas, particularly in Tibetan Autonomous Region. A subpopulation of about 50 individuals in one area was apparently extirpated due to pesticide spraying for control of forest pests (Zhong Tai in litt.)

In Laojan, Yunnan, poaching remains to be the primary threat to the species. This is a real challenge as the communities in the area practice a strong tradition of hunting, as are the other communities within this monkey's range: Yi, Lisu, Tibetan, Pumi, Naxi, Bai, Molimosuo, and Han. Despite the hunting ban, snares and traps continue to threaten the species. The low reproductive rate of the species does not really help with the hunting pressure (Li et al. 2009).
population:
In 2006 the total known population was estimated at less than 2,000, with less than 1,000 mature individuals. There are currently 15 subpopulations, with three locations where subpopulations are known to have been extirpated since 1994 (L. Yongcheng pers. comm). Although the remaining populations are well known, there are very likely to be as yet unsurveyed populations.

Recently, a new group was discovered in Tianchi National Nature Reserve with approximately 20 individuals, and another group thought to have disappeared was rediscovered in Yunling National Nature Reserve in southern China (Wang et al., 2019).
range: This species occurs only in southwestern China (Tibet and Yunnan). It is found in fragmented populations in the Yun Ling Mountains in northwestern Yunnan and southeastern Tibet, west of the Yangtze River, and east of the Mekong River (Yang 2003).
useTrade: this species is hunted for food locally.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on CITES Appendix I. Most of the remaining populations are in protected areas, with only four groups found outside of them. There are currently 11 groups in protected areas: Hongla Snow Mountain Nature Reserve in the Tibetan Autonomous Region (which contains about 300 individuals), and Baima Snow Mountain and Laojun Mountain Nature Reserves in Yunnan. There is a major focus in China on captive breeding of this species, with breeding pairs at the Kunming Zoo and Kunming Institute of Zoology. Most of these individuals are captured from the wild, and so far the program is not sustainable (Wang Sung pers. comm.).

Awareness, education key to the conservation of the species (Li et al. 2009).

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered as there has been a decline of over 50% over the last three generations (approximately 39 years) due to forest loss and unsustainable levels of exploitation. This decline is continuing in some areas, particularly in the range of Rhinopithecus roxellana roxellana, whilst the populations of the other two subspecies seem to have stabilised.
habitat:
This species is found only in montane forests where snow cover can last for up to six months of the year (Allen 1938, Davison 1982). In the Qinling Mountains it is found in mixed deciduous broadleaf forests from 1,400 to 2,800 m (Gao and Liu, 1995; Li et al., 2001). It can also occur in other forest types, including mixed conifer broad leaf and deciduous broad-leaf.

Montane conifer, deciduous, rhododendron forest, bamboo thicket, up to 3,000 m. They are known to move down to lower altitudes in winter, to the valleys at 1,800-2,800 m and stay up in summer at 3,000 m. Conspecific with Giant Panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca). At Baihe, they live in high altitude coniferous forests.

The study by Dong et al. (2019) indicated most of the suitable habitat is found outside the core zone in the Baihe Nature Reserve (BNR). Their findings pointed out that human activities in all the zones can be detrimental on suitable habitat distribution of Sichuan snub-nosed monkeys in the BNR.

Rhinopithecus roxella quinlingensis is found in the mixed-deciduous broadleaf forests, mixed coniferous forests at 1,400-2,800 m in Quinling Mountains.

Lichens, fruits, and seeds form 29% while leaves form 24% of the diet. Other diet include 11%, buds 4%, twigs 1% and occasional shoots, flowers, and animal prey such as insects, small vertebrates, bird eggs and birds. The stress seasons of winter have rendered them often to feed on pine needles and pine cones. In summer, they are known to feed on mature leaves, on pine nuts and fruits in autumn, lichens bark and buds in winter.

Reproductive cycle of 22-30 days. Mating in August-October, birth in March-June and birth peaks in April. Gestation 193-203 days. An adult female gives birth every two years. Infanticide and allomothering observed. Sexual maturity 4-6 days. Interbirth interval 21.9 months. Life span 25-30 years.

Diurnal and known to spend a ‘lot’ of time on the ground. Li et al. (2007) found them to be more arboreal than terrestrial as found in Qianjiaping area of Shennongjia Nature Reserve, China where they spend most of their time on trees (97.1%) than ground (2.9%). They feed on lichens, leaves, mature leaves, flowers, seeds, buds, bark and herbs.

Activity budget 36.2% resting, 35.8% feeding, 22.9% moving, 5.1% other social behaviours.

Live in unimale-multifemale groups or all male groups. Season has a bearing on the size of the group and therefore it varies with season. Winter groups are small as 20-30 individuals and are frequently known to congregate into larger groups. Summer groups are large, as large as 200 individuals. Several bands combine sometime to form big bands of 600 individuals. Home range of 1,000-4,000 ha and daily travel of <1,000 m. Though they can survive the harsh winter unbeknownst of any non-human primate, the snub nosed monkeys are known to have an aversion for snow.  They migrate to low valleys during such extremes and also develop a red winter coat. Bachelor males lead group while on ground. Natural predators are Dhole (Cuon alpinus), Gray Wolf (Canis lupus), Asian Golden Cat (Catopuma temminckii) Leopard (Panthera pardus), Golden Eagle (Aquila chrysaetos), and Northern Goshawk (Accipiter gentilis).

In 2006, R. r. roxellana population estimate was 10,000 individuals, R. r. quinlingensis population estimate in 2001 was 3,800-4,000 individuals (50% mature), lastly the R. r. hubeiensis population in 1998 was 600-1,000 individuals (250 or less mature individuals).

Rhinopithecus roxellana roxellana and Rhinopithecus roxellana hubeiensis are found more often in mixed conifer and deciduous broadleaf forests. They are semi terrestrial, diurnal, and folivorous, but will also eat seeds, fruit, bark, insects, and small vertebrates.
threats:
Rhinopithecus roxellana: the major threat for the species is forest loss due to agricultural expansion, especially outside protected areas.

Rhinopithecus roxellana roxellana: the major threat is habitat loss. Secondarily, there is a serious threat from continued illegal hunting of this subspecies. There is also harassment owing to tourist activities, including the herding of troops for tourists to view.

Rhinopithecus roxellana qinlingensis: in the Qinling Mountains tourism is having a significant negative impact, mainly due to the creation of roads and other infrastructure. Before 1990, there were threats from illegal hunting, but this has stopped due to increased government protection.

Rhinopithecus roxellana hubeiensis: there is a serious threat to this subspecies from tourism related activities, along with continued habitat loss. Before 1990, there were threats from illegal hunting, but this has stopped due to increased government protection. 

Agriculture, tourism contribute to habitat loss, threatening all the three subspecies. Illegal hunting for meat, snares set for other animals, are some of the other threats. But increased protection has indeed contributed to the decrease in hunting and therefore has not been much of a concern, for Hubei and Quinling Snub Nosed Monkeys since 1990. No crop raiding so not much of conflict thereafter. Tourism has indeed affected the Quinling sub species. In fact field studies here employ luring the monkeys to observation sites and the effect of such practices on their behaviour or ranging is unknown. They are known to breed well in Chinese Zoos but not found outside Asia. The coat, often worn by Manchu mandarins, apart from being a symbol of prestige was believed to ward off rheumatism.
population:
Rhinopithecus roxellana roxellana:  there are about 10,000 individuals in 100 troops in Sichuan (6,000 individuals in Mingshan Mountain, 3,500 in Qionglaishan Mountain, and 500 in Daxiangling and Xiaoxianling Mountain), about 800 individuals in eight troops in Gansu, and about 170–200 individuals in one or two troops in Shaanxi (Zhang 1995, Jiang 2005, Li unpubl. 2006).

Rhinopithecus roxellana qinlingensis:  there are approximately 4,400 total individuals belonging to 39 troops (paper in Chines; Long will translate and send). Around half of these are mature individuals. Since the mid 1990s, the population appears to have stabilised.

Rhinopithecus roxellana hubeiensis: there are about 1,100 individuals in 5–6 troops.
range:
This species occurs in west central China (Ganssu, Hubei, Shaanxi, and Sichuan provinces) (Groves 2001).

Rhinopithecus roxellana roxellana Occurs in western Sichuan (Qingchuan, Pingwu, Songpan, Beichuan, Nanping, Maoxian, Heishui, Wenchuan, Baoxing, Tianquan, Lushan, Luding counties, on Qionglaishan Mountain, Mingshan Mountain, Daxiangling and Xiaoxiangling Mountain), southern Gansu (Wenxian county in Mingshan Mountain) and southern Shaanxi (Ningqian country) (L. Yongcheng pers. comm.).

Rhinopithecus roxellana qinlingensis Occurs in southern Shaanxi (Qinling Mountains, including the counties of Taibai, Zhouzhi, Foping, Yangxian, Ningshaan) (Wang et al. 1998, Li et al. 2001).

Rhinopithecus roxellana hubeiensis Occurs in western Hubei and northeastern Sichuan (Shennongjia forest region of Daba Mountain, in Fangxian, Xingshan, and Batong counties) (Wang et al. 1998, Li unpub. 2006).
useTrade: The nominate subspecies is hunted for meat, and also trapped for photo-shoots for tourists.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on CITES Appendix I, and as Category I of the Chinese Wildlife Protection Act, 1989.

Protected areas where this species definitely known to occur include: 

Rhinopithecus roxellana roxellana: Baihe Nature Reserve, Wanglang Nature Reserve.

Rhinopithecus roxellana quinliengensis: Changqing Nature Reserve, Taibai Nature Reserve, Foping Nature Reserve, Laoxiancheng Nature Reserve. 

Rhinopithecus roxellana hubeiensis: Shennongjia Nature Reserve, Zhouzhi Nature Reserve (M. Richardson pers. comm.), although according to L. Yongcheng (pers. comm.) it is to be found in a much larger number of naturereserves. It is almost never seen in captivity outside of Asia (M. Richardson pers. comm.).

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered as it has an extent of occurrence (EOO) less than 5,000 km², and an area of occupancy (AOO) less than 500 km². It occurs in just one location (Fanjingshan National Nature Reserve) and its habitat quality is declining owing to disturbance by tourism. The number of mature individuals has declined by about 10% in just four years. The remaining population is small, with just 700 individuals recorded in 2009. All individuals occur in a single subpopulation.
habitat:
The species occurs in mixed deciduous, broadleaf evergreen or coniferous forest at elevations of 1,500-2,500 m on steep and extremely rugged terrains. Altitudinal migration down to 570 m to rivers during extremely cold conditions is common. The species is sympatric with Macaca thibetana and Macaca mulatta.

Its diet comprises leaves (47%), buds (15%), flowers (9%), fruits and seeds (22%), bark, bulbs, animal prey, insect larvae (7%) and there is considerable variation in diet preference with season: in summer, ripe fruits and seeds are eaten; in autumn, mature leaves are the main food source; in winter, buds are eaten; and in spring, young leaves, flowers, unripe fruits, and seeds form its main diet.

Mating occurs between summer and autumn peaking in September. Birthing occurs March to May. There is an interbirth interval of 3 years.

This is a diurnal, arboreal species, sometimes using ground to cross open areas.

Unimale-multifemale groups of 3-10 individuals are formed, or bachelor groups of 2-5 individuals. As with their conspecifics, small groups are known to join together to form large bands. A characteristic behaviour is that they huddle together in trees with dense foliage to conserve heat.

The species has a home range of ca 3,500 m.
threats:
Main threats to this species include occasional illegal hunting for meat and use in traditional medicine, capture in snares intended for other animals, and habitat disturbance. The species is only known to occur in Fanjingshan National Nature Reserve. Tourism is a growing threat with roads and other modes of transport such as cable cars constructed to cater to the tourist needs.

The small population is vulnerable to inbreeding and has a limited distribution, and this could in fact mean low genetic variability to adapt to environmental and climate change. Other surveys in the area are absolutely essential to determine the actual status of the monkey. Captive breeding has been slow and the Fajingshan National Nature Reserve  maintains a captive colony with a few pairs in other venues.
population: In 2005, the total population was estimated at 750-800 individuals; in 2009 the population was estimated at 700 individuals.
range: Grey Snub-nosed Monkey is endemic to south-central China, where it is restricted to Fanjingshan National Nature Reserve in the Wuling Mts, Guizhou Province. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is smaller than 5,000 km² and its area of occupancy (AOO) is smaller than 500 km².
useTrade: This monkey is occasionally hunted for meat and use in traditional medicine.
conservationActions: This species is included in CITES Appendix I. It is also listed as a Category I species under the Chinese Wildlife Protection Act of 1989.

rationale: With no more than 100 mature individuals estimated, each subpopulation having no more than 30-35 mature individuals, and with a past decline of more than 30% over one generation (12-13 years), Rhinopithecus avunculus is listed as Critically Endangered under criterion C. In addition, it has experienced 80% loss of population during past 36-39 years (three generations) due to hunting for ‘medicine’ and habitat declines caused by excessively intense and unsustainable legal and illegal logging and gold mining; and the population continues to decline at the same rate or more due to continuing habitat loss from cardamom cultivation, development of hydroelectric power project, sudden increases in human populations leading also to increased demand for meat, and thus increased hunting pressure. The threats are ongoing and with observed declines and extirpations in some subpopulations within protected areas, it is suspected that the species will continue to face similar trends in declines in the future.
habitat:
This species is found in tropical evergreen forests associated with karst limestone hills and mountains (Le Xuan Canh and Boonratana, 2006), and is largely restricted to primary forest (Boonratana and Le Xuan Canh 1998). It has been recorded at elevations between 200 and 1,400 m (Le Xuan Canh and Boonratana 2006, Le Khac Quyet and Covert 2010). Ranges of different groups overlap greatly (Boonratana and Le Xuan Canh 1998). It appears to be a selective feeder, feeding on the young and mature leaves, unripe and ripe fruits, flowers and seeds of as many as 52 plant species (Boonratana and Le Xuan Canh 1998, Le Khac Quyet et al. 2007). These animals are diurnal and primarily arboreal only rarely coming to the ground. They sleep in trees close to the ground, on steep mountain sides. Primarily quadrupedal pronogrades that also occasionally use suspensory locomotion and postures (Covert et al. 2008, Le Khac Quyet 2014).

The social organization is characterized by one male – multi-female groups of 12-15 individuals and sometimes up to two dozen and the home range is estimated to be approximately 380-560ha. Groups are known to move and rest in semi-cohesive bands. All male groups, formed by dispersing males from natal groups, are consist of 1-2 adult males and 2-3 juvenile males. Tonkin Snub-nosed Monkeys occasionally form large bands consisting of multiple one male – multi-female groups join together, but as to what prompts them to join together is unclear (Boonratana and Le Xuan Canh 1998, Covert et al. 2008, Dong Thanh Hai 2009).
threats: These animals are threatened from habitat degradation and hunting pressure, with the latter being the most immediate threat to this species (Nadler et al. 2003). Although this species is not usually targeted for bushmeat hunting due to its "foul-taste", it is shot when encountered, and consumed or used in traditional "medicine" (Nadler et al. 2003, Le Xuan Canh and Boonratana 2006). It has been found in trade in China, where it may be used for "medicinal" purposes (Nadler pers. comm.), although this is likely to be limited activity. With the exception of the Khau Ca forest population, there is high hunting pressure in the area where it lives, as evidenced by several gunshots heard almost daily during field trips (2004-2005) in the Na Hang Nature Reserve (Le Xuan Canh and Boonratana 2006) and observations of hunters camps (Thach Mai Hoang 2011). Shifting and settled cultivation, as well as other land development activities, also pose a threat (Nadler et al. 2003, Le Xuan Canh 2006, Le Khac Quyet et al. 2007, Covert et al. 2008, Le Khac Quyet and Covert 2010). In the past, excessively intense and unsustainable legal and illegal logging and gold mining were the biggest threats. Recently, the development of a hydroelectric power project along the Gam River in Na Hang has seriously impacted its habitat, plus the sudden increases in human populations, especially construction workers, have led to increased demand for meat, and thus increased hunting pressure (Le Xuan Canh and Boonratana, 2006). At the present time, hunting pressure continues to be high in Na Hang. In the Tung Vai area the largest threat is extensive cardamom cultivation and the population at Khau Ca is primarily threatened by an ongoing low level of habitat degradation.
population: Tonkin Snub-nosed Monkey has recently been observed in Na Hang Nature Reserve in Tuyen Quang Province and in Khau Ca Forest and Tung Vai Forest in Ha Giang Province. It is also possible that it still occurs in Cham Chu Nature Reserve in Tuyen Quang (Le Khac Quyet and Covert 2010). A study of the Tat Ke sector of the Na Hang Nature Reserve in 1993 estimated a density of fewer than eight individuals/km² (Le Xuan Canh and Boonratana 2006). The latest study at this location, in 2009-2010, found far lower densities. It is thought that hunting pressure is the reason for low densities in Tat Ke Sector. The highest estimate for any one population was in the Ban Bung sector of the Na Hang Nature Reserve, at between 90 and 110 individuals in 1992 (Ratajszczak et al. 1992). There has been significant population decline in both sectors of the Na Hang Nature Reserve, Tat Ke and Ban Bung (Le Xuan Canh and Boonratana 2006, Thach Mai Hoang 2011). Understanding of the number or the size of the subpopulations, with the exception of Khau Ca, is poor: with estimate of ca 20 individuals in Na Hang Nature Reserve (Thach Mai Hoang 2011); lack of recent observations at Cham Chu Nature although it may still occur at this site (Dong Thanh Hai et al. 2006); 130 individuals confirmed in the Tonkin Snub Nosed Monkey Species/Habitat Conservation Area at Khau Ca (Le Khac Quyet, pers. obs. 2015); and possibly 30-40 individuals in Tung Vai forest of Quan Ba District, Ha Giang Province, close to Chinese-Vietnamese border (Nguyen Van Truong 2012). Thus, the global population estimate at approximately 200-250 individuals may be higher than it is in the wild.
range: This species is confined to a few areas in northeastern Viet Nam east of the Red River (Fooden 1996, Groves 2001, Nadler et al. 2003, Le Khac Quyet and Covert 2010). Its distribution has become dramatically restricted in recent decades due to massive deforestation and intensive hunting (Nadler et al. 2003). It is currently known only from small forest patches in Ha Giang and Tuyen Quang Provinces (Le Khac Quyet and Covert 2010, Nadler and Brockman 2014).
useTrade: The species is hunted for 'medicinal' purposes and trade extensively and throughout its range. Due to its unpalatable, 'foul' tasting meat, hunting for food is not as rampant as hunting for 'medicine'.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on CITES Appendix I. Critically Endangered by The IUCN Red List and it is listed as critically endangered in the Vietnam Red Data Book. It is confirmed in two protected areas: Na Hang Nature Reserve and Tonkin Snub-nosed Monkey Species/Habitat Conservation Area at Khau Ca (established in 2009), and an unprotected area of Tung Vai forest (Le Khac Quyet and Covert, 2010). Based on interviews and specimen information, it may occur in Yen Tu Nature Reserve in Quang Ninh Province, but it is unclear whether a population still exists at this location (Le Khac Quyet pers. comm.). Likewise, it is unclear if it still exists in Cham Chu Nature Reserve. During the past 14 years there have been significant conservation activities in the Khau Ca area in collaboration with the Ha Giang Forestry Protection Department and this includes training and supporting community patrol groups and studies of land-use and livelihoods of local communities and population monitoring by Fauna and Flora International (FFI).  FFI has also been involved in conservation education activities in partnership with the Denver Zoo.  Additional examples include long-term ecological studies have occurred here under the direction of Le Khac Quyet and a team of local research assistants working with FFI, the University of Colorado Boulder, the Denver Zoo, and San Diego Zoological Society. Dong Thang Hai also has conducted an ecological study at this site working with the Vietnam Forestry University and the Australian National University. The University of Colorado Boulder, Denver Zoo, and local scientists have also been conducted research focusing on potential overlap in  resource use by human and Tonkin Snub-nosed Monkeys at Khau Ca.

Going forward, conservation actions to preserve this species should include: gun confiscation programs in areas surrounding present populations of Tonkin Snub-nosed Monkeys; actions to mitigate impacts of cardamom cultivation at Tung Vai; continued efforts to establish a protected area designation Quan Ba with a focus on appropriate zonation; habitat restoration and expansion program for the Khau Ca forest area; review boundary of Du Gia – Dong Van NP ensuring that ecologically important habitat is protected (particularly on the southern edge of Khau Ca) and then clear demarcation; habitat protection of the forest corridor linking Khau Ca forest and Du Gia forest; and intensive population survey in Tat Ke, Ban Bung, Cham Chu, and Du Gia.

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable as it is suspected to have declined by more than 30% over the last three generations (30 years), and will continue to do so for the next decade at least. This decline is largely the result of hunting pressure throughout its range and some habitat loss in the north. The species, like other African colobines, is large-bodied and very easy to hunt. With human populations increasing in the region, and the vastly increased access into once-remote forest, this pressure is unlikely to abate in the near future. The subspecies Colobus satanas satanas, found only on the island of Bioko (Equatorial Guinea), is even more at risk from hunting and has a geographic range of only 464 km²; it is assessed separately as Critically Endangered (see Colobus satanas satanas).
habitat:
This species inhabits coastal evergreen, lowland moist, montane and swamp forests. It is typically found high in the canopy of dense, primary rainforest, and is now only present in protected or undisturbed inaccessible areas. It appears unable to survive in secondary forest, and is rare or absent in forests where logging has reduced canopy height.

Colobus satanas is a highly arboreal, diurnal species. Like other colobines, they eat seeds and leaves (seeds being around 50-60% of the diet: Fleury and Brugière 2013). This species lives in groups averaging 13 individuals (range 5–30) and has an annual home range of between 70–570 ha (Fleury and Brugière 2013). They are often found in polyspecific troops with guenons and mangabeys.
threats:
Colobus satanas is directly threatened by habitat loss and hunting throughout its range, and indirectly by increasing human populations and the creation of easy access routes into almost all previously remote forests. Human population growth in the range states of the taxon is roughly 2.7% annually and will not slow down for several decades (UN 2019, World Bank 2019).

Road access into once-remote forests – even around protected areas – has increased hugely over the last 20–30 years (Laporte et al. 2007), facilitating increased hunting and transport of bushmeat to both local markets and distant urban centres (Abernethy et al. 2013, Ziegler et al. 2016).

Black Colobus meat is consumed locally and traded commercially in urban areas. This species is very easy for gun-hunters to kill, being rather slow-moving, and is sought after due to its high body weight (Brugière 1998, Kumpel et al. 2008).

In the northwest of its range, in Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea, the species is subject to habitat modification, as intact forest is converted to farmland and “farm bush” which can be seen clearly in Tyukavina et al. (2016). Forest loss is relatively low in the Gabon parts of this taxon’s range and the small area in Congo where it occurs (Hansen et al. 2013) due to historically low human population densities and use of selective logging techniques as opposed to clearcutting. However, there is an ongoing trend for gradually increasing annual forest loss since 2001 in all four range states, especially since 2013 (GFW 2019). Forest loss will increase greatly in the future as industrial-scale agriculture expands, removing forests suitable for various forest-obligate species (Wich et al. 2014).
population:
Recorded population densities on the mainland range from 7 to 30 individuals/km² (Fleury and Brugière 2013) and, even in unhunted areas, habitat type appears to have a major influence. Density was 11 individuals/km² in mature forest (Brugière 1998) and 30 individuals/km² in gallery forest in Lopé, Gabon (Harrison 1986). In 2011, Black Colobus were recorded only seven times in transect surveys that covered the whole of mainland Equatorial Guinea (Rio Muni), an effort of 231 km and encounter rate of only 0.03 groups/km (Ruffler et al. 2012). Surveys in unhunted, undisturbed habitats have shown encounter rates an order of magnitude higher (0.3 groups/km) (Fleury and Brugière 2013). The most recent survey in Lopé (2008) produced an encounter rate on transects of 0.23 groups/km (A. Bezangoye and F. Maisels unpub. data 2010).

Immediately outside the same park in a logging concession, encounter rate on transects was over 70% lower: 0.07 groups/km (Maisels et al. 2008). Across their range, Black Colobus are entirely or almost absent from large areas with otherwise suitable habitat, due to decades of heavy hunting pressure. The situation on Bioko is of particular concern. There are probably fewer than 1,250 animals remaining, and Cronin et al. (in review) estimated >80% decline in numbers between 1986 and 2016 (ca 3 generations).
range: This species occurs in Cameroon, Congo, Equatorial Guinea and Gabon in tropical moist forest. There are two subspecies: Colobus satanas satanas on the island of Bioko (part of Equatorial Guinea) and C. s. anthracinus on the mainland. The northern limit of its distribution is the left bank of the Sanaga River in Cameroon, and the southern limit is unknown, but likely somewhere around 2° S. The eastern limit is likewise ill-defined, and could be the upper Ogooué and lower Ivindo rivers (both in Gabon) at roughly 12° E, but there are records from up to about 14° E in both the Mwagna National Park in Gabon (Moussavou Makanga 2009) and Garabinzam area in northwestern Congo (Ella Akou and Moussavou Makanga 2010, Mbolo 2010). This species is now rare or absent in those parts of its range where there has been extensive logging. On mainland Equatorial Guinea, its range had been reduced to one-third of its former size by 1967 and these monkeys are now exceedingly rare (Ruffler et al. 2012). On Bioko, approximately 95% of the population lives in two of the island’s protected areas (Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve and Pico Basilé National Park). In the Dja Biosphere Reserve in Cameroon, despite an intensive survey in 2015 (over 500 km of effort), no black colobus were seen at all (whilst C. guereza were reasonably common) (MINFOF/UICN, 2015).
useTrade: Black Colobus meat is consumed in rural areas and traded commercially in urban areas.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES.

Colobus satanas occurs in many of the protected areas in its range, including one World Heritage Site: Lopé (Gabon). The stronghold of this species is now the protected areas of Gabon where it is still found in reasonably good shape, but it is becoming less and less abundant in the unprotected forests outside these protected areas. It is probably almost entirely absent across much of its former range south of the Sanaga in Cameroon apart from in some protected areas.

On Bioko, almost all remaining individuals of the subspecies C. s. satanas are in protected areas and have been hunted out elsewhere. Equatorial Guinea banned the hunting, sale and consumption of primates in 2007, but application of and compliance with this law is very weak (Cronin et al. 2016, Ruffler et al. 2012). The species is named on the completely protected list in Congo, but is not mentioned in the laws of the other three range states, which needs to be rectified.

rationale: Colobus guereza is listed as Least Concern because although it is declining and locally threatened in parts of its range, it is widespread and locally common at many sites, especially in the numerous protected areas. There is no firm evidence for a significant range-wide population decline that warrants listing in a higher category of threat at the present time; however, its status could change as pressures on its habitat grow and if hunting of larger-bodied primates continues to intensify in the western parts of its range.
habitat: Colobus guereza is arboreal, but will travel across the ground between patches of forest. It occupies a wide range of forest types including low, mid-montane and montane moist forest, ground water forest, secondary forest, riverine forest, swamp forest and gallery forest. It is often common in secondary or degraded forest (Fashing and Oates 2013, Groves and Ting 2013). Colobus guereza is strictly folivorous in some regions, but feeds both on leaves and fruits in others (Fashing and Oates 2013). They live in groups of 2-10 adults, and group home ranges are from 1.5 to 100 ha (Fashing and Oates 2013, Groves and Ting 2013).
threats:
Colobus guereza is one of the few primate species which responds well to low to medium levels of habitat disturbance. This species is, however, threatened in many parts of its range by habitat loss through timber extraction, through removal of natural forest for exotic tree plantations and agriculture, and by rapidly expanding human populations (von Hippel et al. 2000, Fashing & Oates 2013, Groves & Ting 2013).

Bushmeat hunting is damaging populations in the western part of the range. C. guereza is also killed for its skins, which are used in traditional ceremonies and as ornaments worn by various African tribes (including Kikuyu, Samburu, Chagga, Kuria and Luhya; Mwenja 2007, de Jong & Butynski 2010, Fashing & Oates 2013, Groves & Ting 2013). In the 19th century, the skins featured in the international fur trade, and in the 1970s large numbers of skins were on sale to tourists in Kenya and Ethiopia (Oates 1977).
population: Colobus guereza is a widespread species that is locally abundant. Densities range from 3 individuals/km² (Ituri Forest, DRC; Bocian 1997) to 800 individuals/km² (Murchison Falls, Uganda; Leskes and Acheson 1970 in Fashing and Oates 2013). Densities tend to be highest in patches of forest along lakes and rivers, intermediate in moist forest that have been subjected to low to moderate levels of human disturbance, and lowest in undisturbed moist forest (Fashing and Oates 2013). Where C. guereza occupies small, isolated, patches of forest, it is prone to local decline and extinction.
range:
Colobus guereza is endemic to equatorial Africa and has a wide geographical range. It ranges from eastern Nigeria and Cameroon, eastwards across the Oubangui River from the Central African Republic (CAR) to northern DRC, and then discontinuously eastwards to southern South Sudan, Uganda, the Kenyan and Ethiopian Highlands, and Mount Kilimanjaro, Mount Meru and Kahé District of Tanzania (Fashing and Oates 2013).

Seven subspecies are recognised here:

Colobus guereza occidentalis (western guereza) occurs from eastern Nigeria (Ngel Nyaki Forest Reserve on the western escarpment of the Mambilla Plateau), the west edge of the Mambilla Plateau, Yabassi District of Cameroon, and northeast Gabon, eastwards across the Ubangui River from western and southern CAR to southern South Sudan and west Uganda to the Nile River, including the Otzi Mountains in northwest Uganda (Oates 2011, Fashing and Oates 2013, de Jong and Butynski 2014a, J. Hart pers. comm. 2016).

Colobus guereza guereza (Omo River guereza) is endemic to Ethiopia. It exists in the Ethiopian Highlands west of the Rift Valley, down into the lowland forests along the Awash River, Omo River, and Blue Nile gorge (Fashing and Oates 2013).

Colobus guereza gallarum (Djaffa Mountains guereza) is endemic to the Ethiopian Highlands east of the Rift Valley (Fashing and Oates 2013).

Colobus guereza dodingae (Dodinga Hills guereza) is endemic to the Imatong Mountains in southeast South Sudan and central north Uganda. It is reported to occur in the hills in and around Kidepo Valley National Park, northeast Uganda (Butynski and de Jong 2014, de Jong and Butynski 2015).

Colobus guereza matschiei (Mau Forest guereza) is endemic to southwest Kenya, northwest Tanzania, and extreme eastern Uganda. It occurs west of the Rift Valley (e.g. Mau Forest Complex, Kakamega Forest National Reserve, Cherangani Hills, Loima Hills in Uganda, Mount Elgon National Park on the Kenya-Uganda border), and in woodlands within the Eastern Rift Valley (including Lake Naivasha and Lake Nakuru National Park). It is also found along the Grumeti River, western Serengeti, northwest Tanzania (Butynski and de Jong 2012, Fashing and Oates 2013, de Jong and Butynski 2014b). Reports of presence in the Ngorongoro Crater Highlands (e.g. Groves 2001) are, it seems, unfounded (Butynski and de Jong 2012).

Colobus guereza percivali (Mt Uarges guereza) is endemic to the Matthews Range, Ndoto Range and Mt. Nyiru of central Kenya (Mwenja 2007, de Jong & Butynski 2012, Fashing and Oates 2013).

Colobus guereza kikuyuensis (Mt Kenya guereza) is endemic to the Kenya Central Highlands, including Ngong Escarpment, Mount Kenya, Aberdare Range, and small forest fragments in the Highlands, including Ol Arabel Forest Reserve (Fashing and Oates 2013, Y.A. de Jong and T.M. Butynski pers. obs. 2016).

Photographic maps of the above subspecies can be found on www.wildsolutions.nl
useTrade: Hunted for bushmeat. Guereza are also killed for their skins, which are used in traditional ceremonies and worn as ornaments.
conservationActions: Colobus guereza is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Occurs in many protected areas throughout its range. Common in many of these protected areas. Further taxonomic work is needed to assess the validity of the various described subspecies.

rationale: Colobus polykomos is listed as Endangered as it is estimated that the population has undergone a decline exceeding 50% over the past 30 years (or three generations), based on the evidence that habitat degradation, human population growth and intense hunting are taking place across its range, and that the species does not persist in degraded areas, requiring at least some mature forest. Habitat destruction and degradation have occurred across the range of C. polykomos in Cote d'Ivoire, Liberia, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Guinea-Bissau. Each of these countries lost between 14% and 21% of their total forest cover between 2001 and 2017, and the drivers of forest loss continue to operate (www.globalforestwatch.org). In addition, human populations in these countries increased by 120%. Commercial logging and subsistence hunting are common across the range countries, and the development of large-scale mining, logging and industrial agricultural concessions in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea are having devastating effects on wildlife (WCF 2014, 2015; Tweh et al. 2015). Laws against hunting and other illegal activities in protected areas are poorly enforced in all countries in the species' range. As a result, during the last three decades, the King Colobus has disappeared from the majority of the protected areas in which it once occurred and now occurs only in a limited number of forests, usually at low densities. Based on the ongoing habitat degradation/fragmentation, poaching pressure, human population growth and the decline in forest cover, the total population of C. polykomos has declined by more than 50% during the last three generations.
habitat:
This species depends on rainforest and gallery forest; it is rarely found in degraded habitats, although sometimes occurs in secondary forests. Colobus polykomos usually forms small multi-male groups. In the Cantanhez Forest in Guinea-Bissau, groups consisted of 3–10 individuals, while at Tiwai Island Wildlife Sanctuary in Sierra Leone, one habituated group had nine members (Dasilva 1989). Lone individuals have also been observed. At Tiwai, it associates with the Western Red Colobus (Piliocolobus badius badius). Mean group size of the Taï population is 15 (range 12–19) (Korstjens 2001, Zuberbühler and Jenny 2002). In Mt. Nimba, Liberia, it associates with the Diana Monkey (Galat and Galat-Luong 2000). Low mtDNA diversity indicates that female philopatry and male dispersal is common in this species (Minhós et al. 2013). Dasilva (1994) studied the diet of C. polykomos in the mid-1990s at Tiwai and found that 30% of feeding time was spent eating leaves and seeds. In Taï, this species is more frugivorous than the sympatric red colobus and Olive Colobus monkeys (Korstjens et al. 2007).

Colobus polykomos can live in high altitude areas. Individuals were observed at montane areas at 673–1,061 m in the Fouta Djallon region in Guinea (C. Alonso and A. Hernansaiz pers. obs. 2014).
threats:
The primary threat to the survival of Colobus polykomos is uncontrolled hunting for bushmeat throughout its range, coupled with forest loss, degradation and fragmentation. The Upper Guinean rainforest is a highly fragmented system and remains one of the most severely threatened forest systems in the world. From 2001 to 2017, Cote d'Ivoire, Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea-Bissau respectively lost 7.2%, 14%, 21% and 12% of their forest cover (Global Forest Watch 2019). The forest cover of these five countries declined from 321,680 km² in 1990 to 300,540 km² in 2015, a loss of 21,680 km² (7%) (FAO 2015). Based on World Bank data (2019), the human population in these countries increased from 30.5 million inhabitants in 1987 to 67.0 million in 2017, an increase of 120%. Habitat encroachment for agricultural purposes occurs throughout the range countries even inside protected areas. In Cote d'Ivoire >80% of the protected areas have been converted to plantations (Bitty et al. 2015). The secondary threats are forest loss, degradation and fragmentation.

Hunting is common across the range countries of C. polykomos. In the Tai National Park in Cote d'Ivoire, where the largest subpopulation of this species remains, several studies have documented the impacts of hunting (Refisch and Kone 2005, McGraw 2007, Campbell et al. 2008). A local bushmeat market survey conducted by Covey and McGraw (2014) on the Liberia-Cote d'Ivoire border found that C. polykomos represented 11.4% of the primate carcasses for sale. A nationwide survey in Liberia found that signs of hunting were the most frequently encountered anthropogenic threat recorded, with a rate of 1.32 signs per km (Tweh et al. 2015).

The development of large-scale mining, logging and industrial agricultural concessions in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea threatens all wildlife (WCF 2014, 2015; Tweh et al. 2015).
population:
Colobus polykomos has declined across its geographic range.

In Côte d’Ivoire, Taï National Park probably sustains the largest population remaining in all the range countries. A survey by Zuberbühler and Jenny (2002) in Taï NP estimated the population density at 35.5 individuals per km² in research areas. Line transect survey data collected by Covey (2009) at the same site indicated a decline of 30% (1.62 group/km², equivalent to 25 individuals/km². Inside Taï NP but outside the research area, the species has become very rare (Covey 2009). With the exception of Taï, the species has been extirpated in more than 95% of the protected areas in Cote d'Ivoire where it previously occurred. During a 2007–2010 monitoring survey in the Cavally FR, the species was reported at a very low encounter rate (0.02 group/km; WCF 2010). The ongoing hunting pressure, habitat encroachment and human settlement within such forest reserves pose severe threats to the survival of these remaining populations.

In Guinea, C. polykomos has been extirpated in several localities, including protected areas. In the Boke region, a 2005 RAP survey (Eriksson and Kpoghomou 2006) found no evidence of the species' presence, although it was formerly reported from the region by local people. A rapid survey of primates conducted from November to December 2015 also failed to find evidence of the species in the CGB-Halco concession (WCF 2015). Surveys conducted between April 2012 and February 2014 confirmed the presence of C. polykomos in the Lebekere sub-prefecture, in the northern sector of the Fouta Djallon mountain range.
