Duckworth and colleagues reported the Bornean Banded Langur not the Tricolored Langurs occurs in Similajau National Park so the respective distributions of the two subspecies and their taxonomy requires further validation. The Bornean Banded Langur may occur in Lanjak-Entimau Wildlife Sanctuary in Southwestern Sarawak near the border with West Kalimantan.
population: This species was reported as common in the early 20<sup>th</sup> century (Baccari 1904, Banks 1931), in areas where today it no longer occurs. Recent records are from five sites: Maludam National Park (Malaysia); Samunsam Wildlife Sanctuary (Malaysia); Similajau National Park (Malaysia); Tanjung Datu National Park (Malaysia); the Lingga area of Sarawak (Malaysia); and possibly Betung Kerihun National Park (Indonesia) (J. Hon pers. comm). Combined population estimates from these sites are very low (approximately 200-500 individuals) (J. Hon and V. Nijman pers. comm.).
range:
This species is endemic to the island of Borneo, it occurs in Brunei, Indonesia (Kalimantan) and Malaysia (Sabah and Sarawak). It is found north and northeast of the Kapuas River in northwestern Kalimantan, and through Sarawak (mainly in coastal areas) and Brunei as far as Melalap, Sabah (Groves 2001). The species is found only in remaining habitat within its extent of occurrence; much of its mapped range is historical. There is some confusion about where this species still remains, as many of the records are also historical.

Presbytis chrysomelas chrysomelas occurs in western Brunei, northwestern Kalimantan (northeast of the Kapuas River) and western Sarawak, as far as the IV Division of Sarawak (Groves 2001). Presbytis c. cruciger ranges from the Baram District (in northeastern Sarawak) to Sabah (Groves 2001).
conservationActions: This species is listed under CITES Appendix II. The majority of the remaining populations are found in national parks. The species is protected in Sarawak. Further research and surveys are necessary to confirm the persistence and population size of the five remaining sites, which include Maludam National Park, Samunsam Wildlife Sanctuary, Similajau National Park, and Tanjung Datu National Park in Malaysia, and possibly Betung Kerihun National Park in Indonesia. It is present as well in the Lingga area of Sarawak, which has recently been proposed as a protected area.

rationale: Natuna Island Surili is listed as Vulnerable because the population size is estimated to number fewer than 10,000 mature individuals, and there is a continuing decline of more than 10% over 36 years (three generations).
habitat: This species is reported from a range of habitats, including primary and logged forest and rubber plantations (Lammertink et al. 2003). Diurnal and arboreal. Small groups of 3.5 ind/group.
threats: The species is threatened in part by the demand for captive individuals as pets, but mostly it is threatened by continuing degradation and reduction of forest (Lammertink et al. 2003), and perhaps by the presence of offshore petroleum production activities and defence facilities.
population: Groups average 3.5±SD 2.0 individuals and occur in a density of 2.3±SD 1.1 groups/km². Extrapolation of the density estimates to the entire island indicates that <10,000 individuals remain, occurring in two subpopulations (Lammertink et al. 2003).
range: This species is confined to Bunguran Island, in the northern Natuna Islands off the northwestern coast of Borneo, Indonesia (Groves, 2001).
useTrade: This species is captured live for the pet trade.
conservationActions: This species is listed on CITES Appendix II, but is not protected by national law. Lammertink et al. (2003) recommend, for the conservation of the species, the implementation by the district government of Natuna of two strict conservation areas on the island, and the maintaining of a larger area of sustainably used natural forest around Mount Bedung.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered based on its small extent of occurrence (EOO = 1,873 km²), small area of occupancy (AOO = ca 300 km²), its fragmented population (in two isolated subpopulations, one of them residing in an area of limited protection), and ongoing threats that are resulting in a continuing decline in both habitat and numbers of mature individuals. This taxon qualifies as Endangered under criteria B1 and B2.
habitat: This species is often found in the lower understorey of submontane and montane forest, and spends ~50% of its time foraging on the forest floor (Ehardt et al. 2005, Ehardt and Butynski 2006). It frequently moves through and uses mosaic habitat and disturbed areas (Ehardt et al. 2005) including secondary or steep, naturally heterogeneous and open forest habitat, especially in USNR (Rovero et al. 2012). Diet is mostly fruit, nuts and seeds, plus some fungi, invertebrates and herbaceous material (McCabe et al. 2013). Mean group sizes range from 15 to >70 animals (Wasser 1993, Ehardt 2001, Ehardt et al. 2005, McCabe and Emery Thompson 2013). Fine-scale camera trapping and habitat assessment revealed that estimated occupancy is higher in montane than in lowland forest in the national park, indicating that the species prefers interior forest away from disturbance (Rovero et al. 2014).
threats: This species is threatened by continuing deforestation for timber and charcoal production. It is also threatened by hunting, including hunting with dogs.
population:
Previously the population was estimated to be between 1,800 and 3,000 animals (Homewood and Rodgers 1981, Rodgers and Homewood 1982, Dinesen et al. 2001). More recent population estimates range between 1,300 (Ehardt et al. 2005) and 3,500 individuals (Rovero et al 2009), although a robust count has yet to be conducted. Increasing use of camera trapping in recent years showed that estimated occupancy (i.e., the probability of presence of the species at a number of sample sites) is higher for the population in the Udzungwa Mountains National Park than in the Uzungwa Scarp Nature Reserve (USNR) (Hegerl et al. 2015), although a robust comparison is ongoing (F. Rovero, unpublished data).

The species is split into two distinct subpopulations: the largest subpopulation (ca 60%) occurs in the national park and the remaining ca 40% in the USNR (Ehardt 2001, Rovero et al. 2009). The USNR was elevated from a Forest Reserve to a Nature Reserve in July 2016; however, threats to the subpopulation, including habitat loss and hunting, will continue until plans by the Tanzania Forest Service to protect this forest are enacted.
range: This species is known from the Mwanihana Forest and Uzungwa Scarp Nature Reserve, on the eastern slopes of the Udzungwa Mountains, Tanzania. It ranges from 290–2,000 m asl.
useTrade: This species is hunted for meat. Often it is terrestrial and susceptible to hunting with dogs.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

It is present in the Udzungwa Mountains National Park and Uzungwa Scarp Nature Reserve, Tanzania (Ehardt et al. 1999, 2005, Ehardt 2001, Ehardt and Butynski 2006, McCabe et al. 2013). Efforts in the early 2000s to expand the National Park boundaries to improve the level of protection in the Uzungwa Scarp forest have been unsuccessful. The USNR was recently elevated from a Forest Reserve to a Nature Reserve, which goes with a management plan for the forest and intentions by the Tanzania Forest Service to increase protection, develop ecotourism and promote community awareness and education; however, threats to the subpopulation, including habitat loss and hunting, remain (Rovero et al. 2012, Hegerl et al. 2015). A robust camera trapping assessment is ongoing and demographic surveys are planned. There is a need to enforce laws prohibiting hunting in the nature reserves, and to increase prevention of habitat alteration.

rationale:
All known populations of the Cercocebus chrysogaster are currently in decline (Inogwabini and Thompson 2013). The species range is now considerably smaller than depicted by Gautier-Hion et al. (1999). Threats include uncontrolled commercial bushmeat hunting, that targets the species, and reduction in occupancy due to habitat loss and degradation by logging.

In the past 20 years, at least 32% of the total habitat has been lost, the species has been extirpated from another 7% the total range, and population declines were recorded in 55% of eastern forest block. Thus, the total decline between 1999 and 2019 is estimated at ~40% of the population. In addition, more than 30% of the remaining habitat has been attributed to logging concessions. With population reduction and habitat loss continuing into the foreseeable future, it is suspected that the population decline over a period of 30 years (three generations for this taxon) will exceed 50%. This species does not occur in any protected areas and commercial hunting affects all portions of its range, with no evidence that effective controls are likely in the near future.
habitat:
A semi-terrestrial species with group sizes averaging about 15 (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999). Cercocebus chrysogaster occurs in seasonally-inundated lowland and upland rainforest and may occur in gallery forest (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999); occasionally ranges into secondary forest. Inogwabini and Thompson (2013) estimate that 58% of the range of the western population is swamp forest. In the Lusambo district (eastern population), the species occurs on white sand terra firma forests in areas where swamps are uncommon (Hart unpublished data 2010). Colyn and Deleporte (2006) classify C. chrysogaster as a riparian taxon capable of swimming.

Beaune et al. (2012) reported C. chrysogaster as a seed-dispersing species in the Lui Kotal forest.
threats:
High numbers of Cercocebus chrysogaster are killed for the commercial bushmeat trade across their range. This has led to ongoing dramatic population declines. The species appears to be highly vulnerable to hunting.

In the western population, Inogwabini and Thompson (2013) report that C. chrysogaster represents 30–70% of bushmeat available in some markets, including a major market at Oshwe, located near a military post at Bungimba. Beaune et al. (2012) report that populations in the Lui Kotal area are hunted and declining. Thompson (unpublished data 2008) documented a hunt on an island in the Momboyo River, created by a seasonal inundation, where numerous animals were systematically hunted down in a confined area.

In the eastern population, market surveys in Lusambo in 2010, revealed numerous fresh carcasses of C chrysogaster, representing about 10% of all bushmeat recorded (Thompson and Hart 2015). These animals came from the forest between the Sankuru and Lubefu rivers (Kapula Block). The presence of high numbers of fresh carcasses suggested that entire groups were being slaughtered in single events. A follow-up enquiry in Lusambo in 2015 confirmed that hunting of C. chrysogaster continues, but that fresh carcasses are now uncommon and populations of C. chrysogaster are reported to be low.

In 2012, 16 of 20 villages (80%) surveyed reported declines in the occurrence of the species due to hunting during the preceding decades, especially following a period of civil conflict (1998–2005; Hart unpubl. data 2015); 5 villages (25%) reported extirpation of the species from their locality (reported as uncommon, difficult to find, or only located far away). Furthermore, during 6 weeks of field surveys in 2012, field teams recorded 10 fresh carcasses, and three cases of mass killings (4–10 animals). Hunting for the species was still reported ongoing, even in villages reporting the declines.

The species is also threatened by habitat loss due to logging, leading to declines in range area and range occupancy. Inogwabini et al. (2013) report that west of the Lake Mai-Ndombe, where the species no longer occurs, local communities reported its disappearance over the course of two decades following the arrival of intensive logging. Industrial-scale logging concessions have been delimited in about 30% of the species’ range. Additional smaller-scale logging operations are widespread in the western range (Ministry of Environment 2013), thus the proportion of the species' range vulnerable to habitat loss and degradation is likely higher.

Captive animals are seen frequently in both the western and eastern locations, and for sale on the streets in Kinshasa (Inogwabini and Thompson 2013). Between 1983 and 2002, CITES records report exports of 43 animals identified as Cercocebus spp. originating from DRC. Lack of CITES export records since 2002 is likely due to inadequate record keeping, rather than elimination of the trade. Nevertheless, declining visibility of C. chrysogaster offered for sale publicly in Kinshasa over the last several years (Hart unpublished observations 2015) might be a result of increasing rarity of the species due to unsustainable offtake.

Cercocebus chrysogaster is persecuted as an agricultural pest in some areas (Inogwabini and Thompson 2013).
population:
The species occurs in two widely-separated populations (Thompson and Hart 2015). No population estimate is available. In the past, Cercocebus chrysogaster was reported as locally abundant with group sizes of over 100 (Ehardt and Butynski 2013). The largest group size recorded in the eastern population was 10 individuals (Hart unpubl. data 2010).

Over the last 20 years, at least 32% of habitat has been lost and the species has been extirpated from another 7% range. A decline of 55% has also been recorded for the eastern population. Hunting pressure continues to be high and 30% of remaining range is attributed to logging concessions. Based on this information, it is suspected that the population will undergo a reduction of at least 50% over the three-generation time period 1999-2029.
range: Cercocebus chrysogaster is endemic to the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The original account of the range is based on just 15 specimen locations, some of doubtful provenance (Ehardt and Butynski 2013). Dorst and Dandelot (1995) depicted the range as consisting of two discrete blocks. The area of western population’s range is ~68,000 km² and that of the eastern subpopulation ~12,000 km², separated by at least 300 km². Inogwabini and Thompson (2013) confirm that the two blocks, one in the northwest and one in the southeast, are separated by an area of non-occupation beginning east of 20°30’ longitude and extending to the Sankuru River north of Lusambo. In the southeast, the species occurs between the Sankuru and Lubefu Rivers, but not on the west bank of the Sankuru (Thompson and Hart 2015). As suggested by Hill (1974), there is no evidence that the species ranges east to Lomami River. The eastern limit appears to be Lubefu River. The range is fragmented within the two known population blocks.
useTrade: This species is killed in large numbers for the commercial bushmeat trade. Cercocebus chrysogaster was the single most abundant species recorded in counts of fresh bushmeat carcasses recorded roadside or in villages (Hart and Mpaka unpubl. data 2012). It is targeted across its entire range: in the western block, the species comprised 20–73% of all bushmeat recorded in three surveys between 2001 and 2007 (Inogwabini and Thompson 2013); in the eastern block, the species represented ~10% of all bushmeat sold in a major market (Lusambo) in a 2012 survey (Thompson and Hart 2015).
conservationActions:
The species is listed with other non-human primates on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Cercocebus chrysogaster is not currently identified in the list of nationally protected species in DRC (Enerunga 2006).

Cercocebus chrysogaster is not known to occur in any established protected areas. The species has been listed as possible for the Salonga National Park, although it has been recorded only outside the park boundaries in Lui Kotal, to the west (Beaune et al. 2012).

rationale: Cercocebus galeritus is listed as Critically Endangered. This species is endemic to forests along a 60-km stretch of the lower Tana River. This species lives in about 27 distinct, small, forests, some of which are isolated. In 1994, the area occupied by this species was less 26 km² and the population was ca 1,000–1,200 individuals. Current population is estimated at ca 1,000 individuals. Population reduction is expected to continue, based on a continuing decline in its area of occupancy and extent of occurrence, as a result of the current high rate of habitat degradation, fragmentation and loss due to unsustainable exploitation of forest, woodland, and bushland by people. A future population reduction exceeding 80% over three generations (33 years) is predicted, given the rate of decline in forest cover levels reached in recent years. This is especially likely if the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR) is officially annulled, an action now being considered by national authorities. The entire population lies in a politically insecure area over which there is a low level of conservation activity, and much unplanned, unregulated, and unsustainable exploitation of natural resources.
habitat: Cercocebus galeritus is restricted to flood-plain forest, riverine gallery forest, and the adjacent woodland and bushland (Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013). Abundance is highly correlated with the spatial characteristics of the forests (Wahungu et al. 2005). It is a semi-terrestrial monkey that can travel up to 1 km through non-forested habitat between forest patches (Wieczkowski 2010). Mean group size is ca 27 individuals (range: 6–62; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013). Cercocebus galeritus is frugivorous and forages predominantly on the ground and up to 2 m above the ground (Homewood 1978). It feeds on seeds, fruits, stems, leaves, insects and fungi (Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013).
threats:
Cercocebus galeritus has declined as a result of several causes including: (a) drastic changes in vegetation due to dam construction, irrigation projects and water diversion, which affect both the water table and the frequency and severity of flooding which, in turn, affect the extent and quality of this species’ forest habitat; (b) forest clearance for agriculture; (c) fires that destroy forests; (d) habitat degradation due to livestock and (e) the unsustainable collection of wood and other forest products; (f) selective felling of fig trees for canoes; (g) exploitation of one of the species’ top food plants, Phoenix reclinata; and (h) corruption, inter-ethnic violence and insecurity. There is also percution of C. galeritus as a crop pest and this is expected to increase as natural foods become less available due to habitat loss (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000, de Jong and Butynski 2012, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013, Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013, Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016, Butynski and de Jong 2019). Because all remaining forests inhabited by C. galeritus are small and seriously threatened, the long-term survival of the species is in question.

There has been considerable alteration of river flow volume and the flood cycle by five hydroelectric power dams up-river (Butynski 1995). A sixth dam, the High Grand Falls Dam, is under construction (Hamerlynck et al. 2012; Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016). The High Grand Falls Dam, the second largest dam in Africa, will be accompanied by large-scale irrigation schemes and water transfer to the ‘Lamu Port and Lamu Southern Sudan-Ethiopia Transport Corridor’. The establishment of this dam is expected to have additional negative impacts on the forests of the Lower Tana River and, therefore, on C. galeritus.

One special concern is the rapidly growing human population in the region. Another is the possible annulment of the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR; 169 km²), which the High Court of Kenya ordered in January 2007. According to the Kenya Wildlife Act 2013, Section 37, change of boundaries or revocation of a National Reserve can only be published by the Cabinet Secretary and approved by Parliament. Change or revocation can only be recommended if they do not endanger any species or critical habitat. As such, it seems unlikely that annulment will occur despite the court ruling in 2007.

About 56% of C. galeritus occur in TRPNR. Even with the continued existence of the TRPNR the long-term survival of C. galeritus is not certain as the high level of insecurity and inadequate law enforcement in the region is expected to continue, as is the growth in the human population (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013, Butynski and de Jong 2019).
population: Cercocebus galeritus is often relatively common where present (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013). In 1994, population density was ca 0.45 individuals per ha of occupied forest habitat (Butynski and Mwangi 1994). Genetic analyses show that the effective population size is <100 individuals (Mbora and McPeek 2015). The global population is roughly 1,000 individuals.
range:
Cercocebus galeritus is endemic to a stretch of flood-plain forests along the lower Tana River, northern coastal Kenya, from Nkanjonja in the north to Hewani in the south, with an altitudinal range of 20–40 m asl. This species lives in about 27 distinct, small (1–500 ha) forests, some of which are isolated. The area over which this species lives is less than 26 km² (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013).

Cercocebus galeritus is broadly sympatric with Piliocolobus rufomitratus, Cercopithecus mitis albotorquatus, Paragalago cocos, Otolemur garnettii lasiotis, and narrowly sympatric on forest edge with Papio cynocephalus ibeanus, Chlorocebus pygerythrus hilgerti, and Galago senegalensis braccatus (De Jong and Butynski 2009, 2012; Butynski and De Jong 2019).
useTrade: There is some hunting of Cercocebus galeritus as a crop pest and this is expected to increase as natural foods become less available due to habitat loss (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000; de Jong and Butynski 2012; Struhsaker and Grubb 2013; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013; Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016; Butynski and de Jong 2018).
conservationActions:
Cercocebus galeritus is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class A of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Given the current poor management of the TRPNR, the continued clearing of forest and settlement of people within the TRPNR, and the low level of conservation activity in the region, the long-term survival of C. galeritus seems bleak. A small number of C. galeritus may still be present in the Tana River Delta. This delta became a Ramsar Site in 2012. Otherwise, the Tana River Delta has no protected area status.

Ndera Community Conservancy, established in 2010 with the help of the Northern Rangeland Trust (www.nrt-kenya.org), aims to conserve 150 km² of habitat along the lower Tana River  and to improve the viability of forest patches within and outside the TRPNR (Mbora and Allen 2011, J. King pers. obs. 2016). The Ndera Community Conservancy provides an opportunity for improved conservation of those forests upon which C. galeritus depends.

Stringent habitat protection is required. The Mchelelo Research Station in the TRPNR should be rehabilitated and re-established.

rationale: Because of its wide range, this species is listed as Least Concern. There are currently no known threats that are likely to result in substantial population declines for Chlorocebus cynosuros. However, this species has rarely been studied and no thorough assessment of its range and numbers have been published in recent years.
habitat:
This species is present in savanna, open woodland and forest-grassland mosaic, and maintains a year-round proximity to water sources. It is an extremely adaptable species that can also live in rural and urban environments. When in woodland or forest areas, the species seems to prefer living near the edge; trees and shrubs provide shelter and sleeping sites while nearby open areas provide ample opportunity for ground foraging (Ansell 1978 in Sarmiento 2013). Most of its range is dry and warm, with temperatures of 18–24°C throughout the year. May occur from near sea level up to 1850 m (see Sarmiento 2013).

In Angola, they are quite common throughout most of the country, especially along the coastal plain (except in the desert and pre-desert), and throughout most of the plateau. Much of the country is characterised by miombo woodlands (Brachystegia, Julbernardia, etc.) and, in those areas, the Malbrouck monkeys are often the only species present (P. Pinto pers. comm. 2016).

The Malbrouck monkey is omnivorous, feeding on fruit, seeds, flowers, gum and bird's eggs. Invertebrates and some small vertebrates (e.g., fledglings and lizards) are also eaten, but detailed dietary data are not available.
threats: Like other members of this genus, the Malbrouck monkey is a skilled crop-raider. Consequently, it is hunted as a pest in some parts of its range (Angola and Zambia, Sarmiento 2013). Poaching for bushmeat is widespread in Angola, yet very few Malbrouck monkeys are found on display in markets. Instead, antelopes and forest primate species (e.g., blue monkey and red-tailed monkeys) are targeted by hunters (P. Pinto pers. comm. 2016). Occasionally, young monkeys of the species are sold alive as pets. The apparently low poaching factor, combined with the adaptability of the species and its ranging in areas with low incidence of human-wildlife conflict, suggest that there are no known major threats at this time.
population: No data on population density exist for this species. It is presumed to be common because much of its range occurs in areas with low human population density. Thus, the current population trend is presumed to be stable, although further study is warranted.
range: Ranges from southern Democratic Republic of Congo southwards through Angola to northern Namibia and to the Luangwa Valley, Zambia, west of the Luangwa River.
useTrade: Hunted as a pest in some parts of its range (Angola and Zambia). Rarely seen in bushmeat markets, but young monkeys are occasionally sold alive as pets.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. It is present in at least three protected areas: Luando National Park in Angola, Chobe National Park in Botswana, and Etosha National Park in Namibia (Wallis 2013).

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern as it is widespread and abundant with apparently no major threats.
habitat:
This species is present in savanna, open woodland and forest-grassland mosaic, especially close to rivers (Dorst and Dandelot 1972). It is an extremely adaptable species that can live in both rural and urban environments; the latter may increase risk of problems arising from human-wildlife conflict in cultivated areas. In fact, Grivet Monkeys will raid crops and are considered a major pest in some parts of their distribution. They have been known to take bananas, citrus and other crops (Zinner et al. 2002). Where not hunted, they become habituated to humans and have been observed to take handouts from tourists.

An omnivorous species, Grivets are especially fond of figs and other fruiting trees and, in some areas, they are heavily dependent on parts of thorn trees (Acacia, Fabaceae), including seeds, thorns and bark (Butynski 2002). They’re known to occasionally eat bird's eggs and animal prey, including invertebrates, chameleons, fledgling birds and small mammals, such as rodents and even galagos (Galagidae).

Grivet Monkeys live in bands of 6–20, averaging a dozen individuals (Dorst and Dandelot 1972). As with other taxa in this genus, males transfer between groups, while females tend to remain in their natal groups. This diurnal and mostly terrestrial species has a complex social structure; most groups have multiple adult males that are usually outnumbered by adult females (Wallis 2013). Individuals may live for more than 30 years. A single offspring is born after a gestation period of approximately 6 months.
threats:
Chlorocebus aethiops is generally common and adaptable over its range. Although Grivet Monkeys have a long list of likely nonhuman predators, many of these species’ numbers have declined in recent years. Thus, for the Grivet, there are presumed to be no major predatory threats. Their affinity for crop-raiding may result in human-wildlife conflict that could impact their numbers in some locales as pests are killed, but hunting grivets for meat by local humans is not widely reported.

As in other areas of Africa, large-scale farming and expansion of human habitations clearly plays a role in reducing suitable habitat. Furthermore, Zinner et al. (2002) noted that the influx of refugees from Ethiopia and Sudan into Eritrea exacerbated loss of habitat and escalated human-wildlife conflict.

Additionally, genetic analyses of Grivet Monkey populations living in a large geographic area along the Awash River (Ethiopia) found a low level of variability compared with many other cercopithecines (Shimada and Shotake 1997). Turner (1981) found similar lack of diversity in a blood protein study of Ethiopian grivets. These findings are explained as a likely consequence of recent and repeated series of rapid habitat expansions following dramatic climate conditions as suggested by paleoclimatic data (Shimada and Shotake 1997). If so, Grivet Monkeys may be one of many primate species facing challenges due to climate change. Further studies are therefore recommended.
population: This is a common species, though not well-studied. Thus, reliable recent population numbers for most of its range are not available. The current population trend of “stable” requires more data for further assessment. Grivet Monkeys are the most widespread monkey species in Ethiopia; Dunbar and Dunbar (1974) recorded their density in the Bole Valley at 73 individuals per km² and the biomass was estimated at 207 kg/km². Elsewhere in their range, they are thought to be found at similar densities to C. pygerythrus, found to the south and in in East Africa (Wolfheim 1983).
range:
The Grivet Monkey is endemic to far northeast Africa, east of the White Nile, in Eritrea, Ethiopia (south to the Omo River and east as far as the Ethiopian Rift Valley), Djibouti, southeast Sudan (from Khartoum in the north), and much of the eastern portion of South Sudan (Dandelot and Prevost 1972, Zinner et al. 2002). Its range formerly extended along the Nile Valley. It is suspected that the species may have once ranged as far north as southern Egypt, but no records have confirmed their presence. Thus, the northern limit of the Grivet Monkey's range is thought to be approximately 15°N, which is likely the northernmost limit of any guenon species (Butynski and Kingdon 2013).

Chlorocebus aethiops intergrades with C. pygerythrus in southwestern Ethiopia; it is unclear whether the resulting hybrids are the form originally described as C. a. zavattarii. Some authors recognise the form C. a. matschiei from the western highlands of Ethiopia as a distinct subspecies, in which all other grivets take the name C. a. aethiops.
useTrade: Killed as pests, but hunting for bushmeat has not been widely reported.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. These monkeys are often common and adapt to a wide variety of habitats throughout their distribution. There are presumed to be no major threats to this species at this time, though recent data are lacking. It is known to occur in several protected areas. It is present in five of Ethiopia’s nine national parks, including Awash National Park (Butynski and Kingdon 2013, Wallis 2013). Eritrea has long-term plans to create a protected area system that will support C. aethiops (EAE 1995, in Butynski and Kingdon 2013).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern, this species has a wide geographical range in which it is locally abundant. Although Chlorocebus pygerythrus is in decline overall, there is no evidence of a significant range-wide population decline that would warrant listing in a higher category of threat.
habitat: C. pygerythrus is a medium-sized, semi-terrestrial primate which occupies savanna, open woodland and forest-grassland mosaic, especially close to rivers and lake shores (Isbell and Jaffe 2013). They are adaptable and able to persist in secondary and/or highly fragmented habitats, including cultivated areas, and they are often found in rural and urban environments. A significant part the range consists of miombo woodland. C. pygerythrus is typically absent from deserts and deep forest (Isbell & Jaffe 2013). They lives in multi-male and multi-female groups of up to 38 individuals; many unrelated males may be present in a group. Home ranges vary from 5 to 103 ha. Vervet Monkeys sleep in tall trees and are omnivorous, feeding on gum, leaves, flowers, fruits, seeds and invertebrates (Isbell and Jaffe 2013).
threats:
Although C. pygerythrus are adaptable and widespread, their very patchy distribution and often small populations make them vulnerable to local decline or extinction (Isbell and Jaffe 2013). The main threats to the species are human-caused habitat degradation, fragmentation and destruction (Isbell and Jaffe 2013, T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016).

C. pygerythrus is often considered a nuisance. It is persecuted in response to crop raiding or negative interactions at tourist facilities (Isbell & Jaffe 2013, Wallis 2013, T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016). They also constitute a source of bushmeat in some areas, including Turkana District, Kenya (de Jong et al. 2008).
population: C. pygerythrus is patchily distributed over their extensive geographic range, probably due to its need to drink water daily and for large trees in which to sleep (Isbell and Jaffe 2013, T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016). Densities vary between 9 and 104 individuals/km² (Isbell and Jaffe 2013). Vervet monkeys are locally abundant but there are large areas within the geographic range from which they are absent. In cultivated areas and at tourist sites, it is often regarded as a nuisance due to raiding activities (Y. de Jong and T. Butynski pers. obs. 2016). Small, isolated, populations may be prone to local extinction (Isbell and Jaffe 2013).
range:
C. pygerythrus is distributed from the Ethiopian Highlands (east of the Rift Valley) and southern Somalia in the north, through Kenya (including the Lamu Archipelago), eastern Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, Tanzania (including Pemba, Zanzibar and Mafia Islands), Zambia (east of the Luangwa Valley), Malawi, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, eastern Botswana and much of South Africa (all provinces: Isbell and Jaffe 2013). It is sympatric with Papio spp. and Erythrocebus patas (T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2014). It inhabits altitudes from sea level to > 2,000 m (Mt Hanang, Tanzania: Isbell and Jaffe 2013, Y. de Jong and T. Butynski pers. obs. 2009).

Four subspecies are recognised:

Chlorocebus pygerythrus hilgerti (Hilgert’s Vervet Monkey) ranges from the Ethiopian Highlands (east of the Rift Valley) and southern Somalia in the north, through Kenya (including the Lamu Archipelago), eastern Uganda, through northeastern Tanzania south to the Rufiji River (de Jong and Butynski 2009, Isbell and Jaffe 2013, Butynski and de Jong 2014). The western limit in Kenya and Uganda, relative to the Tantalus Monkey Chlorocebus tantalus, remains poorly understood (Butynski and de Jong 2014, de Jong and Butynski 2014), as is the northern limit in northwestern Kenya, southern South Sudan, and northern Uganda relative to the Grivet Monkey Chlorocebus aethiops (de Jong and Butynski 2014).

Chlorocebus pygerythrus nesiotes (Pemba Vervet Monkey) is endemic to Pemba and Mafia Island, off the coast of Tanzania (Isbell and Jaffe 2013).

Chlorocebus pygerythrus pygerythrus (Southern Vervet Monkey) is found east of the Okavango Delta and south of the Zambesi River in Botswana, Zimbabwe, southern Mozambique and South Africa (Isbell and Jaffe 2013). The western limit, relative to Chlorocebus cynosures, is poorly understood.

Chlorocebus pygerythrus rufoviridis (Reddish-green Monkey) ranges from Burundi, Rwanda and southwestern Uganda, through western and southern Tanzania southward to the Zambezi River east of the Luangwa River in Zambia (Isbell and Jaffe 2013, Wallis 2013). 

A photographic map of Chlorocebus pygerythrus can be found at www.wildsolutions.nl/photography/
conservationActions:
Chlorocebus pygerythrus is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Further taxonomic work is required to assess the validity C. pygerythrus as a species and of the currently recognised subspecies.

Present in a large number of protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable as its extent of occurrence (EOO) ca 8,000 km² with severe fragmentation of the population. There is continuing decline of the population and the number of mature individuals due to ongoing habitat loss and degradation, hunting and, perhaps, hybridisation. The species occurs at low densities in bamboo forest as well as in fragmented forests. C. djamdjamensis occupies a specialised niche with unusual habitat and diet (reviewed in Butynski et al. 2013, Mekonnen and Jaffe 2016).
habitat: Chlorocebus djamdjamensis has specialised habitat requirements, as it is found in the bamboo forest zone of the Bale Mountains and Sidamo Highlands. C. djamdjamensis is unique among Chlorocebus species, with its specialised niche including habitat (bamboo forest), diet (bamboo young leaves and shoots) and high altitudinal range (inhabiting higher altitudes in a narrow geographic range). Mekonnen et al. (2010a, 2010b, 2012, 2016) and Butynski et al. (2013) summarise the current state of knowledge of this diurnal, semi-terrestrial monkey.
threats:
The main threats to Bale Monkeys are ongoing habitat loss, degradation and fragmentation, hunting and, perhaps, hybridization. For example, the Harenna Forest, where Chlorocebus djamdjamensis is generally uncommon, it is under threat from expanding human populations, fire, agriculture and the removal of forest products such as bamboo, lumber, fuelwood and charcoal. Threatened with extirpation in the Sidamo Highlands due to habitat loss and fragmentation that leave many populations in small, isolated, forest fragments in the human-dominated landscape. Two populations extirpated in southern Ethiopia (e.g. Abera; Mekonnen et al. 2012).

The species is persecuted for crop raiding at some locations. People report intense conflict with C. djamdjamensis and hunt this species with traps, spears and dogs (Mekonnen et al. 2012).

Recent morphological and genetic studies suggest hybridization between C. djamdjamensis and Chlorocebus aethiops on the margins of their ranges (e.g., Ekuma Mountain, Kulla Mountain, and Wotiye; Mekonnen et al. 2012, Haus et al. 2013). Monkeys at these sites exhibited intermediate characters of coat colour, tail length and whisker length (Mekonnen et al. 2012). However, C. djamdjamensis has not yet been found in sympatry with C. aethiops or Chlorocebus pygerythrus, suggesting that any hybridization at these sites occurred more than a century ago.
population: Chlorocebus djamdjamensis was more widespread and abundant in historic times. The current overall population size is unknown. The only locality with a known population size is Odobullu Forest (1,700–2,000 individuals; Mekonnen et al. 2010a). Population has been declining in Sidamo Highlands where <800 individuals are present in 26 small, isolated, forest fragments (Mekonnen et al. 2012).
range: Chlorocebus djamdjamensis is endemic to the highlands of Ethiopia, east of the Ethiopian Rift Valley, in the Bale Mountains and Sidamo Highlands. It occurs between 2,355 and 3,300 m asl (Mekonnen et al. 2012, Butynski et al. 2013, Mekonnen and Jaffe 2016).
useTrade: This species is persecuted for crop raiding, which causes intense conflict with local people. It is hunted with traps, spears and dogs (Mekonnen et al. 2012).
conservationActions: Chlorocebus djamdjamensis is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Present in the proposed Harena-Kokosa National Forest Reserve, but formal gazettement is required. Since habitat destruction is the major threat, and since C. djamdjamensis relies heavily on bamboo, the taking of bamboo at sites with this monkey should be outlawed (Mekonnen et al. 2012). Additional surveys in the Bale Mountains are required to better understand the species' distribution and population status.

rationale: Chlorocebus sabaeus is listed as Least Concern. Increasing hunting pressure for bushmeat and persecution as crop pests in many parts of their range are suspected to be causing a population decline. Habitat loss caused by mining, agriculture and human population growth is also a threat, but the total decline has not exceeded 30% over the past three generations (36 years).
habitat:
C. sabaeus occurs in riverine gallery woodlands, acacia savannas, Sahel savannas, Guinea savannas, savanna-forest mosaic, mangrove forest and at the edge of lowland tropical moist forest (Gippoliti and Dell'Omo 2003, Galat and Galat-Luong 2013). Temperature range is 1–57°C (Galat and Galat-Luong 1977).

Home ranges sizes are variable. For instance, in Saloum, Senegal, home range was reported as 138 ha (Galat and Galat-Luong 1976). In the Senegal River valley, home ranges are 157–164 ha (Galat 1983). Day range length is 2,000–8,000 m. In the Bandia Reserve, Senegal, day range can reach up to 11,000 m during the dry season, when the monkeys are searching for water (Galat-Luong et al. 2016). C. sabaeus is diurnal, semi-terrestrial and spends 28–61% of its time on the ground; 20–80% at 0–5 m height; 12–20% at 5–10 m; 2–8% at 10–20 m. On rare occasions, it climbs above 20 m, for example in Dialium guineense in Burkina Faso (Galat-Luong 1976, Galat 1983, Galat-Luong et al. 2016). Green monkeys swim readily (Galat and Galat-Luong 1976, Oates 2011, Galat-Luong et al. 2016).

C. sabaeus occurs in multi-male/multi-female groups. In Senegal, troop size varies from 8 to 174, and large troops fission into one-male subgroups during the rainy and birth seasons (Galat and Galat-Luong 1977, Galat 1983). In Côte d’Ivoire, group size varies from 4 to 9 individuals (Galat and Galat-Luong 1980). Females of different troops guard offspring in common nurseries in large trees during daytime rest periods (Galat and Galat-Luong 2013).

C. sabaeus is an opportunistic generalist omnivore (Galat et al. 2009). They feed on fruits (24–50%), leaves (28–50%), seeds (13%), flowers (3–13%), buds, young twigs, stems, bark and gum (11–15%), invertebrates (5–50%) and vertebrates, including birds’ eggs, birds, lizards and small mammals. Unusual food items include Acacia seyal thorns, fungi, bird faeces, and soil from termite mounds (Galat and Galat-Luong 1977, 1978, McGrew et al. 1978, Galat 1983, Harrison 1983). In the Senegal River valley, C. sabaeus were observed to prey upon Arvicanthis niloticus, Streptopelia senegalensis, Passer griseus, Tockus erythrorhynchus, eggs, Lepus saxatilis, lizards. They also dug out West African marbled lungfishes Protopterus annectens from their subterranean borrows during the dry season (Galat-Luong 1977, Galat and Galat-Luong 2013, Galat-Luong et al. 2016). In the Saloum mangrove, they feed on Rhizophora mangle aerial roots and prey upon fiddler crabs Uca tangeri (Galat and Galat-Luong 1976). In some locations, they crop raid and steal food from tourists (Galat 1983, Galat and Galat-Luong 2013). 

Territorial behaviour is related to habitat productivity and food availability. At sites with more than 500 mm annual rainfall, C. sabaeus occupies relatively small home ranges because productivity is sufficient to sustain a group in a small area. In rich environments, C. sabaeus live in small groups (less than 36 individual) in small home ranges (15–30 ha, with some local exceptions in less diverse habitats, such as plantations). In such conditions, a dominant male defends an exclusive territory using ritualized territorial displays. In habitats with less than 500 mm annual rainfall, food supply becomes more restricted because of low productivity and low predictability. In such poor environments, C. sabaeus lives in larger groups (up to 174 individuals) and has large home ranges (up to 140 ha). These home ranges are widely overlapping among groups without any territorial behaviour. Up to 300 individuals of different troops have been seen to share a large local food source simultaneously without showing any overt aggression. In smaller food patches, Galat and colleagues observed a form of queuing by subgroups (Galat 1983, Galat and Galat-Luong 2013, Galat-Luong et al. 2016). 

C. sabaeus prefers to sleep in large tall trees with good visibility of surroundings, along riverbanks when available (Galat-Luong et al. 2016). In the Senegal River valley, different troops may share the same sleeping trees (Galat 1983).

The natural predators of C. sabaeus are Panthera pardus, Python sebae, Crocuta crocuta, Lycaon pictus, Pan troglodytes and large eagles. Caracal caracal, Leptailurus serval, Lupulella adustus, Canis lupus familiaris probably also prey on young green monkeys (Pruetz and Bertolani 2007, Galat and Galat-Luong 2013). Experimental exhibition of surrogates of leopards and snakes (Price and Fischer 2014) and leopards, civets and flying eagles (Galat-Luong et al. 2016) elicits threat alarm barks and anti-predatory behaviour.

C. sabaeus are healthy carriers of the simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV). Prevalence can reach 46% in wild populations (Galat and Galat-Luong 1997).
threats:
Humans are major predators – C. sabaeus are hunted as bushmeat and killed to protect crops. Increasing hunting pressure and bushmeat traffic is affecting populations in Burkina Faso, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, Guinea and Sierra Leone (Ginn and Nekaris 2014, Brncic et al. 2015). Green monkeys emit territorial loud calls at dawn and sunset, indicating the location of the whole troop (often a single large tree). This makes them easy to hunt; however, as hunting pressure increases and C. sabaeus density decreases, they adapt their behaviour and become quiet while dispersing into several trees, sometimes with as few as one monkey per tree. As a result, hunting becomes more difficult (A. Galat-Luong and G. Galat pers. obs. 1974–1976, 1988–2002).

There is evidence of increasing live trade as pets. In addition, they are persecuted as crop pests in many parts of their range (Wallis 2013). An exception is in Mali, where this threat is low according to Schleicher et al. (2014).

In addition to hunting pressure, habitat loss caused by mining, agriculture and human population growth are causing declines of populations across their range. For example, in Guinea, important habitat is being cleared at planned mining sites in Sangaredi (Baarman et al. 2014).
population:
There is no total population estimate for the species, but a few decades ago the combined population of Niokolo-Koba in Senegal and Comoé in Côte d'Ivoire was at least 40,000 individuals (Geerling and Bokdam 1973, Galat et al. 1997). C. sabaeus populations can grow rapidly under favourable conditions and have recoved quickly from high mortality in extreme habitats (Oates 2011). During harsh dry weather (temperatures up to 57°C, annual rainfall below 20 mm), reproduction can be halted (Galat and Galat-Luong 1977).

Senegal: C. sabaeus have been censused in two national parks. In Delta du Saloum National Park, a UNESCO MAB Reserve, the mean population size from 1998 and 2001 counts was 700 individuals. The Fathala Forest Reserve population varied from 400 to 550 individuals (mean density 5.5 individuals/km², troop size up to 33 individuals) (Galat and Galat-Luong 1976, Galat et al. 1998, 2002). In Niokolo-Koba National Park, the estimated mean population size from 1990 to 1995 was 28,000 individuals (Galat et al. 1997). Along the left bank of the Senegal River, the distribution of C. sabaeus is very patchy and sensitive to dry conditions. 

Mauritania: a similar situation to that in Senegal was observed along the right bank of the Senegal River (A. Galat-Luong and G. Galat pers. obs. 1988–1996).

Guinea: a rapid assessment of the primate fauna conducted in 2005 in the northwestern Boké Prefecture indicated the presence of green monkeys in several localities (Eriksson and Kpoghomou 2006). Surveys conducted in the same area in 2013 confirmed that the species is relatively common in Sangaredi and Kamsar sub-prefectures, but numbers per group are low (Baarman et al. 2014).

Burkina Faso: the species has been reported in Comoé-Léraba Partial Reserve (Galat and Galat-Luong 2006, Oates 2011). Surveys conducted from May to July 2012 in the southern part of the country confirmed its presence in Comoé-Léraba Partial Reserve, and in Koulbi, and Nazinga Forests although at low encounter rates (0.02–0.10 groups/km) (Ginn and Nekaris 2014). The presence of C. sabaeus in these forests was corroborated by Haus et al. (2013) using mitochondrial DNA sequencing.

Côte d'Ivoire: in Comoé National Park, Geerling and Bokdam (1973) estimated 1.4 individuals/km². Of 195 encounters with groups of primates in Comoé National Park (1980–1986), 7% were with C. sabaeus, ranking 6th of nine monkey species. Outside Comoé National Park, of 235 encounters with groups of primates made in the geographic range of C. sabaeus, 7% were with C. sabaeus, ranking 4th of 14 species (Galat-Luong et al. 2016). Kadjo et al. (2014) encountered the species at a rate of 0.51 group/km during a 2006 survey in Marahoué National Park. However, more recent surveys in that park failed to reconfirm its presence (Bitty et al. 2015).

Cape Verde Islands: C. sabaeus are found on both Santiago and Brava islands. Their numbers are likely smaller now than they were in the past (Hazevoet and Masseti 2011).

Mali: Schleicher et al. (2014) reported that C. sabaeus is relatively common in several localities in the Bafing protected areas in the southwest of the country. Pavy (1993) estimated a density of 1.2 individuals/km².
range: The geographic area over which Chlorocebus sabaeus occurs is ca 1,000,000 km² (Galat and Galat-Luong 2013). The species ranges from Senegal, with the westernmost limit at Mbao and Dakar (Galat and Galat-Luong 2013), and Guinea-Bissau to west of the Nakambe/Volta River system in Burkina Faso and Ghana. It has been recorded from the Bijagos archipelago in Guinea Bissau (Gippoliti and Dell'Omo 2003). In Côte d’Ivoire, the species is distributed mainly through the savanna and savanna-forest mosaic habitats north of the rainforest zone (Galat and Galat-Luong 1980). They were also reported from the forest zone of southern Côte d’Ivoire outside its expected range at the edge of the Ebrié Laguna near Jacqueville (Galat 1983), and in Ile Ehotilé National Park (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2009); however, it is not clear whether their occurrence here is natural or from introduction by humans. Green monkeys have been introduced to Barbados and Saint Kitts and Nevis in the Caribbean, and to Cape Verde.
useTrade: Chlorocebus sabaeus on Saint Kitts and Nevis are trapped each year and imported to Miami for United States Research and testing laboratories (http://arff.org/kitts). Green monkeys are also imported by Canada from Barbados. The monkeys are used for medical research into HIV, SIV and STLV epidemiology and virology, herpes, hepatitis, vaccines and dentistry.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

Chlorocebus sabaeus is present in many protected areas, including: Niokolo-Koba and Delta du Saloum national parks in Senegal; Comoé National Park in Côte d’Ivoire; Comoé-Leraba Hunting Reserve, Mare aux hippopotames de Bala MaB Biosphere Reserve, Bontioli and Deux Balé forêts classées in Burkina Faso; River Gambia National Park in Gambia; Badiar and Haut Niger national parks in Guinea; and Boucle du Baoulé National Park in Mali. In Côte d'Ivoire, C. sabaeus is sometimes protected by traditional beliefs, as it is a sacred monkey in some villages (e.g., Soko) and in sacred forests (Galat-Luong et al. 2016).

rationale: Chlorocebus tantalus is listed as Least Concern, as this species is common and widespread with no known major threats except in very localized areas.
habitat:
Tantalus Monkeys are present in savanna, open woodland, and forest-grassland mosaic, often near rivers and streams. Their preferred forest type varies geographically. They often show a preference for gallery forest (Nakagawa 1999), but they are found in dry woodlands in northern Nigeria, and montane forests in southern Nigeria.

This species is extremely adaptable, residing in degraded habitats or forest edges (e.g., in Togo and Bénin; Campbell et al. 2008), and is found in both rural and urban environments (Wallis 2013). It lives sympatrically with Patas Monkeys (Erythrocebus patas) in much of their range (Nakagawa 1999, 2000). 

As with other members of their genus, Tantalus Monkeys have an omnivorous diet, feeding on leaves, fruits, seeds, flowers, gums, birds’ eggs, invertebrates (including insects), and some small vertebrates (Nakagawa 2000). They spend 20–25% of their time feeding, but this varies by season and location of study (Nakagawa 1999).

Although they can feed high in the trees, much of their feeding takes place on or near the ground (Kavanagh 1978). In fact, Tantalus Monkeys are largely terrestrial and can travel long distances while foraging of approximately 2,500 m per day (Nakagawa 1999). They are key seed dispersers, playing an important role in forest regeneration of their habitats; some disperse seeds as far as 1–5 km from the parent tree (Agmen et al. 2010).
threats:
Chlorocebus tantalus is common and highly adaptable over its range. There are presumed to be no major predatory threats. As with others in their genus, the Tantalus Monkey’s affinity for crop-raiding can result in frequent human-wildlife conflict, which impacts their numbers in some locations. However, because they often live near Patas Monkeys or Olive Baboons (Papio anubis), both of which are larger and bolder in their crop-raiding efforts, the Tantalus Monkey may often escape blame (and persecution). As mentioned, hunting Tantalus Monkeys for their meat by humans is not widely reported, perhaps due to their relatively small size, although Hema et al. (2019) found the species for sale as part of their bushmeat survey in Burkina Faso. 

Occasionally, these monkeys become ensnared by traps set for other wildlife in their habitat or struck by vehicles on roads (Wallis pers. obs. 2009 in Uganda). 

With widespread habitat depletion and forecasts for dramatic ecosystem responses to climate conditions reported for parts of Africa (e.g., Ponce-Reyes et al. 2017), the Tantalus Monkey may eventually face increasing challenges due to climate change. Thus, their numbers should be monitored, and further study of their distribution is recommended.
population: C. tantalus is a common species, widely distributed in various habitat types. Alhough very few population density estimates are available, some recent reports from interviews and surveys indicate a decreasing population when compared with historical accounts (Ginn and Nekaris 2014). In some locations, they may be at risk due to human-wildlife conflict caused by crop-raiding (Wallis pers. obs. 2005–2009 in Nigeria, 2009 in Uganda). Overall, however, the population appears to be stable and may even be increasing in some areas where forest clearance provides more suitable habitat (see Habitats and Ecology section).
range:
The Tantalus Monkey occurs widely across Africa. It ranges from eastern Burkina Faso and east of the Volta River system in Ghana (recorded from Accra Plain and Salaga) eastward to Sudan (Imatong Mountains in the south to Jebel Marra in the north), South Sudan, and much of Uganda. They have been recorded up to about 1,900 m asl. 

The three subspecies range as follows: C. t. tantalus Ogilby, 1841 – from eastern Burkina Faso and Ghana (east of the Volta River) through Central African Republic, Chad and into northwestern DR Congo; C. t. budgetti Pocock, 1907 – northeastern DR Congo, Sudan, South Sudan, and Uganda; and C. t. marrensis Thomas and Hinton, 1923, found in western Sudan (west of the White Nile), and in South Sudan from the Imatong Mountains in the south to Jebel Marra in the north, where it is isolated from other populations by desert.

Previous assessments have placed this species in northwest Kenya, but more recent surveys suggest the Chlorocebus monkeys in that area are C. pygerythrus instead (Butynski and de Jong 2017). It should be noted that the taxonomic status of the species and subspecies of Chlorocebus is complex and needs further phenotypic study. Butynski and de Jong (2017) report that C. tantalus, C. aethiops and C. pygerythrus occur in extensive phenotypic clines in parts of northwest Kenya and northeast Uganda. There appear to be no effective geographic barriers between these species.
useTrade: Hunting Tantalus Monkeys for their meat is not widely reported, perhaps due to their relatively small size, although Hema et al. (2019) found the species for sale as part of their bushmeat survey in Burkina Faso. Some local hunters are known to target Tantalus Monkeys when presented with the opportunity and some are kept as pets (Wallis pers. obs. 2005–2009 in Nigeria).
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

The C. t. tantalus subspecies is found in many protected areas. These include: Pendjari and west of the Niger national parks in Benin; Bénoué, Bouba-Ndjida, Kalamaloue, and Waza National Parks, Faro Reserve, and Kimbe River and Mbi Crater game reserves in Cameroon; west of the Niger National Park in Niger; Cross River, Gashaka-Gumti, and Kainji Lake national parks, Oban Hills, Ngel Nyaki, and Olokemeji forest reserves, and Borgu, Kwiambana, Pandam, Upper Ogun, and Yankari game reserves in Nigeria; and Keran and Malfacassa Reserves in Togo. Budgetti’s Tantalus, C. t. budgetti, occurs in several national parks in Uganda, including Murchison Falls, Kibale, and Bwindi national parks, as well as in the Budongo, Kasokwa-Kityedo forest fragments and other protected or semi-protected areas. The Jebbel Marra Tantalus, C. t. marrensis, is apparently not found in any protected areas.

Although there are no known organised conservation efforts focused only on C. tantalus, the species occurs in many protected areas and is monitored by several primatologists in their studies of other species. Still, their semi-terrestrial and gregarious nature often places them in conflict with humans. Educational efforts should focus on increasing awareness of the species’ seed dispersing benefits, particularly since they thrive in degraded habitats (see Agmen et al. 2010, Albert et al. 2014).

rationale: <span class="apple-converted-space">Considering the extensive habitat loss and fragmentation from changing land use such as large scale conversion to plantations, small-holder farming, limestone quarrying and potentially the construction of dams that has taken place within the species’ range, and the fact that the population is under high hunting pressure for traditional medicine and pet trade, it is suspected that the population is quite small, fragmented and in decline, probably at a rate of more than 50% over three generations (approximately 36 years), thus qualifying for listing as Endangered. Since the threats are continuing and there is a lack of conservation 'will' politically and amongst the public, it is suspected that the decline will continue at the same rate if not more over the next three generations.
habitat:
The Indochinese Silvered Langur occurs in lowland, semi-evergreen and evergreen forests on Phu Quoc Island, and forest on karst areas, mangrove forest and inundated melaleuca forest in mainland Viet Nam (Hoang Minh Duc et al. 2012b, Hoang Minh Duc pers.com). In Cambodia, it is found in a wide variety of primarily lowland habitats, including evergreen and semi-evergreen forest patches within the extensive deciduous dipterocarp forests, mixed deciduous patches, riparian strips, gallery forest (Kong and Tan 2002, Moody et al. 2011), and the seasonally inundated forests of  the Tonle Sap Lake  and Mekong floodplains (Davidson 2006). The upper altitudinal limit is not clear, but there are no known records in Cambodia above 450 m (Moody et al. 2011). The species occurs from sea level (Ca Mau Province) up to 600 m asl in Phu Quoc Island in Viet Nam (Tran Van Bang pers. obs).

Little is known about the feeding ecology of this species. The Indochinese Silvered Langurs in karst environment are highly folivorous. They consume parts of 53 plant species, representing 23 families. The most common food part was leaves, including 58.8% young leaves and 8.5% mature leaves, followed by fruit at 23.6%, flowers at 2.8%, buds at 5.1% and unidentified items (Le Hoang Thia et al. 2015). Group size ranges from seven to more than 50 individuals and the species exhibits a multi-male – multi-female social structure. Similar to most Asian colobines, fission-fusion is also observed (Le Hoang Thia et al. in prep.). Breeding is not seasonal but infants with orange pelage are most often seen between November and May (Hoang Minh Duc pers. obs).
threats:
Major threats to this species include habitat loss due to land use, hunting, use in traditional medicine, and collection for the pet trade.

In Cambodia, deforestation is evidently a threat in the preferred habitats of this species, including large scale conversion to plantations, small-holder farming, and potentially the construction of dams (Moody et al. 2011).

The most severe threat in Lao PDR is hunting followed by encroached and fragmented areas (Timmins et al. 2011).

In Viet Nam, habitat loss and fragmentation are considered as severe threats to the survival of the species in the Mekong delta. Particularly, limestone quarrying will destroy the habitat of half of the subpopulation in karst areas of Kien Giang Province. Hunting and habitat loss have resulted in the extirpation of the population in Mui Ca Mau National Park, and also other small, isolated populations in the Seven Mountains, Ngoc Hien and Nam Can districts of Viet Nam (Tran et al. 2017).
population:
There are no population estimates available for this species throughout its entire geographic range.

In Cambodia, it is reported to occur at low density in some areas, such as the Cardamoms (Daltry and Momberg 2000) and Botum-Sakor NP (Royan 2010), but is frequently  encountered in other areas, such as Samkos Wildlife Sanctuary (Coudrat et al. 2011) and across the Northern Plains landscape, where in some areas it is considered common suggesting that this area in particular may represent a species’ stronghold (Moody et al. 2011). In Lao PDR, it is probably localized though possibly common in a few areas; however, no large continuous area is known to support high populations (Duckworth et al. 1999). The Indochinese silvered langur is probably the rarest and most threatened monkey in Lao PDR (Timmins et al. 2011).

In Thailand the taxon is moderately common in several protected areas, but has declined significantly (W. Brockelmann pers. comm).

Trachypithecus germaini is known only from a few small isolated populations in the Mekong Delta of Viet Nam (Nadler et al. 2003). The largest confirmed population in Viet Nam is at least 223 individuals found in Kien Luong Karst Area of Kien Luong Province (Hoang Minh Duc et al. 2012b). Another potentially viable population in Viet Nam is confirmed on Phu Quoc Island with estimated 31-44 individuals (Le Khac Quyet and Nguyen Vu Khoi 2010). Some small populations have also been recorded in Bay Nui Area of An Giang Province, Tam Giang State Forest Enterprise (Hoang Minh Duc et al. 2012b) and U Minh Ha NP (Hoang Minh Duc pers. observation) in Ca Mau Province. Tran et al. (2017) found no evidence of T. germaini in Mui Ca Mau National Park and Ca Mau Province. The estimate the total population of the langur in Viet Nam to be 362–406 individuals, with the largest population found in the Kien Luong Karst Area.
range:
The precise limits of the distribution of this species are unclear. The Indochinese Silvered Langur occurs to the west of the Mekong River in Southern Lao PDR, where Duckworth et al. (1999) reported it as far north as about 15.4°N south to the tip of the Mekong Delta in Ca Mau province The southernmost record is reported (South limit of 8°50’ N) in Ca Mau Province (Hoang Minh Duc et al. 2012b). It is widely distributed throughout Cambodia west of the Mekong, from the Cardamom Mountains in the southwest, through the flooded forests of the Tonle Sap Lake, and across the Northern Plains landscape bordering Lao PDR (Moody et al. 2011). It also occurs along the Mekong River in northern Cambodia, in particular along the braided section of the Mekong between Stung Treng and Kratie Towns (Bezuijen et al. 2009). To the west, it  extends to Kanchamburi Province in southern Thailand right to the Bay of Bengal in Myanmar (Groves 2001; Nabhitabhata and Chan-ard 2005).

Tran et al. (2017) recorded the species different habitats within three provinces in the Mekong delta region, the semi-evergreen forest at the Seven Mountains of An Giang province, the mangrove forest in Ngoc Hien and Nam Can districts, Melaleuca forest in U Minh Ha National Park of Ca Mau province, the limestone forest at Kien Luong Karst Area and semi-evergreen and evergreen forests at Phu Quoc National Park of Kien Giang province.
useTrade: The species is hunted extensively for use in traditional 'medicine', and for the pet trade.
conservationActions:
This species is included in CITES Appendix II. It also occurs in some Protected Areas (noted below)

In Cambodia the species is listed as Endangered.

In Lao PDR, the species is considered At Risk and it is legally protected under the ‘Prohibited’ category of the list of threatened species, and the Wildlife and Aquatic Law (2007).

In Thailand, the Indochinese Silvered Langur is listed as Near Threatened under the name Semnopithecus germaini (Nabhitabhata and Chan-ard 2005).

In Viet Nam, the species is legally protected under Appendix 1B of Decree 32 (2006) and Appendix I of Decree 160 (2013) under the name of Trachypithecus villosus.

Within its range, this species has been recorded in several protected areas:

  • Cambodia: Tonle Sap Biosphere Reserve, Kirirom, Botum-Sakor, and Phnom Kulen NPs, Phnom Samkos and Kulen Promtep WSs, Central Cardamoms, Southern Cardamoms and Preah Vihear PFs.
  • Laos PDR: several records have been reported in Dong Khanthung Proposed National Biological Conservation Area.
  • Thailand: the species also occurs in several protected areas in Thailand (Nabhitabhata and Chan-ard 2005).
  • Viet Nam: it has been recorded in U Minh Ha and Phu Quoc NPs, Hon Chong Special Use and Protected Forest and Bay Nui Proposed NP.

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable as the number of mature individuals is less than 10,000 across some severely fragmented locations, with continuing decline in habitat quality, area and suspected decline in mature individuals due to degrading habitat quality and instances of poaching, with no subpopulation containing more than 1,000 mature individuals.
habitat: This species is found in evergreen, semi­evergreen, moist deciduous forests, montane evergreen forests and in riparian forests in lower altitudes in some places (e.g. Megamalai and Anamalai) (Kurup 1979, Singh et al. 1997, Kumara et al. 2011). It ranges from 300 to 2,000 m in elevation (Molur et al. 2003). It is folivorous, but will also eat flowers, buds, seeds, bark, stems, insects, and earth (Roonwal and Mohnot 1977, Poirier 1969, Oates et al. 1979); it has been reported to be a facultative frugivore (Sushma and Singh 2006). The species has also been reported to forage for cultivated cabbage, potatoes, and cauliflower and ornamental garden poppies (Poirier 1969). It is an arboreal and diurnal species, and typically occurs in uni­male groups (Molur et al. 2003), usually with nine or ten animals in a group.
threats: This species was hunted for traditional “medicine” (Roonwal and Mohnot 1977), but this has decreased in recent years due to better protection and NGO activities through community participation (A. Kumar and M. Singh pers. comm). Present threats include limited habitat loss due to crop plantations, mining, dams, fragmentation, human settlement, hunting, road kills, deliberate fires, storms/flooding and landslides.
population:
Molur et al. (2003) estimate a total population of less than 20,000 (<10,000 mature) individuals, based on studies in a few areas (Karnataka, M. Singh pers. comm.; Kerala, S. Ram ongoing study; Tamil Nadu, M. Singh and A. Kumar pers. comm.) and extrapolated to the rest of its distribution. After the introduction of the Indian Wildlife Protection Act in 1972, the population has increased (Kurup 1979), and this trend was seen until the early 1990s. The population since then was relatively stable, but in the last decade there are some declines suspected (A. Kumar and M. Singh pers. comm).

Relative abundance as recorded in the High-wavys 0.56±3.06 and primarily occupied high altitudinal and mid-altitude regions, with higher encounter rates in high altitudes (0.83±1.51) than mid-altitudes (0.18±0.72) (Srinivas et al, 2013). Densities of 70 ind/km² when not hunted.
range: This species occurs only in the Western Ghats in southwestern India (Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu). It is found, rather unevenly, in the hill country of the Western Ghats from the Aramboli Pass (at 8°16’N near the southern tip of India) north to Srimangala (12°01’N, 75°58’E) (Groves 2001, Kumara and Singh 2004).
useTrade: The species is hunted in some locations for food and in some other locations to make artifacts and jewelry. It is occasionally kept as a pet.
conservationActions:
The species is listed on CITES Appendix II, and Schedule I, Part I of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972 amended up to 2002 (Molur et al. 2003).

This species is known to occur in numerous protected areas, including: Aaralam Sanctuary, Brahmagiri Sanctuary, Chimmony Sanctuary, Chinnar Sanctuary, Eravikulam National Park, Grizzled Giant Squirrel Sanctuary, Idukki Sanctuary, Indira Gandhi Sanctuary, Kalakkad Sanctuary, Mudumalai Sanctuary, Mukurthi National Park, Mundanthurai Sanctuary, Neyyar Sanctuary, Parambikulam Sanctuary, Peechi Sanctuary, Peppara Sanctuary, Periyar National Park, Periyar Sanctuary, Shendurney Sanctuary, Silent Valley National Park, Thattekadu Sanctuary, Wayanad Sanctuary (Molur et al. 2003).

The following are recommended areas of research: taxonomy, life history, survey studies, and ecology. The following are recommended management actions: habitat management, monitoring, public education, poaching control measures, Population and Habitat Viability Assessment, and prevention of conversion of forest areas to private lands, prevention of conversion of natural private forests, coffee and cardamom plantations into tea plantations (Molur et al. 2003; M. Singh pers. comm.).

rationale: Delacour's Langur is listed as Critically Endangered because the population has declined by more than 80% in the last three generations (36 years) due to increasing hunting for medicine and fragmentation from habitat loss, and is continuing to decline at the same rate. Presently, its population size is estimated to number fewer than 250 mature individuals with a continuing decline.
habitat:
This species is presently restricted to limestone karst forest habitat with broadleaf evergreen forests, but with some records from secondary forest in limestone areas as well (Nadler 1996, 2004, 2015; Rowe 1996).

They prefer the karst habitat for several reasons, one being the bowl-like surface of karst habitats that retain rain water. They thrive in such habitats where caves and crevices offer warm shelter during cold winters. They mostly occur in lower elevations of ca 500 m up to 1,000 m asl in Pu Luong Nature Reserve.

Leaves make up most of the diet (80%) therefore they are primarily folivorous, of which 60% constitutes young leaves and 20% mature leaves. They do not eat insects and the leaves those are preferred contain a high protein to fibre ratio (Workman 2010a, 2010b; Workman and Le Van Dung 2009).

Sexual maturity in male Delacours ca 5 years and females at 4 years. Gestation of 180-196 days. Females typically bear single offspring. Home range of 20-50 ha. Unimale-multifemale type social organization and sometimes, two males are present in the group. In such cases the males are relatives (either father-son or brothers). Typical group size is 10 but the largest group observed is 17 individuals. Bachelor groups of up to four individuals also exist. Inter-group aggression is common and home ranges of groups overlap.
threats: <span class="None">Hunting for the purposes of traditional "medicine" is the primary threat facing this species; most of the populations that survive are heavily reduced and fragmented. Only the subpopulation at Van Long, is thought likely to survive given the current hunting pressure; however, quarrying for limestone (cement), which is currently taking place there, has affected the ranging behavior of the animals (Nadler 2004, 2014). The smallest populations are extremely unlikely to survive should the one reproductively active male be taken or killed (Nadler 2004). Forest loss is a more minor threat as the species occurs in degraded areas. A potential threat is the rapid development of tourist facilities adjacent to protected areas.
population:
Surveys carried out between 1990 and 2000 resulted in the discovery of 19 subpopulations in a restricted area of northern Viet Nam. Taken from these surveys the total of all populations was estimated at 49-53 groups and 270-302 individuals. In three areas where Delacour’s langur occurred in the past the species was already eradicated by the 1990s, following information provided by local people (Nadler et al. 2003). About half of all discovered populations (10) occurred in unprotected areas. The protection level in protected areas is mostly low, but still under control of the Forest Protection Department. In unprotected areas there is no control over hunting, and the animals are under high pressure.

With additional surveys in the first decade of the 21st century the total number of recorded individuals increased slightly. The number of groups is 50-57 and the number of individuals 281-317. The increased total number of langurs resulted in the development of the population in Van Long Nature Reserve, the area under special protection through the Vietnam Primate Conservation Program of Frankfurt Zoological Society, which included additional education and awareness programs for the surrounding communes of the area. The distribution of animals within subpopulations during this period indicates a reduction in the occurrence of larger populations compared to the previous decade (Nadler 2004; 2015). During this decade a number of small populations were eradicated. The exact years of extirpation cannot be verified. The information is based on interview surveys of local villagers, who indicated that the last sighting or record of the species was often several years ago. Therefore, these small populations are believed to be eradicated.

Surveys were carried out between 2012 and 2015 by the Endangered Primate Rescue Center and Forestry University Hanoi to verify the current situation of the species. The results of the surveys in all known subpopulations shows a dramatic decline compared to the last decade. The total number is estimated at 234-275 individuals. The majority occurs in Van Long Nature Reserve and if the population of the nature reserve is combined with the adjacent planned extension area to count as one population, the total for the area is 164-191 individuals. The remaining 70-84 individuals occur in the additional seven areas. Not one of these populations has a size which can guarantee a secure future, even if hunting could be eliminated. The problem of inbreeding for these small populations is not relevant. Before the inbreeding coefficient increases over a certain level, the populations will be extinct through other pressures.

The results of the surveys clearly illustrate the dire situation for the species and the extreme value of Van Long Nature Reserve as the last and only refuge for the survival of the species.
range: This species is endemic to Viet Nam and occurs in a very restricted area of north-central Viet Nam that totals about 5,000 km². The distribution of subpopulations and smaller social groups is closely related to the series of limestone mountain ranges in the provinces of Ninh Binh, Nam Ha, Hoa Binh, and Thanh Hoa (Nadler et al. 2003, 2004, 2015; Nadler and Brockman 2014). The area of occupancy (AOO) for this species prior to 2000 was only about 400 km² but with eradication of several populations the AOO is currently smaller than 300 km² (Nadler 2015).
useTrade: The species is hunted primarily for the purposes of traditional "medicine", but also for food and occasionally for the pet trade.
conservationActions:
This species is currently listed in CITES Appendix II. It is considered 'critically endangered' in Viet Nam, and is listed under the highest protection level in Decree 32/2006, and as species for special conservation considerations in Decree 160/2013. It occurs in six protected areas. Van Long Nature Reserve was established for conservation of this species in 2001, and there has been evidence of population growth in this reserve in the past 15 years.

The primary focus of conservation activities for the species should be the protection of all remaining populations. But this is far from the reality. The protection of areas without current protection status - which are three areas - is not feasible. To apply for a protection status and establish strong protection for an area is not a viable option for such extremely small populations with little chance of ever developing into viable populations. These populations will be eradicated and disappear in the near future. The most efficient option to stabilize the largest existing population in Van Long Nature reserve and to save sufficient habitat for the long-term existence of a viable population would be the extension of the reserve.

Translocation of isolated groups of animals or small populations from areas under pressure or for improving the genetic pool of a larger population is undoubtedly an important conservation tool for many species. The most critical point is the method with which to catch the animals in the areas which are often very difficult to access.
