rationale: Listed as Least Concern as the species is widespread and common, present in a number of protected areas throughout the range, and there are no major threats.
habitat:
Demidoff's Dwarf Galago mainly occurs in primary and secondary tropical moist forests, but is also present in savanna woodlands, riverine, deciduous, littoral and gallery forests (Ambrose & Butynski 2013, Bersacola et al. 2015). This species is commonly associated with the understorey of secondary forest and forest edges, such as road sides, beside water courses and tree-fall zones (Ambrose & Butynski 2013). It prefers vegetation below 5 m, particularly dense undergrowth with fine branches (±1 cm) where it scurries, rather than leaping (Ambrose & Butynski 2013; Bersacola et al. 2015). It sleeps in small groups of up to 10 individuals, huddling in dense vegetation or in rounded leaf nests (Bearder et al. 2003). This galago has an insectivore-frugivore diet, consisting mainly of invertebrates (such as beetles and moths) and snails, but also fruits, gum, leaves and buds (Nekaris 2013). It gives birth to one or two young per year.

The vocal profile is available on: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/vocal-profiles/galagoides/demidovii/
threats: This species is locally threatened by habitat loss through deforestation for timber and conversion to agricultural land.
population: This species is common and widespread. Encounter rates range from 0.3 animals/km in semi-arid savanna woodland in western Angola, and 0.6 animals/km on Bioko Island (Croce 2009), to 6.8 animals/km in the northern part of the Angolan Escarpment (Bersacola et al. 2015).
range: This species has been recorded from southern Senegal and Guinea-Bissau in the west, through the Guinean forests of West Africa and into the Congo Basin. In the east it ranges as far as the River Nile north of Lake Victoria in Uganda and southwards along the Albertine Rift region, including northern Tanzania. In the south, it is found in the Cuanza Sul province of Angola, and possibly as far south as the Lukuga River (DRC) in the east. Widely sympatric with G. thomasi, but G. demidoff is thought to be absent from the Dahomey Gap: Ghana, Togo and Benin (Dowsett-Lemaire & Dowsett 2011).
conservationActions: Galago demidoff is listed on Appendix II of CITES. It occurs in several protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern. Paragalago granti is widespread over southeastern Africa and locally common. There is no indication that P. granti is currently undergoing a significant range-wide decline.
habitat:
Paragalago granti is a nocturnal and arboreal species that occupies dry coastal forest, gallery forest, lowland evergreen and semi-evergreen forest and species-rich woodlands, including hilly miombo woodlands (e.g., Mahenge foothills) (Butynski et al. 2006, Honess et al. 2013). In ‘sand forest’ and dense woodland in northeastern South Africa (Génin et al. 2015, Yokwana et al. 2015).

This species uses tree holes and is presumed to give birth to one or two young per year. Twinning appears to be common in South Africa (Génin et al. 2015).
Paragalago granti is omnivorous, eating invertebrates, fruits, gums, flowers, and occasionally small birds (Honess 1996b, Lumsden and Masters 2001, Honess et al. 2013, Génin et al. 2015).

A vocal profile of P. granti is available at: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/vocal-profiles/galagoides/mozambique-dwarf-galago-galagoides-granti/
threats: Paragalago granti is able to survive in habitats marginally affected by humans (Honess et al. 2013, Génin et al. 2015). There appear to be no major threats resulting in a range-wide population decline. Local declines are taking place due to habitat loss from clear-cutting and intensive agriculture related to fast-growing human populations.
population: Paragalago granti is locally common and abundant in evergreen and semi-evergreen forest and thicket, although its optimal habitat remains unknown (Honess et al. 2013, Génin et al. 2015). In southern Tanzania, most common in Namatimbili, Mtopwa, Ruawa, Ndimba, Matumbi Hills, Noto, Chitoa Forest and Rondo Nature Reserve (Honess 1996b, A. Perkin pers. obs. 2016). Is a common and widespread species.
range: Paragalago granti occurs from the Kilombero-Rufiji River and Udzungwa Mountains of southeastern Tanzania, southwards through eastern Mozambique, southern Malawi, and eastern Zimbabwe to Tshanini Nature Reserve in extreme northeastern South Africa (Smithers and Lobão Tello 1976, Smithers 1983, Jenkins 1987, Honess 1996b, Wallace 2005, Butynski et al. 2006, Bearder and Karlsson 2009, Perkin et al. 2011, Honess et al. 2013, Génin et al. 2015, Yokwana et al. 2015). Foley et al. (2014) report presence in Mahale National Park and Sitebe Mountains in southeastern Tanzania, but validation is required (Butynski et al. 2006). Validation also needed for a record from Mount Namuli in Mozambique. Recorded to at least 1,800 m asl (Butynski et al. 2006).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES. It is present in the East Ngorima Reserve and Chimanimani National Park of Zimbabwe.

rationale: Paragalago zanzibaricus is endemic to Tanzania. This species is currently listed as Near Threatened. Although the taxon is declining and the population is severely fragmented (leading to population declines), currently the extent of occurrence (EOO) and area of occupancy (AOO) for this species are much larger than the criterion B thresholds. However, with a severely fragmented distribution and ongoing rapid loss of Eastern Arc coastal forest habitat, it is feasible that the EOO and AOO could rapidly decline towards the Vulnerable thresholds for criterion B. If declines continue for this species, it is likely that it will move into a threatened category in the near future.
habitat:
This species occurs in riverine forest, coastal thicket, and mid-to-high canopy of lowland and submontane forest. Appears to prefer secondary forest. Presumed to give birth to one or two young per year. Ecology and behaviour reviewed in Honess et al. (2013).

Vocal profile for P. zanzibaricus is available at: http://wildsolutions.artexion.nl/vocal-profiles/galagoides/zanzibaricusruvu/, and a photographic map is available at: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/photomaps/galagoides/.
threats: The main threat to this species is degradation, loss, and fragmentation of its forest habitat through conversion to agricultural land (both subsistence and commercial), tree plantations, timber extraction, collection of fuelwood and building poles, and charcoal manufacture.
population:
Paragalago zanzibaricus is the most abundant and widespread galago in the coastal forests of Tanzania. Density varies greatly from site to site. In the Udzungwa Mtns. (for example, Matundu Forest Reserve), P. z. udzungwensis is estimated at >500 individuals/km², whereas <100 individuals/km² occur at many other sites (Butynski et al. 2006).

Although P. z. zanzibaricus is confined to Unguja Island, it is widespread over the southern part of the Island where it  is common in some places (e.g., 200 individuals/km² in Jozani–Chwaka Bay National Park (Butynski et al. 2006). 

About 30-50 individuals/km² in Mlola Forest Reserve, Mafia Island (A. Perkin pers. obs. 2008).

Populations are suspected to be in decline.
range:
Paragalago zanzibaricus is endemic to Tanzania.

Paragalago z. zanzibaricus is endemic to Unguja (Zanzibar) Island, Tanzania. This subspecies probably once occurred throughout the Island. The current geographic range is mainly in the southern half of Unguja, with small populations in the north (Kiwenga Forest Reserve), west (Masingini Forest Reserve), and on Uzi Island off the southwest coast (Nowak et al. 2006, 2009, Honess et al. 2013).

Paragalago z. udzungwensis is endemic to mainland Tanzania. Geographic distribution is from the South Pare Mtns. and East Usambara Mtns. south to the Rufiji R. and west to the Kihansi R. in the Udzungwa Mtns. (Butynski et al. 1998, 2006, Honess et al. 2013).

A population in Mlola Forest Reserve, Mafia Island, has not be identified to subspecies level (A. Perkin pers. obs. 2008).

Broadly sympatric with Otolemur garnettii and narrowly sympatric with Otolemur crassicaudatus and P. orinus. Parapatric to the south with P. granti, meeting at the Rufiji R. and P. cocos to the north of the East Usambara Mtns. on the coastal strip of northeastern Tanzania just south of the Kenya-Tanzania border.
useTrade: This species is not hunted.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES. Occurs in several protected areas, including Jozani-Chwaka Bay National Park, Udzungwa Mountains National Park, Saadani National Park, Nyerere National Park (formed from the former Selous Game Reserve), and Amani Nature Reserve, as well as several forest reserves.  Better information is needed on the geographic distribution, abundance, and ecology of this species. The subspecies on Mafia Island needs to be determined.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern as the species is widespread and relatively common, and there are no major threats believed to be resulting in a major range-wide decline.
habitat:
G. thomasi are found in savanna and open woodland areas (e.g. Miombo), littoral and riparian forests, marshland, and at the margins of montane forest from at sea level up to 2,690 m above sea level. This species also occupies farmland and plantations (Ambrose & Butynski 2013), but avoids areas of grassland. They have been found in forests where no other galagos are present. G. thomasi are found in all strata although when sympatric with G. demidoff they tend to occupy the upper strata (10-20 m above ground; Bearder et al. 2003). G. thomasi tends to use broader support and leaps more frequently than G. demidoff. They build nests in thorn trees or nest in dense tangles of vegetation (Bearder et al. 2003, Kingdon 2015). Group size is normally 1-5, although in Uganda groups of up to 12 individuals were observed to nest together (Ambrose & Butynski 2013). They forage separately at night. Their diet consists mainly of insects, but also gum, fruits and seeds. This species gives birth to one or two young annually and births take place throughout the year (Ambrose & Butynski 2013).

The vocal profile of G. thomasi is available on: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/vocal-profiles/galagoides/thomass-dwarf-galago-galagoides-thomasi/
threats: This species is locally threatened by habitat loss through deforestation for timber and conversion to agricultural land, but there are no major threats to the species as a whole.
population: This is a widespread, adaptable and often common species. Highest densities have been observed in old secondary and mountain forests. No density estimates are available but encounter rates range from 0.2 animals/hr on Bioko Island (Ambrose & Perkin 2000) to 3 animals/hr in Okomu National Park, Nigeria (Bearder & Oates 2009).
range: Galagoides thomasi is found in West and Central Africa, although the distribution limits are uncertain. Animals currently assigned to this species have been recorded as museum specimens or in the wild from Senegal, Côte d'Ivoire, Nigeria, Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea (Bioko), Gabon, Ghana, Togo, Benin, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Republic of Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, Uganda, Rwanda, Tanzania, Kenya and Zambia. The species may also occur in Angola, Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Central African Republic, Burundi and South Sudan, but this remains to be confirmed.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES. It occurs in several protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern, Paragalago cocos is fairly widespread, locally abundant, and able to persist in secondary and/or highly fragmented vegetation. Although it is affected by habitat loss in some parts of its geographic range, there are no major threats to the species.
habitat:
Paragalago cocos typically occupies the middle storey of dry, mixed, coastal lowland moist forest, riverine forest and secondary growth such as cultivated mosaic habitat (Bearder et al. 2003, Butynski et al. 2006, Harcourt and Perkin 2013). It has been found in Acacia woodland in some places where Galago senegalensis is absent (e.g. Bodhei on the north coast of Kenya; de Jong and Butynski 2011). G. cocos is also present in mixed cultivation, which includes coconut palm (Cocos nucifera), mango (Mangifera indica), cashew nut (Anacardium occi), and neem (Azadirachta indica). G. cocos sleeps in tree holes (de Jong and Butynski 2011; Harcourt and Perkin 2013). Paragalago cocos is omnivorous, feeding on both invertebrates and fruit. Females give birth to singletons (rarely twins) twice a year (Harcourt and Perkin 2013).

Paragalago cocos is sympatric with Galago senegalensis and Otolemur garnettii, and is parapatric with G. z. udzungwensis or, perhaps, narrowly sympatric at a few sites on coastal north Tanzania. It is also probably parapatric with Galago gallarum near the coast in southeast Kenya (Butynski and de Jong 2004, Butynski et al. 2006).
The vocal profile of P. cocos is available at: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/vocal-profiles/galagoides/cocos/ and a photographic map at: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/photography/photomap/
threats: Paragalago cocos is locally threatened over much of its range by conversion of habitat to farm land, including plantations of pineapple and sisal. Persist in high density, however, in secondary growth, gardens and farms where a good tree cover occurs (Harcourt and Perkin 2013).
population: Paragalago cocos is the most abundant and widespread galago in the coastal forests of Kenya. Densities of ca 170–180 individuals/km² have been reported at both Gedi and Diani, Kenya (Harcourt and Nash 1986).
range: Paragalago cocos is endemic to the coastal region of Kenya and northern Tanzania (Butynski et al. 2006). From the north coast of Kenya to the northern coast of Tanzania (Mgambo Forest Reserve and Kilulu Hill Forest Reserve). Paragalago cocos might occur on the south coast of Somalia as far north as the Juba River or Shabeelle River (Butynski et al. 2006). A locality record from Nairobi (see Butynski et al. 2006, Harcourt and Perkin 2013) appears unfounded (T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2014). At altitudes from sea level to at least 210 m asl on coastal of Kenya, and to at least 350 m asl in the foothills of the East Usambara Mountains, Tanzania (Butynski et al. 2006).
conservationActions: Paragalago cocos is listed on Appendix II of CITES. It is present in the Arabuko-Sokoke National Park, Shimba Hills National Reserve, Tana River Primate National Reserve, Kipini Conservancy, Dodori National Reserve and probably Boni National Reserve, Kenya (Butynski et al. 2006, de Jong and Butynski 2011, Y. de Jong and T. Butynski pers. obs. 2011). There is a need to better determine the geographic range, especially in Somalia (Butynski et al. 2006).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern. Widespread species which is sometimes locally common. There are no major threats that would lead to a significant range-wide population decline.
habitat:
Galago gallarum is a nocturnal, arboreal species which lives in semi-arid thorn scrub and thorn scrub/woodlands. Occupies all strata within Acacia-Commiphora deciduous bushland and thicket (Butynski and de Jong 2004, 2013). Occupies woodland (including Acacia spp, Newtonia hildebrandtii, Melia volkensii) bordering swamp and Acacia-Commiphora bushland. Survives in severely degraded habitats (de Jong and Butynski 2010). Lives in drier and thornier habitats than any other African primate (Butynski and de Jong 2004, 2013). 

G. gallarum is either solitary or exists in small groups. There is no information on reproduction, but it is likely that a single infant is born.

G. gallarum produces a distinctive loud ‘quack’ call (Butynski and de Jong 2004). Their vocal profile can be found at: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/vocal-profiles/galago/gallarum/ and photographs at: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/photography/
threats: A number of subpopulations throughout the range may be threatened by habitat degradation, fragmentation and loss. However, the semi-arid areas these galagos occupy are of little value for crop production. Present in over-grazed and over-browsed, degraded habitats (Butynski and de Jong 2004, 2013).
population: Galago gallarum is patchily distributed and locally common. Absent from large areas of unsuitable habitat throughout its range. Density over much of the range is <1 animal/ha, but much higher at some sites (e.g., >4 animals/ha in Meru National Park; Butynski and de Jong 2004).
range:
Galago gallarum is endemic to the semi-arid thorn scrub and thorn scrub/woodlands of central and eastern Kenya, southern Somalia, and extreme south and extreme central east Ethiopia (Butynski and de Jong 2004, 2013). Distribution may extend into southeast Sudan but no records as yet. Present between the Webi Shebeli River Valley, Somalia, in the northeast and Tana River, Kenya, in the southwest. Towards Lake Turkana (at least as far west as South Horr) in Kenya and the Rift Valley in Ethiopia in the northwest. Not known to occur west of the Eastern Rift Valley. Distribution limits in the Ogaden area, south Ethiopia, and east and north of the Webi Shebeli River not known. Found in oases dominated by acacia and doum palm Hyphaene thebaica in the southeast Chalbi Desert, northern Kenya. Found from sea level to 1,250 m asl (Butynski and de Jong 2013).

Narrowly sympatric with Galago senegalensis in Meru National Park, Kenya (Butynski and de Jong 2004) and near the Ndoto Mountains, Samburu County, Kenya (T. Butynski and Y. de Jong unpubl. data).
conservationActions: Galago gallarum is listed on Appendix II of CITES. In Kenya, present in Meru National Park, Shaba National Reserve, Arawale National Reserve and Dodori National Reserve (Butynski and de Jong 2004; de Jong and Butynski 2011). Further studies on the biogeography, taxonomy and ecology of this species are needed.

rationale: Galago moholi is listed as Least Concern as the species is widespread and common, and indeed expanding its range in some areas. There are no major threats, and the species occurs in many protected areas throughout its range.
habitat: This species is found in all strata in savanna woodland (being particularly associated with Acacia spp, which are a source of gum and invertebrates) (Bearder et al. 2003, Pullen & Bearder, 2013). It is also found in miombo woodland and mopane woodland and riverine gallery forest. Acacia and mopane trees provide holes for resting and breeding sites (Bearder et al. 2003). G. moholi commonly sleep on leafy platform nests and tree forks protected by thorns (Bearder et al. 2003). They are independent of water, obtaining their moisture requirements from food (S.K. Bearder pers. obs. 1975-1977). They rest in groups of 2-7, but disperse to forage alone although regularly meeting others (Bearder et al. 2003). This species gives birth to twins twice per year (Bearder et al. 2003).
threats: There are no major threats. The range of the species is expanding in some parts, particularly in the south (e.g., in Gauteng, South Africa, where previously known). Arable farming is giving way to game ranching and regeneration of natural vegetation. Galago moholi is recorded in small numbers in the bushmeat trade in Zimbabwe (Svensson et al. 2015) and traded for traditional practices in Zambia (Baskind & Birbeck 2005, Alves et al. 2010), as well as in the pet trade throughout southern Africa (Svensson et al. 2015).
population: This is a common and widespread species. Found in highest densities in association with Acacia karroo.
range:
Galago moholi has a wide distribution, ranging from northern Namibia and Angola, eastwards through south-eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Zambia, Zimbabwe and northern Botswana to eastern Mozambique and the northern and north-eastern parts of South Africa. The northern limits of the distribution range of this species are not well defined; it appears to be absent from Swaziland, Malawi, northern Mozambique, Tanzania, Burundi and Rwanda. Reports of presence in four countries are in need of confirmation; Rwanda, Burundi (de Jong & Butynski 2012), Malawi (S.K. Bearder pers. obs. 2009), and Swaziland (J. Culverwell, pers. comm. to T. Butynski 2012).

The subspecies are disputed. The two most recently recognised subspecies are G. m. moholi, which ranges from the eastern part of the species’ distribution to south-eastern Botswana, and Zambia. This subspecies intergrades with G. m. bradfieldi in the Western Province of Zambia. Galago m. bradfieldi occupies the western part of the species’ range. Recorded from the Waterberg, northern Namibia, northwards into central south Angola, and eastwards through southern DRC and northern Botswana (Makgadikgadi Pans) and Western Province of Zambia (Meester et al. 1986, Pullen & Bearder 2013).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES. Occurs in a number of protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: Galago matschiei is listed as Least Concern. The species is widespread, in some areas common, and present in several well protected sites. The geographic range is declining. This is mainly due to habit degradation, fragmentation and loss caused by rapidly expanding human populations. Overall, however, this species is not threatened range-wide.
habitat:
Galago matschiei is an arboreal, nocturnal primate which occupies all strata within both primary and secondary lowland, mid-altitude, montane and bamboo forest; especially where Parinari excelsa is the dominant tree (Kingdon 2015, Ambrose 2006, Butynski and de Jong 2013).

G. matschiei is omnivorous. They presumably feed on insects, fruits, flowers and gums. Their diet, however, is poorly known (Kingdon 2015, Ambrose 2006, Butynski and de Jong 2013).

G. matschiei produces a distinctive loud call called ‘churr’ (Zimmerman 1990, Bearder et al. 1995, Ambrose 2002, 2006). Their vocal profile can be found at http://www.wildsolutions.nl/vocal-profiles/galago/matschiei/ and a photographic map at http://www.wildsolutions.nl/photography/
threats: Galago matschiei is locally threatened by deforestation, degradation and fragmentation mainly due to a fast growing human population in their geographical range, the conversion of forest into agricultural land and pasture, and the expansion of human settlements (Butynski and de Jong 2013).
population: Galago matschiei is relatively common in some sites, such as Kibale National Park, Bwindi Impenetrable National Park, Zika Forest Reserve and Mpanga Forest Reserve (Ambrose 2002, 2006; Butynski & de Jong 2013). Encounter rates in Uganda vary between 0.08 and 1.71 individuals/hour and 0.00 to 0.57 calls per hour (Ambrose 2002, 2006).
range: Galago matschiei is found primarily in the forests of the Albertine Rift. Out-lying populations occur north of Lake Victoria and in the Bondo-Bili area of DR Congo. In forests from near Lake Albert (including Budongo), southwards along the flanks of the Albertine Rift to the southern end of the Itombwe Massif, DRC (Omari et al. 1999, Butynski and de Jong 2013). There is a narrow eastward range extension to just west of the Nile River, where in forest such as Mabira and Mpanga (Ambrose 2002). There is also a record from Moroto in northeast Uganda (Nash et al. 1989).  Galago matschiei occurs at 670–2,500 m asl (Dowsett and Dowsett-Lemaire 1990, Butynski and de Jong 2013).
conservationActions: Galago matschiei is listed on Appendix II of CITES. It lives in a number of protected areas, including Bwindi Impenetrable National Park (Uganda), Kibale National Park, and several forest reserves in southwest Uganda, Kahuzi-Biega National Park in DRC, Nyungwe National Park in Rwanda, and Kibira Natinal Park in Burundi. Additional surveys on population numbers and range are required, and taxonomic work is needed to elucidate the status of the Itombwe population.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern, the Northern Lesser Galago is widespread and locally abundant. Although it is affected by habitat loss in some parts of its geographical range there are no major range-wide threats to the species.
habitat:
Galago senegalensis is found in savanna woodland (e.g. miombo), in dense to open bushland, (e.g. Laikipia Plateau, Tsavo Region, Kenya), in montane forest (e.g. Mau Forest, Kenya, Otzi Mountains and Agoro-Agu Forest Reserve in the Imatong Mountains, northern Uganda, Harenna Forest, Ethiopia), riverine woodland (Tana River Primate National Reserve, coastal Kenya), and in secondary and/or highly fragmented forest and woodland, including cultivated areas [e.g. Isiolo, central Kenya (T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016) and Jinack Island, The Gambia (Svensson and Bearder 2013)]. G. senegalensis avoids areas of grassland, and is sometimes found in close-canopy montane forest when no other species of galago is present (e.g. Mau Forest Complex, Kenya), otherwise, it is not a forest species (Nash et al. 2013). 

In woodlands and riverine forest at low altitude, Galago senegalensis is sometimes sympatric with Paragalago cocos, Otolemur garnettii and O. crassicaudatus, and narrowly sympatric with Galago gallarum (e.g., lower Tana River forest) and, perhaps, Galago moholi and Perodicticus potto (Butynski and de Jong 2004, T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016). 

Galago senegalensis occurs from sea level to 2,400 m asl (G. s. senegalensis, Mau Forest Complex, Kenya; T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016). 

Galago senegalensis is nocturnal, arboreal and omnivorous. It feeds mainly on gum, invertebrates and fruit (Nash et al. 2013), and builds nests in dense thorn trees or in tree holes (Bearder et al. 2003, Nash et al. 2013, Svensson and Bearder 2013, T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016). Group size is 2–5, although they forage separately. They are presumed to give birth to one or two young annually (Nash 1983).

Vocal profile of G. senegalensis is available at: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/vocal-profiles/galago/senegalensis/ and a photographic map at: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/photography/photomap/.
threats: Galago senegalensis is able to survive in habitats marginally affected by humans and near human settlements. There are no major threats resulting in a range-wide population decline. Local declines are taking place due to habitat loss from clear-cutting and intensive agriculture related to fast-growing human populations in its geographic range.
population:
Galago senegalensis is locally common throughout its range. Typically G. s. braccatus exists in densities <1 individual/ha in scrubby habitats and in closed canopy forest at higher altitudes (T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016). Higher densities (2.4 individuals/ha) occur in yellow fever tree (Acacia xanthophloea) woodland (Off et al. 2008, T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016). On the Laikipia Plateau, central Kenya, can reach 300–500 individuals/km² in whistling thorn (Acacia drepanolobium) and yellow fever tree woodland (Y. de Jong and T. Butynski pers. obs. 2016).

Encounter rates have been recorded as 0.1 individuals/km (1.0 individuals/h) by vehicle in Ol Pejeta Conservancy, Laikipia Plateau (1,800–1,900 m asl), 1.1 individuals/h by foot in Makindu (960 m asl), 1.2 individuals/km (1.4 individuals/h) by foot in Kajiado, south Kenya (1,500 m asl), and 1.1 individuals/km (3.4 indiduals/h) by vehicle in Kora National Park, central Kenya (500 m asl) (Y. de Jong and T. Butynski pers. obs. 2016)

In Tanzania, encounter rates with G. s. braccatus were 0.1 individuals/km (2.4 individuals/h) by vehicle in Tanga (10 m asl), 0.9 individuals/h by foot in Meia Meia (1,330 m asl), 4.1 individuals/km (3.5 individuals/h) by foot near Mikumi National Park (470 m asl), and 4.0 individuals/h by foot at Mto wa Mbu, Lake Manyara National Park (970 m asl; T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2008).

Galago s. sotikae encountered at the rate of 2.5 individuals/km (7.1 individuals/h; 1,480 m) in Grumeti Game Reserve, western Serengeti, Tanzania, 0.9 individuals/hr by foot in Meia Meia (1,330 m asl), 4.1 individuals/km (3.5 individuals/h) by foot near Mikumi National Park (470 m asl), and 4.0 individuals/h by foot at Mto wa Mbu, Lake Manyara National Park, Tanzania (970 m asl; T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016).
range:
Galago senegalensis is endemic to tropical Africa and has a large geographical range. It occurs from Senegal in the west to Sudan, Ethiopia, Somalia in the east, southwards through Kenya to south Tanzania. The limits of the distribution remain poorly understood. It is sympatric with Galago gallarum in central Kenya (e.g., Meru National Park), and potentially sympatric with with Galago moholi in Tanzania.

Four subspecies are recognised (Grubb et al. 2003, Nash et al. 2013):

Galago s. senegalensis (Senegal Lesser Galago). Ranges from Senegal and the Gambia in the west through to Sudan, Uganda (including Otzi Mountains, Imatong Mountains, and Kidepo Valley National Park) into western Kenya (west of the Great Rift Valley). Sites include Mt. Elgon National Park, Saiwa Swamp National Park, Mau Forest Complex and Cherangani Hills (Nash et al. 2013; de Jong and Butynski 2014a,b; Butynski and de Jong in press).

Galago s. braccatus (Kenya Lesser Galago). Known from a number of districts in Kenya (east of the Eastern Rift Valley, including the Central Highlands, coastal forests, Nairobi, Meru – Kora Region and Tsavo Region), southwards to northeast and north-central Tanzania (Nash et al. 2013, Butynski and de Jong 2004, de Jong and Butynski 2009). The southern and northern extent of the range is poorly understood.

Galago s. dunni (Ethiopia Lesser Galago). Somalia and the Ogaden region of Ethiopia. Limits of range unknown (Nash et al. 2013).

Galago s. sotikae (Uganda Lesser Galago). Ankole (south Uganda) to Mwanza (south of Lake Victoria, Tanzania) to the Telek River (Mara Ecosystem, southern Kenya), southwards to northern and central Tanzania (including Lake Manyara National Park, Mikumi National Park, Serengeti-Grumeti Region, north of Dodoma, Selous Game Reserve; Nash et al. 2013, T. Butynski, Y. de Jong and A. Perkin pers. obs. 2016). The southern limit of G. s. sotikae is probably in far southern Tanzania near Lake Rukwa (A. Perkin pers. obs. 2016).
conservationActions: Galago senegalensis is listed on Appendix II of CITES. Occurs in a large number of protected areas throughout the range including Tsavo West National Park, Tsavo East National Park, Mt. Kenya National Park, Meru National Park, Kora National Park, Samburu National Reserve, Shaba National Reserve, Buffalo Springs National Reserve in Kenya. In Tanzania, in Grumeti Game Reserve, Serengeti National Park, Lake Manyara National Park, Tarangire National Park and Mikumi National Park (T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016). In Uganda, in Kidepo Valley National Park, Otzi Forest Reserve, Agoro-Agu National Reserve (Butynski and de Jong 2014). In the Gambia, in Niumi National Park (Svensson and Bearder 2013).

rationale: Otolemur crassicaudatus is listed as Least Concern as the species is relatively widespread and common, present in a number of well-managed protected areas, and there are no major threats, other than bushmeat hunting. Population monitoring is recommended, because fragmentation is increasing dramatically among forests along the east coast of South Africa owing to expansion of sugar cane and forestry plantations.
habitat:
This species is mostly found in coastal forest, woodland and riparian forest. In the southern parts of the range (e.g. KwaZulu-Natal and the Limpopo Province), the species is found in riparian and coastal forest, whereas in the northern parts of the range it extends into bushland and open woodland (Skinner & Chimimba 2005). This species may possibly be found in timber plantations, and in western Swaziland have adapted to living in wattle forests. It is not uncommon in urban gardens and farmland where there is sufficient tree growth to afford them shelter and where there are orchards of tropical and semi-tropical fruits to provide food. Sleeps alone or in groups of 2-6 and generally disperses solitarily or in small groups at night to forage. It gives birth to between one and three infants per year (Skinner & Chimimba 2005).

O. c. monteiri is known from Brachystegia woodlands and riparian forests. It extends over a wide range using corridors of vegetation along rivers and streams. On the other hand, O. c. kirkii is mostly found in coastal forest, woodland and riparian bushland and, in the northern parts of the range, it extends into bushland and open woodland. It is not uncommon in urban gardens and farmland where there is sufficient tree growth to afford them shelter and where there are orchards of tropical and semi-tropical fruits to provide food.
threats: There are no known major threats other than habitat destruction. However, it may be locally threatened in parts of its range through the loss of suitable forest habitat. For example, although O. c. monteiri was once common around Lake Victoria, it has now almost completely disappeared together with the woodlands, due to cultivation. Similarly, huge swathes of previously available forest have been replaced by avocado and fruit orchards in Mpumalanga Province, and areas that once resounded with galago calls are now silent.
population: This is a relatively common species, but populations are isolated form one another by virtue of the fragmented distribution of the forests in which they are found.
range:
This species ranges from the KwaZulu-Natal Province in eastern South Africa, and northwards into Swaziland and Mpumalanga and Limpopo Provinces, Zimbabwe, Mozambique and southern Malawi (Chikwawa), Zambia, Angola, south-eastern Republic of Congo, Burundi, Rwanda, Tanzania and southern Kenya. Up to 1,800 m in the highlands of eastern Zimbabwe.

Three or four subspecies are recognized: O. c. crassicaudatus is known from the South African provinces of KwaZulu-Natal, Mpumalanga and Limpopo; O. c. kirkii ranges from Massangena, Mozambique, in the south to Zimbabwe and southern Malawi in the north; and O. c. monteiri is found in the Brachystegia miombo woodland zone from Angola in the west, to Zambia, Malawi and northern Mozambique in the east and from here north to Rwanda and western and south-eastern Kenya.

Some taxonomic authorities state that O. c. monteiri can be split into two groups with a monteiri group present from Angola, through the southern Democratic Republic of Congo, Zambia, Zimbabwe, northern Mozambique, Malawi and southern Tanzania (Tabora). The distribution of the argentatus grouping is unclear, but it has been recorded from Rwanda, Kenya and Tanzania.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES. It occurs in several protected areas. Taxonomic and survey work is needed to determine the relationship of the subspecies O. c. monteiri.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern. Otolemur garnettii is widespread and locally common. Major threats include habitat loss, degradation and fragmentation. The species is not thought to be threatened range-wide.
habitat:
The nocturnal and arboreal O. garnettii has a wide geographical range. In submontane and montane forest, dry coastal forest, riverine gallery forest and forest-agriculture mosaics (Harcourt and Perkin 2013). It is able to persist in secondary and/or highly fragmented forest and in cultivated areas, urban suburbs and neem forest (de Jong and Butynski 2009, 2011; Harcourt & Perkin 2013).

Otolemur garnettii is omnivorous, with a diet consisting of 50% animal matter (mainly invertebrates such as beetles, orthopterans and centipedes) and 50% fruits (Harcourt and Perkin 2013). They sleep in dense tangles or clumps of trees. They are not reported to make nests or sleep in tree holes (Bearder et al. 2003). Females give birth to one or two young annually.

The vocal profile of O. garnettii is available at: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/vocal-profiles/otolemur/garnettii/ and a photographic map at: http://www.wildsolutions.nl/photography/photomap/.
threats:
Major threats for O. garnettii are habitat loss and fragmentation. As a result, O. garnettii is locally threatened by the conversion of habitat to agricultural land, fuel wood collection, expansion of human settlements and tourism.

Otolemur garnettii is killed as a presumed agricultural pest and a symbol of bad luck (Harcourt and Perkin 2013). Hunted in southwest Tanzania (Makonde tribal area) for bushmeat (Harcourt and Perkin 2013). In Zanzibar, they are trapped for dog food (A. Perkin pers. obs. 2012). Live individuals have been observed for sale as pets in Kenya and Tanzania, and recorded in international pet trade for sale in United Arab Emirates (Svensson et al. 2016).
population:
Otolemur garnettii is a widespread and locally abundant species (e.g., on the Kenyan Highlands and on the islands of Zanzibar and Pemba). It is, however, patchily distributed and conspicuously absent from some forests (e.g., Matundu Forest Reserve, Tanzania). At Diani and Gedi, Kenya, it is found at densities of ca 31-38 individuals/km² (Nash & Harcourt 1986).

Foot and vehicle surveys at more than 20 sites in Kenya and Tanzania yielded encounter rates of between 1 and 5 individuals per hour. In Kenya, it is most abundant at the Tana River Primate National Reserve, Ngaia Forest Reserve, Meru Forest Reserve and Diani (de Jong and Butynski 2004, 2009). In Tanzania, this was the primate most often encountered in Ngezi-Vumawimbi Nature Forest Reserve (Pemba Island), Zanzibar Island, Arusha, Zaraninge Forest and Lake Manyara National Park (Y. de Jong and T. Butynski pers. obs. 2011).
range:
Otolemur garnettii is endemic to eastern East Africa and extreme northern Mozambique. Patchily distributed from near Mogadishu in southern Somalia southwards through Kenya and Tanzania to extreme northern Mozambique (just south of the Ruvuma River; Olson 1979, Harcourt & Perkin 2013). It is also found in Milo Forest, the only known site in the Southern Highlands of Tanzania, on the northern end of Lake Malawi (Honess 1996, A. Perkin and T. Davenport pers. obs. 2010 cited in Harcourt & Perkin 2013). O. garnettii is present on Zanzibar, Pemba and Mafia Islands (Tanzania) and Manda Island (Kenya). A population occurs in the Central Kenya Highlands, east of the Eastern Rift Valley (Harcourt and Perkin 2013) and in Tsavo. There are no records for Malawi (Ansell and Dowsett 1988).

Otolemur garnettii ranges from sea level to about 2,000 m asl, occasionally up to 2,400 m (Olson 1979, Harcourt and Perkin 2013). It is sympatric with Paragalago zanzibaricus, Paragalago cocos, Galago senegalensis, Paragalago granti and (narrowly) with Otolemur crassicaudatus (T. Butynski & Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2016). 

Four subspecies are recognised:

Otolemur g. garnettii (Zanzibar Small-eared Galago). Endemic to Zanzibar, Pemba and Mafia Islands, Tanzania.

Otolemur g. panganiensis (Pangani Small-eared Galago). Ranges from the Loita Hills and Taveta in Kenya to Lake Manyara, Mount Meru, Mount Kilimanjaro and Tanga, southwards to the south bank of the Ruvumu River in northern Mozambique (Olsen 1979, Butynski and de Jong 2012, Harcourt & Perkin 2013).

Otolemur g. lasiotis (White-tailed Small-eared Galago). From the Juba River in southern Somalia, southwards along the Kenya coast to Tanga, northern Tanzania. In Taita Hills and Kibwezi area, Kenya (north of Mount Kilimanjaro; de Jong & Butynski 2009, Harcourt & Perkin 2013).

Otolemur g. kikuyuensis (Kikuyu Small-eared Galago). Endemic to the Central Kenya Highlands east of the Eastern Rift Valley (e.g., Nairobi, Ngong Hills, Aberdares Range, Masinga area, Nyambeni Range, Mount Kenya; de Jong and Butynski 2004, Harcourt and Perkin 2013, T. Butynski & Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2014).
conservationActions: Otolemur garnettii is listed on Appendix II of CITES. The species is supported by a number of protected areas including the following: Tsavo West National Park, Tsavo East National Park, Aberdares National Park, Mount Kenya National Park, Meru National Park and Arabuke Sokoke Forest Reserve in Kenya, and Ngezi National Park, Jozani Chakwa National Park, Lake Manyara National Park, Arusha National Park and Kilimanjaro National Park in Tanzania (T. Butynski, Y. de Jong, & A. Perkin pers. obs. 2016).

rationale: Hylobates moloch is considered Endangered based on a suspected population reduction of 50% or more over the course of three generations (2001-2015, 2016-2030, 2031-2045). This ongoing decline is due to the combined threats of forest habitat loss and hunting for subsistence purposes, in addition to supplying the pet trade.
habitat: Confined to the western part of the island of Java, Indonesia, in the provinces of Banten, West and Central Java. Lowland and lower montane rainforest up to 2,400 m asl but usually below 1,600 m asl (Asquith 1995, Farida and Haran 2000, Iskandar 2007, Kim et al. 2010, Supriatna and Ario 2015). They can tolerate disturbed habitat, but are known to prefer floristically-rich patches of forest. Their diet is composed mainly of fruit (61%) and leaves (38%), and, to a lesser degree, flowers and insects. In captivity, the average age at first birth was 8.8 years and inter-birth intervals were about 2.3 years (Gates 1998). The average home range is between 17-60 ha (Setiawan et al. 2012).
threats: Hylobates moloch is threatened throughout its range in the provinces of Banten, Jawa Barat and Jawa Tengah by continuing deforestation (the rate of forest loss is increasing in all localities, but is greatest in Banten Province, according to Global Forest Watch) and by hunting. A significant portion of hunting activity supplies young animals for the pet trade. The extirpation of at least seven former sub-populations has been documented (Asquith et al. 1995) and recent studies of three of the four largest remaining populations (Ujung Kulon NP, Haliman-Salak NP and the Dieng Mountains) suggest high probabilities of extinction within a 100-year period if current conditions do not change, or if they worsen (Smith et al. 2018).
population:
From 1994-2002, Nijman (2004) assessed the entirety of the silvery gibbon’s population in its known areas of occurrence by using fixed-point counts and forest transect walks, as well as by a review of literature. Their presence was detected by listening for gibbon song and affirmed by local park officers and residents. Over 95% of the gibbons are in populations of more than 100 individuals, and the four largest areas support populations of more than 500 individuals each. Asquith et al. (1995) reported that, in 1995, nine local populations had gone extinct, though Nijman found two of these localities to still harbor silvery gibbons. This is attributed to the effects of habitat disturbance and low population density on calling frequency, and suggests an under-representation of gibbon abundance and number of remaining populations (Nijman 2004). Recent studies of three of the four largest remaining populations - Ujung Kulon NP, Haliman-Salak NP and the Dieng Mountains - suggest high probabilities of extinction within a 100-year period if current conditions do not change, or if they worsen (Smith et al. 2018).

Median population density ranges are 2.7 groups/km2 or 9.0 individuals/km2 in lowland forest (below 500 m), 2.6 groups/km2 or 8.6 individuals/km2 for hill forest (500-1,000 m), and 0.6 groups/km2 or 1.5 individuals/km2 for lower montane forest (1000-1,750 m) (Iskandar 2007, Setiawan et al. 2012).
range: Hylobates moloch is endemic to Java (Indonesia). It is mostly confined to Java’s western provinces (Banten and West Java), but is also present in central Java, as far east as the Dieng Mountains (Kappeler 1981, Supriatna et al. 1994, Setiawan et al. 2012, Smith et al. 2018).
useTrade: The species is hunted both for meat and for the pet trade.
conservationActions:
Like all species of gibbon, H. moloch is included on Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES); all countries of occurrence are signatories to CITES. The species has been protected under Indonesian law since 1925. It occurs in 30 forest areas, 10 of which contain populations of over 100 individuals.

Protected areas include Ujung Kulon, Gunung Halimun-Salak and Gunung Gede-Pangrango National Parks, Telaga Warna, Sanggabuana, Burangrang, Gunung Simpang, Gunung Tilu and Gunung Papandayan nature reserves, amongst others, but not all forest where gibbons occur in these sites is necessarily included within reserve boundaries. The largest populations residing within forest that is not protected are in the Dieng Mountains in Central Java and Mount Wayan in West Java.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered as it is suspected to have experienced a reduction of more than 50% over a time frame of three generations (45 years) in the past, for the period 1970-2015, as a result of rampant forest loss and loss of mature individuals due to hunting. The causes for this reduction have not ceased. Over the coming 45 years, this decline is suspected to reach similar proportions due to continuing habitat loss, fragmentation and impacts of wildlife trade on this species.
habitat:
This species is found in moist, seasonal evergreen and mixed deciduous-evergreen forests. It has been recorded to about 1,500 m in Cambodia and to around 1,200 m in Thailand. This species is similar to H. lar in diet and general ecology, consuming mostly fruits, shoots, and some immature leaves, as well as insects (Srikosamatara 1980, 1984). Researchers find the species somewhat shyer and more elusive than H. lar (W. Brockelman pers. comm.).

Average group size in Thailand is four individuals (Brockelman and Poonjampa unpubl. data). There has been no long-term study of behavior and life history.
threats: This species is threatened by both hunting, primarily for subsistence, and severe habitat fragmentation and degradation (Duckworth et al. 1999, Traeholt et al. 2005). In Thailand, all populations are now within protected conservation areas and the era of logging and slash-and-burn agriculture (Brockelman 1983) is now mostly over. Nevertheless, severe encroachment has occurred in eastern Khao Yai Park and other major protected areas, and subsistence hunting by minor forest product collectors is still uncontrolled (Phoonjampa and Brockelman 2008). In Cambodia, however, habitat destruction is a more immediate threat than poaching, especially in remote areas. Most populations are not yet secured in protected areas, and the main threats are habitat loss due to logging, agricultural conversion, hydroelectric development and new human settlements (W. Brockelman pers. comm.).
population:
In Cambodia, the primary area of importance is the Cardamom Mountains, in the southwestern part which is relatively intact, where densities are in the order of 1-2 groups/km2, with an estimated 20,000 individuals (Traeholt et al. 2005). Populations in the north, where the habitat is similar but more open with a very small percentage of evergreen forest, are smaller. Bokor National Park in southwestern Cambodia has an estimated 1,000 groups and is likely to be isolated from the remainder of the range (Traeholt et al. 2005). Pileated gibbons might number around 35,000 individuals in Cambodia in total (Traeholt et al. 2005, Nielson et al. 2013).

In Lao PDR, the population is significantly smaller, mainly since it comprises a smaller part of the range (Duckworth et al. 1999). The average group size in Thailand is four individuals (Brockelman and Poonjampa unpubl. data).

In Thailand, there are an estimated 12,000 individuals (3,000 breeding groups) surviving in the four largest forest areas, including five major protected areas (Khao Yai National Park, Thap Lan National Park, Khao Ang Ru Nai Sanctuary and Khao Soi Dao Sanctuary), based on an auditory census in 2004–2005, plus around 1,000 to 2,000 individuals in 15 other scattered and highly fragmented smaller protected areas (Phoonjampa and Brockelman unpub. data). Population densities are generally low, averaging close to one group (average 4 individuals)/km2, with pockets of higher density populations in some remote mountain areas (Brockelman and Srikosamatara 1993). An earlier study generated a total population estimate of 30,000 pileated gibbons for Thailand (Tunhikorn et al. 1994).
range: The range of this species includes southeastern Thailand, a portion of southwestern Lao PDR (west of the Mekong), and western Cambodia (west of the Mekong). In Thailand, the western limit may once have been the Bang Pakong River, extending north to Khao Yai National Park, east of the Lam Takhong watershed, and all forested areas east and south of the Moon River (Geissmann 1995, Groves 2001, Marshall and Sugardjito 1986). In Khao Yai, the limit is Khao Rom Mountain and the upper reaches of the Lam Takhong River on the north side (Phoonjampa and Brockelman 2008, Srikosamatara 1984, Traeholt et al. 2005, Tunhikorn et al. 1994).
useTrade: The species is hunted primarily for subsistence as human food.
conservationActions:
This species is listed in CITES Appendix I. In Cambodia the major stronghold is three contiguous protected areas, including Samkos and Aural Wildlife Sanctuaries, and the Central Cardamom Protected Forest. This last area contains about 3,350 km2 of gibbon habitat and a population of nearly 7,000 groups. This potentially could ensure the long-term survival of the species if effectively managed. The Cambodian Forestry Administration, in collaboration with Conservation International, is developing a management plan for this area, and ranger units have been established to stop illegal poaching and logging. Gibbons also occur in Bokor National Park (1,220 km2 of habitat), which is generally well managed. As in Thailand, numerous smaller fragmented areas also contain pileated gibbons, most with low long-term prospects. In Cambodia, there is a need to strengthen protected area administration and protection activities, and to halt logging and development activities in important conservation areas (W. Brockelman pers comm.; Traeholt et al. 2005).

In southeast Thailand, all populations are included within protected areas, but more effort needs to be made to change the behavior of local villagers who hunt. The largest protected forest areas are the Tab Lan National Park, Pang Sida National Park, Ta Phraya National Park, Khao Ang Ru Nai Sanctuary and Khao Soi Dao Sanctuary, totalling over 3,000 km2 of forest habitat in three blocks (Phoonjampa and Brockelman unpubl. data). In 2009, a conservation intervention through community involvement was made at the iconic study site of Srikosamatara (1980) in North Ta-riu watershed, Khao Soi Dao wildlife sanctuary, with success. Before the intervention, the gibbon population declined by 70% between 1979 to 2008, as a result of opportunistic hunting for bush meat by local Non-Timber Forest Product (NTFP) collectors. A social theory called “Diffusion of innovations” and “Conservation marketing” was applied, using educational and campaign materials, and resulted in increased conservation behavior among local NTFP collectors. In 2012, the gibbon population increased by 20% (Kolasartsanee and Srikosamatara 2014). Re-survey in 2016 showing further increase of gibbon population indicated a persistence effect of 2009 intervention on conservation for at least 7 years (Kolasartsanee 2016).

rationale: Hylobates albibarbis is considered Endangered under Criterion A4cd, based on an overall suspected population reduction of 50% or more over the previous two generations (1990-2019), which is also expected to continue impacting the current generation (2020-2035). The reduction is driven by a corresponding loss of suitable habitat (that has averaged 1% annually in Borneo over the past 30 years) and is expected to continue at that rate (or higher) for the next 10 to 20 years, as well as by significant losses due to hunting and live capture for the pet trade.
habitat:
The species inhabits a range of primary, secondary and selectively logged tropical evergreen forest types (Cheyne 2010, Cheney et al. 2016, Harrison et al. 2010, Marshall et al. 2009). Peat swamp forest is a particularly important forest type for H. albibarbis (Cheyney 2008, 2010; Cheyney et al. 2008). Population densities are correlated with forest structure (Hamard et al. 2010, Cheyne et al. 2016, Marshall et al. 2014), altitude (Marshall 2009), and the abundance of important fallback foods (Marshall and Leighton 2006). The species appears able to adapt to low to moderate levels of selective logging, although additional studies are needed to characterize the extent of their tolerance of forest degradation (Cheyne et al. 2013, Singh et al. 2018).

Hylobates albibarbis is chiefly arboreal and diurnal. The species is socially monogamous and highly territorial (Mitani 1987); estimates of territory size are 47 ha at Sabangau (Cheyne 2010) and 30-43 ha at Gunung Palung (Mitani 1990; Marshall 2004). The taxon is predominantly frugivorous, preferring ripe, sugar-rich fruits (Cheyne 2008, Cheyne et al. 2016, Dillis et al. 2014, McConkey 2000, Singh et al. 2018) although unripe fruits, immature leaves, insects, and flowers are consumed during periods of low fruit abundance (Coiner-Collier et al. 2016, McConkey 1999).
threats: Hylobates albibarbis is threatened by habitat loss within peat swamp ecosytems due to the expansion of agricultural plantations, clear-felling for timber and, to a lesser extent, selective logging, all of which are exacerbated by forest fires associated with El Niño events (Oka et al. 2000, Marshall et al. 2000, 2014; Bartlett 2007, Harrison et al. 2007, Campbell et al. 2008, 2015; Struebig et al. 2015, Cheyne et al. 2016). Illegal hunting and live capture for the pet trade pose additional threats (Nijman 2005). Between 1973 and 2017, Borneo (overall) has lost an average of 1% of its forest cover annually (Gaveau et al. 2014, 2018), and the most recent Global Forest Watch data indicates this rate continues. If conditions do not change, a loss of close to 50% of suitable habitat can be anticipated over the course of three generations (45 years).
population: There are no estimates of the total number of individuals remaining, although the species is generally common in suitable habitat. A tentative estimate based on surveys from 2005-2018 suggests a population size of 22,000 individuals within the mixed-swamp forests in Sabangau, representing one of the largest remaining populations of this species (Cheyne et al. 2008, 2016; Cheyne 2010, Hamard et al. 2010). Population density estimates in undisturbed habitats range widely among forest types, from less than 0.5 individuals/km2 in montane forests to more than 10 individuals/km2 in lowland and swamp forests (Marshall 2004, 2009, 2010; Marshall and Leighton 2006). Lowland and peat swamp forests support high densities and population abundance declines predictably with altitude (Cheyne et al. 2016; Marshall 2004, 2009, 2010; Marshall and Leighton 2006). Long term monitoring in Gunung Palung National Park suggests that upland forests are of insufficient quality to maintain viable gibbon populations in the absence of inputs from lowland source forests (Marshall et al. 2009). Population density appears to be highly stable in the absence of hunting or habitat degradation (Marshall et al. 2014), presumably due to the slow life histories and low infant and juvenile mortality in this taxon (Mitani 1990, Marshall 2009, Marshall et al. 2009). Logged peat swamp forests in the Sabangau catchment area of central Kalimantan support densities of approximately 10.4 individuals/km2 (Cheyne 2010, Cheyne et al. 2008, 2016; Hamard et al. 2010).
range: This species occurs in Borneo (in the West Kalimantan and Central Kalimantan provinces of Indonesia) south of the Kapuas River and west of the Barito River (Marshall and Sugardjito 1986, Groves 2001, Cheyne et al. 2016).
useTrade: The species is hunted for subsistence and captured alive for the pet trade.
conservationActions: Bornean White-bearded gibbons are protected throughout their range by Indonesian law and are listed on CITES Appendix I. They are found in six Indonesian protected areas: Bukit Baka-Bukit Raya National Park, Gunung Palung National Park, Tanjung Puting National Park, Sabangau National Park, Hampapak Nature Reserve, and Kendawangan Nature Reserve.

rationale:
This species is listed as Endangered as it is believed to have undergone a decline of more than 50% in the last three generations (45 years) due to rampant forest loss in addition to loss of mature individuals due to hunting and capture for the pet and photo-prop trade (Marshall et al. 1972; Geissmann 1991; Tunhikorn et al. 1994; Round and Brockelman 1998; Nijman et al. 2009; Campbell et al. 2015; Osterberg et al. 2015). The species as a whole is found in northern Sumatra (Indonesia), throughout Peninsular Malaysia (except for a narrow strip between the Perak and Mudah Rivers, where H. agilis occurs), north through southern and eastern Myanmar (east of the Salween River), most of Thailand (though not in the north-east; Marshall et al. 1972), and marginally into southern China, though now extirpated there (Grueter et al. 2009).

No population estimates are currently available for Indonesia, Malaysia, and Myanmar (Ellefson 1974; Geissmann et al. 2013). While for Lao PDR, there are no reliable estimates, but for Nam Poyi National Protected Area (which is the only protected area from which they are recorded; Duckworth et al. 1995), the species is uncommon to rare, perhaps numbering in the mid- to high-hundreds (Boonratana 1997; Boonratana et al. 2011; Geissmann 1991). In some parts of Thailand there are several populations where numbers are at least in the thousands, though in northern Thailand they are now very rare. The largest population is in Kaeng Krachan National Park, which probably has on the order of 3,000-4,000 individuals. The Western Forest Complex may well have on the order of 10,000 animals, and likely upwards of 1,000 survive in the western part of Khao Yai National Park, as well as in Phukhieo Wildlife Sanctuary and Nam Nao National Park.

The major threat to this species is hunting (having replaced forest clearance as the top threat); they are hunted both for subsistence food use and for the pet trade (Bartlett, 2007; Malone et al. 2001; Osterberg, et al. 2014, 2015). Hunting pressure varies across the range but takes place even within protected areas. Much of the hunting is done by villagers exploiting Aquilaria spp. trees prized for their aromatic wood, and other forest products (W. Brockelman pers. comm.). Over the coming 45 years, this decline is suspected to reach similar proportions due to continuing habitat loss, fragmentation and the impacts of wildlife trade on this species.
habitat:
This species is found in evergreen, semi-evergreen, and mixed evergreen-deciduous forest (sometimes known as "dry evergreen" forest, in the northern parts of its range), and is known to utilize regenerating secondary forest and selectively logged forest (Johns 1985). In northwestern Thailand, white-handed gibbons utilize patches of dry evergreen, mixed deciduous, and bamboo forest near Karen settlements if they are not hunted. This is predominantly a lowland species (below 1,000-1,500 m).

Like most other species of gibbon, H. lar consumes a largely frugivorous diet that includes mainly figs, as well as young shoots, leaves, some flowers, and insects. Gibbons, unlike most macaques and leaf monkeys that often share their habitats, swallow nearly all the seeds that they ingest, making them potentially important as seed dispersers. Certain species of fruits that require the consumer to remove a tough outer cover appear to rely almost entirely on gibbons for seed dispersal (Bartlett 2007; Ellefson 1974; Gittins and Raemakers 1980; MacKinnon and MacKinnon 1978; Palombit 1992, 1997; Ungar 1995).

Generation length in white-handed gibbons is on the order of 15 years. They mature late, with females maturing at 8-10 years and males at 8-12 years and have one offspring every 3 to 5 years (Brockelman et al. 1998). If a female loses a baby, she may come into oestrus sooner, but the average inter-birth interval in a population at carrying capacity is about 3.5 years (W. Brockelman pers. comm.). Average group size in H. lar generally increases with latitude, illustrating that group size is not a very useful species-specific character in gibbons. This reflects a general trend of increasing birth rate with latitude found in many vertebrate groups. Average group size has been reported at 2.7 (Chivers 1978) and 3.3 (Ellefson 1974) individuals in Peninsular Malaysia, 3.7 in central Thailand (Brockelman and Srikosamatara 1993), and 4.4 (Carpenter 1940) and 4.9 (Yimkao and Srikosamatar 2006) in northern Thailand. The average home range sizes are 44-54 ha on the Malayan peninsula (Ellefson 1974, Gittins and Raemaekers 1980, MacKinnon and MacKinnon 1980) and about 16 ha in the Khao Yai National Park in Thailand (Chivers 1984a,b).
threats:
The major threat to this species is hunting (having replaced even forest clearance as the top threat); they are hunted both for subsistence food use and for the pet trade (Bartlett 2007, Malone et al. 2001, Osterberg et al. 2014, 2015). Hunting pressure varies across the range but takes place even within protected areas. Much of the hunting is done by villagers exploiting Aquilaria spp. trees prized for their aromatic wood, and other forest products (W. Brockelman pers. comm.).

Construction of roads through protected areas (for example, the Security Highway through Nam Poyi in Lao PDR, the north-south highway in Peninsular Malaysia) may also pose a threat since it promotes forest clearance and strip development, possibly increases fragmentation, and increases access by hunters into protected areas. Ongoing localized forest loss due to shifting agriculture and commercial plantations of palm oil poses a threat. On northern Sumatra, most of the lowland forests have been logged out and the threat of Ladia Galaskar, a network to link the west and east coasts of Aceh province, means that much of the remaining forest is at risk.
population:
Population densities for this species range from 2.4 groups/km2 in Ketambe, Sumatra (Palombit 1992) to 0.7-2.6 groups/km2 in Kuala Lompat and Tanjong Triang on the Malayan peninsula (Bartlett 2007, Ellefson 1968, 1974; MacKinnon 1977, MacKinnon and MacKinnon 1978) to 6.5 groups/km2 in Khao Yai National Park, Thailand (Bartlett 2009, Reichard and Barelli 2008, Reichard 2009). A few smaller, fragmented populations survive in southern Peninsular Thailand and northwestern Malaysia, perhaps together numbering in the low thousands. There are no recent estimates of the populations in the Tenasserim section of Myanmar, northern Sumatra and in southern Peninsular Malaysia (W. Brockelman pers. comm.).

In China, during the 1960s, there were estimated to be 200 individuals on both sides of the Nangunhe River. In 1988, the date of last sighting, it was estimated that there were less than 10 groups. And in 1992, the last survey date, the authors did not find any direct evidence for the species' persistence but estimated that three groups may remain with about 10 individuals in total. Recent data indicate that this species is extirpated in China (Grueter et al. 2009).

No population estimates are currently available for Indonesia, Malaysia, and Myanmar (Ellefson 1974, Geissmann et al. 2013). While for Lao PDR, there are no reliable estimates, but for Nam Poyi National Protected Area (which is the only protected area from which they are recorded (Duckworth et al. 1995), the species is uncommon to rare, perhaps numbering in the mid- to high-hundreds (Boonratana 1997, Boonratana et al. 2011, Geissmann 1991). In some parts of Thailand there are several populations where numbers are at least in the thousands, though in northern Thailand they are now very rare. The largest population is in Kaeng Krachan National Park, which probably has somewhere in the order of 3,000-4,000 individuals. The Western Forest Complex may well have on the order of 10,000 animals, and likely upwards of 1,000 survive in the western part of Khao Yai National Park, as well as in Phukhieo Wildlife Sanctuary and Nam Nao National Park. A few smaller populations survive in the south, for example Khao Sok (W. Brockelman pers. comm.).
range: The species as a whole is found in northern Sumatra (Indonesia), throughout Peninsular Malaysia (except for a narrow strip between the Perak and Mudah Rivers, where H. agilis occurs), north through southern and eastern Myanmar (east of the Salween River), most of Thailand (though not in the north-east; Marshall et al. 1972), and marginally into southern China, though now extirpated there (Grueter et al. 2009). The break in distribution between Perak and Muda/Thepa Rivers on the Malaysian Peninsula is genuine (Carpenter 1940, Geissmann 1984, Harcourt and Schwartz 2001, Matsudaira et al. 2013). The species also occurs in a small area of northwestern Lao PDR (west of the Mekong River). The range formerly extended into southeastern Thailand, where it was parapatric with H. pileatus (Brockelman 1978, Brockelman and Gittins 1984, Phoonjampa and Brockelman 2008). It is unclear whether the population on Phuket (Thailand) is native, but they certainly have been introduced or reintroduced (Osterberg et al. 2014, 2015). The species is extirpated in China (Grueter et al. 2009, Li et al. 2018).
useTrade: The species is hunted both for subsistence food use and for the pet trade.
conservationActions: Hylobates lar, like all gibbons, is a nationally protected species in all the countries across its range, and is listed under CITES Appendix I. In most of its range it is confined to protected conservation areas (for example in Thailand, where no significant populations survive outside of protected areas). However, in most countries, these areas are not well patrolled, even if they are well managed for tourism. There is an urgent need for improved protection of these areas, ideally involving local communities that should benefit from as well as participate in management. Illegal use of forest products, as well as poaching, is common in most protected areas. Inadequate management and protection, rather than forest destruction, are the main long-term threats and conservation efforts must seek to identify the hunters and incorporate them into new management priorities.

rationale: Hylobates klossii is Endangered due to a past and continued population reduction, estimated at more than 50% over a period of 45 years, including two past generations (1986-2015) and the current generation (2016-2030). The population reduction is due to widespread local hunting for cultural reasons and loss of habitat, particularly in North Pagai, South Pagai and Sipora Islands.
habitat:
This species is arboreal, diurnal, and omnivorous, though predominantly frugivorous (Whitten 1982a). Although disturbance levels in this species' habitat are variable on different islands, a recent survey detected similar population densities in un-logged forests, forests logged 10 years ago, and those logged 20 years ago (Paciulli 2004, Whittaker 2005).

Gibbons in the Siberut area studied by both Tenaza (1974, 1975) and Tilson (1980) had unusually small average home ranges of 7-11 ha. A gibbon group studied in a different area on Siberut had a home range size of 32 ha, similar to that in other species of the genus Hylobates (Whitten 1980, 1982b).

Primarily occurs in deciduous, monsoon, tropical evergreen forests at all elevations. This species prefers the upper canopy and is also known to dwell in swamp forests. Annual rainfall in these forests are up to 4,000 mm. Primarily frugivorous, fruits make up 73% of their feeding time while insects and arthropods are consumed about 25% of the time. Breeding happens through the year with single births. Average daily movement is around 1,514 m and groups are typically composed of 4-6 individuals.
threats:
This species is threatened mainly by hunting and commercial logging (Whittaker 2006). It is also threatened by conversion to oil palm plantations, in addition to forest clearing and product extraction by local people (Whittaker 2006). A recent study shows that habitat loss in the Mentawai islands was mainly due to forest conversion for agriculture expansion by local communities. A total of 73,500 ha of forest in Siberut, North Pagai, South Pagai and Sipora Islands have been allocated for oil palm plantation by the local government and about 34,000 ha (46%) was granted to only two companies (FFI, unpublished report)

Recently, hunting pressure has increased because of increased access to remote areas due to logging roads and tracks, as well as the replacement of bows and arrows with .177 caliber air rifles (Whittaker 2006). Also, local rituals and taboos which formerly regulated hunting have been eroded by brands of Christianity which have not recognised the conservation imperative (Whittaker 2006). The pet trade is also a threat to this species (Whittaker 2006). Although this may be a greater threat to this species than to other gibbons (D. Whittaker pers. comm.), it is rarely seen in the pet-trade in Java (Nijman 2005). A recent report (Quinten et al. 2014) suggests Kloss’s gibbons to be rarely hunted. The Kloss’s Gibbons of Paelonan forests of Siberut Island are reported to exhibit ‘decoy’ behavior, wherein one member of the troop distracts the incumbent human danger while the rest of the troop escape. This is seen as an effective behavioral trait to escape human predation (Dooley and Judge 2014).

The extent of the threats from logging, hunting, and the pet trade faced by this species varies depending on location. The very large population in Siberut National Park, on central Siberut, lives in a protected area but is subject to moderate hunting pressure from local people. In the Peleonan forest, northern Siberut, the habitat was logged 20 years prior but faces low hunting pressure. This area is significant because four of the endemic Mentawai primates (H. klossii, Simias concolor, Presbytis potenziani and Macaca siberu) exist here in high densities. Populations in Saureinu, Sipora are subject to traditional use by locals but limited logging. In South Pagai, forest plots are selectively logged but there is high hunting pressure. Animals on North Pagai were not censused, but logging and hunting occurs there as well (Whittaker 2005b).
population: John and Kathy Mackinnon (1984, 1986) estimated the total population of Hylobates klossii to be 36,000 individuals. Whittaker (2005) revised this estimate to 20,000-25,000 animals nearly 20 years later. More recently, Hoing et al. (2013) gathered population estimates on all four Mentawai Islands (Siberut, Sipora, North Pagai and South Pagai) using loud-call monitoring and forested area estimates to census the animals. Throughout the Mentawai Islands, density averaged 12 individuals/km2. The largest population (~10,500 individuals; 3.67-6.5 individuals/km2) is found in Siberut National Park and represents 72.21% of the island’s population. The smallest remaining population is that found on Sipora, comprising 753-880 individuals (Paciulli 2005, Höing et al. 2013). The combined populations on North and South Pagai are estimated at 2,029 individuals (Paciulli 2005, Höing et al. 2013). Based on these studies, the most recent estimate of the total population would be approximately 17,500, a decline of more than 50% of that estimated in the 1980s.
range: This species is endemic to the four Mentawai Islands (Siberut, Sipora, North Pagai and South Pagai) off the west coast of Sumatra, Indonesia (Marshall and Sugardjito 1986, Geissmann 1995, Groves 2001).
useTrade: This species is collected for the pet trade and hunted for cultural ceremonies.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on CITES Appendix I, and is protected by Indonesian law. More than half of the remaining Kloss's gibbons reside in Siberut National Park, a government protected area. Whittaker (2005b, 2006) suggested the following conservation actions: 1) increased protection for Siberut National Park, which currently lacks enforcement, 2) formal protection of the Peleonan forest in North Siberut, which is home to unusually high primate populations and is easily accessible, 3) protection of areas in the Pagai Islands by cooperating with a logging corporation that has practiced sustainable logging technique there since 1971, 4) conservation education, especially regarding hunting, and 5) the development of alternative economic models for the local people to reduce the likelihood of selling off their lands to logging companies (Whittaker 2006).

The more recent Workshop of the National Strategic and Action Plan for the Conservation of the Kloss’s Gibbons which involved participants from the central and local governments, local governments, scientists and academicians, NGOs, protected area managers and private sector, outlined several key strategies and conservation issues, including:

1) Spatial planning: avoid infrastructure development within the Kloss’s gibbon habitats, identify and map priority Kloss’s gibbon habitats, protection of the remaining Kloss’s gibbon habitats outside the Siberut NP, incorporate the Kloss’s gibbon strategic and action plan into the spatial planning.

2) Concessions: identify and map Kloss’s gibbon distribution within concessions, implement robust monitoring protocol for Kloss’s gibbon population within the concessions, designate and protect Kloss’s gibbon habitats and corridors within the concessions, implement SMART patrol system within the concessions.

3) Kloss’s gibbon population and ecology: develop standardized robust monitoring protocol for Kloss’s gibbon population and consistently implement it across the remaining populations and habitats, define and designate centers for Kloss’s gibbon ecological researches, habitat restoration and rehabilitation, and habitat enrichments.

4) Community awareness and education: implement conservation campaign and awareness programs, appoint Kloss’s gibbon ambassador, develop and implement Kloss’s gibbon conservation award programs.

5) Law enforcement: implement SMART patrol system in the protected areas, implement road block patrols, work with seaport authorities to prevent and strengthen law enforcement against illegal trade of the Kloss’s gibbons, establish a community-supported investigation network, and establish and operate a network of guard posts at optimum check point locations.

rationale: The species is considered Endangered in light of a continued decline inferred from habitat loss. This is inferred from work on sympatric Sumatran orangutans (Campbell-Smith et al. 2011, Gaveau et al. 2009, Wich et al. 2016), mainly as a result of expanding agriculture, land clearance through fire, and road building, calculated to be over 50% over the past 45 years (approximately 3 generations), in combination with poaching and illegal trade for the pet market (Lee et al. 2015, O'Brien and Kinnaird 2011, Sultan et al. 2009). In some areas of the species' Sumatran range, humans opportunistically hunt agile gibbons for consumption (Campbell et al. 2015, Gittins 1983, Gittins and Raemakers 1980, Lee et al. 2015). Threats are occurring primarily in the Sumatran portion of its range where the species seems to be declining rapidly and is certainly endangered. On the mainland (Peninsular Malaysia and Thailand), there seem to be a number of stable populations, but the range is contracting. The species is entirely confined to closed canopy forest, and thus, habitat conversion, road building and fragmentation are increasingly threatening the species (Gittins 1983, Gittins and Raemakers 1980, Lee et al. 2015).
habitat:
This species occurs at highest densities in dipterocarp-dominated forests, but their known habitat ranges from swamp and lowland forests to hill, submontane, and montane forests (O'Brien et al. 2004; Yanuar 2009). Additionally, populations in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park in Sumatra do not seem to avoid forest edges near human habitations (O'Brien et al. 2004), a behavior that has also been observed in the Batang Toru Forest Complex, North Sumatra, Indonesia (Nowak pers. obs.). While they prefer undisturbed primary forest, some studies from Sumatra indicate that they can also be found in previously disturbed regenerating forest (Sultan et al. 2009; Lee et al. 2015). In southern Sumatra, populations were found up to 1,400 meters (O'Brien et al. 2004).

These arboreal and diurnal primates are primarily frugivorous (preferring fruits high in sugar, such as figs), but they will consume flowers, immature leaves, and insects as well (Gittins 1979, 1982). An average home range size of 29 ha has been determined in a study at Sungai Dal (Gunung Bubu Forest Reserve) on the Malayan peninsula (Gittins 1979, 1982; Gittins and Raemaekers 1980), whereas a study from within and in areas surrounding Kerinci-Seblat National Park, Sumatra, Indonesia has documented average home ranges of 22.5 ha in forest fragments and 24.7 ha in more continuous forested areas (Yanuar and Chivers 2010). Within the submontane forests of the Batang Toru Forest Complex, agile gibbons have been documented to have home ranges over 50 ha (Nowak pers. obs.). 

Wild gibbons from the genus Hylobates are known to have relatively slow life histories, including a late age at first reproduction (8-12 years) and long interbirth interval (2.2-3.8 years) (Palombit, 1995; Reichard and Barelli, 2008; O’Brien and Kinnaird 2011). Recent work by O’Brien and Kinnaird (2011) has also shown that agile gibbons in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park have extremely low birth (0.22-0.28 infants female-1 yr-1) and infant to juvenile survival rates (33.3%), which they suggest is related to increased resource competition with larger and more abundant sympatric species (e.g. siamangs).
threats:
On Sumatra, this species is threatened by forest conversion, mining, road construction, human encroachment, and a subsequent opportunistic capture for the pet trade and in some areas human consumption. These threats extend to populations within national parks and forests, including illegal agricultural and road development inside designated conservation areas. Between 1985 and 2007 on Sumatra, nearly 50% of the conceivable habitat for this species was lost to logging, road development, and conversion to agriculture or plantations (Ancrenaz et al. 2013, 2015). Forests, where they remain, are extremely fragmented (Estrada et al. 2017). Agricultural expansion (e.g., coffee, oil palm, and rubber), in addition to the expansion of pulp-paper and sawn-timber plantations, are currently the main drivers of forest loss on Sumatra (O'Brien et al. 2003). A recent report indicates that agile gibbons are often encountered in Indonesian wildlife markets and are a common species entering the Kalaweit rehabilitation center in Padang, Sumatra, Indonesia (Nijman et al. 2009).

The species' status in Malaysia is more uncertain, however, as with Sumatra, oil palm expansion has been identified as one of the main causes of deforestation in Peninsular Malaysia (Miyamoto et al. 2014). In Thailand there is extensive conversion of forests to rubber plantations and other crops (even inside protected areas), as well as hunting for the pet trade.
population:
