Sakis exhibit behaviours associated with territory defense (Marsh 2014).Congregatory: Amazonian sakis are frequently seen in association (travelling, feeding and resting) with other primates such as Callicebus, Alouatta, Ateles, Saimri, Saguinus, Lagothrix (Marsh pers. obs).
threats: The main threat to this species is hunting and habitat loss. They are sometimes hunted for the pet trade.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, although it is suspected to be declining due to habitat loss and hunting pressure.
range: In Brazil, P. irrorata follows the west side of the Rio Purus, south to Acre. Specifically, there are specimens from Lago Mapiocu (likely Lago Mapixi) and Aruma in the North, and Rio Branco and Xapuri in the South. While it is tempting to say they are in the entire region between the Rios Jurua and Purus, there are not enough specimens to support this assumption. Especially, since the southern reaches of the upper Jurua are the area in which P. vanzolinii is found, and the north-west pocket between these rivers is where P. albicans occurs (i.e., around Tefe and, as of 1935, at Jaburu on the Rio Purus). It is not known where the boundaries between the two taxa lie, with P. vanzolinii in the upper Rio Jurua watershed or with P. albicans in the lower Rio Purus. It is also remains unknown whether P. irrorata is found east of the upper Rio Madeira in the southern-most reaches of Rondonia (Marsh 2014). In Peru, they are primarily in the Manu region, west of the Rio Manu and south of the upper Rio Madre de Dios, west of the Rio Manu confluence. The distribution extends further to the lower Rio Urubamba and it is likely that they occur in all areas north-east of the Rios Urubamba/ Madre de Dios/ Manu to the Brazilian border where, theoretically (as there are no specimens of either in the area), they would meet with P. vanzolinii. More data are needed on sakis in this region. Likewise, it is unclear how far east they occur in Peru, as P. rylandsi appears to be in the Los Amigos/ Madre de Dios Conservation Concessions (Marsh 2014).
useTrade: All Saki species are subject to hunting throughout their range. They are often hunted for the pet trade, and occasionally for decoration or outfits, such as hats.
conservationActions: This species occurs in some protected areas of Peru, and possibly in Brazil.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern as although the distribution of this species is not well known, there is no reason to believe that it is currently undergoing a decline that would warrant listing in a higher category of threat.
habitat:
All Pithecia species tend to prefer mature forest that includes variations of flooded forest—várzea (white-water flooded forest) and igapó (black-water flooded forest)—palm swamp (Mauritia swamp for some) and terra firma forest. They can be found in disturbed habitats and in fragments with secondary forest, but as seed predators of large forest tree species (notably of the family Lecythidaceae), they tend to be in higher densities in mature forest. One possible explanation for their very large geographic distribution as a genus and as individual species is their ability to use a range of forest types, from várzea to igapó to terra firma (c.f. Marsh 2014).  

Sakis are the smallest of the pitheciines, but are larger than other non-prehensile-tailed platyrrhines (Aotus, Saimiri, Callicebus and the Callitrichinae). Adults weigh in at 1.5–4.0 kg, with a wide range in total body length (250–980 mm) and tail length (255–545 mm) reflecting the diversity among the taxa. Their tails are often 1:1 with the body length, but in many species tails are longer by >100 mm (based on museum specimen data) for both males and females. Size dimorphism is not striking but, depending on the species, females tend to be smaller in weight and overall size. Sakis are characterised by their long, coarse, fluffy hair that easily piloerects when they are approached in the wild, making them look bigger than they actually are. The hair on the tail tends to be longer than on the back, but this varies among species, and the tail hair also “puffs up” as a threat. Hair on the trunk is always longer than that on the forearms and hind limbs, and underbellies are very lightly covered or bare. Coronal hairs are directed forward as a hood, and, depending on the species, overlap the facial region making them appear to have “bangs.” Both males and females have distinct throat glands for scent marking, with varying development depending on the species; some males have obvious neck folds and others only a bare skin patch. Sakis are frugivore/seed predators, but they eat insects such as army ants, as well as spiders, and other arthropods. They vocalize in grunts, chirps, whistles, and low calls, but can be exceptionally quiet when sneaking away from a perceived threat such as a field researcher. Sakis are specialized morphologically for seed predation. The diet is made up of seeds, fruit pulp, young leaves, insects and flowers.

Movement Patterns: Locomotion consists of quadrupedal walking/ running, climbing and leaping. Members of this genus form small groups (2-9 individuals) which in some species may resemble a loose “fission-fusion” (Marsh, pers. obs) but core groups generally comprise a single male-female breeding pair and several young. Day ranges (1.5-2 km), home ranges are small (10-25 km) and sakis exhibit behaviours associated with territory defense (c.f. Marsh 2014).Congregatory: Somewhat. Amazonian sakis are frequently seen in association (traveling, feeding and resting) with other primates such as Callicebus, Alouatta, Ateles, Saimri, Saguinus, Lagothrix (Marsh, pers. obs).
threats: The main threats are hunting and habitat loss. They are sometimes found in the pet trade as far away as Lima, Perù (F. Cornejo pers. comm.).
population: In 1993, Peres reported the population of P. albicans in the upper Rio Urucu to be 8.8 individuals/km². Haugaasen and Peres (2005) reported an average of 2.2 individuals/km² in the lower Purus watershed at Lago Uauaçu with slightly higher results for terra firma (3.3 individuals/km²) and igapó (4.6 individuals/km²) but lower for várzea km² (0.8 individuals/km²).
range: Pithecia albicans occurs only in Brazil. Hershkovitz (1987) places it between the lower Rio Purus and Rio Tefe, south bank tributaries of the upper Rio Solimoes-Amazonas, Amazonas, Brazil. This distribution is accepted by Marsh (2014) specifically noting collections near Lago Tefe, Lago Ayapua, Lago de Boia and Jaburu on the left bank of the Rio Purus. Johns (1985 - 1986) observed P. albicans in terra firma forest on both sides of the Rio Tefe and principally at the Ponta da Castanha on the eastern side of the lake. They also occur along the Rio Bauana, a tributary entering the lake on its eastern shore (A.B. Rylands pers. comm. in Johns 1986). Peres (1997) observed P. albicans west of the Rio Tefe, at a locality called Vai Quem Quer, in terra firma on the right bank of the lower Rio Jurua.
useTrade: All Saki species are subject to hunting throughout their range. They are often taken for pets and occasionally for decoration or outfits, like hats.
conservationActions: This species is not present in any protected areas in Brazil, but is sometimes found in captivity (Sao Paulo Zoo, Rio de Janeiro Primate Center, Marsh pers. comm.).

rationale: This species is considered Least Concern because of its adaptability and relatively wide range, and because there is no evidence of a decline that would warrant listing in a threatened category.
habitat:
Although P. donacophilus is found in tropical humid forests, it seems to be restricted to the slightly drier forests of southern Amazonia and is absent from the more humid forests of northern Beni Department (Wallace and Mercado 2007, Martinez and Wallace 2010). Continued presence in forest remnants in urban areas shows the tolerance of P. donacophilus to habitat disturbance (Martinez and Wallace 2010).
The diet of titi monkeys comprises mainly fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds. They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small homes (1.5-30 ha) and day ranges (0.5-1.5 km). A study on the behavioural ecology and calling behaviour of P. donacophilus is underway at two sites in forest patches in and on the outskirts of Santa Cruz (K. Dingess pers. comm. to R. Wallace 2007).
threats: Agricultural activities have resulted in considerable habitat loss across the range of P. donacophilus especially near urban areas, such as a recent loss of 5ha of forest inhabited by this titi monkey species on the margins of Santa Cruz de la Sierra city (P. Adret pers. comm. 2017).  Nevertheless, it is one of three primate species that survives within the confines of the city and has been observed on the outskirts of several rural communities (Martinez and Wallace 2010).
population: Unpublished data from San Miguelito ranch in Santa Cruz provides relative abundance indices of between 0.04 and 0.18 groups (0.12-0.54 individuals) encountered per 10 km of line transect (Wallace and Mercado 2007; WCS, unpubl.).
range: This species has a wide distribution that stretches east from the Maniqui River in Beni, Bolivia, and north into Brazil where Ferrari et al. (2000) confirmed the presence of titis with a greyish pelage in southern Rondônia. It is possible that its range extends as far north as the Serra dos Pacaás Novos. It is found in Bolivia south to the forests around the city of Santa Cruz.
useTrade: One individual of P. donacophilus is currently in a rescue center (Senda Verde) after being confiscated from a wildlife trader.
conservationActions:
This species is present in the Beni Biosphere Reserve and Amboro National Park in Bolivia (Wallace and Mercado 2007, Martinez and Wallace 2010). More information is required regarding the species' eastern distribution, and limits with P. pallescens in the south.
It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to its relatively large range in a pristine region of the Amazon, and because there are no known major threats believed to be resulting in a decline sufficient to qualify it for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: Plecturocebus cupreus are mainly found in terra firme forests where they occupy the middle and lower strata, but are less common or absent from várzea forests. They may tolerate short-term seasonal flooding and low levels of anthropogenic habitat disturbance. The diet comprises fruit pulp, seeds, leaves and arthropods (Nadjafzadeh and Heymann 2008). Small family groups (2-5 individuals) occupy home- range size of 10-20 ha, day ranges are generally less than 1 km².
threats: This species occurs in a remote isolated region, and is not considered to be under any immediate threat.
population: Population densities vary strongly between areas and habitats. Densities of 6.2 and 26.5 individuals/km² were found at four different survey sites on the Rio Purús, Rio Urucu and Rio Juruá (Peres, 1988). Along the Rio Juruá, Plecturocebus cupreus was present in all terra firme census sites, ranging in population density between 1.1 and 30.1 individuals/km²; it was present in only two out of five várzea sites, with populations densities of 7.4 and 8.5 individuals/km², respectively (Peres 1997). At Lago Uauacú, the species was observed only in terra firme forest at population densities of 0.3 individuals/km² (Haugaasen & Peres 2005). In terra firme sites in north-eastern Peru, population densities of 2-2.5 individuals/km² were recorded (Puertas & Bodmer 1993).
range: Plecturocebus cupreus occurs south of the Río Amazonas/Rio Solimões, from the east bank of the Río Ucayali, in Loreto and northern Ucayali, Peru, to the west bank of the Rio Purús. To the south it ranges into Acre as far as the headwaters of the Rios Juruá and Purús in Brazil, and north-east as far as the lower and middle Rio Juruá and extending into the Rios Juruá/Purús interfluve south (Aquino & Encarnación 1994; Hershkovitz 1990; van Roosmalen et al. 2002). Van Roosmalen and colleagues (2002) suggest that P. cupreus and P. moloch groups are ecologically similar and therefore allopatric, but members of these groups are sympatric with species from the torquatus group.
useTrade: Opportunistically hunted for bush meat, tails used as dusters, live animals as pets
conservationActions: In Brazil, the species is found in the Parque Nacional Serra do Divisor, in several indigenous reserves (Terras Indígenas), biological reserves (Reservas Biológicas), national forests (Florestas Nacionais), and extractive reserves (Reservas Extrativistas). In Peru, the species is found in the in the Reserva Nacional Matses and Area de Conservación Regional Comunal Tamshiyacu-Tahuayo.  It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to its relatively large range in a pristine region of the Amazon, and because there are no known major threats believed to be resulting in a decline sufficient to qualify it for listing in a threatened category.
habitat:
There are no data available on the ecology of this species. Titi monkeys are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (E. Heymann pers. comm. 2008), and Plecturocebus donacophilus drier forests (Ferrari et al. 2000; R. Wallace pers. comm.). Species of the Plecturocebus genus are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (van Roosmalen et al. 2002).

The diet of titis comprises mainly fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds. They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small home (1.5-30 km²) and day ranges (0.5-1.5 km²).
threats: This species occurs in a remote part of the Amazon, and there are currently no known major threats.
population: There is no information available on the population status of this species.
range:
Central Amazonia, Amazonas state, Brazil, south of the Rio Solimões in the interfluve delineated by the lower Rios Purús, Solimões and Madeira, south as far as the Rio Ipixuna (or Paranapixuna). Hershkovitz (1990) considered the species sympatric with Plecturocebus dubius, P. brunneus, and P. cupreus, based on, in his view, mislabeled specimens collected by the Olalla brothers in Boca Río Inuya, Iquitos, Río Orosa, Río Tapiche and Sarayacu, Rio Ucayali, in the department of Loreto, Peru. Voss and Emmons (1996) note that Hershkovitz' report on the sympatry of two members of the moloch Group (P. cupreus and P. caligatus) was an error caused by "inadvertently listing both original and revised identifications of the same series from Orosa among the specimens examined". The correct identification for the monkeys is Plecturocebus (cupreus) cupreus. Specimens collected by Peres (1993) along both banks of the Rio Juruá and deposited in the Muséu Goeldi, Belém, all were identified as Plecturocebus (cupreus) cupreus (van Roosmalen et al. 2002).

The geographic distribution for P. caligatus described above contradicts that given by Hershkovitz (1990), who fills in its actual distribution with P. dubius. Four specimens of P. caligatus were caught in July 2001 by locals along the north bank of Lago Jarí at the mouth of Igarapé Bacaba and released at the same place after being measured and photographed, and a complete skeleton with some hair found on the forest floor was collected (private collection no. MGMR55) on the north bank of Rio Ipixuna near its mouth, a few kilometers south of the town of Tapauá.
Byrne et al. (2016) proposed that Plecturocebus dubius is a junior synonym of P. caligatus, and that thus the distribution of P. caligatus should include that of P. dubius. Therefore, this species’ distribution would be Central Amazonia, south of the Rio Solimões in the interfluve delineated by the Rios Purús, and Madeira, possibly as far south as the Rio Ituxi (a right bank tributary of the Purus), where it would be limited by the presence of the newly reinstated species P. toppini. (Vermeer and Tello-Alvarado, 2015). However, this taxonomic change is still under debate, and we will regard both taxa as valid until further evidence has been published.
conservationActions: The species is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to its relatively large range and because there is no evidence that it is undergoing a decline that would warrant listing it in a threatened category.
habitat: No data on the ecology of this species are available. Titi monkeys are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (Heymann pers. comm., 2008) and Plecturocebus donacophilus drier forests (Ferrari et al. 2000 & Wallace pers. comm.). Members of the Plecturocebus moloch and Plecturocebus cupreus groups are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (Roosmalen et al. 2002).The diet of titis comprises mainly of fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds. They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small home (1.5-30 ha) and day ranges (0.5-1.5 km).
threats: Although the species is hunted locally by indigenous people, hunting is not currently considered severe enough to be a major threat at present.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: Callicebus torquatus has a relatively wide range, and is the only titi monkey to be found in the Solimões-Negro interfluvium. It occurs in the state of Amazonas, on the left (north) bank of Rio Solimões/ Rio Japurá, west as far as Río Apaporis/ upper Río Vaupés, north delineated by Rio Negro/ Rio Uaupés, east at least as far as the town of Codajás, maybe even as far as the town of Manacapurú (Hershkovitz 1990; Roosmalen et al. 2002). Its distribution may extend into southeastern Colombia between the ríos Apaporis and Vaupés, where it probably intergrades with the distribution of Callicebus lugens (Ferrari et al. 2013). A recent study (Casado et al. 2007) suggests that C. lugens may also occur south of the Rio Negro, in the municipality of Barcelos in Brazil and that the two species may be sympatric, but further surveys are needed to confirm this.
conservationActions: This species occurs in Jaú National Park. It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to having a relatively large range in a region that is still secure from anthropogenic impact, and there is no evidence of any major threats resulting in a decline that would qualify the species for listing in a threatened category.
habitat:
Monção et al. (2008) mentioned Plecturocebus bernhardi occurring in secondary growth forest. Titi monkeys (Plecturocebus spp.) are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (E. Heymann pers. comm. 2008), and P. donacophilus drier forests (Ferrari et al. 2000; R. Wallace pers. comm.). Members of the P. moloch and P. cupreus groups are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (van Roosmalen et al. 2002).
The diet of titis comprises mainly fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds. They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small home (1.5-30 km²) and day ranges (0.5-1.5 km²).
threats: This species occurs in a remote region still relatively isolated from anthropogenic impact, and there are currently no known major threats.
population: Two sighting rates with an average of 0.19 / 10 Km were recorded in Ipixuna Indigenous Land (Cardozo & Vale Junior-2012).
range: Prince Bernhard's Titi monkey is endemic to Brazil, it is present in the states of Amazonas and Rondônia as a resident and native and Mato Grosso as native and uncertain presence (Veiga 2008b).Occurs between the Madeira and Aripuana rivers, with its northern boundary given by this confluence, the eastern boundary is defined by Madeira and Jiparaná rivers in the states of Amazonas and Rondônia. Although (Van Roosmalen et al. 2002) have inferred distribution also between the rivers Aripuanã and Roosevelt, the recent description of Plecturocebus miltoni (Dalponte, Ennes e Silva Jr. 2014) excludes it from that region. The distribution can be expanded to the southwest, south of Ji-Parana river near the headwaters, in the municipality of Alto Alegre dos Parecis, Rondônia, as noted by Monção et al. (2008).There is a possible sighting of the taxon in a 50 ha reserve in Alta Floresta (Mato Grosso) (Stepp 2003), which needs confirmation. The geographical distribution of Plecturocebus bernhardi, Plecturocebus cinerascens and Plecturocebus hoffmannsi, can overlap in the area of ​​the headwaters of the Juruena river, Aripuanã and Roosevelt (Veiga 2008b).
conservationActions: Thought to occur in Alta Floresta Reserve in Mato Grosso State in Brazil (Stepp 2003). There are Plecturocebus bernhardi records in the Sustainable Development Reserve of Juma (van Roosmalen et al. 2002) and Indigenous Land Ipixuna (215,000 ha) (Cardoso & Vale Junior 2012), both in the Amazon. It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to its relatively large range in a remote part of the Amazon, occurrence in protected areas, and because there is no evidence of a decline that would warrant listing in a threatened category. In Ecuador, however, it is considered Vulnerable (A4c), since it has a small, restricted area of occurrence (only in certain forests north of the Aguarico River) that is affected by deforestation.
habitat:
Studies on habitat preferences and home range undertaken in Ecuador (Campos 1991; Campos et al. 1992; de la Torre et al. 1995) suggest that C. lucifer exhibits a preference for non-flooded terra firme forest in north-eastern Ecuador and it has been suggested that in Peru, this species may be restricted to "varillales", forests on white-sand or sandy-clay soils (E. W. Heymann pers. comm.). 
Group size in this species varies from 2-5 individuals (E. W. Heymann, E. Palacios pers. comm.)
threats: In Ecuador, the species is considered Vulnerable (A4c). It has a small, restricted area of occurrence (only in certain forests north of the Aguarico River) that is largely affected by deforestation. Elsewhere, it occurs in a remote part of the Amazon, which has generally suffered low levels of impact.
population: This species has been recorded at population densities estimated between 2.5 and 2.8 individuals/km² in Peru (E. W. Heymann pers. comm.). In Colombia surveys in indigenous communities in the lower Río Caquetá showed densities between 1.1 and 5.4 individuals/km² (Palacios 2003), and between 4.6 and 6.8 individuals/km² in four sites in Río Puré National Park (Palacios unpublished data).
range:
Occurs in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador and Perú. Present in the interfluve between the Rio Solimões and Río Napo in the south, and the Rio Japurá and Río Caquetá in the north; in Brazil between the Rios Solimões and Japurá; in Colombia between the Ríos Caquetá below mouth of Río Caguán, and Rios Putumayo and Amazonas in the departments of Caquetá, Putumayo and Amazonas; in Ecuador between the upper Ríos Aguarico and Putumayo, Napo province (van Roosmalen et al. 2002); and in Peru in northern Loreto, north of the Río Amazonas between the Ríos Putumayo and Napo, but does not occur between the Riós Napo and Nanay as suggested by van Roosmalen and colleagues (E. W. Heymann pers. comm.). The titi monkey found south of the lower Río Nanay (Heymann et al. 2002), between the right bank of the riós Nanay and lef bank of the lower Ríos Tigre and Pucacuro, may represent a new taxon (E. W. Heymann pers. comm.).
Martinez and Rowe (2003) confirmed that it is C. lucifer that occurs in Ecuador and not C. medemi as suggested by van Roosmalen et al. (2002).
conservationActions: Occurs in the Cuyabeno Reserve in Northeastern Ecuador (De la Torre et al. 1995) and in Amacayacú National Park (293.500 ha), Río Puré National Park (999.980 ha), and Cahuinarí National Park (575.500 ha). In Brazil, the species has been recorded in ESEC Juami-Japurá (8315245 ha) and the RDS Mamirauá (1310802 ha) (Rylands & Bernardes 1989). It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because it occurs in protected areas and there is no evidence of a decline that would warrant listing in a threatened category. This species has an extensive geographic range over the most remote part of Amazonia. Due to its small size it is not targeted by local people. Widow monkeys are hunted by the Yanomami as a source of meat but only when preferred species are not found.
habitat:
Cheracebus lugens occurs in terra firme forests, evergreen and montane forests, and a complex of transitional forests between tropical rainforests and Rio Negro caatinga (campinarana). 
A study of C. lugens reported that its diet consisted mainly of fruits, immature seeds, leaves, leaf buds, liana tips, and stems, flowers, and insects and spiders (Palacios et al. 1997). A mean group size of 3.5 individuals was recorded in Vichada in eastern Colombia (Defler 2003). The species is commonly observed along river banks feeding on liana fruits and also along the road from Sao Gabriel da Cachoeira in Brazil to Cucuy in Colombia.
threats: Occurs in a relatively remote region, and there are currently no known major threats to the species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: This species has the largest range of the Cheracebus genus, occurring between the Rios Branco and Negro rivers in Brazil stretching as far north as the Rio Orinoco in Venezuela and the upper Caquetá in Colombia. Occurs in eastern Colombia in the departments of Vichada, Meta east of the Río Ariari, Guainiá, Guaviare, Vaupés, and Caquetá east of the Río Caguán, between the Río Tomo in the north and Río Caguán-Caquetá in the south; in southern Venezuela, in the state of Amazonas south of the Río Ventuari, and state of Bolívar between the Ríos Caura, Caroni, and Orinoco; and bordering parts of north-western Brazil, in Amazonas state north of the Rios Uaupés-Negro, and the state of Roraima west of the Rio Branco, north as far as the foothills of Mount Roraima (personal observations by M.G.M. van Roosmalen) (van Roosmalen et al. 2002). Byrne et al. (2016), Boubli et al. (2005, 2015) and Casado et al. (2007) report that this species occurs along the right bank of the Rio Negro, although presenting genetic differences which could be described as a cryptic species or at least sub-speces of C. lugens.
conservationActions:
Occurs in various protected areas including, the following national parks:

El Tuparro, Chiribiquete, Puinavia and Nukak (CO) (Defler 2003)
Pico da Neblina National Park (BR)
Serra do Araca State Park (BR)
Estacao Ecologica do Niquia (BR)
Serra da Mocidade NP (BR)
Yanomami Indigenous Territory (BR)
Serrania de la Neblina NP (VE)
Imeri  Tamacuari National Park (VE)

It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to its relatively large range, although naturally rare, and because there is no evidence that it is undergoing a decline that would warrant listing in a threatened category.
habitat: No data on the ecology of this species are available. Titi monkeys are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (Heymann pers. comm., 2008) and Plecturocebus donacophilus drier forests (Ferrari et al. 2000 & Wallace pers. comm.). Members of the Plecturocebus moloch and Plecturocebus cupreus groups are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (Roosmalen et al. 2002).The diet of titis comprises mainly of fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds. They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small home (1.5-30 ha) and day ranges (0.5-1.5 km).Size: Adult male: HB 33.1cm, TL 47.8cm (Hershkovitz, 1990); weight 1.1-1.5kg (for Cheracebus torquatus) (Kinzey, 1981)Adult female: HB 32.5cm (23.2-36), TL 45.8cm (42.5-49.3) (for C. torquatus) (Hershkovitz, 1990); weight 1.15-1.46kg (for C. torquatus) (Kinzey, 1981)
threats: There are no known major threats to this species at present.
population: There is no information available on the population status of this species.
range: Occurs in Brazil (endemic) in the state of Amazonas, between the upper Rio Solimões, the lower Rio Javarí, and the west bank of the Rio Juruá, from the mouth at the Rio Solimões to about 7ºS (Hershkovitz 1990). This species is sympatric with Plecturocebus cupreus in the Juruá-Solimões interfluve (Veiga 2008).
conservationActions: Present in the following Amerindian Reserves: Rio Biá and do Vale do Javari. May also occurs in Jutaí-Solimões Biological Reserve (Rylands & Bernardes, 1989).It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to its relatively large range, and because there is no evidence that it is undergoing a decline that would warrant listing in a threatened category.
habitat: An inhabitant of igapó (seasonally flooded forest), but also seen in terra firme (rainforest), (Haugaasen and Peres 2005). Average group size at Lago Uauaçú was 3.3 individuals.
threats: There are no known major threats to this species at present.
population: Very little is known about the population status of this species. Apparently it prefers riparian forests. It has been recorded at population densities of 0.4 individuals/km² in terra firme forests and 1.8 individuals/km² in igapó (Haugaasen and Peres 2005).
range: This species occurs in the State of Amazonas, Brazil, south of the Rio Solimões between the Rios Purús and Juruá, south as far as the Rio Tapauá or even the Rio Pauiní (if the species reported to occur in between the Rios Tapauá and Pauiní does not represent a new form).
useTrade: This species is used as a pet in rural communities.
conservationActions: Present in Abufari Biological Reserve (233,864 ha) (Rylands & Bernardes 1989), RESEX Catuá-Ipixuna (217,486 ha) (Moraes et al. 2006) e Tefé National Forest (865,126 ha) (Rossato et al. 2011). Also present in the Maratu and Tatutu Amerindian Reserves.This species is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to its relatively large range, and because there do not seem to be any major threats resulting in a significant range-wide decline sufficient to qualify it for listing in a threatened category.
habitat:
Titi monkeys (Plecturocebus spp.) are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, varying from primary and secondary forest, deciduous, semi-deciduous, evergreen, white-sand forests, terra-firme, gallery, flooded, dry and moist, etc. (Bicca-Marques and Heymann 2013). Members of the P. moloch and P. cupreus groups are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (van Roosmalen et al. 2002). de la Torre et al. (1995) suggest that P. discolor exhibits a preference for flooded forest (Várzea) in north-eastern Ecuador, but they also use lowland terra firma forest (Youlatos and Rivera 1999). In Colombia it was observed in low and poorly-developed forests, often along rivers and possibly also in flooded forest (Defle 1994). In Peru it was observed in flooded forest, terra firma forest, white sand forest and tropical dry forest (Jan Vermeer, pers. observations). 
In Yasuni, the titi monkeys used primarily liana forest, high forest and tree fall edges. In 62.5% of the encounters the animals were found below 10m. Groups were composed of a pair with one or two infants. Locomotion was dominated by quadrupedal walking; leaping from and to vertical supports was rare. They fed equally on ripe fruits and young leaves and insect foraging was an important activity (Youlatos and Rivera 1999). In another study in the same locality a C. discolor group used 3.3 ha and consumed principally fruits, seeds and flowers of 30 different plant species. (Carrillo-Bilbao et al. 2005).
threats: In Ecuador, the species is considered Near Threatened (Tirira 2011) due to the high rates of deforestation and forest fragmentation in large areas of its range. There are no major threats throughout most of its range in Peru, however much of the western margins of this species range suffers from high levels of deforestation and the species is found in the illegal pet trade in northern Peru (S. Shanee unpublished data). The species is considered Vulnerable in Colombia; it has a restricted range in in a region subject to petroleum exploration, coca plantations and their destruction with herbicides by the government, making conservation activities very difficult (Defler and Bueno 2010, Defler 2013).
population: This species is generally very abundant throughout its distribution range, and although it is sometimes difficult to observe it can be heard calling in the early morning. A density of over 57 individuals/km² has been recorded in Ecuador (Dacier et al. 2011).
range: This species occurs in the upper Amazonian region, in Peru north of the Río Marañon between the Ríos Napo and Santiago and south of the Río Marañon between the Ríos Huallaga and Ucayali, with known populations north of the Río Napo, west of the Río Huallaga and east of the Río Ucayali (Aquino and Encarnación 1994, Brooks and Pando-Vasquez 1997, Shanee et al. 2013, Vermeer and Tello-Alvarado 2015, Proyecto Mono Tocón, unpublished data). The species is also known in the area between the Río Marañon and the Cordillera Cahuapanas (Vermeer et al. 2011); in Ecuador from the Andean foothills east to the Río Napo/Aguarico basin, and north to the Río Putumayo; and in Colombia between the rios Guamués and San Miguel.
useTrade: Has been found in illegal trade in Peru (S. Shanee unpublished data)
conservationActions:
Occurs in the Cuyabeno Wildlife Reserve Limoncocha National Biological Reserve, Cayambe-Coca Ecological Reserve, Yasuni National Park and Sumaco Napo-Galeras National Park in Ecuador; In Peru the species occurs probably in the Tingo Maria, Cordillera Azul and Güeppi-Sekime National Parks; in the Airo Pai, Huimeki, El Sira and Yanesha Comunal Reserves; in the Pucacuro, Pacaya Samiria and Allpahuyo-Mishana National Reserves; in the Tamshiyacu Tahuayo, Imiria, Alto Nanay-Pintuyacu-Chambira and Ampiyacu Apayacu Regional Conservation Areas; in the Yaguas Reserved Zone; the San Matías - San Carlos Protected Forest and possibly in some smaller private conservation areas.
It is listed on CITES Appendix II. The species does not occur in any protected area in Colombia.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient in light of a complete lack of information on its distribution, ecology and threats. The type locality is unknown and the species phylogenetic relationships with P. caligatus has not been determined. This species should be a priority for future research.
habitat: There are no data available on the ecology of this species. Titi monkeys  are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (E. Heymann pers. comm. 2008), and Plecturocebus donacophilus drier forests (Ferrari et al. 2000, R. Wallace pers. comm.). Species of the Plecturocebus genus are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (van Roosmalen et al. 2002).The diet of titis comprises mainly fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds. They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small home (1.5-30 km) and day ranges (0.5-1.5 km).
threats: There is no information on major threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: Van Roosmalen et al. (2002) posited that C. stephennashi should occur along the right bank of the Rio Purús between the distributions of C. caligatus and C. dubius in Brazil. As a possible distribution, they suggested the interfluvium of the Rios Purús/Ipixuna/Madeira/Mucuím.
conservationActions: It is not known whether the species occurs in any protected areas.It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to its relatively large range in a pristine region of the Amazon, and because there are no known major threats believed to be resulting in a decline sufficient to qualify it for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: Titi monkeys are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences. Members of the moloch and cupreus groups are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (van Roosmalen et al. 2002). Plecturocebus cinerascens was seen in terra firme, campinarana and secondary forests (Noronha et al. 2007). Individuals were frequently observed in relatively open areas of young secondary growth, which may indicate a degree of flexibility in habitat use by this species (Noronha et al. 2007; Gusmao & da Costa 2014). The diet of titis comprises mainly fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds. They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small home (1.5-30 km²) and day ranges (0.5-1.5 km²).
threats: The southern portion of the species distribution is located in a highly fragmented landscape (Gusmao and da Costa 2014). Also, in middle Aripuana, 7 hydroelectric schemes are expected to be implemented in the next years (ANEEL, 2012).
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: Van Roosmalen et al. (2002) predicted that the species extends as far east as the left bank of the Rio Sucundurí. A survey conducted by Noronha et al. (2007) extended the eastern limit of this species range to the left bank of the rivers Abacaxís, Tapajós and Juruena, in the states of Amazonas and Mato Grosso in Brazil. Sampaio et al. (2012) and Gusmao & da Costa (2014) recorded the species in Rondonia State, extending its distribution until the right bank of Guapore River. It is possible that the ranges of Plecturocebus bernhardi, P. cinerascens and P. miltoni, intergrade in some way in the region of the headwaters of the Juruena, Aripuanã and Roosevelt Rivers.  Recently, Dalponte et al. (2014) described a new species of titi monkey (Plecturocebus miltoni) from the Aripuana-Roosevelt interfluve. This species’ range should extend to the Rio Paraná do Urariá in the north, east to the left bank of the Rio Abacaxís, and the left bank of the upper Rio Tapajós, west as far as the right bank of the Rio Madeira, and south to the corridor formed between the Rios Aripuanã-Roosevelt and Tapajós-Juruena, in the states of Amazonas and Mato Grosso.
conservationActions: Its range includes the following protected reserves in the state of Amazonas: Floresta Nacional Jatuarana (837,100 ha), the Parque Nacional do Juruena (2,002,565 ha), the Floresta Estadual Sucundurí (492,905 ha), and the Parque Estadual do Sucundurí (808,312 ha). Also present in the Floresta Estadual de Apuí (185,946 ha), the Reserva de Desenvolvimento Sustentável Bararatí (113,606 ha), the Parque Estadual do Guariba (72,296 ha), the Reserva Extrativista do Guariba (150,465 ha), the Floresta Estadual do Aripuanã (336,040 ha) and the Reserva de Desenvolvimento Sustentável Aripuanã (224,291 ha). In Mato Grosso, it is expected to occur in the Reserva Extrativista Guariba Roosevelt (57,630 ha), the Floresta Estadual Rio Roosevelt (27,860 ha) and the Parque Estadual Igarapés do Juruena (227,800 ha) (Noronha et al. 2007). In addition, Sampaio et al. (2012) included the species in the following Protected Areas: Estação Ecológica de Iquê and Estação Ecológica do Rio Flor do Prado. The species is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Although this species has a restricted range, it is listed as Least Concern. There is no indication of any anthropogenic threats for the time being and no suggestion that the species is currently undergoing a significant decline.
habitat: There are no data available on the ecology of this species. Titi monkeys  are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (E. Heymann pers. comm.) and Plecturocebus donacophilus dry forest (Ferrari et al. 2000; R. Wallace pers. comm.). Species of the Plecturocebus genus are considered to be tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activities or seasonal flooding (van Roosmalen et al. 2002).The diet of titis comprises mainly fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds. They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small home- (1.5-30 km²) and day ranges (0.5-1.5 km).
threats: Although this species has a small geographic range, it is relatively well protected by isolation from areas of human colonisation. Currently, there are no major threats.
population: There is no information available on the population status of this species.
range: According to van Roosmalen et al. (2002), Plecturocebus baptista has a disjunct distribution. It occurs in central Brazilian Amazonia, south of the Rio Amazonas, east of the Rio Madeira in the state of Amazonas (reaching almost as far as the state of Pará), and north of the Paraná do Canumã, Paraná do Urariá, and Paraná do Ramos (van Roosmalen et al. 2002). It was first seen in the wild on the west (left) bank of the Rio Uíra-Curupá, and is believed to have crossed over the Paraná do Ramos west of the town of Parintins forming an enclave population in the lower Rio Uíra-Curupá-Andirá interfluve. Further surveys are required in this area to establish the exact range.
conservationActions: A small part of the species' range is within the Andira Marau Amerindian Reserve.It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Plecturocebus ornatus is listed as Vulnerable in light of a continued decline inferred from more than a 30% loss of habitat in the past three generations (24 years), which is expected to continue at the same rate for the next three generations, due to a decline in area of occupancy and habitat quality as a consequence of deforestation caused by African palm oil expansion, petrol exploration and exploitation, illicit crops and expanding human settlements (Carretero-Pinzón 2013).
habitat:
Titi monkeys are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (Heymann pers. comm., 2008) and Plecturocebus donacophilus drier forests (Ferrari et al. 2000, Wallace pers. comm.). Members of the Plecturocebus moloch and Plecturocebus cupreus groups are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (Roosmalen et al. 2002). Plecturocebus ornatus typically occurs in lowland tropical forests (canopy 15-20 m) (Defler 2010) and disturbed habitats (Mason 1968). A recent research in San Martin area, in 100 forest fragments, found P. ornatus groups in fragments of gallery forest, lowland rainforest and Mauritia flexuosa swamps (Carretero-Pinzón and Defler, in prep).

The ecology of this species has been studied in the department of Meta by Mason (1965, 1966, 1966, 1968, and 1971) and Robinson (1977, 1979, 1979, 1981, and 1982). Polanco (1992) and Porras (2000) studied a population near the Duda River.
threats: This species occurs in an area subject to intense human colonization that has been subject to widespread habitat destruction and fragmentation. As mentioned by Carretero-Pinzón (2013) a reduction of 35% of their distribution area has occurred in the last decade. This habitat loss and fragmentation has been produced by cattle ranching, palm oil plantation extensions and petrol exploration and exploitation (Wagner et al. 2009, Carretero-Pinzón 2013).
population:
Robinson (1977) recorded a population density of five individuals/ km². Wagner et al. (2009) found higher densities (192.2 ind/ km2) in small fragments, while Carretero-Pinzón (2013) found lower densities (57.94 ind/ km2 and 1.073 ind/ km2) for range of fragments between 16 ha and 1,050 ha.

Carretero-Pinzón (2013) reported a 35% reduction of distribution area for this species between 2003 and 2013 caused by habitat loss and fragmentation. Habitat loss is continuing. As a result, it is suspected that the population has suffered a reduction of at least 30% over the last 24 years (three generations), and that this reduction is likely to continue over the next 24 years.
range: This species occurs in eastern Colombia, in the department of Cundinamarca (Medina) north as far as the lower Río Upía/ Río Meta, south into the department of Meta, along the base of the Cordillera Oriental and the Sierra de la Macarena to the Río Guayabero/ upper Río Guaviare. It is the only member of the cupreus and moloch group occurring north of the Rios Amazonas/ Solimões/ Napo axis, in the upper Río Orinoco basin and is separated from the nearest other member of the cupreus group (Plecturocebus discolor) in the south by at least 350 km (Roosmalen et al. 2002). Eastern limits are poorly known but probably extend beyond Metica River (Defler 2010).
conservationActions: This species occurs in La Macarena National Park and Tinigua National Park. Although some populations are found within protected areas, guerilla activity makes it difficult to monitor these areas (T. Defler pers comm.).It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Callicebus barbarabrownae is a rare species, endemic to the Caatinga of the states of Bahia and Sergipe in Brazil. It occurs in very low densities with the number of mature individuals estimated at fewer than 250, in subpopulations holding fewer than 50 mature individuals. Numbers are evidently still declining, due to loss and fragmentation of their habitat. It is not known to occur in any protected area. For these reasons Callicebus barbarabrownae is categorised as CR C2a(i).
habitat: Occurs in caatinga (dry scrubland) with a preferences for dense arboreal caatinga (Printes 2007). There is no available information on its ecology.
threats: This species occurs in a region of Brazil with widespread deforestation and habitat fragmentation. Cattle ranching, agriculture and continuing urbanisation are the main threats. The area is characterised by rapid development facilitated by an extensive network of highways. Other threats include potential dangers from roads and power-lines and predation by domestic pets. This species occurs in small fragmented populations that are exposed to synergistic genetic and demographic risks. Hunting pressure needs to be ascertained, but it is probably moderate due to the small body size. During surveys, a few individuals were found being kept as pets (Printes et al. 2013).
population: Based on the data of Printes et al. (2011) the total known population of Callicebus barbarabrownae is less than 1,000 individuals, and we infer that the number of mature individuals is less than 250.
range: Endemic to Brazil, the Blond Titi Monkey occurs in the states of Bahia (Hershkovitz 1990) and Sergipe at approximately 240-900 m asl (Printes 2007), from the Rio Paraguaçú basin to the border between the states of Bahia and Sergipe along the margins of the Rio Real. Prior to the survey of Printes (2005, 2007), this species was known from only four localities: Lamarão (type locality), Formosa, Bandeira de Melo and Mirorós in the municipality of Ibipeba all in the State of Bahia (Hershkovitz 1990, Marinho-Filho and Veríssimo 1997). However, the taxon has now been confirmed at over 55 sites in Bahia and Sergipe (Printes 2007, Estrela et al. 2007). In recent surveys (195 km) undertaken in Lamarão in Bahia, the species was registered in four locations, all caatinga scrubland fragments (Estrela et al. 2007), some considerably smaller than previously estimated (A. Estrela pers. comm). In the past, the coastal forests of the ‘Agreste’ in eastern Bahia probably supported large populations; however, this type of vegetation is rare today (Printes et al. 2011). Populations have been located in three main regions: Agreste, Lamarão and north of the Chapada Diamantina. No titis were recorded in the region west of Araci and Nova Soure, which is dominated by the Cerrado. However, C. barbarabrownae was recorded in the Caatinga of the moister uplands northeast of Araci (Mandacaru, Mirandela and Serra Branca). The species was also recorded in Caatinga habitat further north as far as the Salitre river, 170 km from Juazeiro, but titis were not recorded west of the Chapada Diamantina (Printes 2007, Printes et al. 2011) Callicebus melanochir replaces C. barbarabrownae in the region known as the ‘Recôncavo Baiano’ (south of the Paraguaçu river in the municipality of Igrapiuna). The lower Paraguaçú forms the limit between the geographic ranges of C. coimbrai, restricted to the left or north bank, and C. melanochir, found on the right bank. Further west, in the region of Feira de Santana, C. barbarabrownae occurs on both banks of the Paraguaçú. There appears to be no physical barrier between the eastern limit of the range of C. barbarabrownae and the western limit of C. coimbrai. An important population has been found in the arboreal caatinga of the Quiriri Indigenous Land, em Banzaê, Bahia. It has been recorded near Chapada Diamantina National Park, Lençóis, Bahia in the buffer zone of Sete Passagens State Park, Miguel Calmon, Bahia. The extent of occurrence of the Blond Titi Monkey is estimated to cover an area of some 291,438 km², but its area of occupancy is only thought to be 2,636 km² (Printes 2007, Printes et al. 2011).
conservationActions:
The species has not been seen in any officially protected area. Although is a record of its occurrence in the Raso da Catarina Ecological Station (104.843 ha) (Sousa et al. 2008), Printes and Rylands (2008) have not been able to confirm it.

It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern since there are no current major threats resulting in a significant range-wide population decline, and with a significant portion of its known range located within protected areas of Bolivia and Peru.
habitat: Found in the floodplain and piedmont forests on the lower hills of the Andes (less than 500 m asl), where it is more common in forests with a higher density of lianas (R. Wallace, pers. obs.). A six-months behavioural ecology study on Plecturocebus aureipalatii at the Hondo River study site within the Madidi National Park reported home range sizes of 17 to 25 ha for two study groups with more than 30 plant species consumed (P. De La Torre pers. comm.).
threats: Occasionally hunted, usually for fishing bait. However, hunting databases from several indigenous communities in the region hardly include this species. There is a general threat of habitat destruction related to road development, planned hydrocarbon exploration and exploitation, and sugarcane plantations. Proposed dams may also affect portions of known distribution.
range: Plecturocebus aureipalatii was recently described from the western lowlands of Bolivia (Wallace et al. 2006), from the piedmont forest at the base of the Andes in the South and from lowland humid riverine and floodplain forests. Primate surveys indicate that it occurs on the western side of the Río Beni (Wallace et al. 2006; Martinez and Wallace 2007; Martinez 2010). The western and northern distributional limits require further study but the Madre de Dios River may represent the distributional boundary. Preliminary data indicate that the species is not a Bolivian endemic, with localities extending into southern Peru until at least the Tambopata River (Ayala pers. comm.).
conservationActions: This species occurs in the Madidi National Park, in the Natural Area of Integrated Management in Bolivia, as well as in the Tambopata National Reserve and the Bahuaja-Sonene National Park in Peru. Assuming these protected areas remain intact; the conservation status of this species is not of immediate concern. It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to its relatively large range in a pristine region of the Amazon, and because there are no known major threats believed to be resulting in a decline sufficient to qualify it for listing in a threatened category.
habitat:
Rohe and Silva Jr. (2009) observed P. dubius occupying areas of ‘Campinarana’ and ‘terra-firme’ open canopy forests covered by palms. They also reported several individuals during an intraspecific agonistic interaction on an unpaved road that crosses the Rio Mucuim. The animals were on the right bank of the Rio Mucuim, close to the wooden bridge that crosses this river. This observation could imply a possible range expansion of P. dubius into the distributional range of P. stephennashi. The average group size observed in this study was approximately 3 individuals.
Titi monkeys are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (E. Heymann pers. comm. 2008), and Plecturocebus donacophilus drier forests (Ferrari et al. 2000; R. Wallace pers. comm.). Members of the P. moloch group are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (van Roosmalen et al. 2002).

The diet of titis comprises mainly fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds. They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small home (1.5-30 km) and day ranges (0.5-1.5 km).
threats: This species occurs in a remote isolated region of the Amazon, and is not considered to be under any immediate threat.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: According to Veiga (2008e) Plecturocebus dubius has a relatively large, but poorly known, range that includes parts of northern Bolivia, south-eastern Peru and three Brazilian states. It occurs between the Madeira and Purus rivers. In the northern boundary, it occurs on both banks of the river Mucuim (Rohe and Silva Jr. 2009) (but a better investigation is required between the Ipixuna and Mucuim rivers to verify co-occurrence with Plecturocebus stephennashi), and both right (east) bank tributaries of the Rio Purús.  The southern limit is unknown. Van Roosmalen et al. (2002) placed P. dubius in northern Bolivia, but Rowe and Martinez (2003) found no evidence to support this supposition, and P. brunneus is the species in the Pando, north and south of the Río Madre de Dios (R. Wallace pers. comm.)
conservationActions:
This species is present in the following Reserves.
Amazonas State: REBIO Abufari (233,864 ha) (Rylands and Bernardes 1989), Parque Nacional do Mapinguari (Rohe and Silva Jr 2009), TI Caititu (Veiga 2008e).
Rondônia State: ESEC Estadual Antônio Mujica Nava (18,281 ha) (Messias et al. 2001), ESEC Cuniã (186,743 ha) (M.R. Messias personal communication).
Rondônia e Amazonas: TI Kaxarari (Veiga 2008e).
It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Cacajao calvus is considered Vulnerable (under criterion A4cd) due to a suspected population reduction of at least 30% over the course of 30 years (three generations (2018-2048). This decline rate is supported by Global Forest Watch data from the Brazilian states of Amazonas and Acre and the Peruvian departments of Loreto and Ucayali, in which the species occurs. Should ongoing rates of forest loss continue, between 10-15% of the forest within this species’ range is likely to be lost by the middle of this century.  Combined with hunting, which is reported to be heavy in parts of this species’ range, these threats place Cacajao calvus at or above the Vulnerable level.
habitat:
Bald-headed Uacaris are habitat specialists that are limited primarily to white-water várzea habitats. In addition to their ecological range restrictions, their distribution along rivers makes them relatively more vulnerable to human impact. They are highly specialized seed predators, with immature seeds and fruits comprising the bulk of the diet. Uacaris live in large multi-male, multi-female groups with a fission-fusion social organization. Specialist habitat and feeding requirements may mean greater sensitivity to habitat modification. While other pitheciines (Chiropotes and Pithecia) have demonstrated a degree of tolerance and adaptability in the face of habitat disturbance, the capacity of uacaris to cope with anthropogenic disturbance is unknown.

Cacajao calvus calvus
This taxon is a habitat specialist that is primarily limited to flooded forests such as the lower Rio Juruá or the white-water várzea habitats of the low Rio Japurú. The White Bald-headed Uacari is a highly specialized seed predator, fruits and seeds are the most important food item and just a handful of tree species made up the bulk of the diet (Ayres 1986).

Cacajao calvus rubicundus
No field data on ecology are available for this subspecies.

Cacajao calvus ucayalii
Occurs in flooded forests, low to medium hill and high terrace forests, and palm swamps. As with other Bald Uacaris, Red Uacaris are specialized for the predation of seeds, with fruits and immature seeds making up the bulk of the diet. Mauritia flexuosa palm fruit was also the most important species in the diet of this taxon at Lago Preto, accounting for 20% of the annual diet (Bowler 2007).
threats:
The major threats to this species include forest loss and hunting. The distribution along rivers may make this taxon relatively more vulnerable to human impact, while specialist habitat and feeding requirements may result in greater sensitivity to habitat disturbance.

Cacajao calvus calvus
Although this subspecies is rarely hunted in its range because its appearance is considered too human-like (Ayres 1986), the main threat facing this primate is the reduction and transformation of its flooded forest habitat. The main forms of deforestation in the area, are small-scale agriculture and logging (Ayres and Johns 1987). Current data indicate that almost the entire (confirmed) population are included within the Mamirauá Sustainable Development Reserve and population densities appear to have increased in the 20 years up to 2005 (Ayres 1986, Paim 2005).

Cacajao calvus rubicundus
This species is hunted for food. It may be affected by habitat loss due to logging and forest loss especially along the main stream of the Amazon.

Cacajao calvus ucayalii
Surveys conducted between 1979 and 1986 (Aquino 1988) showed that the range was much reduced, hunting having exterminated the species in several areas. Aquino (1988) suggests that populations close to the Ucayali and Amazon Rivers have been greatly reduced and in some areas exterminated, caused by hunting and habitat disturbance. The Yavarí River and its tributary the Yaquerana represent the stronghold for remaining populations. Close to Iquitos, Mauritia flexuosa is extracted in large quantities by felling the palms (Bodmer et al. 1999, Meyer and Penn 2003); the unsustainable extraction of this resource may have an impact on Cacajao c. ucayalii in some areas (Bowler 2007). Logging concessions designated in 2004 cover around one-third of the geographic range of Cacajao c. ucayalii. While the selective removal of low-density, high-value timber species does not appear likely to have a great impact on populations of Cacajao c. ucayalii, the logging operations increase human populations and bushmeat hunting in remote parts of the range (Bowler 2007). Hunting levels on the Yavarí-Mirín and Yavarí have increased since 2004, when human populations increased due to logging activities. Bodmer et al. (2006) found that more wild meat was consumed per capita in a commercial forest concession on the Yavarí than in the nearby rural communities.

Cacajao calvus novaesi
This subspecies is affected to some degree by hunting and the exploitation of natural resources within the two extractive reserves where it occurs.
population:
Uacaris generally tend to occur at low densities. A population reduction of at least 30% is suspected over the course of three generations (30 years), including the current (2018-2028) and two subsequent generations (2028-2048), due habitat degradation and other threats.

Cacajao. calvus calvus
Average population densities in the region surrounding Mamirauá and Teiu Lakes (Mamirauá Reserve) were 10 individuals/km² (5 sites) in 1984/5 (Ayres 1986) and 17/km² (6 sites) in 2004/5 (Paim 2005).

Cacajao calvus ucayalii
In surveys undertaken in the Sierras de Contamana, part of the Sierra del Divisor located on the right margin of the Ucayali River, near the frontier with Brazil, this subspecies was recorded at an abundance of 479 individuals/100 km (Aquino 2005). Sites on the Yavarí and Yavarí-Mirín have some of the highest densities of (Puertas and Bodmer 1993; Salovaara et al. 2003). Jorge and Velazco (2006) discovered some new populations on the upper Tapiche River and on the Divisor ridges in the Zona Reservada Sierra del Divisor.
range:
This species is found in Brazil and Peru. The distribution of the Bald-headed Uacari is poorly known and field surveys are needed to resolve a series of issues related to the distribution and taxonomy of these taxa. Available data suggest that there is no range overlap among the subspecies of Cacajao calvus, although there may be a contact zone between Cacajao calvus calvus and Cacajao calvus rubicundus (Ayres 1986).

Global Forest Watch data from the Brazilian states of Amazonas and Acre and the Peruvian departments of Loreto and Ucayali, in which the species occurs, suggests that, should ongoing rates of forest loss continue, between 10-15% of the forest within this species’ range is likely to be lost by the middle of this century.

Cacajao calvus calvus has a restricted range, from the confluence of the rios Japurá and Solimões north-west between the two rivers connecting to either the Paraná Yaula, or the Furo or Paraná da Aranapa in Brazil (Hershkovitz 1987). Until recently, the White Bald-headed Uacari was considered endemic to Mamirauá Sustainable Development Reserve, but observations indicate the presence of this taxon in the region of the lower Juruá (Vira Volta), south of the Solimões (Silva Jr. pers. comm.). A new population of white uacaris was recorded from the Rio Jurupari, a tributary of the Rio Envira in the state of Amazons, about 750 km to south-west of the current range (Silva Jr. pers. comm.), and another sighting along the Alto Jurupari south of the town Feijó in the state of Acre (L. Veiga pers. comm.), but it has not yet been confirmed whether or not these are the same or distinct taxa (see Figueiredo 2006). Unlike most other Amazonian platyrrhines, uacaris tend to range along rivers rather than within interfluvia; várzea forests connect the two populations along the rivers between these two areas. No field data are available to determine if these populations are allopatric. The subspecies Cacajao c. novaesi occurs in the middle of these two populations (Silva, Jr. and Martins 1999).

The geographic range of Cacajao c. novaesi has been updated since first described by Hershkoivitz (1987) when it was thought to occur only on the south bank of the upper rio Juruá between the Rios Tarauacá and Eirú. Peres (1988, 1997) extended its range north-east of the range described by Hershkovitz (1987), on the left bank of the Juruá and at Lago da Fortuna, Carauari to the north. Populations of Cacajao calvus observed by Peres on the upper Juruá, and unconfirmed reports by Fernandes (1990) in the Brazilian state of Acre on the upper Juruá and Purus, are either of Cacajao calvus novaesi or Cacajao calvus ucayalii, which would extend the known ranges of either of these subspecies (Bowler 2007).

Cacajao c. rubicundus occurs in Brazil, with a relatively restricted (poorly known) range. It presents an apparent disjunct geographic distribution, known from an area situated in the Iça-Solimões interfluve in Amazonas (type locality: opposite the town of São Paulo de Olivença, north bank of the Solimões [Hershkovitz 1987]), and another near the mouth of the Auati-Paraná. Cacajao c. rubicundus also occurs south of the Solimões, west of the Jutaí River at the Jutaí-Solimões Ecological Station (Nogueira-Neto 1992). It may have formerly occurred in the Trapezium of Colombia, but if they did they are now believed to be extirpated.

Cacajao c. ucayalii is found south of the Amazon River in Peru between the Ucayali and Yavarí Rivers. In the past, its range probably extended as far as the Urubamba River (Hershkovitz 1987), but surveys undertaken in the 1980s suggest that the southern limit is now the Sheshea River (Aquino 1988). Hershkovitz (1987) claimed this taxon also occurs on the east bank of the lower Yavarí in Brazil. The subspecies has a patchy distribution. It may no longer be present on the Brazilian side of the Yavarí, and is absent from a long stretch on the Peruvian side, upriver from the mouth of the Yavarí-Mirín perhaps as far as Quebrada Curacinha close to the town of Colonia Angamos (Salovaara et al. 2003). On the Yavarí-Mirín, the species is present on a large of the North bank, but is absent from the south side of the river, except in the upper reaches. As noted earlier, populations of Cacajao calvus observed by Peres on the upper Juruá and unconfirmed reports by Fernandes (1990) in the Brazilian state of Acre on the upper Juruá and Purus, may be either of Cacajao calvus novaesi or Cacajao calvus ucayalii, which would extend the known ranges of either of these subspecies (Silva Jr.and Martins 1999).
useTrade: This species is hunted. Hunting is reported to be heavy in parts of this species’ range.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on CITES Appendix I. The Primate Protection Centre (Centro de Proteção de Primatas Brasileiros: ICM/CPB ), of the Federal Environmental Protection Institute (Instituto Chico Mendes), supports and coordinates primate conservation programmes throughout Brazil. An international committee (Comitê Internacional para Conservação e Manejo dos Primatas Amazônicos) was established by the the CPB and Instituto Chico Mendes (ICM) to discuss and define actions for the conservation of Amazonian primate taxa, and together with the members of the Pitheciine Action Group (PAG), is currently developing Conservation Action Plans for each of the four subspecies in Brazil.

A decree (No. 34-2004-AG) was published by the Peruvian government in 2004 that approves the categorization of threatened Peruvian wildlife and prohibits hunting, capturing, owning, transporting, and exportation for commercial purposes. It is hoped that this will help in conservation actions and stimulate research on threatened Peruvian wildlife (Heymann 2004).

Cacajao calvus calvus
This subspecies is protected within the Mamirauá Sustainable Development Reserve (Ayres et al. 1999).

Cacajao calvus novaesi
Afforded some protection within two extractive reserves, the Middle Juruá and the Upper Juruá, where hunting and the exploitation of natural resources are permitted.

Cacajao calvus rubicundus
Cacajao c. rubicundus should be relatively well protected as it occurs within the Jutaí-Solimões Ecological Station (284,285 ha), south of the rio Solimões (Nogueira-Neto 1992).

Cacjao calvus ucayalii
Until recently, the only protected area known to contain C. c ucayalii was the regional Tamshiyacu Tahuayo Communal Reserve (TTCR). The TTCR extends over an area of 322,500 ha, and is situated close to the city of Iquitos in upland forests between the Amazon and the Yavarí (Newing and Bodmer 2004). The reserve was created as a result of a strong alliance between local people and conservationists. The presence of Cacajao calvus ucayalii has become part of the justification for three areas either under proposal or newly created. These are the Sierra del Divisor Reserved Zone, the Lago Preto Conservation Concession (LPCC) and the proposed Greater Yavarí Reserve. Community conservation work is conducted by WCS-Peru and the Durrell Institute of Conservation and Ecology on the Yavari and Yavari-Mirin Rivers in Peru. This project aims to reduce the hunting of C. c. ucayalii in this area (Bowler 2007).

rationale: Although hunted by locals, its range is within one of the most pristine and preserved parts of the Amazon where human population densities are low and no development projects are planned for the near future, hence assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: No information on the habitat preference or ecology of this species is currently available.
threats: Little information on the threats facing this species is currently available.
population: No population information is currently available.
range: If confirmed that C. israelita deserves full species status and does not represent a junior synonym of C. chiropotes, the boundary separating these two taxa is the Rio Orinoco (Amazonas State, Venezuela), with the former being restricted to the left bank and the latter to the right bank.  In Brazil, C. israelita is restricted to the Rio Branco – Rio Marauia interfluvial area (left bank of the Rio Negro in Amazonas and Roraima States).

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because it is very wide ranging over a very large part of the northeastern Amazon where vast expanses of forest remain intact and very little disturbed. Although the northern and eastern limits of its geographic range are not known, and the taxonomic arrangement for the members of this wide-ranging genus is still precarious, the name Cebus castaneus is currently ascribed to the wedge-capped capuchin known to occur over a large part of the Guiana Shield, north of the lower Amazon and east of the Atlantic Coast, in the northeastern Amazon in Brazil, extending into French Guiana, Suriname and Guyana.
habitat:
In Suriname, Cebus castaneus is for the most part restricted to undisturbed high forest, although it is occasionally seen in liana forest and mountain savanna forest as well. Although Mittermeier and van Roosmalen (1981) never observed C. olivaceus along rivers in Suriname, Muckenhirn et al. (1975) sighted four groups in river edge forest in Guyana. However, it is not clear from their description if the sightings were in marsh forest or riverbank high forest. They are absent from lowland alluvial plains of the Rio Amazonas and from the coastal plains in the state of Amapá (Brazil), French Guiana, Suriname and Guyana.Cebus castaneus is shy and scarce. It forages in small, dispersed subgroups or in foraging columns that stretch over a considerable distance, up to 150 m. Accurate group counts are difficult to make but the evidence suggests that they are generally a little larger than those of the tufted capuchin, Cebus apella, and larger groups may contain two or more breeding males.

Head and body of type specimen, sex unknown: 455 mm
Tail of type of type specimen, sex unknown: 525 mm
threats: No threats information is currently available.
population: No information on the population of this species is available.
range: Poorly known but current understanding has it in the northeastern Amazon, north of the lower Rio Amazonas on the upland Guiana Shield (but not in the relatively narrow, alluvial plain), east of the Rio Negro, and both sides the Rio Branco, possibly as far as the Rio Demini (a northern tributary of the Rio Negro), north into the Territorio Federal Amazonas of Venezuela, east of the upper Río Orinoco and Río Ventuari, and east through the state of Roraima to Guyana. Not found along the coastal plains of Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana and Amapá, Brazil.
conservationActions: In Suriname, they occur in the following protected areas: Raleighvallen-Voltzberg Nature Reserve (56,000 ha), Tafelberg Nature Reserve (140,000 ha), Eilerts de Haan Gebergte Nature Reserve (220,000 ha) – all within the 1,600,000-ha Central Suriname Nature Reserve – Brownsberg Nature Park (8,400 ha). Sipaliwini Savanna Nature Reserve (100,000 ha) (Mittermeier and van Roosmalen 1982). They are believed to occur in the Brinckheuvel Nature Reserve (6,000 ha) but this has not been verified.  In Guyana, they occur in the Kaieteur Falls National Park (11,655 ha) and the Iwokrama Forest Reserve (364,000 ha) to the west of the middle Essequibo River (Sussman and Phillips-Conroy 1995). In French Guiana, Nouragues Natural Reserve (100,000 ha), La Trinité Natural Reserve, and Kaw Reserved Area (76,800 ha). In Brazil, the Montanhas de Tumucumaque National Park (3,867,000 ha), and possibly Mote Roraima National Park (116,000 ha) and Maracá Ecological Station (101,312 ha).

rationale: The habitat in which Presbytis mitrata lives is experiencing conversion to agriculture and the species is targeted for illegal collecting for the pet trade. Although forest loss has almost certainly exceeded 70% over the last three generations (approximately 30 years) in the well-known area where this species occurs, it is suspected that at least 30% of the population has declined in the past. Due to ongoing threats the population is expected to continue to decline in the near future.
habitat: This species could be found in disturbed forest, primarily in understory, of primary, secondary forest, rubber plantations. It is considered tolerant of habitat conversion and to survive well in primary and secondary forest. They eat young leaves, mature leaves, unripe raw fruit, and seeds. It is a diurnal and arboreal species, with a home range of 14-29.5 ha. Daily distance travelled is around 300-1,360 m.
threats:
There has been extensive loss of habitat, especially for oil palm plantations, and this is a serious threat. However, the species has some tolerance to forest conversion, but not to complete replacement of forests. Trapping of the species for the illegal pet trade is a threat across their range, with some incidental hunting for food.

Patchy occurrence in disturbed forest though believed to cope well in such degraded habitat: habitat conversion and habitat degradation for Palm Oil Plantation. The pet trade is another threat and the current scenario of hunting and trapping is described as ‘heavy’. Field research necessary to understand distribution and intra-specific geographic variations.
population: The population is suspected to have declined by more than 30% in 30-35 years due to extensive habitat loss from conversion to agriculture. The species is targeted for illegal collecting for the pet trade.
range: South eastern Sumatra, from Batang Hari River, south-west to the upper Musi River drainage, eastern Barisan range, south of Lampung Province. Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park, Way Kambas National Park in Sumatra are two protected (Ami and Baker 1992, 1996) areas sheltering the species (Meyer et al. 2011).
useTrade: This species is illegally collected for the pet trade.
conservationActions: The species is included in CITES Appendix II.

rationale: The habitat in which Presbytis sumatranus lives is experiencing conversion to agriculture and the species is targeted for illegal collecting for the pet trade. Although forest loss has probably exceeded 70% over 30 years, the population is suspected to have declined by 50% in three generations (30 years approximately) and is continuing to decline.
habitat: This species inhabits secondary growth forests, lowland and hill rainforests, and old growth forest. As for Presbytis bicolour, this langur feeds on raw, unripe fruit, young leaves, mature leaves, seeds and flowers. No studies in the wild on these langurs but presumed to live in one male (multi female?) groups, defending ‘exclusive’ territories.
threats: The main threats to this langur are illegal pet trade, extensive degradation in the habitat range (more than 50% of forest loss over the past 30 years).
population: The species is suspected to be declining at a rapid rate due to massive ongoing habitat loss from conversion to agriculture and illegal collecting for the pet trade.
range: Presbytis sumatranus occurs in Western and North Central Sumatra (Northern Islands and the western coasts, south of Simpang Kiri River, North of Gunung Talamay, E coast of Wampu River, Barumun River, South East Rokan River and Batu Islands). It occurs in the Batang Gadis National Park (Meyer et al. 2011).
useTrade: It is illegally caught for the pet trade.
conservationActions: The species is included in CITES Appendix II.

rationale:
This species is considered Endangered due to a past and continued population decline, estimated at more than 50% over the past 40 years (three generations) due to hunting and loss of habitat (Whittaker 2006).

In 1986, Presbytis potenziani was listed as “Indeterminate,” and then evaluated as “Endangered” in 1988. Its status was downgraded to “Vulnerable” in 1996 (IUCN 2004) and then upgraded again to “Endangered” (IUCN 2008)  under criteria A2cd, which state that the species is facing a very high risk of extinction in the wild due to “(A) a reduction in population size based on […] (2) an observed, estimated, inferred, or suspected population size reduction of ≥50% over the last 10 years or three generations, whichever is the longer, where the reduction or its causes may not have ceased OR may not be understood OR may not be reversible, based on […] (c) a decline in area of occupancy, extent of occurrence and/or quality of habitat and (d) actual or potential levels of exploitation.”

All these assessments were at the species-level, consequently including the former subspecies P. p. potenziani (now: P. potenziani) and P. p. siberu from Siberut (now: P. siberu). The latter was initially assessed “Vulnerable” (2000) and then upgraded to “Endangered” in 2008 due to a past and continued population decline, estimated at more than 50% over the past 40 years (3 generations) due to hunting and loss of habitat (Whittaker 2006).

Although Whittaker’s evaluation suggests a rather substantial population decline, even on Siberut (where much more suitable habitat is still available compared to the southern islands), newer survey data from the National Park indicates, that the Siberut Langur is the most abundant of the four Siberut primates within the protected area, estimating a total population of 17,384 (11,014-27,439) individuals within the National Park alone (Quinten et al. 2015). Thus, the total population on Siberut is likely substantially higher than the 1,600–9,500 individuals Whittaker previously assumed (given that the circumstances/threats faced by the species have not actually changed, it is unlikely that the species has recuperated in between assessments). Nevertheless, at the same time, P. siberu is still the second most hunted primate on Siberut Island and annual off-take rates appear to be at least 17% if not much higher (see Quinten et al. 2014). None of the other primates on Siberut faces a higher off-take, when based on estimated population size.
habitat:
Presbytis siberu is a diurnal and arboreal primate inhabiting the ever-wet rainforests of Siberut Island (rainfall of up to 4000 mm), where it is sympatric with Macaca siberu, Simias concolor, and Hylobates klossii.
