This species is listed as Critically Endangered because of a serious reduction in population size suspected to be more than 80% based on a decline in the forested habitat available over the past three generations (48 years). Populations remain in a few protected areas (e.g., PN Cerros de Amotape, RN de Tumbes, R. Manglares Churute, R. Mache Chindul, PN Machalilla, Pacoche Marine and Coastal Wildlife Refuge and small private reserves in the northern western slopes of the Andes) across its range.

Where the species persists it is persecuted as a crop pest by farmers. In other areas it is hunted for bushmeat and for the pet trade.
habitat: Dry forest in lowlands to wet montane Andean forest.  Jack and Campos (2012) report C. aequatorialis preference for “relatively flat, high-elevation, well-forested, semi-evergreen areas close to streams” in Cerro Blanco, Ecuador.  C. aequatorialis can exploit both disturbed mature and secondary forest.  A MAXENT analysis by Campos and Jack (2013) suggests that environmental conditions ideal for supporting C. aequatorialis include more equal than 25% tree cover, mild temperature seasonality, annual precipitation less than 2,000 mm, and low human population density.
threats: The species is affected by deforestation and hunting for bushmeat and the pet trade. Forests in the western lowlands of Ecuador have been severely reduced in the past century. It is considered a pest in plantations of corn (maize), bananas, plantain and cacao, and is persecuted and hunted for this reason. Captive animals have been observed in local villages in western Ecuador and in the Huaquillas market at the Ecuador-Perú boundary.From their habitat suitability assessment, Campos and Jack (2013) prioritise four areas for conservation action, in descending priority: Chongon-Colonche mountain range; Mache-Chindul and Jama-Coaque mountain ranges; North-West Peru Biosphere Reserve; and Andean foothills of southern Ecuador.
population: An ongoing population reduction of greater 80% over the past three generations (48 years) is suspected from loss of forested habitat available.
range: This species is distributed in western lowland Ecuador (from the Guayllabamba-Esmeraldas rivers to the south, with Bilsa Biological Station in Mache-Chindul National Park the northernmost locality) and NW Peru (Tumbes, the southernmost locality is PN Cerros de Amotape; Mittermeier et al. 2013). While most known sites are near the Pacific coast, some new localities have also been reported further inland in the Ecuadorian Andean foothills (La Hesperia, Jauneche and Mindo in Ecuador: Jack and Campos 2012; de la Torre pers. obs.).
useTrade: People from local communities in western Ecuador hunt this species mainly as a pest control measure to protect crops. Furthermore, the species is affected by illegal trade. Captive animals have been recorded in local villages across its range in Ecuador.
conservationActions:
The species is present in the following protected areas:

Ecuador
Bilsa Biological Station
Mache-Chindul National Park
Manglares-Churute National Park
Cerro Blanco Forest Reserve
Machalilla National Park
La Hesperia Biological Reserve
Mindo-Nambillo Forest Reserve
Puyango Forest Reserve (considered absent from this reserve in Campos and Jack 2013)
Lalo Loor Dry Forest Reserve
Pacoche Marine and Coastal Wildlife Refuge (very low densities reported by Cervera et al. 2015)
Cerro de Hayas-Naranjal Reserve
Loma Alta Ecological Reserve
Cerro Pata de Pájaro Protected Forest
Tito Santos Biological Researve

Peru
Cerros de Amotape National Park
Tumbes Nature Reserve

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient due to an almost complete lack of information of the distribution of the species. Most of the known range of this species has been deforested, but over the past 300 or so years. Remaining forests are currently threatened by cultivation of illegal crops, coffee, mining, monoculture plantation, and cattle ranching. This species is a priority for research and surveys are needed in remaining habitat - especially the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta and surrounding areas.

This species is listed as Endangered due to a reduced geographic range (approximately ~3,000 km²) and continuing decline resulting from deforestation and coastal development. Within the remaining extent of occurrence (EOO), the area of occupancy (AOO) is only several hundred square kilometers along the northern flanks of the Santa Marta Mountains - restricting them to a small and fragmented area. However, very little is known of the current status, and although the species is considered threatened, further research is necessary to quantify the distribution and condition of the remaining subpopulations.

This species is listed as Endangered due to an ongoing decline in the population estimated to be greater that 50% over the past 3 generations (48 years). The species is threatened by deforestation, persecution from farmers where it is considered a crop pest, capture for the pet trade, and in some areas by excessive hunting.

This species is listed as Critically Endangered under criteria A2 and A4. A combination of historic forest loss and continued degradation has resulted in less than 20% of suitable habitat for Nycticebus javanicus remaining. Species distribution modelling and a gap analysis have also revealed that the remaining subpopulations of N. javanicus are highly fragmented, with only 17% of the potential distribution within the protected area network (Thorn et al. 2009). The species is inferred to have experienced a population size decline of at least 80% over the last 24 years (three generations; Nadler et al. 2007) due to severe and persistent and ongoing persecution for the pet trade (Nekaris et al. 2010), in combination with habitat loss.
habitat:
This species is nocturnal and arboreal, and is found in secondary disturbed forest, in plantations and to some extent in primary forests. It needs arboreal connectivity (vines and lianas) due to its unique locomotor adaptations, although it can cross short open spaces on the ground. It feeds largely on sap and floral florescence, gum and insects with fruit being an extremely limited part of its diet (Moore et al. 2015; Wirdateti et al. 2004, 2011; Rode, et al. 2014). As with other slow loris species, exudates make up the majority of the species diet and is an important year round resource (Starr and Nekaris, 2013).

The species sleeps alone, but more commonly in units of two or three individuals and in groups of up to six, in vegetation ranging from 2-30 m. It is often found in dense bamboo or branch tangles but not in tree holes (Wirdateti et al. 2004, Nekaris 2014). Home ranges vary with habitat, ranging from 3-30 ha. Although often seen alone, social pairs and trios can occur, as can adult infant/juvenile pairs. Occurs from sea level to 2,300 m, although it is less common at higher elevations. This species has been observed to go into torpor at higher elevations (Nekaris, 2014). The species is venomous; its venom is effective against other lorises as well as ecto-parasites, and can cause anaphylactic shock or death in humans (Nekaris, et al. 2013).
threats:
Java is one of the world’s most densely populated areas and has a long history of deforestation. Extensive habitat loss and fragmentation threaten the Javan slow loris throughout its range. In comparison to other Indonesian slow lorises, Nycticebus javanicus is significantly more vulnerable to anthropogenic activity due to intensive land use by humans (Thorn et al. 2009). Lack of connectivity between protected areas also poses a threat to loris populations, with every forest area containing slow lorises being effectively isolated by several kilometres of intensely modified and unsuitable habitat. The conversion of land to agricultural plantations is correlated with a sharp decline in slow loris population over the last 10 years (Wirdateti and Dahrudin, 2011).

This species, like other slow lorises in Indonesia, is caught for use in the pet trade and to a lesser extent for traditional beliefs and folk medicines (Nekaris et al. 2010, Shepherd et al, 2004). Together with other loris species, N. javanicus is one of the most common protected primates found in animal markets in Java (Nekaris et al. 2008, Thorn et al. 2009). Due to their non-leaping locomotion, their choice of sleeping sites in trees and bamboo that can be cut through and accessed, and nocturnal habits, the animals are easily caught by humans (Nekaris and Starr 2015). The majority of the trade is to satisfy a large domestic demand, with a smaller proportion being smuggled abroad to destinations like the Middle East and Japan (Musing et al. 2015). From there the species may appear on online videos which perpetuate the pet trade (Nekaris et al. 2013). The trade chain poses a perilous threat for many reasons. Conditions during transport (stuffed in boxes or sacks) and inappropriate husbandry techniques (poor diet and social housing, forced diurnal activity, excessive handling) afterwards result in large mortality rate. Slow Lorises are the only venomous primates; to avoid their bites middle men or traders cut or remove teeth, a process that almost invariably leads to the animal’s death (Nekaris and Starr 2015). If confiscated, reintroduction to the wild has proven difficult. Animals with no teeth are not viable candidates, and in a two-year study of 11 healthy radio-collared animals released, only two are known to have survived (Moore et al. 2015).

Hybridization poses a real threat both on Java and elsewhere. Some taxa of slow loris are known to hybridize in zoos. Javan slow lorises have been observed on animal markets outside Java (e.g., Medan, Bandar Lampung on Sumatra) and other Indonesian slow loris species (N. coucang, N. menagensis) have been observed to Javan markets. Due to the morphological similarity of Nycticebus spp. misidentification is rife. Furthermore, there is a general feeling that ‘if it is a slow loris, release it.’ Not only does this pose welfare risks to the individual, but also translocated individuals may harbour infections and parasites, and could potentially hybridize (Nekaris et al. 2008, Schulze and Groves 2004).
population:
This species has been recorded at very low densities (0.02-0.20/km) (Nekaris et al. 2008). Several surveys in large forest blocks revealed few or no slow loris (Ujung Kulon, Halimun-Salak, Carita Nature Recreation Park, Gunung Gede Pangrango, Cibodas, Talaga Sumrut Game Reserve, Masigit Kareumbi, Slamet, Dieng) (Voskamp et al., 2013) indicating a decline of over 80% in the population over its range. Some small isolated populations persist in gardens and agricultural lands where they are at high risk from hunting and easily poached for the pet trade; severe population declines in these habitats have been documented (Wirdateti et al. 2004, 2011; Voskamp et al., 2013). A specific survey in Gunung Gede Pangrango reported a density of 15.6 individuals/km², with a calculation that some 70 slow lorises occupy the study area (Nekaris et al., 2014). Based on the results of the survey, a very slow walking speed was deemed important in being able to detect slow lorises. More recently Nekaris and colleagues (unpublished) surveyed East Java, increasing the geographic range of N. javanicus, finding it at sites including Tumpang Pitu Forest, Meru Betiri National Park and Salakan Forest.

The population is inferred to have declined by over 80% over the last three generations (24 years) due to exploitation and declining availability of suitable habitat; less than 20% of suitable habitat suitable for Nycticebus javanicus remains. Severe population declines have been documented in forested habitats in Java (Wirdateti et al. 2004, 2011).
range: <span class="apple-converted-space">This species is only known from the province of Banten, West Java, and at least as far east as the western part of East Java in Indonesia.
useTrade: This species is used for traditional medicines (Nekaris and Nijman 2007) and as a pet species.
conservationActions:
This species is protected by Indonesian law (No. 5 of 1990) and is listed on CITES Appendix I. It is currently represented in three captive collections (Jakarta, Indonesia; Singapore; Saitama Children’s Zoo, Japan); it should be noted the specimen in Prague Zoo is in fact a N. coucang. There is no viable captive breeding programme, and reproduction in captivity is known to be difficult. Some ecological studies with conservation education components have been completed or are in progress. Training workshops have been conducted to provide law enforcement officers, CITES officials and zoo and rescue centre personnel with improved identification skills to identify Nycticebus spp. within the pet trade.

Several rescue centres in the region maintain facilities for confiscated individuals, where behavioural problems occur and require enrichment and expert care (Gray et al. 2015, Moore et al. 2015). Numerous attempts have been made to release Slow Lorises, both monitored and unmonitored, but until more is known about the complexities of taxonomy and ecology of lorises within the region, whether these releases make a positive contribution to conservation remains to be seen (Moore et al. 2015).

There are permanent education programmes across parts of the range of N. javanicus, including ‘Slow Loris Forest Protector’ book and teachers pack, Nature Clubs, village Pride Days, film nights, and reforestation projects, working with farmers to explain the benefits of the slow loris to prevent pests and also as a pollinator (Nekaris 2014). There are ongoing campaigns to combat the number of slow lorises, including N. javanicus, observed in illegal social networking videos (Nekaris et al. 2015).

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient as it is currently known from the type locality only. There is no information on the species' population status and limited information on its distribution. As more information becomes available, it will be necessary to reassess the species.
habitat: In the Forêt des Abeilles, Sciurocheirus makandensis occurs at low to medium elevations, in primary, closed canopy forest on hilly ground (Ambrose 2013).  If the galagos occurring to the south and west of this area prove to belong to the same taxon, then its habitat range will be wider.
threats: The forests of Gabon are threatened by accelerating commercial logging activities (Kingdon 2015, Ambrose 2016).
population: Little is known about population densities of this species, but they are likely to be low (Ambrose 2013).
range: The distinct loud-call repertoire and profile of the Makandé Squirrel Galago have to date been recorded only in the Forêt des Abeilles in Gabon. The taxon may be endemic to this area, or range into other areas of Gabon and even Congo (Ambrose 2013, Kingdon 2015). Several other mammal species are known to be endemic to the Forêt des Abeilles (Ambrose 2013).
conservationActions: Sciurocheirus makandensis is listed under Appendix II of CITES. This is a poorly known species in urgent need of further research, in particular to determine whether or not it is restricted to the Forêt des Abeilles. The confirmed range of this species falls outside any protected areas; however, it has been proposed that Lopé National Park is enlarged to include the Forêt des Abeilles, as this area is an important centre of endemism (Kingdon 2015).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern as this species is widespread and common. It may be declining in some areas due to habitat destruction, particularly on the eastern extent of the range, but there is currently no evidence of a significant range-wide population decline that would warrant listing in a higher category of threat.
habitat: This species inhabits all strata of lowland and montane tropical moist forest, swamp forest and other lowland forest types. It is most common in secondary and colonising forests, and along the margins of these forests (Pimley & Bearder 2013). Its diet shows distinct seasonal variation: gums are dominant during drier periods, with insects, snails and fruits (such as figs, Musanga, Parinari, Uapaca and Myrianthus) eaten during the rainy seasons (Nekaris 2013). P. edwardsi are solitary animals, but do display some degree of sociality (Pimley et al. 2005). Charles-Dominique (1977) recorded females ranging over 3-9 ha, and males over 9-40 ha with their ranges overlapping that of one or more females; however, Pimley et al. (2005) found no significant difference in the range area of P. edwardsi between males (mean = 30.6 ha ± 2.97) and females (mean = 31.5 ha ± 7.25) with most overlap being between ‘paired’ males and females, which were found in close proximity and engaged in more social behaviours with each other than with other individuals (Pimley et al. 2005). Females give birth to one young annually. P. edwardsi in Gabon live to at least nine years of age (Charles-Dominique 1977).
threats: Perodicticus edwardsi are known to be widespread in secondary and primary forests, and even in disturbed forest near human habitation. There are probably no major threats resulting in a range-wide population decline, but localised declines are likely taking place due to habitat loss from clear-cutting and intensive agriculture, particularly on the eastern extent of the range. P. edwardsi is hunted and recorded in the bushmeat trade (Cameroon, Congo and DRC), pet trade (DRC and Nigeria) and in traded for traditional practices (Congo), although in small quantities (Svensson & Friant 2014, Svensson et al. 2015).
population: The species is widespread and common. Density averages 8–10 animals/km² at Makokou, in north-east Gabon (Charles-Dominique 1977) and 4.7 animals/km² in mixed secondary forest and farm bush on Mt. Kupe in Cameroon (Pimley 2002). In Angola, encounter rates of 0.83-1.80 animals/km were observed in moist, primary and secondary forest habitats (Bersacola et al. 2015).
range:
Pseudopotto edwardsi occurs from the Niger River in Nigeria east through Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea (mainland), Republic of Congo, then south of the Congo River through the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) as far east as Irneti and as far south as Angola. It occurs from sea level up to about 1,500 m asl.

Pseudopotto martini, originally described as a new genus but here included in the synonymy of  P. edwardsi, is known from only one skeleton (which came from a specimen that died at Zurich Zoo) and two skulls, as well as some undocumented sightings around Mount Kupe, Cameroon, at 820–940 m altitude. However, P. martini was not observed on Mt Kupe during a two-year field study when only P. edwardsi (some with long tails) were recorded (E. Pimley pers. obs. 2000).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources  (as P. potto). This species is present in many protected areas throughout its range. However, further surveys are needed to determine the true conservation status of P. edwardsi, and careful research is required to better understand the impacts of habitat conversion and hunting on its populations.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern, Perodicticus ibeanus is widespread and locally common. To some extent, it is adaptable to habitat alteration caused by humans as long as sufficient fragments of forest remain within farm bush for refuge (Mittermeier 2013, Pimley & Bearder 2013). As a low density, non-gregarious, small bodied primate, P. ibeanus are vulnerable to local declines where habitat is lost due to human activities. There is no evidence, however, of a significant range-wide population decline that would warrant listing in a higher category of threat.
habitat:
Perodicticus ibeanus inhabits all strata of lowland and montane moist forest, swamp forest and other lowland forest types. It is found in western Kenya at low densities in gardens and coniferous plantations adjacent to secondary forest (E. Pimley, pers. obs. 2006). This species is most common on the forest edge, flooded primary forest, secondary forest, colonising forest and riverine forest (Kingdon 1971, Charles-Dominique 1977, Wolfheim 1983, Pimley 2002, Pimley & Bearder 2013). Mean annual rainfall in its geographical range is 60–230 cm (Butynski & de Jong 2007).

This species is omnivorous and forages in all forest strata but prefers the canopy. It forages mainly on ripe fruit, gum, nectar and invertebrates, but it also eats moss, frogs and bird’s eggs (Kingdon 1971, Charles-Dominique 1977, Wolfheim 1983, Pimley 2002, Pimley & Bearder 2013).
threats: Perodicticus ibeanus is widespread in secondary and primary forests, and in disturbed forest near human habitation. The main threat is habitat loss (Pimley & Bearder 2013). There are probably no major threats resulting in a range-wide population decline. Local  declines are, however, taking place due to habitat loss from clear-cutting and intensive agriculture that are related to fast growing human populations over much of the geographic range. In northern DRC, pottos are traded in small numbers for pets and body parts for various indigenous medicinal and witchcraft practices (Svensson et al. 2016). This species is easily detected by torch light and is thus readily located by hunters.
population: Perodicticus ibeanus is widespread and locally common, but occurs at low density over large areas. Densities range typically between <2 and 28 individuals/km². The encounter rates from several sites are presented in Butynski and de Jong (2007).
range:
Perodicticus ibeanus ibeanus (Eastern Potto) ranges from east and south of the Ubangi River, and north and east of Congo River, Democratic Republic of the Congo, eastwards to east of the Lualaba River, then northwest to Burundi, Rwanda, Uganda to southwest Kenya (Kakamega Forest, Nandi Forests and surrounding forests). Occurs at 600-2,300 m asl (Butynski and de Jong 2007).

Perodicticus ibeanus stockleyi (Mount Kenya Potto) is known only from one specimen collected in 1938 on Mount Kenya, central Kenya (Butynski and de Jong 2007).
conservationActions: Perodicticus ibeanus is an Appendix II CITES species and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (as Perodicticus potto). Present in many protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: This species is declining rapidly and is thought to be undergoing further habitat degradation and increased pressure from hunting, particularly in Ghana. It is presumed to have declined by at least 50% over the past 27 years, although this decline may have been even more severe.
habitat: Cercocebus lunulatus occurs in primary and secondary forests, gallery and swamp forests, as well as mosaic habitats in the Guinean savanna zone. It is diurnal and largely terrestrial, but will also use the forest canopy. In gallery forest along the Comoé River in Burkina Faso, Galat and Galat-Luong (2006) observed this mangabey eating the fruits of the liana Saba senegalensis; at this site, a group of nine individuals was counted, while groups of up to 23 individuals were seen in the past in Comoé National Park, Côte d’Ivoire (Fischer et al. 2000). In the Tanoé swamp forest in Côte d’Ivoire, a mean group size of 5.13 (range: 1.53–8.73) was reported during a 3-month survey conducted in 2009 (Gonedelé Bi, unpublished data 2009).
threats: The species is hunted for its meat, both for local consumption and for the commercial bushmeat trade. Unregulated hunting has probably been the major cause of its decline. Illegal timber exploitation and mining is on the increase, which is leading to further habitat loss and fragmentation as a result of logging, the clearing for agriculture and charcoal, the demand for firewood, and fire. Cercocebus lunulatus has also been killed because of its crop raiding. In Ghana, many forests have been converted to rubber plantations. In Côte d’Ivoire, in the last decade, several forest reserves and protected areas that the species formerly inhabited have been completely converted into plantations, resulting in the local extirpation of the species and other primates in these forests (Bitty et al. 2015). In the remaining forests that still harbour the species, hunting and forest encroachment are affecting this monkey's survival. These threats are ongoing.
population:
This species has a very patchy distribution and is now rare at all the sites where it still survives. At one of these sites, the Ankasa Conservation Area in Ghana, Gatti (2010) reports an encounter rate of 0.002 groups per km. Surveys conducted in 2012 in the Ankasa-Tano Community Forest, Western Region of Ghana, reported an encounter rate of 0.006 groups per km. In 2011, about 60 individuals were counted in a survey conducted by D. Osei in the Cape Three Point Forest Reserve. In April 2016, about 20 individuals were encountered during a survey conducted by D. Osei in the Ankasa Community forest (Osei et al. 2015). Although it was observed in the Comoé Lébara Reserve in 2005, in 2012, a survey of five protected areas across the southern border of Burkina Faso, including Comoé-Lébara Reserve, did not encounter this mangabey, although interviews in a nearby village suggested that it might still be present (Ginn and Nekaris 2014).

The most important population of the species is probably that in Tanoé swamp forest in Côte d’Ivoire, where groups of up to 300 individuals were seen in past surveys. In 2009, a density of 12.3 individuals per km² was estimated for the Tanoé Forest, during a 3-month survey (Gonedelé Bi, unpublished data, 2009). In Port Gauthier and Dassioko Sud forest reserves in central coastal Côte d’Ivoire, the species was encountered at low rates of 0.004 and 0.009 groups per km, respectively (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2014).
range: Cercocebus lunulatus once ranged from the Nzo-Sassandra River system in western Côte d’Ivoire to just west of the Volta River in Ghana. The current presence of this species in southwestern Burkina Faso is uncertain (Ginn and Nekaris 2012). In Cote d'Ivoire, it occurs in the Comoé National Park and the Tanoe-Ehy Community Forest; its continued presence in the Dassieko Classified Forest is uncertain. In Ghana, the forested area it once occupied has been drastically reduced from its past distribution (Grubb et al. 1998) and the species is now restricted to the Western Region, apart from one population discovered in 2017 in the Atewa Forest Reserve situated in the Eastern Region of the country. In the Western Region, the species has declined dramatically since at least the 1970s, and has been extirpated from the Bia National Park, Krokosua Hills Forest Reserve, the Mamre Forest Reserve, and other protected areas and forest reserves. Recent surveys have shown that the species may now be restricted to Cape Three Points Forest Reserve and the Ankasa-Tano (or Kwabre) Community Forest (Danquah and Tetteh 2016); a population in the Ankasa Conservation Area appears to be on the verge of extirpation (Ossei et al. 2015).
useTrade: This species is hunted for bushmeat.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (as Cercocebus atys). European Union listed in Appendix I.

Cercocebus lunulatus occurs in Comoé National Park, Côte d’Ivoire, but its survival there has been jeopardized by the combined effects of civil conflict and hunting; it has also been recorded from Ankasa Conservation Area, Dadieso Forest Reserve, Yoyo Forest Reserves, Cape Three Points Forest Reserve, and the Ankasa-Tano Community Forest in Ghana, and in Dassioko Sud Forest Reserve and Port Gauthier Forest Reserve in Côte d’Ivoire.

rationale: Previously assessed as Near Threatened, Cercocebus atys is now listed as Vulnerable as the population is estimated to have declined by at least 30% over the past 27 years (equivalent to three generations). The causes of the decline are intensive hunting across its range, combined with habitat loss and degradation resulting from the expansion of commercial and subsistence agriculture. This estimate is based on the results of foot surveys in both protected and non-protected areas, surveys of bushmeat markets, and interviews with hunters and farmers (e.g., Gonedelé Bi et al. 2012, Covey and McGraw 2014, Greengrass 2016, Binczik et al. 2017, Soiret et al. 2019). The declining population trend is predicted to continue at the same or an accelerated rate.
habitat:
Cercocebus atys is found in primary and secondary forests, gallery forest, swamp forest (including mangrove) and mosaic habitats in the western part of the Guinean forest zone. Sooty Mangabeys are large, predominantly terrestrial monkeys typically found in large multimale, multifemale groups (McGraw and Zuberbühler 2007). Groups of mangabeys at Tai National Park consist of up to 100 individuals (McGraw and Zuberbühler 2007), with males averaging 11 kg and females 6.2 kg (Oates et al. 1990). They forage mainly through leaf litter on the forest floor, and the staples of their diet include fruits, seeds and invertebrates, with seeds making up 68% of the diet and invertebrates making up 26% (Bergmüller 1998, McGraw and Zuberbühler 2007). Sooty Mangabeys are able to process food items that are too hard for other fruit eating monkeys to consume (Daegling et al. 2011). They show evidence of spatial memory skills when searching for fruit from Anthonata fragrans trees (Janmaat et al. 2006). They are known to raid farms, and are tolerant of some degree of habitat degradation in the absence of hunting (Binczik et al. 2017). The home range of a Sooty Mangabey group is estimated at 4-6 km² (1.54–2.32 mi²), but can be as large as 6.5 km² (2.5 mi²) (Galat and Galat-Luong 1985, McGraw and Zuberbühler 2007).

In Côte d’Ivoire's Taï National Park, Sooty Mangabeys intermingle with groups of Western Red Colobus (Piliocolobus badius) and Diana Monkey (Cercopithecus diana) for approximately 5% and 10%, respectively, of total observation time (Taï Monkey Project unpubl. data 1990–2001).

Monkey species associating with Sooty Mangabeys will often descend to lower canopy levels because of the latter's ability to detect predators approaching from the ground (McGraw and Bshary 2002). Sooty Mangabey vocalisations include a number of twitters, grunts and whoop calls (Range and Fischer 2004).
threats:
Cercocebus atys is threatened by hunting and habitat loss. Forest habitat is being lost through farming, logging, firewood harvesting and mining, all of which are being accentuated by a high rate of human population growth. According to FAO 2015 data, Cote d'Ivoire, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Liberia and Sierra Leone lost a combined 6% of their forest-woodland area over 25 years (1990–2015). The species is locally hunted for meat, and this is an increasingly important threat with ongoing forest fragmentation, because animals can be located more easily by hunters in small forest fragments. Increasing hunting pressure and bushmeat traffic is affecting the species in Côte d’Ivoire, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone (Kümpel et al. 2008, Covey and McGraw 2014, Greengrass 2016, Brncic et al. 2015). Cercocebus atys is the most hunted primate species in the Forécariah/Kounounkan region of coastal Guinea bordering Sierra Leone (Dufour 2013), and the species is among the most hunted primates in the Sime Darby oil palm concession in central Liberia (Béné et al. 2013b,c). A survey in Liberia's Nimba County revealed that Sooty Mangabeys were the most common primate in bushmeat markets, representing 3.03% of all market prey (Bene et al. 2013b,c).

Sooty Mangabeys are natural reservoir hosts of Simian Immunodeficiency Virus (SIV). Despite a high prevalence in the wild population, the virus has no detectable impact on the survival or health of this host species (Silvestri et al. 2003). Sooty Mangabeys do not develop AIDS despite high levels of SIV infection because of several genetically-based mechanisms that enhance immune function (Palesch et al. 2018). Cercocebus atys can contract leprosy (Rojas-Espinosa and Løvik 2001), and Type 2 diabetes is more common in mangabeys than in other primate species (Jones et al. 2014).

The bushmeat trade, the practice of keeping monkeys as pets, and the growing number of people living near wild Sooty Mangabeys significantly increases the risk of transmission of multiple zoonotic diseases (Mossoun et al. 2015)
population:
Current, comprehensive data on the abundance and distribution of Sooty Mangabeys throughout much of their six-country range are lacking; however, available evidence suggests the species has declined across most of its distribution. In Côte d’Ivoire, the species has been extirpated in most of its range, except for the Taï National Park and the sacred grove of Gbepleu near the town of Man in western Côte d’Ivoire (S. Gonedelé Bi pers. obs. 2015). In Taï National Park, a survey by Covey (2009) estimated population density to be 4.35 groups/km² and N’Goran et al. (2012) estimated that approximately 63,000 individuals reside in the park. Recent surveys failed to detect the species in the Dodo Coastal Forest of southwestern Côte d’Ivoire (Soiret et al. 2019) and the Tonkpi region of west-central Côte d’Ivoire (Kramoko et al. 2017).

During nationwide surveys of Liberia, Sooty Mangabeys were the second most common monkey detected on line transects (Junker et al. 2015). Surveys of four counties (Gbarpolu, Bomi, Bong and Grand Cape Mount) comprising the Sime Darby Plantation (oil palm, rubber) reported Sooty mangabeys present, although specific locality information were not published (Béné et al. 2013a). Several surveys carried out over the last ten years in the Mount Nimba region confirm the presence of Sooty Mangabeys there (Béné et al. 2013b,c, Granier 2016). In southeastern Liberia, surveys in the Grebo-Sapo Corridor reported a Sooty Mangabey encounter rate (groups/km) of 0.08 (Furnell et al. 2015a). The species appears to still be common in Sapo National Park (Vogt, 2011, Oates 2011) though it is hunted regularly (Greengrass 2016). Encounter rates in the Putu Range (0.09) are significantly lower than those inside Sapo National Park (0.19) (Vogt, 2011). During a 4-month survey in 2015, Sooty Mangabeys were heard but not seen in the newly-created Grebo-Krahn National Park (Furnell et al. 2015b).

In Guinea in 1992, the species was often encountered during a 10-day field visit to the Kounounkan region, near the small town of Moussayah, Forécariah Province (Barnett et al. 1994). However, it was rarely encountered during a rapid assessment of the primate fauna conducted in 2005 in Sangaredi sub-prefecture in northwestern Boké Préfecture (Eriksson and Kpoghomou 2006). During site visits in 2017 and 2018, Sooty Mangabeys were observed in several areas in the Fouta Djallon region (R.A. Mittermeier pers. comm. 2017, C. André pers. comm. 2018).

Recent surveys confirm Sooty Mangabeys near the village of Beli in the Boe region of Guinea-Bissau (Binczik et al. 2017) and they are present in Cantanhez Forest National Park (Garriga et al. 2018); however, their presence elsewhere in Guinea-Bissau is no longer certain (Gippoliti and Dell’Omo 2003, Minhos et al. (2013).

In Sierra Leone, the population of C. atys in Gola Forest National Park may have actually increased in the last 20 years. In 1985, before Sierra Leone’s 1991-2001 civil war, Davies (1987) had 0.14 encounters per km with this species (sightings and calls combined), while in 2006–2007 Klop et al. (2008) had an encounter rate based on sightings and vocal detections of 0.45 per km. It is not possible, however, to translate such encounter rates accurately into population density estimates, especially in the case of a species like C. atys whose calls carry for a considerable distance in the forest, and whose calling patterns can be affected by many factors. A nationwide survey of chimpanzees in Sierra Leone revealed Sooty Mangabeys mostly in the northern part of the country where human population numbers are lower (Brncic et al. 2015). Surveys carried out in the Moyamba and Port Loko districts of Sierra Leone during 2013–2014 identified Sooty Mangabeys as crop-raiders (Garriga et al. 2018).
range: This species ranges from Senegal, Guinea-Bissau, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia to the Nzo-Sassandra system in Cote d'Ivoire. It occurs between sea level and at least 1,000 m asl; possibly higher in the Loma Mountains in Sierra Leone.
useTrade: The species is hunted for bushmeat across its range. The price of a freshly killed adult male in areas bordering the Cavally River (Cote d'Ivoire and Liberia) is equivalent to approximately US $5 (Covey and McGraw 2014). Prices are substantially higher in towns and cities that are more distant from rural areas.
conservationActions:
Cercocebus atys is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. European Union listed in Appendix I.

Cercocebus atys occurs in a number of protected areas including Taï National Park (Côte d’Ivoire), Sapo National Park, Grebo-Krahn National Park and Gola National Park (Liberia), Tiwai Island Wildlife Sanctuary, Gola Forest National Park and Loma Mountains National Park (Sierra Leone), and the Cantanhez Forest National Park (Guinea-Bissau).

The species is also conserved in Gbepleu sacred grove in western Côte d’Ivoire near the town of Man.

rationale: Perodicticus potto is listed as Near Threatened because although this species is still relatively widespread, its forest habitat is rapidly being destroyed and converted across a large part of its range. In the nine West African countries where the species is known to occur, forest cover over the last three generations (27 years, given a P. potto generation length of 9 years, Pacifici et al. 2013) has declined by more than 20% (FAO 2015), while human population has more than doubled (United Nations 2019). Also, P. potto is increasingly hunted for food and is traded for traditional practices (Svensson and Friant 2014, Svensson et al. 2015, Gonedelé Bi et al. 2016). Although data on declines in P. potto populations are not available, due to an absence of systematic surveys, it is likely that the population has declined by at least 20% over the last three generations (27 years). This species is likely to qualify for the threatened category of Vulnerable in the near future.
habitat: This species inhabits the mid- to upper strata of lowland tropical moist forest, swamp forest and other lowland forest types, both primary and secondary, as well as plantations. In Côte d’Ivoire, P. potto was observed mainly in younger, more disturbed forests (Pimley pers. obs. 2013). However, the opposite has been observed in other parts of their range where they more commonly encountered in mature forests (Oates pers. obs. 1966–2009). There is very limited information on the diet of P. potto, but Oates (1984) reports that P. potto consumes gum, fruits and insects. Pottos are predominantly solitary animals, but display some degree of sociality, with mothers and young maintaining contact by means of olfactory communication and occasionally high frequency vocalisations (Bearder et al. 2003). Pottos in Taï National Park, Côte d’Ivoire, were found in proximity of another potto for 30% of observations, with a proportion of this time spent allogrooming, which suggests that the species may also associate in pairs, as observed in P. edwardsi in Cameroon (Pimley pers. obs. 1998–2000).
threats:
Perodicticus potto is endemic to West Africa, and although the species is known to survive in some disturbed forest near human habitation their entire range falls within a part of Africa where human population is growing rapidly and habitat destruction is rampant. In the nine West African countries where the presence of P. potto has been confirmed, the United Nations Population Division estimates that the combined human population increased in the 27 years from 1992 to 2019 from 154 million to 311 million, an increase of 102% (United Nations 2019). Associated with this increase in human population and the spread of settlement, agriculture, timber harvesting and development projects, forest cover in these same nine countries is estimated by FAO (2015) to have fallen from 671,880 km² in 1990 to 530,900 km² in 2015—a forest loss of 21%. Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone are among three of 10 countries in the world that had the fastest annual acceleration of tree cover loss in the 2001–2014 period, based on an analysis of satellite imagery, with Sierra Leone recording the world’s second greatest annual forest loss rate of 12.6% (Petersen et al. 2015).

Perodicticus potto is also hunted, mainly for subsistence, but the species occurs in the commercial trade as well. It has been observed in the bushmeat trade (Ghana, Côte d’Ivoire, Liberia and Nigeria), in the pet trade (Nigeria, Liberia and Togo) and in the trade for traditional medicines and practices (Benin, Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana) (Svensson and Friant 2014, Svensson et al. 2015, Gonedelé Bi et al. 2016). In the forest zone of West Africa, smaller mammals began to feature more commonly in the bushmeat trade more than a decade ago, as larger-bodied wild mammals have become scarce (Swensson 2005). This trend is now impacting on species such as P. potto, whose decline is suggested by a recent reduction in the number of pottos seen in western Nigeria in the possession of hunters or in bushmeat markets (R. Ikemeh pers. comm. 2016).
population: Perodicticus potto has been considered to be relatively widespread and abundant suitable habitat within its geographical range; however, population density data on the species throughout its range are lacking. Given accelerating rates of habitat destruction and increasing hunting pressure, it is inferred that the population is declining, and the subspecies juju in Benin, Togo and Nigeria is Endangered (see Perodicticus potto juju).
range:
This species has a wide range in West Africa, with confirmed presence in SE Senegal, SE Guinea, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, S Togo, S Benin and SW Nigeria (Oates 2011, Nekaris 2013, Pimley and Bearder 2013). Perodicticus potto may also occur in the Gambia and Guinea-Bissau, but this is yet to be confirmed (Nekaris 2013, Pimley and Bearder 2013). For Guinea-Bissau, decades of field surveys and a recent survey of bushmeat markets using molecular markers failed to find the presence of the species (Gippoliti and Dell’Omo 1996, Minhós et al. 2013).

There are two subspecies: the nominate P. p. potto is found in West Africa from SE Senegal, SE Guinea, Sierra Leone to the Volta River in Ghana (there are no confirmed records for the Gambia, Guinea-Bissau and most of Guinea); P. p. juju  is found from the east bank of the Volta River in SE Ghana through southern Togo and southern Benin to the west bank of the Niger River in Nigeria.
useTrade: Perodicticus potto is hunted, mainly for subsistence, but the species occurs in the commercial trade as well. It has been observed in the bushmeat trade (Ghana, Côte d’Ivoire, Liberia and Nigeria), in the pet trade (Nigeria, Liberia and Togo) and in the trade for traditional medicines and practices (Benin, Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana) (Svensson and Friant 2014, Svensson et al. 2015, Gonedelé Bi et al. 2016).
conservationActions: Perodicticus potto is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. This species is present in many protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: Papio cynocephalus is listed as Least Concern, as the species is widespread and common, present in numerous protected areas, and there are no major range-wide threats believed to be resulting in a significant population decline.
habitat:
The Yellow Baboon lives primarily in open and woodland savanna. Over much of its range, it is associated with fire-climax Miombo (Brachystegia) woodland. Both in this zone and especially to the northeast of its range, the species may also occupy dry bushland, thickets, steppes, and the coastal littoral (including mangroves). Fever Trees (Acacia xanthophloea) and Tortilis Trees (A. tortilis) are often used as both sources of food and shelter (Altmann et al. 2013). The Yellow Baboon typically forages in extended, well-spaced troops that may occasionally number up to 300 animals, though more typically average 30 to 80 individuals. The species is not territorial but, instead, uses home ranges that may overlap with other troops’ ranges. They drink almost daily, so their ranges tend to include a water source within a half-day’s journey (Altmann et al. 2013).

Like other members of the genus, Yellow Baboons are opportunistic omnivores. They primarily feed on the seeds, flesh, and pods of the leguminous trees including Acacia, Albizia, mopane (Colophospermum), and tamarind, all of which are seasonal staples. They also feed on grasses, shoots, fungi, lichens, and a range of animal prey, including invertebrates, lizards, birds, reptile and bird eggs, and small mammals. The latter include other primates, such as Vervet Monkeys (Chlorocebus pygerythrus) and Northern Lesser Galago (Galago senegalensis) (Altmann et al. 2013).

Yellow Baboons prefer foods with unusual chemistry, suggesting that this species has acquired special digestive adaptations. Such adaptations may help to explain why the boundaries of the species’ distribution do not follow specific geographic discontinuities but coincide closely with the distribution of a plant community (Jolly 1993, Kingdon 1997).

Although Yellow Baboons exhibit clear preference for woodland life, they can persist in secondary and highly fragmented vegetation, including areas that have been cultivated. In fact, some troops have adapted to living close to humans and regularly visit garbage dumps for foraging. While wild-foraging groups may spend approximately 70–75% of their time foraging and travelling up to 10 km per day, baboon troops that exploit garbage dumps forage for only 35–40% and travel only 2–4 km per day (Muruthi et al. 1991).

Extensive review and summary of the Yellow Baboon’s anatomy, behaviour and reproduction may be found in Altmann et al. (2013) and Zinner (2013).
threats:
There are no major threats to this species across its range, although some populations may be under pressure from agriculture and development projects. As other wildlife species decline and human populations increase, a potential increase in hunting pressure may be likely and trapping due to crop-raiding.

Both Papio anubis and P. cynocephalus are naturally infected with Treponema pallidum subspecies pertenue, the bacterium that causes human yaws and closely related to the bacterium that causes syphilis (T. p. pallidum) (see Harper et al. 2012, Chuma et al. 2019). In Papio sp., the infection appears to spread through sexual contact and is associated with open lesions in and around the genitalia of both sexes. The degree of morbidity varies, including some cases of deaths occurring in the Tanzania’s Gombe National Park’s Olive Baboons, when the genitalia are so badly damaged that urinary flow was obstructed (Wallis and Lee 1999).

Although the current hunting pressure and incidence of disease do not constitute “major threats”, both phenomena merit attention and monitoring.
population: This species is widespread and locally common, but patchily distributed over its extensive range.
range:
The Yellow Baboon ranges from southern Ethiopia into Somalia, coastal Kenya, and northeastern Tanzania southwards to the Zambezi valley, where they are found in Malawi, northern Mozambique, and the far eastern part of Zambia (Jolly 1993). There are hybrid zones with Papio anubis near Sultan Hamud (2°02'S, 37°23'E) and Amboseli National Park in Kenya and Mkomazi National Park in Tanzania. As mentioned above, baboons in the broad clinal hybrid zone between Laikipia District, just to the northeast and east of Mt. Kenya, and the Lower Tana River, Kenya coast are intermediate in appearance; they become increasingly “yellow-like” in their phenotypes towards the Kenya Coast (De Jong and Butynski 2009, Zinner 2013). Yellow baboons are sympatric with Chlorocebus pygerythrus, Erythrocebus patas and Cercopithecus mitis.

There are two subspecies: P. c. cynocephalus occurs in the central and southeastern parts of the range including Zambia east of the Luangwa, Malawi, northern Mozambique, and most of Tanzania and P. c. ibeanus is found in far southeastern Ethiopia, southern Somalia, and southeastern and coastal Kenya.
useTrade: Hunting of Yellow Baboons is not widespread, although occasional reports occur. As with other members of this genus, the species is often persecuted for crop-raiding activity as indicated in reports of trapping and killing by farmers in Tanzania’s Nguru (Doggart and Loserian 2007) and Nguu Mountains (Ceppi and Neilson 2014). Previous export of this species for use in medical research has apparently declined in recent years, although no current records are available.
conservationActions:
This species is currently listed under Appendix II of CITES. It is listed as Vermin under the African Convention and is thus subject to legally sanctioned trapping and killing in certain areas. This may result in local extinction, if not controlled (Altmann et al. 2013).

Yellow Baboons are present in many protected areas. These include, for example, Amboseli National Park and Tsavo East National Park in Kenya; Ruaha National Park, Mikumi National Park, Udzungwa National Park, Mkomazi National Park, and Selous Game Reserve in Tanzania; and Liwonde National Park in Malawi.

They are susceptible to the spread of Treponema pallidum, which can have debilitating or even deadly consequences. Thus, research and ongoing monitoring for hunting pressure and disease transmission is recommended in assessment of the species’ long-term future. The effect of global climate change should be monitored; Altmann et al. (2002) noted measurable woodland loss in Amboseli since the 1970s, associated with temperature increases in the area. Thus, research into their habitat use, range, boundaries and reasons for separation into distinct subspecies could be useful for conservation planning.

rationale: Papio kindae is listed as Least Concern, as the species is widespread and common, present in numerous protected areas, and there are no major range-wide threats believed to be resulting in a significant population decline.
habitat:
Kinda Baboons occur in miombo (Brachystegia) woodland habitat and evergreen forest throughout most of their range and spend less time in open grasslands than do other baboon species (Weyher, unpublished data; Zinner 2013). On average, this species lives in cooler, wetter (average precipitation is approximately 1000 mm) environments with less stable daily and annual temperatures compared with Papio species. Studies using niche modelling found that the environments Kinda Baboons inhabit are distinct compared with other baboon species (Fuchs et al. 2018).

There have been no systematic studies of their diet content, but Kinda Baboons are omnivorous, with a preference for fruits. Similar to other baboons, Kinda Baboons spend about 35% of their time feeding, 14% travelling, 32% resting, and 19% in social activities (Weyher, unpublished data). Higher temperatures are associated with more time spent feeding and travelling and less time in social activity and resting, while higher humidity is associated with more time spent feeding and in social activity (Weyher, unpublished data). These findings suggest a vulnerability to climate change.

As with the Yellow, Chacma, and Olive Baboons, females form a close social bond; most adult grooming partnerships occur between females. However, male-female relationships and female-female relationships of Kinda Baboons differ substantially from those seen in Yellow, Chacma, and Olive Baboons, suggesting that the social system of the Kinda Baboon constitutes a further variant of baboon social systems (Weyher et al. 2014). Compared with other baboons, the Kinda Baboon exhibits relatively low degrees of sexual dimorphism and large relative testis size, leading to the suggestion that they have evolved under reduced direct, and increased indirect, male-male competition (Petersdorf et al. 2019).
threats:
There are no major threats to this species across its range, though some populations may be under pressure from agriculture and development projects. As other wildlife species decline and human populations increase, a potential increase in hunting pressure may be likely in some areas.

The closely related Papio anubis and P. cynocephalus are naturally infected with Treponema pallidum subspecies pertenue, the bacterium that causes human yaws and closely related to the bacterium that causes syphilis (T. p. pallidum) (see Harper et al. 2012, Chuma et al. 2019). In Papio spp., the infection appears to spread through sexual contact and is associated with open lesions in and around the genitalia of both sexes. The degree of morbidity varies, including some cases of deaths occurring in the Tanzania’s Gombe National Park’s Olive Baboons, when the genitalia are so badly damaged that urinary flow was obstructed (Wallis and Lee 1999). The presence of this disease has not been confirmed in the Kinda Baboon, but their range is known to be previously endemic for yaws (Knauf et al. 2018).

Thus, although the current hunting pressure and potential incidence of disease are not known to constitute “major threats,” both phenomena merit attention and monitoring.
population: This species is widespread and locally common, but patchily distributed over its extensive range. No populations numbers are available, but they are thought to be stable at present.
range: The Kinda Baboon occurs in southwestern Tanzania (possibly as far north as the Mahale Mountains National Park), in southern Democratic Republic of the Congo, western Zambia (west of the Luangwa River), and in northern Angola. Kinda Baboons hybridize with Chacma Baboons and Yellow Baboons in their respective Zambian contact zones.
useTrade: The hunting of Kinda Baboons is not widespread, though occasional reports occur. As with other members of this genus, the species may be persecuted for crop-raiding.
conservationActions:
This species is listed under Appendix II of CITES (as Papio cynocephalus) and is considered as Vermin under the African Convention (as a subspecies of Papio cynocephalus). It is present in many protected areas, including Upemba and Kundelungu National Parks in DR Congo and Kafue, Kasanka, and South Luangwa National Parks in Zambia.

As mentioned earlier, there are currently no reports of major range-wide threats resulting in a significant population decline of Kinda Baboons, although they are likely at risk in some areas where encroachment by local humans may be impacting their habitats and where crop-raiding behaviour by the baboons may be met with retribution killings. This may lead to local extinction in some areas. Consequently, impacts of human-baboon interactions should be monitored.

As noted in the Threat section, research and monitoring for hunting pressure and disease transmission is recommended in assessment of the species’ long-term future. Also, Weyher (unpublished data) found that temperature and humidity significantly predict activity patterns of Kinda Baboons. Thus, the effect of global climate change should be monitored.

Research and ongoing monitoring for hunting pressure and disease transmission is recommended. Additionally, research into their range, boundaries, and reasons for separation into distinct subspecies could be useful for conservation planning.

rationale: Southern Patas Monkey is listed as Critically Endangered because there are estimated to be no more than 40 to 100 mature individuals left in the wild, with no more than 50 mature individuals in each of the two populations thought to persist. Erythrocebus baumstarki has a small extent of occurrence (EOO may be as small as 12,300 km²) and fragmented geographic distribution. A rapid population reduction has been observed. One, probably two, of the three historic (pre-2009) populations are now extinct. The geographic distribution of the one confirmed remaining populations (currently in an area of approximately 11,500 km² in the western Serengeti) appears to be about 56% the size that it was in 1995 (20,536 km²) and now comprises two fragments. The current number of E. baumstarki is probably between 80 and 200 individuals; the number of mature individuals may now be no more than 40 to 100 individuals. The EOO, area of occupancy (AOO), and population size are expected to continue to decline as the causes (mainly habitat degradation, fragmentation, and loss, but also hunting and reduced access to water) are ongoing and unlikely to be reversed in the foreseeable future.
habitat: Erythrocebus baumstarki is a medium-sized, diurnal, largely terrestrial, monkey. Occurs mainly in semi-arid acacia woodland, particularly Whistling Thorn Acacia (Acacia drepanolobium) woodland (De Jong et al. 2009). The habits and ecology of this species are poorly known but are likely similar to those of E. p. pyrrhonotus in northwestern Uganda (Hall 1965) and central Kenya (Chism and Rowell 1988, Isbell 1998, 2013).
threats:
The main threats to E. baumstarki are habitat degradation, fragmentation, and loss due primarily to agricultural expansion and intensification (both crops and livestock), charcoal production, fire, and ‘development’ activities (e.g., settlements, roads; De Jong et al. 2009, Loishooki et al. 2016), but also hunting and loss of access to water. In Grumeti Game Reserve, western Serengeti, Whistling Thorn Acacia woodlands are disappearing due to over-stocking by livestock (G. Tolchard pers. comm. 2019).

Bushmeat is a serious problem in the western Serengeti (K. Snyder pers. comm. 2020) and a threat to E. baumstarki (Loishooki et al. 2016). The pelt is used in traditional ceremonies (including dances and witchcraft). Hunted in retaliation for crop raiding (Loishooki et al. 2016). Hunted by domestic dogs in Burko Masailand Hunting Concession (D. Hurt pers. comm. 2019) and, probably, other places.

The human population is doubling every 20-30 years over much of the range of E. baumstarki. ‘Rate of Natural Increase’ of the human population in Tanzania is 3.0%, compared to a worldwide rate of 1.1% (PRB 2019). Over the past decade, the western boundary of the Serengeti-Mara Ecosystem experienced a sharp human population increase, including a four-fold increase in some of the higher rainfall areas (Veldhuis et al. 2019).

The human population growth rate is also high in the Arusha-Kilimanjaro region (TNBS  2020). Patas habitat is being increasingly converted into cropland in the densely settled areas at the western boundary of the protected areas of the western Serengeti (Serengeti National Park, Maswa Game Reserve, Keijereshi Game Reserve, Grumeti Game Reserve, Ikorongo Game Reserve, Ikona Wildlife Management Area). Due to a shortage of grazing land, pastoralists move their livestock illegally into protected areas (Veldhuis et al. 2019). As such, there is ever increasing competition between people and E. baumstarki for habitat and water (De Jong et al. 2009, G. Tolchard pers. comm. 2019). Within the Ngorongoro Conservation Area, the human populations increased nine-fold in just 46 years (from 8,700 in 1966 to 79,000 in 2012) while the number of livestock in 2012 was 300,000 (IUCN 2014).
population:
Old records indicate that Erythrocebus baumstarki has, historically, always occurred at low densities.

Numbers of E. baumstarki are in rapid decline. In 2009, there were <900 individuals in Tanzania (De Jong et al. 2009). Currently, it can be assumed that the remaining global population (now limited to Tanzania) has between 80 and 200 E. baumstarki remaining in the wild. Given that about half of the individuals in populations of E. patas are mature (Hall 1965, Struhsaker and Gartlan 1970, Chism and Rowell 1988), the number of mature E. baumstarki is probably between 40 and 100.

One, probably two, of the three historic (pre-2009) populations are now extinct (of those that existed before 1995). The Serengeti population appears to be in rapid decline. Twenty-one encounters with Erythrocebus in Tanzania have been documented since January 2009. Nineteen of these records are from the western Serengeti (1-24 individuals/encounter), one from Ngorongoro Conservation Area (one individual, 2012), and one from the Arusha population (one individual, 2014). Some western Serengeti groups were likely counted more than once. Ten of the western Serengeti records were obtained during a survey completed in 2015 (Loishooki et al. 2016). Ten of the 21 records are for solitary individuals and 11 records are for groups. Group size for five of the 11 groups is unknown, six groups comprised 2-24 individuals (83 individuals in total; mean = 12.2 individuals/group). Assuming that all six groups were encountered only once, the total number of individuals in Tanzania between January 2009 and December 2019 was between 93 (83 individuals and five uncounted groups with a minimum of two individuals) and 203 (83 individuals and five uncounted groups with a maximum of 24 individuals. It is highly likely, however, that some solitary individuals and groups were encountered more than once, particularly as the distance between some encounters was small (<100 m). It may be that there are groups in Tanzania that have remained undetected.
range:
Erythocebus baumstarki is endemic to central north Tanzania. In March 2006, T. Butynski and Y. de Jong identified an E. baumstarki skin, from an unknown location in Kenya (specimen ZD.1934.4.7.1, labelled as “Erythocebus patas”), in the Natural History Museum (London). This specimen was collected by Lord Rothschild sometime prior to 1935, presumably in southern Kenya. Patas are known in southern Kenya from the Masai Mara-Loita Hills region and from the Namanga-Amboseli-Tsavo West-Athi River region (De Jong et al. 2008). Although these sites are contiguous with sites for E. baumstarki in northern Tanzania (De Jong et al. 2009), and the Patas of southern Kenya can be safely presumed to be baumstarki, we are not aware of any photographs or specimens of Patas from southern Kenya. Thus, specimen ZD.1934.4.7.1 appears to be the only confirmation that the population of Patas in south Kenya is/was a population of baumstarki.

During a primate survey in the Loita Hills (southern Kenya) in 2012, unverified verbal reports of at least one group of E. patas were received from local people. Otherwise, there are no post-2004 records for Patas from southern Kenya (F. Allan, T. Allan, Z. Cockar, S. Dloniak, D. Grammaticas, S. Hatfield, B. Heath, J. Heath, P. Reynolds, H. Saunders pers. comm. 2019-2020, Y. de Jong and T. Butynski pers. obs.). The last records that we are aware of for Patas in southern Kenya are from south of the Chyulu Hills in 1996 (R. Bonham pers. comm. 2004) and from Tsavo West National Park in 2006 (J. Mutiso pers. comm. 2008). Given the 14-year absence of records for Patas from southern Kenya, it appears that E. baumstarki has been extirpated from Kenya.

With the extirpation of E. baumstarki from Kenya, this species is now endemic to central north Tanzania. Here it occurred in three populations as of 1995: Serengeti ecosystem (including western Ngorongoro Conservation Area and Grumeti Game Reserve), southwest of Mount Kilimanjaro, and southwest of Arusha (De Jong et al. 2009) with a total geographic distribution of ca 37,400 km² (De Jong et al. 2009, R. Knocker pers. comm. 2012, Y. de Jong & T. Butynski unpubl. data 2019). Today, the Kilimanjaro population probably no longer exist (C. Foley pers. comm. 2019). The most recent evidence for the Arusha population is from 2014 when a Patas was killed by a domestic dog in Burko Masailand Hunting Concession (D. Hurt pers. comm.). Preliminary data suggest that the historic geographic distribution of the Serengeti population (ca. 20,500 km²) declined to ca. 11,500 km² (56% of historic range) as of 2019, and fragmented into two populations; one in western Serengeti (last encounter in 2019; Loishooki et al. 2016, R. Hoare pers comm 2010, Lomo Tanzania Safari, D. Hurt G. Tolchard pers. comm 2019) and one in western Ngorongoro Conservation Area (last and only encounter in 2012; R. Knocker pers. comm 2012). The Ngorongoro Conservation Area record (Naibardat Hill), the first record of E. baumstarki in the Ngorongoro Conservation Area, is, however, of a single encounter with what seemed to be a solitary individual (R. Knocker pers. comm. 2012).

The extent of occurrence for this species is somewhere between 12,300 km² (Y. de Jong & T. Butynski unpubl. data 2019) and 31,267 km² (estimated using a minimum convex polygon around polygons on the submitted distribution map).

Erythrocebus baumstarki has an altitudinal range of 800–1,580 (De Jong et al. 2009).
useTrade: Most killing of Southern Patas Monkeys is persecution/control resulting from resource competition. Bushmeat is a serious problem in the western Serengeti (K. Snyder pers. comm. 2020) and a threat to E. baumstarki (Loishooki et al. 2016). The pelt is used in traditional ceremonies (including dances and witchcraft). Hunted in retaliation for crop raiding (Loishooki et al. 2016). Hunted by domestic dogs in Burko Masailand Hunting Concession (D. Hurt pers. comm. 2019) and, probably, other places.
conservationActions:
All 21 records for Erythocebus baumstarki since 2009 are from protected areas [Serengeti National Park (N=16), Ngorongoro Conservation Area (1), Grumeti Game Reserve (1), Ikorongo Game Reserve (1), Ikona Wildlife Management Area (1), Burko Masailand Hunting Concession (1)].

There are currently no conservation activities in place that focus on E. baumstarki. Enhance support for the conservation of E. baumstarki in Serengeti National Park, Ngorongoro Conservation Area, privately protected areas, and hunting concessions. Put into place, and fund, conservation, research, and monitoring activities that focus on E. baumstarki. Bring the plight of E. baumstarki to wide national and international attention so the urgent actions for its conservation are funded and implemented.

rationale: Allochrocebus lhoesti has undergone a significant population decrease in the past and continues to decline. Most of this species' range is in a region of intense conflict, which has exacerbated the known threats, which are mainly bushmeat hunting and habitat loss due, in large part, to artisanal mining. It is suspected that these declines will continue in the face of ongoing political turmoil, and will result in an overall population reduction of more than 30% over a 30-year time frame from 1995 to 2025 (given a 10-year generation period), qualifying the taxon as Vulnerable A4cd.
habitat:
L’Hoest’s Monkey is semi-terrestrial and restricted to the lowland, submontane and montane forests of the Albertine Rift in eastern DRC and western Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda. The species forms one-male-multi-female groups that travel long distances on the ground and forage mainly in lower forest strata (Kaplin and Moermond 2000, Ukizintambara 2010). They are omnivorous with a diet consisting of terrestrial herbaceous vegetation, invertebrates, mushrooms, fruits, flowers and small vertebrates. In areas close to cultivated land, such as the periphery of Bwindi Impenetrable and Nyungwe national parks, these monkeys enter fields and gardens to forage on crops. They are found in small groups averaging 10 to 17 individuals, although larger bands of up to 37 individuals have been observed (Tashiro 2006).

This species is often sympatric with Owl-faced Monkeys Cercopithecus hamlyni, especially west of the Albertine Rift. It is among the most important primate prey of leopards Panthera pardus in the Ituri Forest (Hart et al. 1996).
threats: Much of the geographic range of l’Hoest’s Monkey has seen significant human population growth, displacement and armed conflicts that have put pressure on natural resources. Deforestation is taking place on the eastern edge of the main block of the species' range in DRC, primarily as a result of agricultural expansion. This monkey is hunted for meat in parts of its range and is particularly vulnerable to both snaring and shotgun hunting. Bushmeat specimens have been seen at Wanie Rukula, Pembeliba and Kindu, which might come from Lualaba in DRC (J. Hart pers. obs. 2016). Expansion of artisanal mining and shifting cultivation pose additional threats, especially in eastern DRC. Mining is of particular concern as mining operations can open up formerly remote areas to exploitation and settlement, leading to habitat loss. Mines are also centres of commercial bushmeat trade and a stimulus for poaching in protected areas (Spira et al. 2019).
population: Current population size is unknown, but the abundance of l'Hoest's Monkey in DRC is certainly decreasing due to hunting. Widespread in the lowland forest block of eastern DRC, but only locally common in the Mikeno Sector of Virunga National Park and Epulu in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve (the latter is probably one of the largest protected populations). It is also common in Bwindi and Nyungwe national parks.
range: Allochrocebus lhoesti ranges from eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), east of the Lualaba River through the Ituri Forest and south to the Itombwe Massif, to Burundi, Rwanda and western Uganda (southwest Kigezi District and the Ruwenzori mountains). The species still occurs in Lualaba, along the eastern bank of the Congo River, but the southern limits of its range are poorly defined. Isolated populations occur east of the main block of the range and include Virunga and Kahuzi-Biega national parks (DRC), Kibira National Park in Burundi, Nyungwe National Park in Rwanda, and Kibale Forest National Park, Kalinzu Forest Reserve, Ruwenzori Mountains National Park, Maramagambo Forest Reserve and Bwindi Impenetrable National Park in Uganda. This species occurs up to 2,900 m asl.
useTrade: This species is hunted with guns and is trapped by snaring for bushmeat.
conservationActions:
Allochrocebus lhoesti is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (as Cercopithecus lhoesti). It is protected by national legislation in Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda, and listed as a partially protected species in DRC. The most important action needed to protect this species is control of bushmeat hunting through effective law enforcement.

Protected areas that are important for the conservation of l’Hoest’s Monkey include: Kahuzi-Biega, Maiko and Virunga national parks and Okapi Wildlife Reserve in DRC; Kibira National Park in Burundi (restricted to the northern sector of Mabayi; Hakizimana 2014); Nyungwe National Park in Rwanda; and Bwindi Impenetrable, Kibale and Ruwenzori Mountains national parks and Kalinzu and Maramagambo forests in Uganda.

rationale: Cercopithecus lowei is listed as Vulnerable because populations throughout its geographic range are estimated to have declined by at least 30% over the past 27 years (three generations, if average generation time is about nine years). Considering the species' now patchy distribution and low population densities at many sites, and that population decline in unprotected areas has been extreme, the total population of this monkey could now number fewer than 10,000 mature individuals. This population decline has occurred mainly as a result of unregulated hunting, habitat loss, habitat degradation and habitat fragmentation due to agriculture, cattle-ranching, human settlement and mining. Hence, the taxon qualifies as Vulnerable under criterion A.
habitat: Lowe’s Monkey has been found in a wide variety of tropical forest types, including lowland forest, gallery forest, mangroves and forest-savanna mosaic zones. It has been found in secondary forest, farmland and farmbush. Cercopithecus lowei is active mainly in low (<5 m) forest strata and on the ground. Its locomotion is a mix of quadrupedal walking and running. Leaping and climbing are less common, and dropping is rare (Schubert 2011). Home range estimates from 1.5–40 ha were given by Bourlière et al. (1970). In Adiopodoumé, Côte d’Ivoire, a group varied in size from 6-16 individuals, while in Boabeng-Fiema Monkey Sanctuary, Ghana, average group size was 16.6 (s.d.=3.8, N=13). Cercopithecus lowei has a large repertoire of vocalisations. One of the most prominent calls is the adult male's loud call, which consists of low-frequency double booms followed by a series of higher-frequency hacks (Bourlière et al. 1970).
threats:
The greatest threat to the Lowe’s Monkey is from hunting, using firearms and snares (Oates 2011, Danquah et al. 2012). Lowe’s Monkeys are hunted as food for personal consumption and for the bushmeat trade, and their loud vocalizations make them an easy target for hunters. A recent market survey indicated that C. lowei and Perodicticus potto are now the two top primate species found in bushmeat markets in Côte d’Ivoire (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2017), in part reflecting the scarcity of other species. The monkeys are also captured as pets, both in live-traps as adults or as young when the mother is killed for the meat trade.

Habitat loss and fragmentation due to conversion of forests and farmbush into cocoa, palm oil and rubber plantations is an almost equally important threat to this species. Since 2000, Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana have lost 17% and 13% respectively of their forest cover (Global Forest Watch 2019). Between 1988 and 2007, at least 23,000 km² of the Upper Guinean rainforest in Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana were cleared for cocoa farms, and the clearing of forests for cocoa production continues in both countries. In Côte d’Ivoire, the annual deforestation rate between 2000 and 2015 was estimated to be 2.69%, with an average forest loss of 2,500 km²/year (BNETD 2016), and many of the ~180 forest reserves in the geographic range of C. lowei have already been converted into plantations and human settlements. In some parts of Ghana, surface mining for gold, diamonds, bauxite and other metals also threatens the species’ survival, even in farmbush areas (E. Wiafe, pers. obs. 2015).
population:
Although firm data are lacking, the total population of this monkey could number fewer than 10,000 mature individuals. Cercopithecus lowei now has a patchy distribution and low population densities at most of the sites where it still occurs (Gatti 2010, Danquah et al. 2012).

In Ghana, at the Boabeng-Fiema Monkey Sanctuary (BFMS) in Kintampo South where the species is protected by a traditional belief system (Wong and Sicotte 2006), the population size in the BFMS proper was estimated to be 181 individuals per km² in 2012 (Elgart 2016). However, a 2009 survey of several protected areas in southwestern Ghana found C. lowei at low encounter rates (0.04–0.4 groups per km²; Danquah et al. 2012).

In Côte d’Ivoire, the most important population is found in the Tanoé swamp forest, where a density of 11.7 groups per km² was reported by a survey conducted in 2009 (Gonedelé Bi, unpublished data), but very low encounter rates (0.03–0.33 groups per km²) were reported (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2014) for several community forests and protected areas (that have not been converted into cocoa plantations). Strong poaching pressure and habitat degradation continue in most protected areas, presenting a serious threat to the survival of of C. lowei populations (Bitty et al. 2015).

Considering the foregoing information, it is evident that the total population of C. lowei has declined by more than 30% during the last three generations, hence qualifying this taxon for a Vulnerable threat category.
range: Cercopithecus lowei once ranged from the Cavally River on the Côte d’Ivoire-Liberia border in the west to the Volta River in Ghana in the east (Oates 2011). Galat-Luong et al. (2013) reported observing this species as far north as 6°34'30°N in the Forêt classée de Duékoué, east of the N'zo River and west of Sassandra River. Between the Cavally and Sassadra-N'zo rivers in western Côte d’Ivoire, monkeys resembling C. campbelli were observed, as well as individuals with coat patterns intermediate between C. lowei and C. campbelli, indicating that this is a zone of hybridization (Booth 1955, Oates 1988).
useTrade: This species is hunted for local consumption and local trade.
conservationActions:
Although it was once widespread, and is able to persist in modified habitats if hunting pressure is low, Cercopithecus lowei population declines in unprotected areas has been extreme, and the species now survives mainly in protected areas. Law enforcement against hunting is weak or lacking even in many protected areas; nonetheless, populations appear to be stable in a few well-protected areas. For example, the results of surveys carried out in 1993 and 2009–2010 (Oates et al. 2000, Wiafe 2016) indicate that conservation efforts in Kakum National Park, Ghana, in the last 20 years have been effective.

Cercopithecus lowei is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

rationale: This species’ Red List status has been upgraded to Near Threatened from Least Concern in the 2008 assessment in view of the fact it has been experiencing ever-increasing hunting pressure and populations are suspected to be declining, but at the rate of less than 30% over a period of 36 years (based on the generation period of 12 years). The habitats throughout its range have experienced ≥30% loss and degradation, and human population size in the range countries increased by 120% during the same period. The species, however, still has a wide distribution, is adaptable and can persist in some degraded habitats such as farmbush as long as hunting pressure is low or non-existent. The predicted future trajectory for populations of Cercopithecus campbelli is an accelerated rate of decline as larger-bodied primates are being depleted from their shared forests
habitat:
Campbell’s Monkey is found in a wide variety of habitats, including lowland forest, gallery forest, mangroves, woodland, woody savanna and farrow lands (Oates 2011, Campbell 2013). It also occurs in secondary forest, in areas of subsistence agriculture, and in farmbush. The highest elevation area where this species occurs is the lower latitudinal locations (up to 600 m) in the Guinea Highlands. The estimated home range size for two groups in Taï NP was 52 ha and 67 ha (Buzzard and Eckardt 2007). C. campbelli mainly feeds on fruits and insects. In Taï NP, the diet of this species was found to be 46% fruits, 33% animal matter and 8% leaves (Buzzard 2006). Foraging for insects often involved unrolling curled-up leaves.

The typical group structure is a one-male group, but the species is sometimes found in multi-male groups, and all-male groups outside heterosexual groups have been observed (Galat and Galat-Luong 1985, Buzzard 2006). In Taï NP in 1976, mean group size was 11.4 individuals (5–33, N=8) (Galat and Galat-Luong 1985), but had decreased to 9.3 (N=3) in 2001 (Buzzard and Eckardt 2007). Group size in Guinea-Bissau ranged from 1–20 (Gippoliti and Dell'Omo 2003). On Tiwai Island, mean group size recorded in 1982–1984 was 14 (Oates et al. 1990).
