This species is preyed upon by Leopards (Panthera pardus), Western Chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes verus), and Crowned Hawk-eagles (Stephanoaetus coronatus) (Zuberbühler and Jenny 2002).
threats:
Cercopithecus campbelli has been impacted by, first and foremost, bushmeat hunting, and secondly, habitat loss.

Due to its relatively small body size, it was not a prime target for hunters until quite recently, but because the larger-bodied primates such as the Upper Guinea Red Colobus (Piliocolobus badius) and the King Colobus (Colobus polykomos) have been decimated or even extirpated from many areas due to unregulated hunting, even this small-bodied guenon (adult male ~4.5 kg) has now become a target for hunters. In Mount Nimba, Liberia, Bené et al. (2013) monitored hunters’ activities in 2009–2011 and found a high rate (0.7 per km) of encountering hunters carrying the carcasses of this species. In Konobo District in Liberia on the border with Côte d’Ivoire, an unsustainable level of hunting is taking place (Covey and McGraw 2014). During Tweh et al.’s (2015) primate surveys, conducted across Liberia in August-December 2010, hunting signs (empty cartridges, gunshots, poachers’ camps, and snares) were the most frequently observed anthropogenic signs. Due to unregulated hunting, logging and mining operations, the Lagoas de Cufada NP in Guinea-Bissau is becoming an “empty forest” (Starin 2010). Minhós et al.’s (2013) study using a DNA bar-coding method estimated that 1,550 individual primates, which included C. campbelli, sold in two markets in Guinea-Bissau, were consumed by the inhabitants during the 2010 dry season. Hunting pressure has been exacerbated by an increase of 120% in human population size in the habitat countries during the last three decades (World Bank 2019).

Habitat loss through deforestation and forest fragmentation is due to creation of road networks, agriculture and mining (Gippoliti and Dell’Omo 2003, Starin 2010, Minhós et al. 2013, Covey and McGraw 2014, Greengrass 2016). This species once thrived in disturbed habitats and farmbush, but many of these habitats have been converted to plantations of non-native species.
population:
Cercopithecus campbelli is still common in some areas, although its total geographic range has been reduced by deforestation, forest fragmentation and forest conversion. In Senegal, other than the fact that this species is present in the Parc National de Basse Casamance and several forest reserves, information on this species is scarce (P.I. Ndiaye pers. comm. 2019). In Guinea-Bissau, the species is still widespread except in the highest latitudinal areas in the northeast (Limoges 1989 cited in Gippoliti and Dell'Omo 2003, Minhós et al. 2013), but Bersacola et al.’s (2018) survey in 2015 at Dulombi and Paiai in Dulombi National Park found low encounter rates of 0.38 and 0.18 groups per km, respectively. This species is widespread and still common also in many parts of Guinea, even though hunting pressure is increasing, while many forests are fragmented and degraded (Campbell 2013, WCF 2015a).

In Sierra Leone, C. campbelli occurs at Tiwai Island Wildlife Sanctuary (hereafter Tiwai), the Gola Forest National Park, Loma Mountains Forest Reserve (FR), Bumbuna in northern Sierra Leone, where the hydroelectric dam is being upgraded, and several other protected areas. Encounter rates vary between 0.02 to 0.54 groups per km (Brncic et al. 2015, Ganas-Swaray et al. 2017). In the early 1980s, population density at Tiwai was 39-44 per km² (Oates et al. 1990). In Gola Forest NP, surveys made before and after the 1991–2001 civil war obtained various group sighting data (Davies 1987, Klop et al. 2008, Lindsell et al. 2011). For example, Klop et al. (2008) reported an average encounter rate of 0.34 groups per km for their surveys conducted between October 2005 and June 2007, but the use of different survey methods and the manner in which auditory and visual sighting data were presented in different reports make it impossible to gauge with precision any changes in population numbers of this species. Nevertheless, Lindsell et al. (2011) concluded that primates “continue to have healthy populations in the forest… and showed little or no sign of reduced abundance". For this reason, the data are still insufficient to assess the current status of this species across the rest of Sierra Leone.

In Liberia, this species occurs in a number of protected areas including North Lorma National Park, Gola National Park, Grebo-Krahn National Park, Krahn-Bassa National Forest, and Sapo National Park. Group encounter rates obtained in the early 2000s in all of these forests were in the range of 0.10–0.33 (Waitkuwait 2003, Barrie et al. 2007, Vogt 2011, WCF 2015b).

In Côte d’Ivoire, C. campbelli occurs in several protected areas including Goulaleu and Krozialé Forêt Classées (FC or Classified Forests), Taï National Park, Goin-Débé FC, Cavally FC (Zuberbühler and Jenny 2002, Normand 2010, Kramoko et al. 2017) and community forests. However, Campbell’s Monkey appears to have been extirpated from Monogaga FC, Rapide Grah FC, Mont Péko NP, Kani-Bandaman Rouge FC, Séguéla FC and Koba FC, as all were converted into cocoa plantations (Bitty et al. 2015). The most important population is found in Taï NP, where a density of 24.4 individuals per km² was reported more than 15 years ago (Zuberbühler and Jenny 2002). More recent surveys conducted in Goin-Débé FC found that encounter rates had declined from 1.65 groups per km in 2007 to 1.31 in 2009–2010, and from 3.08 to 1.93 in Cavally FC (Normand 2010). Outside the protected areas in Côte d’Ivoire, this species persists even in areas where hunting occurs regularly (Soiret et al. 2019).
range: Campbell’s Monkey ranges from the Gambia and Senegal, just north of the Casamance River in the west, through Guinea-Bissau, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia to the Cavally River on the Côte d’Ivoire-Liberia border in the east (Oates 2011). Between the Cavally and Sassandra-Nzo Rivers in western Côte d’Ivoire is a region where individuals of this species and of Cercopithecus lowei occur, as well as individuals with intermediate features (Oates 1988, 2011). This species also occurs on the island of Caravela in the Bijagos Archipelago of Guinea-Bissau (Gippoliti and Dell'Omo 2003).
useTrade: Campbell’s Monkey is hunted for bushmeat in all its range countries (see Threats). It costs 2,000 CFA (equivalent of US$ 3.6 as of 2019) to purchase four or five pieces of monkey meat at a market in Bissau, Guinea-Bissau (Starin 2010), while a small individual of this species is sold for about 3,000 CFA (US$ 5.3), and an adult male for 5,000 CFA (US$ 8.8) in markets in southwestern Côte d’Ivoire (S. Soiret pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions:
Cercopithecus campbelli is listed on Appendix II of CITES and Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

This species occurs in many protected areas in its geographic range (e.g., Gola Forest NP, Loma Mountains NP, and Tiwai Island in Sierra Leone; Sapo NP and Grebo NP in Liberia; Taï NP in Côte d'Ivoire), but anti-poaching enforcement is poor in Sapo NP and in the northern sections of Taï NP away from the research station. Rigorous law enforcement against poaching and in protected areas is needed throughout the range. Protection is sometimes improved where there is a permanent presence of researchers (e.g. southern Taï NP).

rationale: Previously assessed as Vulnerable, Cercopithecus diana is now listed as Endangered. Based on deforestation rates in Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea, and Ivory Coast, this species has lost at least 30% of its primary habitat over the past three generations (~1990-2018). Due to the combined negative impacts of hunting, which has resulted in the extirpation of a number of subpopulations and reduced others to levels that may not be viable over the long-term, C. diana numbers are suspected to have undergone a decline of 50% or more over this time period.
habitat: This largely arboreal species lives in the canopy of primary and old secondary lowland moist forest, and riverine and gallery forests. It is rare in degraded forest, but it appears that it can survive in lightly-logged forest where the canopy is relatively intact. This species occurs from just above sea level in Sierra Leone to at least 1,300 m asl in the Loma Mountains, Sierra Leone. Diana Monkeys feed mainly on fruits, arthropods and flowers; leaves become seasonally important when other items are less available (Buzzard 2006, Whitesides 1989). They spend much of their time in association with other primate species, which may be an anti-predator strategy (Whitesides 1991, Noë and Bshary 1997). Humans are the main predators on Diana Monkeys (Koné and Refisch 2007, McGraw 2007). Other important predators include Chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes), Leopards (Panthera pardus), and African Crowned Eagles (Stephanoatus coronatus) (Boesch and Boesch 1989, Shultz and Noë 2007, Oates 2011).
threats:
Cercopithecus diana is threatened by hunting, and habitat degradation and loss.

The relatively large body size of this species and the value of its meat and skin make it a preferred game species across its range in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. Subsistence hunting is widespread and laws against commercial hunting and other illegal activities (mining, habitat encroachment) inside protected areas are poorly enforced throughout the C. diana range. The increasing scale of commercial hunting poses the greatest threat (Béné et al., 2013c; Covey and McGraw 2014, Greengrass 2016). Although Diana Monkeys adopt certain behaviours to minimize mortality due to hunting (Bshary 2001, Koné and Refisch 2007), they are now rarely found in areas with high hunting pressure, compared to areas where hunting pressure is relatively low (N’Goran et al. 2012). In Côte d’Ivoire, the species has been extirpated from almost all the protected areas within its Extent of Occurrence (>80%).

In addition to hunting pressure, large-scale deforestation in the region, through mining, logging, conversion to agricultural land and charcoal production, continues to reduce the habitat available to this species (McGraw 1998, Tweh et al. 2014, Bitty et al. 2015, WCF 2015).  Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea each lost between 14 and 21% of their total forest cover between 2001 and 2017, and dominant drivers of loss continue (www.globalforestwatch.org).

Combining the significant loss of suitable habitat with intense poaching pressure, it is suspected that the total population of C. diana has declined by more than 50% during the last three generations.
population: Cercopithecus diana is now a rare and declining species throughout most of its range. Populations are affected by habitat loss through agricultural expansion (cocoa, oil palm, rubber, rice), intensive commercial logging, and by hunting for bushmeat (Lindsell et al. 2011; Gonedele Bi et al. 2012; Béné et al. 2013a,b,c; Covey and McGraw 2014; Greengrass 2016). In Côte d’Ivoire, the species has been extirpated from almost all (>80%) the protected areas within its extent of occurrence (EOO). In the Taï NP where a viable population occurs, an estimated 97,000 individuals were reported in 2006-2008 based on survey data (N’Goran et al. 2012); a number that has almost certainly declined since that time. Within Taï NP, Diana Monkey abundance is strongly influenced by hunting pressure and this monkey is nearly 100 times more common near research stations and tourist sites than areas where hunting is unchecked (N’Goran et al. 2012). Outside Taï NP, a 2007-2010 biomonitoring survey reported the species in two reserves (Cavally, Goin-Debe) at a very low encounter rate (0.08–0.2 grp/km) with a decrease in the encounter rate ranging from 0.2 to 0.16 grp/km in Cavally FR and 0.08 to 0 grp/km in Goin Debe FR (WCF 2010). The ongoing hunting pressure, habitat encroachment and human settlement with these forest reserves pose severe threat to the survival of remaining populations. Currently, viable populations are found in Tiwaï Island Wildlife Sanctuary, Gola Forest National Park and Loma Mountains National Park in Sierra Leone; Sapo National Park in Liberia. Surveys within the Grebo-Sapo Corridor of southeastern Liberia reported a Diana Monkey encounter rate (N/km) of 0.31 (Furnell et al. 2015). The ongoing strong hunting pressure, habitat encroachment, and mining within these areas pose severe threats on these populations (Tacugama Chimpanzee Sanctuary 2012, WCF, 2015).
range: This species is found in the forests of Upper Guinea in West Africa, ranging from coastal southeastern Guinea to Sierra Leone, Liberia, and southern Côte d'Ivoire (west of the Sassandra River).
conservationActions:
Cercopithecus diana is threatened by habitat loss and hunting pressure, and is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class A of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

The species is found in the following protected and semi-protected areas:
  • Cote d'IvoireTai National Park (330,000 ha)
  • Cavally Classified Forest (64,200 ha)
  • Goin-Debe Classified Forest (133,100 ha)
  • Sierra LeoneTiwai Island Wildlife Sanctuary (1,200 ha)
  • Gola Forest National Park (71,070 ha)
  • Loma Mountains National Park (33,200 ha)
  • LiberiaSapo National Park (180,400 ha)

rationale:
The Roloway Monkey (Cercopithecus roloway) is listed as Critically Endangered, compared to Endangered in the previous assessment, because the species has suffered greatly from uncontrolled hunting for the bushmeat trade, as well as losing a considerable amount of its original habitat to logging and agriculture over the past ~30 years (ca three generations), leading to a population decline that is estimated to have exceeded 80%. The species is no longer found in most parts of its historical range, resulting in a major decline in its area of occupancy (AOO) as a consequence of ongoing hunting pressure, and habitat conversion and destruction. The species is at high risk of local extinction at three of the only four sites where it has been reported recently.
An estimated population reduction of >80% in three generations (1991–2018) qualifies this species as Critically Endangered under criterion A. The causes of the reduction, although largely understood, have certainly not ceased and are not easily reversible.
habitat: This highly arboreal species was once confined to moist evergreen and moist semi-deciduous primary and old secondary lowland forests and swamp forests. Field studies on its ecology and behaviour are scarce. A group of 14–15 individuals in Bia National Park, Ghana, had a home range of 190 ha, and a diet of fruits (including mature seeds), insects and leaves (Curtin 2002). A mean group size of 6.85 (range: 2.89–11.85) and a population density of 36 individuals per km² were recorded in parts of the Tanoé swamp forest in Côte d’Ivoire during a survey in 2009 (S. Gonedelé Bi, unpublished data).
threats: This species is threatened by hunting and habitat degradation and loss. The relatively large body size of this species, its conspicuousness and the value of its meat and skin make it a preferred target of hunters. Large-scale deforestation in the region, through logging, conversion to agricultural land and charcoal production, continues to reduce the habitat available to this species, especially in Côte d’Ivoire (McGraw 1998, McGraw and Oates 2007, Bitty et al. 2015). Between 2001 and 2017, Côte d’Ivoire is estimated to have lost 17% of its tree cover (Global Forest Watch 2019) and this loss has been exacerbated by a large increase in the human population in the southern forest zone and the spread of cocoa farming, including illegal cocoa cultivation within protected areas (Bitty et al. 2015, Higonnet et al. 2018). In Ghana, hunting for the commercial bushmeat trade has decimated populations of Roloway Monkeys; recent surveys have failed to find any surviving groups in two national parks (Bia and Nini-Suhien) and in several forest reserves where it formerly occurred (Gatti 2010, Oates 1999, Osei et al. 2015). Even though relatively large areas of suitable habitat remain in these theoretically protected areas, laws against hunting in these areas have been poorly enforced. The species has probably undergone a decline of more than 90% in Ghana.
population: Cercopithecus roloway is now extirpated from most of its original range and it is likely that fewer than 2,000 individuals survive in Cote d’Ivoire and Ghana. Primatologists have been documenting its decline since the mid-1990s (Struhsaker and Oates 1995; Oates et al. 1997; Abedi-Lartey 1998, 1999; Oates 2006; Gonedelé Bi et al. 2008, 2012, 2014; Gatti 2010; Wiafe 2013; Bitty et al. 2015; Osei et al. 2015). The Tanoé forest in southeast Cote d’Ivoire seems to still support a population of the species (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2008), as does the adjacent Kwabre forest in southwest Ghana (Osei et al. 2015). A very small number of individuals may have survived in central coastal Côte d’Ivoire: two individuals were sighted in a mixed species group in Dassioko Sud Forest Reserve in 2012, and in 2013 a specimen was retrieved from a poacher in Petit Jacqueville, a remote camp on the outskirts of Port Gauthier Forest Reserve (S. Gonedelé Bi, pers. obs. 2016).
range: Cercopithecus roloway is endemic to Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana. It once occurred from the Sassandra River, Côte d'Ivoire, north and east to Goaso in the Brong-Ahafo Region and east to the Pra River, Ghana (Oates 1988, Grubb et al. 1998, Oates et al. 2000). There is an historical museum record and some reports of this species in Togo to the east of Lake Volta (see Campbell et al. 2008 for a summary), but recent surveys failed to document the persistence of the species in Togo and there is considerable doubt about the provenance of the museum specimen. The last forests where this rare primate species still exists are located in central coastal and southeast Cote d’Ivoire (Dassioko Sud and Port Gauthier forest reserves, Tanoé forest) and southwest Ghana (Kwabre forest).
useTrade: Roloway Monkeys have long been hunted to provide meat for local consumption. Roloway Monkey carcasses have historically been traded as bushmeat for commercial gain, along with the carcasses of many other forest mammal species in West Africa. The relatively large size of this monkey and the value of its meat and skin make it a preferred target of hunters. However, the rarity of Roloway Monkeys means that their meat will now be only a very small component of any local diets and will no longer be a significant component of any trade.
conservationActions:
The Roloway Monkey is one of the most threatened monkeys of the Upper Guinean Forest block (Oates 1996). It has previously been recorded from a number of protected areas across the region. However, recent surveys failed to confirm the presence of Roloway in several forest reserves in Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana.

In Côte d’Ivoire, the Roloway Monkey has been extirpated from almost all the protected areas and forest reserves where it was recorded in the past. In the late 1990s, surveys documented the species in the Yaya Forest Reserve, Niégré Forest Reserve, Bolo Ouest Forest Reserve, Marahoué National Park, but more recent surveys report its extinction from these forests (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2008, 2012, 2014; Bitty et al. 2015); only the Tanoé forest is confirmed to still harbour a small population. A couple of individuals were observed during a survey of the Dassioko Sud Forest Reserve in 2012, and its probable survival in Port Gauthier Forest Reserve has been reported by local residents, but follow-up surveys in these two forests have not yet confirmed its continuing survival (S. Gonedelé Bi, pers. obs. 2016).

In neighbouring Ghana, recent surveys failed to confirm the presence of the species in the few forest reserves that were suspected to be its last refuges in the country including Krokosua Hills Forest Reserve, Ankasa Conservation Area, Bia National Park (Oates 2006, Gatti 2010, Osei et al. 2015) and Dadieso Forest Reserve (Wiafe 2013). Only the swampy community-owned Kwabre forest has been confirmed to still harbour a population of this monkey (Osei et al. 2015).

Conservation programmes that involve local communities living around the Tanoé and Kwabre swamp forests have been developed and need to be strengthened, along with the appropriate involvement of national government agencies and international conservation organizations. Further careful surveys are needed in Tanoé and Kwabre, along with surveys to ascertain whether any viable populations survive elsewhere.

This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class A of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

rationale: A Red List status of Vulnerable was proposed for this species at the time of its description (Hart et al. 2012). Currently, Cercopithecus lomamiensis is known to occur over a small extent of occurrence (which is likely to be smaller than 20,000 km²), which—despite its remoteness—is exploited by commercial bushmeat hunters supplying regional urban centres, in particular Kisangani. The largely terrestrial Lesula is vulnerable to snare trapping and hunting with dogs, indeed the first specimens collected originated from hunters (Hart et al. 2012). The Lomami National Park, patrolled by armed park guards, protects only 20% of the Lesula’s known range. Outside the park, hunting is largely uncontrolled.
habitat: Cercopithecus lomamiensis is a medium-sized monkey. The species occupies closed-canopy terra firma forest. It is uncommon or absent from secondary forests. Cercopithecus lomamiensis is terrestrial, although it does climb in the lower and middle forest strata. Based on camera trap studies in Lomami National Park, group size is usually 5–15 individuals; however, 30 animals were identified in one series of video recordings. Group size at a hunted site is lower (also based on a camera trap study), with a maximum of 11 individuals detected (McPhee 2015). Foods include fruits gathered from forest floor and herbaceous vegetation, in particular meristems of Megaphrynium spp. C. lomamiensis has been recorded feeding on the ground on fallen fruits beneath foraging groups of arboreal primates.
threats:
Cercopithecus lomamiensis is threatened over most of its range by uncontrolled commercial bushmeat hunting. Cercopithecus lomamiensis is particularly vulnerable to snares set for duikers and bushpigs, although it is not targeted. C. lomamiensis population densities are lower in heavily-hunted areas relative to patrolled protected areas with similar forest habitats.

Localized habitat loss caused by shifting agriculture affects the species’ range, in particular at its northern limits in the Opala area. Habitat loss through further expansion of subsistence shifting cultivation and commercial growing of upland rice is likely to increase in the future.
population: Cercopithecus lomamiensis occurs widely across its known range and can be locally abundant in some areas (Hart et al. 2012). Total population size is unknown, but thought to be more than 10,000 individuals.
range: The range of Cercopithecus lomamiensis is estimated at 19,600 km² in eastern-central Democratic Republic of Congo. Most of this range has very little human settlement or disturbance at present; however, localized habitat loss is occurring on the northern limits in the Opala region. The species was unknown before 2007, and range loss to shifting cultivation and levels of hunting before that date are not known.
useTrade: Outside Lomami National Park, hunting is largely uncontrolled.
conservationActions:
The species is not listed specifically by CITES, but is included in Appendix II as a member of the genus Cercopithecus. The government of Tshopo Province has designated C. lomamiensis a protected species at provincial level; however, C. lomamiensis should be considered for designation as a totally-protected species at the national level.

Most of the known range of C. lomamiensis is in Tshopo Province (formerly Oriental Province) in eastern-central DRC. It occurs in the Lomami National Park, where patrols protect about 20% of its known geographic range.

rationale: Cercopithecus denti is listed as Least Concern, as it remains widespread, despite being hunted across its range for consumption in rural areas and for the commercial bushmeat trade. It is also threatened by habitat loss and degradation due to shifting agriculture and human settlements, and large parts of its geographic range are exploited by artisanal miners, thus its population is likely to be decreasing.
habitat:
C. denti is a small, arboreal guenon that occurs across a wide range of forest types. In the core of its geographic range, it lives in low- to mid-elevation tropical forest, including closed primary mixed forest, secondary and riverine forest (Thomas 1991). In the eastern part of its range, it occurs in submontane to montane forests up to 2,000 m asl, and sometimes occurs at 2,400 m (Detwiler pers. obs. 2004–2005).

C. denti is yet to be the focus of a systematic behavioural ecology study, but its diet is mostly fruit and arthropod prey (Thomas 1991), and Kingdon (2015) adds flowers, caterpillars, shoots and leaves. Group size estimates range from 7 to 21 individuals (Thomas 1991), and the species forms mixed-species associations with C. ascanius, C. mitis stuhlmanni, C. mitis doggetti, Lophocebus albigena, Colobus guereza and Piliocolobus oustaleti (Sarmiento and Kingdon 2013, Detwiler pers. obs. 2004–2005, Hicks pers. obs. 2004–2008).
threats:
Cercopithecus denti is threatened throughout its range in DRC by subsistence and commercial shotgun hunters who target small, diurnal monkeys. Field biologists have identified fresh kills of C. denti along trade routes to the Kindu and Kisangani markets (Hart pers. obs. 2016, Hicks pers. obs. 2016). A bushmeat study conducted in the main market in Kisangani documented a significant increase in the hunting of small diurnal monkeys, including Cercopithecus, from 2002 to 2008–2009 (2,221 and 8,228 carcasses, respectively) (van Vliet et al. 2012). During both study periods, the two main trade routes for carcasses entering the Kisangani market were Ituri and Lubutu (van Vliet et al. 2012), both of which are core forest areas for C. denti. In a second, more recent study, which investigated urban and rural bushmeat consumption in the greater Kisangani region, small monkeys were among the top three types of bushmeat reported to be preferred and eaten by children (van Vliet et al. 2014).

Cercopithecus denti is likely also sold in bushmeat markets in the southeastern part of the range, the South Kivu area, but it is difficult to confirm species identity, as the carcasses are sold without skin as “monkey” (K. Guschanski pers. comm. 2016). In this area, the Centre de Rehabilitation des Primates de Lwiro cares for wildlife confiscated by park rangers and conservationists, and C. denti is one of the monkey species living at Lwiro (K. Guschanski pers. comm. 2016). The most likely reason for the presence of this species at Lwiro is that young C. denti are captured by hunters when the mother is killed.

Expanding artisanal mining poses a growing threat to C. denti over large areas of its geographic range – in Maniema, North Kivu, South Kivu, Ituri and Haut-Uélé provinces – and illegal mining is established in several of the largest protected areas that support populations of this species, notably Kahuzi-Biega and Maiko national parks, and Okapi Wildlife Reserve. Mining sites that occur far from established roads and villages pose a particularly significant threat, as these sites are often provisioned by resident bushmeat hunters who target primates.

In addition to an increase in hunting pressure, C. denti is impacted in parts of its range by habitat loss through deforestation, agriculture and human settlement (Potapov et al. 2013). Increased rates of deforestation are also associated with artisanal mining in eastern DRC (Butsic et al. 2015).
population:
Cercopithecus denti is likely common throughout the core area of its range. There are no recent survey data for the Ituri Forest, but the species is still common (Hart pers. obs. 2012), and data from surveys conducted in 1986 provided density estimates of 2.41 groups per km² and 23.1 individuals per km² (Thomas 1991). South of Ituri, Hall et al. (2003) reported C. denti population densities of 12.55 and 17.34 individuals per km² at two survey sites in the Itebero lowland sector of Kahuzi-Biega National Park (KBNP; survey data collected 1994–1995). Despite ongoing security issues, encroachment by artisanal miners, and human settlement in the lowland sector of KBNP, C. denti’s occurrence was confirmed in a survey of the Itebero sector in 2012, and in the Kasese sector of the park in 2013 (K. Guschanski, pers. comm. 2016).

Hicks (pers. obs. 2004–2008) found that the species’ occurrence varied from rare (≤0.10 encounters per km walked) to common (0.50 encounters per km walked) at multiple survey sites in the forests south of the Uélé River.

Outside DRC, the only confirmed populations occur in Semuliki National Park, Uganda, and in Nyungwe National Park (including Cyamudongo) in Rwanda. In Nyungwe, C. denti is rare due to the small area of the lower elevation forest that is its preferred habitat (Detwiler pers. obs. 2004–2005, B. Kaplin pers. comm. 2016).

C. denti is known to hybridize with both C. (mitis) doggetti and C. ascanius (Detwiler pers. obs. 2004–2005, Detwiler et al. 2005). A recent genetic study confirmed the identity of a wild C. denti x C. ascanius hybrid living in a small forest fragment near Gisakura (Nyungwe NP headquarters) in Rwanda (Detwiler et al. 2013).
range: Cercopithecus denti is found in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, east and north of the Congo-Lualaba River, extending north to the Uélé River. The species’ western limit is thought to be the lower Itimbiri River (Sarmiento and Kingdon 2013). In a series of primate surveys in northern DRC, C. denti was not encountered at any of the eight sites north of the Uélé River, but was observed at three sites (Aketi-Akuma, Buta and Lebo) north of the upper Itimbiri/Rubi River (Hicks pers. obs. 2004–2008). The eastern limit of the species’ range includes the forests of the Albertine Rift in DRC, Rwanda and Uganda, and possibly Burundi (Sarmiento and Kingdon 2013). It extends east into Semuliki National Park, an extension of the Ituri Forest in western Uganda, and into Nyungwe National Park, including the Cyamudongo forest, in southwestern Rwanda (Sarmiento and Kingdon 2013, B. Kaplin, pers. comm. 2016). The species’ southern limit in DRC is not well known, but likely reaches the forest-savanna ecotone south of Kindu, at approximately 3°S (Hart pers. obs. 2016). In the southeast, C. denti is reported to range to the area of Kabambare, approximately 04°42' S (Sarmiento and Kingdon 2013). Sarmiento and Kingdon (2013) also reported a small extension of its range into northern Burundi, along the Ruzizi Plain, but the current status of this population is not confirmed.
useTrade: Hunted for local consumption and commercial bushmeat trade.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

Several populations occur in protected areas, including Kahuzi-Biega National Park, Maiko National Park, Semuliki National Park, Nyungwe National Park, Okapi Wildlife Reserve and Rubi-Télé Hunting Reserve.

rationale: This species is reassessed as Vulnerable because it has an extent of occurrence greater than 5,000 km² but less than 20,000 km² (EOO = 7,709 km²), and its area of occupancy is less than 2,000 km² (AOO = 1,786 km²). Its geographic range is fragmented with no or limited movement between forest fragments, and there is a continuing decline in the species' EOO, AOO, area and quality of habitat, and number of mature individuals remaining. In addition, Piliocolobus gordonorum is hunted illegally in parts of its range.
habitat: Piliocolobus gordonorum inhabits a variety of forest habitats, including lowland old-growth, secondary and montane forests of the Udzungwa Mountains, and miombo Brachystegia woodland adjacent to old-growth or secondary forest in the lower parts of Mwanihana Forest and elsewhere (Struhsaker et al. 2013). Group size is highly variable, ranging from 7–83 (Struhsaker et al. 2004). Groups are smaller in forests that are small (<5 km²), dominated by deciduous trees, and/or are heavily degraded by human activities, compared to groups living in large, intact and relatively mature blocks of moist, mixed evergreen and semi-deciduous forest (Struhsaker et al. 2004). Recent ecological modelling analyses show the importance of basal area and other vegetative features for P. gordonorum, and preference for lowland to sub-montane zones, relative to montane and upper montane zones (Barelli et al. 2015, Cavada et al. 2016).
threats:
Piliocolobus gordonorum is threatened by illegal hunting and by habitat loss due to logging, conversion to agriculture, collection of firewood, and charcoal production. The population in Magombera, in Kilombera Valley, was severely affected by the construction of the Tanzania-Zambia Railway (in 1972–1975) which bisected Magombera Forest, and through selective logging and agricultural expansion. The presence of the railway facilitated agricultural encroachment into the reserve, and increased the number of bush fires. Agriculture was responsible for a decline in the reserve’s size from 15 km² in 1955 to less than 11 km² by 1979. The area was threatened with total destruction in 2002 when the Government of Tanzania agreed to relocate squatters there from the nearby Kilombero Sugar Estate. Fortunately, the international conservation community appealed to the Government of Tanzania, which averted destruction of the forest, which contains >1,000 red colobus (Struhsaker 2005). 

The local Wahehe people hunt P. gordonorum, particularly in the western and south-western parts of the range (Struhsaker et al. 2013). This is evident from long-term monitoring in the southern Uzungwa Scarp Nature Reserve, where a marked decline has occurred over the last 10 years (Rovero et al. 2015, F. Rovero, unpubl. data).
population: The total population of Piliocolobus gordonorum is difficult to determine with precision due to the many difficulties of counting arboreal primates (Marshall et al. 2008), but it is clearly in the tens of thousands. Efforts to census the species using systematic distance sampling have increased steadily in recent years. Rovero et al. (2009) reviewed existing knowledge and proposed population sizes ranging between 25,000 and 35,000 individuals. Araldi et al. (2014) conducted systematic transect censuses in four major forest blocks (Magombera, Matundu, Mwanihana and Uzungwa Scarp) estimated 45,000–50,000 individuals using distance sampling. These authors, however, did not consider variations in detectability (due to group size, habitat structure, etc.) and density (due to habitat and human disturbance factors), which are important for obtaining precise estimates (Cavada et al. 2016). The large Ndundulu-Luhomero forest may also contain thousands of individuals, given that the encounter rate from a recent survey across Ndundulu averaged 0.59 groups/km walked (N. Cavada and F. Rovero unpubl. data), which is within the upper side of the range of values recorded in other forests (0.08–0.62 groups/km walked; Araldi et al. 2014). In conclusion, while a precise estimate is still unavailable, the total population of P. gordonorum likely ranges between 30,000–40,000 individuals. Yet, some populations, such as in Uzungwa Scarp are under heavy pressure from poaching and are in rapid decline (see below and Rovero et al. 2015).
range:
Piliocolobus gordonorum is restricted to the Udzungwa Mountains in Tanzania, including Udzungwa Mountains National Park and several adjacent forests, most of which have protected status as a Forest Reserve (FR) or a Nature Reserve (NR) status: Kilombero NR, Matundu FR, Uzungwa Scarp NR, Nyanganje FR, Kiranzi-Kitungulu and New Dabaga/Ulangambi (Marshall et al. 2010, Jones 2013, Struhsaker et al. 2013). However, in the recent decades, numerous small forests outside the park have been lost or severely degraded, such as New Dabaga/Ulangambi FR (Marshall et al. 2005). The only viable population in Kilombero Valley along the eastern base of Udzungwa Mountains is in Magombera Forest. During the past decade, it has been extirpated from small forest patches such as Kalunga (Struhsaker 2005, 2010). There has been no recent assessment of its presence in gallery forest along the Msolwa River south of the railway to its confluence with the Kilombero River, including the Ibiki and Msitu ya Kinjugu forests (Struhsaker et al. 2013). Given the agricultural intensification and expansion that have occurred in recent years, it is unlikely that these small patches hold viable numbers.

The altitude range is 250–2,200 m, with density being lowest at higher elevations (Marshall et al. 2005, Struhsaker et al. 2013, Barelli et al. 2015, Cavada et al. 2016).
useTrade: Hunted illegally. Meat is eaten and traded.
conservationActions:
Piliocolobus gordonorum is listed as Class A under the African Convention, and under Appendix II of CITES. At present, only about half the range of this species is effectively protected in Udzungwa Mountains National Park. As such, this population is reasonably secure. The remaining habitat is in forest reserves or nature reserves, or is not protected as it is on public land. This species is nominally protected by law in Tanzania as ‘Presidential Game’. Better enforcement of these laws is essential in areas where the species is hunted.

Conservation priorities for this P. gordonorum are:

1) Greatly improved management of the forest reserves and nature reserves;

2) Clarification of the conservation status of Magombera Forest, provision of effective management and allocation of formal and on-the-ground protection;

3) Prevention of fire in order to promote forest expansion and establishment of corridors among forest blocks, thereby facilitating the dispersal of forest-dependent species, including P. gordonorum;

4) Generally, improve law enforcement to prevent poaching, fires, encroachment and  illegal logging.

Struhsaker et al. (2004, 2013) outlined recommendations for future research.

rationale: Piliocolobus preussi is listed as Critically Endangered (CR) as this species is estimated to have declined over the last three generations (ca 30 years). This is due to unsustainably high levels of mostly illegal hunting throughout its range, habitat loss and reduced habitat quality outside protected areas from timber exploitation and small- and large-scale industrial agriculture. An 80% decline in monkey sightings was recorded between 1990 and 2016 in the Korup National Park, the species’ stronghold. Although data are lacking on monkey populations outside protected areas, this species is known to be extremely vulnerable to hunting pressure and loss of mature, high canopy forest. The primary driver of these threats—human population growth—is expected to increase into the foreseeable future. The taxon is suspected to have undergone an overall population reduction of more than 80% over the past three generations and is listed as CR under criterion A2d. The causes of this decline have not ceased, nor will they in the foreseeable future.
habitat: Preuss’s Red Colobus inhabits mature, high canopy, lowland, mid-altitude and sub-montane moist forest up to 1,000 m asl (Butynski and Kingdon 2013), where it spends most of its time in the upper canopy. Preuss’s Red Colobus is highly folivorous, often feeding from trees that are exploited for timber. Group sizes of 20–60 animals have been observed in Korup (Edwards 1992, Linder 2008, S. Nguedem pers. comm. 2015), with some counts exceeding 100 individuals (D. Okon pers. comm. 2015).
threats:
The major threat to Preuss’s Red Colobus is unsustainable and hunting, which is mostly illegal (e.g., Dowsett-Lemaire and Dowsett 2001, Linder and Oates 2011). In Korup National Park, P. preussi made up a relatively large proportion of the total primate offtake (22% of carcasses) in a recent study (Linder and Oates 2011). Hunting sign encounter rate has increased through time in southern Korup NP from 0.28 signs/km (86 signs along 196.5 km walked) in 2001–2002 (D. Okon pers. comm. 2015) to 0.41 signs/km (155 signs along 382.2 km walked) in 2013–2015 (Linder et al. 2015). Between 2013 and 2014, nearly 300 P. preussi were killed by 30 surveyed hunters living within 3 km of Korup (Astaras and Linder 2016). Offtake surveys of hunters in a village in northeast Korup NP indicated that Preuss’s red colobus represented 2.4% of the 824 animals killed by hunters in June 2016 (Hofner 2016). Fa et al. (2006) counted 494 Preuss’s Red Colobus carcasses for sale in rural Cameroonian bushmeat markets and 284 Preuss’s Red Colobus in rural Nigerian bushmeat markets between August 2002 and January 2003. Most of these red colobus carcasses were recorded in markets close to Korup NP.

In addition to the threat from hunting, red colobus habitats have suffered and continue to suffer from forest loss and declining habitat quality, driven primarily by logging and small- and large-scale agriculture (Waltert et al. 2002, Forboseh et al. 2007, Linder 2013, Schoneveld 2014, B. Morgan pers. obs. 2016), resulting in a 3.8% decrease in tree cover since 2000 (Global Forest Watch 2019). Forests directly to the north and east of Korup NP have been and continue to be selectively logged, as have forests in the Makombe-Ndokbou area. One of the most exploited timber species in southwestern Cameroon is Lophira alata (Namuene 2014), a tree species that red colobus monkeys rely on for food. Large-scale industrial oil-palm plantations located adjacent to Korup NP and Ebo Forest threaten the integrity of forests in both areas.

Underlying these threats is an increasing human population, leading to increasing demands for bushmeat and other natural resources. The human population growth rate in Cameroon and Nigeria is high and has been increasing from ~2.0% annual growth rate in the early 1960s to 2.6% in 2017–2018 (World Bank 2019). 

The so-called “Anglophone Crisis” in the South West and North West Regions of Cameroon further exacerbates the threats listed above. Since 2017, conservation activities in Korup NP (SW Region) have been suspended due to civil unrest, which has forced a substantial proportion of the human population to flee into the forest. This has likely led to increased pressure on forest resources in and around Korup NP, including increased hunting of red colobus monkeys.
population:
Based on extrapolation of a known number of groups in a circumscribed area in southern Korup National Park and an average group size of 24–33 individuals, there are estimated to be between ~3,300 and 4,600 red colobus monkeys in Korup NP, the remaining stronghold for this species (J. Linder and C. Astaras, unpublished data 2018). 

Sighting frequency of Piliocolobus preussi in northeastern and southern Korup is relatively low and has declined through time. In northeastern Korup, group sighting frequency has declined from 0.07 groups/km (eight groups sighted; survey effort = 112.3 km) in 1990 (Edwards 1992) to 0.05 groups/km (four groups sighted; survey effort = 73.7 km) in 2004–2005 (Linder and Oates 2011) to 0.03 groups/km (two groups sighted; survey effort = 59.2 km) in 2014 (C. Jost Robinson pers. comm. 2016) to 0.02 groups/km (one groups sighted; survey effort = 60 km) in 2016 (Hofner 2016). 

Similarly, in southern Korup, group sighting frequency has declined from 0.06 groups/km (11 groups sighted; survey effort = 196.5 km) in 2001–2002 (D. Okon pers. comm. 2015) to 0.05 groups/km (10 groups sighted; survey effort = 211.7 km) in 2004–2005 (Linder and Oates 2011) to 0.02 groups/km (nine groups sighted; survey effort = 382.2 km) in 2013–2015 (Linder et al. 2015) to 0.01 groups/km (1 group sighted on 99 km walked) in 2016–2017 (C. Astaras and J. Linder unpublished data 2018). 

In the Oban Division of Cross River National Park, group sighting frequency calculated for the period between December 2014 and December 2017 was 0.001 groups/km (Abanyam 2018).

Groups of Preuss’s Red Colobus were sighted in the Makombe-Ndokbou forest in 2000 (Dowsett-Lemaire and Dowsett 2001) and 2002 (B. Morgan pers. obs.) and in the Ebo Forest in 2012 (E. Abwe, pers. obs.). However, systematic line transects in the Ebo Forest since then have yielded no further signs of red colobus monkeys. Similarly, surveys conducted in 2018 in the Makombe and Ndokbou forests failed to detect any signs of red colobus monkeys. These results suggest that Preuss’s Red Colobus may now be extremely rare in the Ebo-Makombe-Ndokbou forest block.
range: Preuss’s Red Colobus is present in Korup National Park and surrounding forests in southwestern Cameroon (Forboseh et al. 2007, Linder and Oates 2011), and in the contiguous Ikpan block of the Oban Division of Cross River National Park in the southeastern corner of Nigeria (Abanyam 2018). This red colobus also occurred in the Ebo Forest just north of the Sanaga River (Dowsett-Lemaire and Dowsett 2001, Morgan et al. 2012), although last observed there in 2012 (E. Abwe pers. obs. 2019). At least until fairly recently, Preuss’s Red Colobus still persisted in the Makombe-Ndokbou forest to the north and northeast of Ebo Forest, where they were seen in both 2000 (Dowsett-Lemaire and Dowsett 2001) and 2002 (B. Morgan pers. obs. 2016). However, surveys conducted in 2019 failed to detect the presence of red colobus in Makombe-Ndokbou.
useTrade: This species is hunted unsustainably throughout its range, and most of this hunting is illegal. Preuss’s Red Colobus is commonly found in hunter offtakes (Linder and Oates 2011, Astaras and Linder unpublished data 2018) and in bushmeat markets near to Korup National Park (Fa et al. 2006).
conservationActions: This taxon is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. P. preussi is present in Korup National Park (1,260 km²) and its perimeter in Cameroon, with a small number residing in the adjacent Oban division of Cross River National Park (Nigeria). It has also been recorded in the Ebo Forest, which is proposed as a new national park, but its present status in Ebo Forest is unclear.

rationale: Piliocolobus pennantii is listed as Critically Endangered as this species has a very restricted range on the island of Bioko (approximately 160 km²), and is suspected to have undergone a decline of more than 80% over three past generations (1986-2016), mainly due to heavy hunting impact across its limited range.
habitat:
Piliocolobus pennantii is a largely arboreal species found in lowland and mid-montane tropical moist forest, and marsh forest in the southwestern sector of the Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve. These are considered ‘monsoon forests’, receiving over 10,000 mm of rain per year (Oates et al. 2004). This monkey is reported to occur from sea level through montane forests into Schefflera forests at elevations of 1,800 m or higher (Butynski and Koster 1994, González-Kirchner 1997); however, Cronin et al. (in review) observed it from only 0–1,200 m, and suggested that they are likely not found higher than that based on habitat suitability modelling.

Abundance of P. pennantii is concentrated in the southwestern region, and especially in the lowland forests near Playa Moraka (Cronin et al. 2016, Cronin et al. in review), which suggests that it may have a preference for lowland tropical moist forest, contrary to González-Kirchner (1997), who suggested it preferred montane forest. It is locally abundant in parts of its range (e.g., the forests near Playa Moraka), but abundance drops significantly outside core areas (Cronin et al. in review).

Group size is variable. In a brief survey, Struhsaker (2000) estimated that group size ranged from 5–30 animals, with a mean of 14 individuals. Using data from 506 encounters; however, Cronin et al. (in review) observed a maximum group size of 20 individuals and a mean group size of 2.85 animals (2.64–3.07) across its entire range, and 3.08 animals (2.71–3.52) in the crater of the Gran Caldera, where primate populations are most likely as close to ‘natural’ as is possible on Bioko due to isolation and very low hunting pressure.
threats:
The major threats to this species are hunting (e.g., Cronin et al. 2015b, 2016), development and habitat degradation.

Cronin et al. (2015b) reported that 1,754 individuals were available in the Malabo bushmeat market between 1997 and 2010. P. pennantii was hunted at a lower rate than most of the other diurnal primate species due to its isolated distribution in remote areas of the Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve. It is, however, the primate species most vulnerable diurnal to hunting pressure on Bioko (Cronin et al. 2016).

Hunting has continued unabated in the Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve since 2010 (e.g., Cronin et al. 2016), and the recent completion of a road bisecting the reserve has eroded much of the isolation that had passively protected wildlife populations (Cronin et al. 2015a), and contributed to increased hunting activity in the reserve (D.T. Cronin, unpublished data, 2015, 2016).

There are also plans for a significantly greater military presence in the near future at Ureca, the only village entirely within the Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve, and construction of a large base is already underway to accommodate its personnel. This represents a potentially grave threat for P. pennantii and other wildlife in the reserve, as Cronin et al. (2016) reported that military staff in Ureca were the only gun owners and perpetrators of gun-hunting in the area around the village at the time of the study (2011–2012). This situation is still generally the case, but hunting activity has been augmented by hunters from outside the reserve visiting the area to hunt as a result of the road (D.T. Cronin, pers. obs. 2015, 2016). An increased number of arms and military personnel at Ureca are very likely to lead to increased hunting of primates, including P. pennantii.
population:
There are probably fewer than 1,200 animals remaining on Bioko, and Cronin et al. (in review) estimate a >80% decline in numbers between 1986 and 2016.

Piliocolobus pennantii is encountered at a rate of 0.26 groups/km (3.92 groups/km²) on Bioko, but abundance is highly localised (Cronin et al. in review). At Moraka in the remote southwest, abundance was 0.49 groups/km, but at Ureca near the limit of its range, abundance was 0.16 groups/km. Hunting and recent road development and the associated increasing in anthropogenic disturbance in the Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve are contributing to declining population numbers and a reduction in its extent of occurrence.

A past reduction of more than 80% is suspected over the last three generations based on bushmeat hunting and market surveys (Cronin et al. 2015, 2016) and the fact that this species is most favoured by bushmeat hunters.
range: Piliocolobus pennantii is endemic to the island of Bioko, Equatorial Guinea, where it is now restricted entirely to the southwest of the island with a range of approximately 160 km² in the Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve (Cronin et al. in review). P. pennantii was thought to have persisted in the Iladyi valley in southeastern Bioko until recently, and in Pico Basilé National Park in northern Bioko into the early 1990s (Butynski and Koster 1994, González-Kirchner 1994, IUCN 2016), but there have been no records in subsequent studies in either area (Nowak and Rioso Etingue 2007, Butynski and Owens 2008, Grande-Vega et al. 2013, Cronin et al. 2013, Cronin 2014) and interviews with hunters who have worked extensively on Pico Basilé report not having seen it for ≥30 years (M. Grande Vega, unpublished data). Earlier reports detailed P. pennantii at elevations ranging from 0-800 m and potentially up to 1,800 m (Butynski and Koster 1994, González-Kirchner 1997), but Cronin et al. (in review) estimate its current elevational range is more likely between 0-1,200 m.
useTrade: From 1997 to 2010, 1,754 Piliocolobus pennantii carcasses were available for sale in the Malabo bushmeat market (Cronin et al. 2015b). During the final period of the survey (November 2007 through September 2010), the average change in the rate of P. pennantii carcass availability per month was increasing by approximately one carcass/month, i.e., the general offtake pattern was gradually increasing. The average price paid in the Malabo market for an adult P. p. pennantii in 2008 was about US$50 (Cronin et al. 2014).
conservationActions:
P. pennantii receives some measure of protection under both national and international legislation. Its population is entirely within a legally-recognised protected area (IUCN 1b Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve), in which hunting is prohibited (Republic of Equatorial Guinea 2003). Furthermore, the hunting, sale and consumption of all primates was banned by Presidential Decree in October 2007 (Republic of Equatorial Guinea 2007). However, there is no management plan in place for the Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve, and the National Institute for Forestry Development and Protected Area Management (INDEFOR-AP) has a very limited budget, with few staff and low capacity with which to effectively manage the reserve. Internationally, this taxon is also listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

The remaining populations of P. pennantii on Bioko are confined to approximately 160 km² Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve (510 km²); however, there is almost no control of hunting in these protected areas.

Butynski and Koster (1994) provided the contemporary baseline for the status of Bioko’s primates, including P. pennanti, and there has been continual monitoring of primate populations on Bioko by the Bioko Biodiversity Protection Program (BBPP) since the early 2000s (Hearn et al. 2004, 2006, Cronin et al. 2010). More recently, there have been numerous systematic survey efforts throughout Bioko, especially in the Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve, in order to assess primate abundance and hunting intensity (e.g., Cronin et al. 2016), including targeted surveys for P. pennantii (Cronin et al. 2013). This work has led to an increased understanding of the distribution and population density of P. pennantii and shed light on both the threats it faces and the urgent need for effective measures to protect the species (Cronin et al. 2017, in review).

In order to effectively conserve primates on Bioko, Cronin et al. (2017) have proposed (i) the development and implementation of a management plan for the Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve; (ii) the strengthening of the legal basis for protection and management of the GCSR; (iii) greater involvement of INDEFOR-AP in the GCSR; (iv) increased enforcement; and (v) a more proactive government approach to conservation, especially towards primate hunting. Also called for is a ban on shotgun hunting, as has been argued before (Albrechtsen et al. 2004, Hearn et al. 2006), as well as the implementation of bushmeat spot checks at existing checkpoints at key transit intersections. An area-based prioritization scheme was also recently developed using primate species richness as its basis (Cronin et al. in review), in which the ‘critical zone’ will encompass almost all of the range of P. pennantii. The ‘critical zone’ delineation has been adopted into the Equatoguinean ‘National Biodiversity Strategy & Action Plan for the Conservation of Biological Diversity’ (Engonga Osono et al. 2015); however, the completion of this plan has not yet resulted in the development of a comprehensive management plan for the reserve, nor has the plan bolstered government support for its conservation.

The BBPP has many projects underway in the Gran Caldera Scientific Reserve, including primate monitoring, alternative livelihoods, educational programmes, professional development training (i.e., ecoguard training), the development of a Nature Centre in the village of Ureca, and partnering with INDEFOR-AP to foment their active involvement in the reserve and its day-to-day management. A United Nations Development Programme (UNEP) Global Environmental Facility (GEF) project is also ongoing on the island with the goal of strengthening Equatorial Guinea’s system of protected areas. This project is helping to support BBPP’s efforts in Ureca, as well as working towards gaining recognition of Bioko Island as a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.

rationale: This species is assessed as Critically Endangered as it is estimated to have undergone a decline of more than 80% over the past three generations (ca 30 years) due to heavy hunting impact across its limited range in the Niger Delta, compounded by habitat loss and degradation. It persists in small pockets of fragmented and degraded forest but has been extirpated from most parts of the area where it was previously reported to be present (Ikemeh 2015). Piliocolobus epieni does not occur in any formal protected area, and although some conservation efforts have been attempted they have been significantly hampered by insecurity in the Niger Delta, a lack of political will, and a lack of consensus amongst key local communities over the scope of proposed conservation programmes. Therefore the decline of the species is expected to continue. Immediate conservation attention is required if P. epieni is to be saved from extinction.
habitat: It is a largely arboreal species restricted to freshwater swamp forest. Its diet is dominated by young foliage from large and medium-sized trees, with seeds being seasonally important. The Niger Delta red colobus flourishes only in areas where their favoured food trees occur in large patches (Werre 2000), and their populations are therefore very sensitive to the loss of these trees.
threats: The major threats to this species are habitat degradation and loss; hunting is reported to be relatively rare and opportunistic (Ikemeh 2015).  Artisanal-scale logging has seriously degraded the habitat of P. epieni, removing many important red colobus food trees, such as Hallea ledermannii (Werre and Powell 1997, Grubb and Powell 1999). These threats have further intensified during the last decade as a result of growing human population and migration, and increased economic activities accompanied by a rise in income levels. A survey in 2013 found that many of the forests across the range of P. epieni now lacked any large trees, and that even medium-sized trees were scarce, while an analysis of remote-sensing imagery indicated annual rate of forest loss across this range of 1.2% between 1991 and 2013  (Ikemeh 2015)
population: Piliocolobus epieni was discovered only in 1993, and was then quite common within its limited range, but surveys over the following 15 years suggested significant declines as a result of habitat loss and degradation from logging, and from hydrological changes resulting from oil industry activities (Werre and Powell 1997, Grubb and Powell 1999, M. Isoun and D. Otobo pers. comm. 2009). A survey in 2013 found no evidence (from sightings and local reports) for the presence of Niger Delta Red Colobus at 10 of the16 sites where Werre (2000) had recorded their presence in the mid-1990s (Ikemeh 2015). The current population may now only number in the hundreds (Ikemeh 2015).
range: The historical range of Piliocolobus epieni extended from the Forcados-Nikrogha Creek and the Sagbama-Osiama-Agboi Creek in the marsh forest of the Niger Delta, Nigeria (Grubb and Powell 1999, Werre 2000). Recent surveys suggest that remaining populations are now highly fragmented, and concentrated in an area of approximately 200 sq. km in the central south-eastern part of their original range (Ikemeh pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions: This taxon is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.   Protection of the remaining habitat of this taxon is an urgent priority, along with serious efforts to control hunting. Piliocolobus epieni is not represented in any protected area, although a forest reserve, Apoi Creek, near Gbanraun had been proposed for upgrading to national park status. Additional sites have also been proposed that could protect viable populations of the species (Ikemeh 2015), but there has been a lack of political will to implement these recommendations. Conservation efforts have also been hampered at a local level, particularly in the Apoi Creek area, where key communities have disagreed over land rights and the scope of conservation programmes that can be implemented. In the long run, any conservation action must include close monitoring of surviving populations and their habitats.

rationale:
Piliocolobus semlikiensis has an extent of occurrence of ~78,500 km² and an area of occupation of ~54,400 km², but forest loss is ongoing across its range. Total forest loss is estimated at 4,430 km² (8.1% of the range) over 17 years (2001–2018; GFW 2019), which is 1.7 generations for this monkey (generation time for the genus is estimated at 10 years; Pacifici et al. 2013). This species occurs in eastern DRC, where the rate of forest cover loss is increasing: since 2014, it has been ~1% per year. Prior to that, annually rate of loss was 0.25–0.4% (GFW 2019).

Projecting backwards three generations (to 1990) goes beyond the last 17 years for which forest loss data are available; however, we know that forest loss was occurring before 2001. Extrapolating 0.25-0.4% annual loss to the decade 1990–2000 gives an additional 2.5-4%  lost. Therefore, we estimate an overall range loss of 12–14% between 1990 and 2020.

Added to forest loss is increasing hunting for bushmeat. Monkey meat is eaten in rural locations and traded commercially for consumption in towns and cities, and the bushmeat trade is a serious threat to red colobus monkeys across Central Africa (Struhsaker 2010). Red colobus are targeted for because of their large size, which affords a good return to a hunter for the cost of a shotgun cartridge. Red colobus live in relatively large groups (Struhsaker and Grubb 2013), and their behaviour when faced with a hunter tends to be to observe rather than flee – which affords very easy, multiple targets for the hunter. Hunting pressure was high throughout the areas surveyed in the last few years: Maiko National Park (Amsini et al. 2006a,b), Usala (S. Nixon pers. comm. 2019) and Okapi Wildlife Reserve (Vosper et al. 2012, Madidi et al. 2019).

In 2019, there were roughly three times more people in DRC than in 1990 (mean human population growth 1990–2018 was ~3% annually). In addition, once intact blocks of forest are increasingly fragmented and made far more accessible to hunters: in DRC, 4.2% of forests classified as intact were lost between 2000–2013 (Potapov et al. 2017). Finally, the ability of the ever-increasing proportion of urban dwellers to pay much higher prices for bushmeat has created a highly lucrative market for commercial hunters, driving ever more rapid extraction of bushmeat from the regions’ forests. At present, 44% of the human population in DRC lives in towns and cities (World Bank 2019), compared with 27% in 1980, and this upward trend has been the case since 1960 (when it was 22%).

Because red colobus monkeys are large-bodied and bring a higher profit per cartridge than smaller species, it is preferentially selected by hunters and tends to be eliminated or at least greatly reduced in abundance before other, smaller monkeys. Red colobus now appear to be very rare, even in protected areas.

Thus, there is a combination of 12–14% of total habitat loss, plus 4.2% loss of intact forest, plus the increased demand for bushmeat, plus increased access too remote areas and an increased incentive for hunters to supply bushmeat to towns and cities. Piliocolobus semlikiensis is therefore suspected to have undergone a population decline exceeding 30% during the past three generations (1990–2019). The taxon is listed as Vulnerable under criterion A2cd, as the decline has been ongoing for some time and will continue into the future; causes have not ceased (indeed, the intensity of the causes is increasing), nor will they in the foreseeable future.
habitat: Little is known of this species but all observations have been in forest habitats – terra firma, swamp forests and along rivers. The animals live in groups. It is assumed, that like other red colobus, they are primarily folivores.
threats:
The Semliki Red Colobus is directly threatened by habitat loss and hunting, and indirectly by the creation of easy access routes into huge areas of previously remote forests and increasing human populations.

The species is subject to habitat modification, as intact forest is converted to farmland and “farm bush,” which can be seen clearly in Tyukavina et al. (2016) and Harris et al. (2017). In DRC, over 90% of forest loss is due to shifting agriculture (Tyukavina et al. 2018). Since 2001, there has been a trend towards gradually increasing annual forest loss, especially since 2013–2014 (GFW 2019).

Hunting for bushmeat is increasing throughout the range. The meat is eaten by rural populations, traded to miners (Spira et al. 2019), or sold in urban markets. Road access into once-remote forests – even around protected areas – has hugely increased during the last 20–30 years (Kleinschroth et al. 2019), facilitating increased hunting and transport of bushmeat for commercial trade in both local markets and distant urban centres (Abernethy et al. 2013, 2016; Ziegler et al. 2016).

Human populations in the range of the taxon are growing at roughly 2.7% annually, and this rate will not slow down in the near future (United Nations 2019, World Bank 2019).
population: The Semliki Red Colobus is targeted by hunters due to its large size. In recent years, they have rarely been seen, despite intensive survey efforts. They were recorded eight times in Maiko National Park in 2005 (both in the north and the south of the park: 380 and 300 km of effort, respectively; Amsini et al. 2006a,b). In 2007, red colobus vocalisations were heard on three separate transects close to the Ituri River (which forms the limit between P. semlikiensis and P. oustaleti), but which side of the river the vocalisations emanated from was unclear (WCS unpubl. data 2005–2007). Also in 2007, they were seen only once in the Usala area (which lies between Maiko National Park and Tayna Natural Reserve), although teams walked over 200 km of recces (Nixon et al. 2007). In the past, two groups were observed in Virunga National Park (Struhsaker 2010), but they were not recorded during surveys of the Semliki forest, Virunga National Park in 2008 (S. Nixon pers. comm. 2019) – the site of the taxon’s type locality. Finally, they were not found in Mt. Hoyo Reserve by Plumptre et al. (2015), but were apparently recorded in that area in 2018 (D. Kujirakwinja pers. comm. 2019).
range:
The geographic range (area of occurrence) of Piliocolobus semlikiensis covers approximately 54,400 km². This is a forest-dwelling, Central African taxon and the vast majority of its range is in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) although, given the known distribution, it is possible that they could (rarely) occur in the contiguous forests of Semuliki and Rwenzori national parks, western Uganda. However, they were not recorded in Semuliki during a recent survey (Nixon et al. 2019) and there are no records in Rwenzori to date.

The southern limit of P. semlikiensis is roughly 1° S, comprising the Lowa River (to the southwest) and further east, its tributary, the Oso River. The northern limit is roughly 1.2° N, comprising the Nduye River (at the northeastern edge of the range of this taxon), which then runs west and joins the Ituri River that in turn becomes the Aruwimi River, which completes the northern limit. The eastern limit is the Albertine Rift, especially the northern sector of Virunga National Park, with a possible extension into Uganda, as noted above. The western limit is unclear but can be described as a very rough north-south line veering west towards the south at about 27.9° E. The reason for this vague boundary is that this taxon, as defined here, incorporates what has been described as a “hybrid swarm”, flanked to the west by P. langi and to the south by P. lulindicus and P. foai, with possible contribution from P. oustaleti in the north.
useTrade: The species is illegally hunted for local consumption and sale to bushmeat markets. The level of offtake is probably declining as remaining populations are reduced and those remaining are mostly remote and depleted (and hence more costly to hunt).
conservationActions:
This taxon is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. In DRC, the taxon (as Procolobus badius) is on the totally protected list (may not be hunted) (Enerunga 2006).

It occurs in Maiko and Virunga national parks. It should also occur in Tayna Natural Reserve and Kisimba Ikobo Primate Reserve, and was found in Okapi Wildlife Reserve in the past.

Efforts to control the killing of red colobus and trade in bushmeat would have a positive impact on remaining populations, especially in areas where mining and increasing settlement do not occur.

The first conservation action plan for red colobus monkeys will be published in 2020. The plan identifies priority areas for conservation and recommends range-wide and taxon-based actions to prevent red colobus extinctions. Range-wide conservation priorities include actions that aim to improve government investment in wildlife conservation, expand and improve protected areas, determine taxon-specific distribution and abundance, engage with local human populations and integrate them into conservation activities, remove barriers that prevent local access to human healthcare and family planning, and raise awareness of the plight of red colobus.

rationale:
This species is listed as Endangered, based on a precipitous reduction in extent of occurrence (EOO) in the past 30 years that is expected to continue into the future. Piliocolobus foai is threatened by uncontrolled hunting and habitat loss in an area that has seen high levels of civil unrest in the past 30 years. The geographic range described by Colyn (1991) was approximately ~23,000 km². Since then, surveys have shown that this species remains in only two small and isolated populations and currently has an EOO of ~6,700 km², representing a 70% decline since the range was defined in the 1990s. Furthermore, only a single sighting was recorded between 2003 and 2019 in for one of the populations (D. Kujirakwinja pers. comm. 2019). Given past trends of uncontrolled hunting that have not stopped, it is extremely likely that P. foai will be extirpated from Itombwe Nature Reserve in the near future, if it even still exists there.

The two known locations for P. foai are 1) Kabobo and Ngandja Reserves and adjacent Luama Hunting Reserve (together comprising the Kabobo Massif protected area complex) where it occupies an area of forest of about 1,200 km²; and 2) Itombwe Nature Reserve, where numbers have declined dramatically during the past 30 years due to habitat loss and hunting.

Piliocolobus foai has not been recorded in Kahuzi-Biega National Park in the past three decades, and is thought to be no longer present in this area.

The Kabobo Massif, the location of the only confirmed population, has had low levels of human impact; it has been protected historically because civil conflicts meant that human settlement in the region has been low (Plumptre et al. 2008, 2010). Establishment of the Kabobo Massif protected area complex (Rainforest Trust 2016) has contributed significantly to the conservation of Foa's Red Colobus. Nevertheless, human populations are currently increasing in the area. Hunting and habitat degradation associated with artisanal mining are occurring, particularly in Luama Hunting Reserve (A. Plumptre and D. Kujirakwinja pers. comm. 2019).

In addition to habitat loss, a major threat is hunting: P. foai is targeted for bushmeat across its range. Because red colobus monkeys are large-bodied and bring a higher profit per cartridge than smaller species, they are preferentially selected by hunters and tend to be eliminated or at least greatly reduced in abundance before other, smaller monkeys. They live in relatively large groups (Struhsaker 2010, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013), and they have a tendency to observe humans rather than flee – which affords hunter with very easy, multiple targets. Hunting pressure was high in all areas surveyed in the recent past, and is associated with the expansion of artisanal mining and insecurity during periods of civil unrest.

Monkeys are eaten in villages and traded commercially for consumption in towns and cities; the bushmeat trade is a serious threat to red colobus monkeys across Africa (Struhsaker 2010). In the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), there were approximately three times more people in 2019 than in 1990 (3% mean annual human population growth in DRC 1990–2018). The ability to pay much higher prices for bushmeat by the increasing proportion of urban dwellers in DRC has created a highly lucrative market for commercial hunters, which is the increasing rate of bushmeat extraction. At present, 44% of the human population in DRC lives in towns and cities (World Bank 2019), compared with 27% in 1980, and this upward trend has been the case since 1960 (when it was 22%). Given the human population growth, increasing human access to previously intact forest, uncontrolled hunting and the vulnerability of red colobus to hunting, this species is expected to continue declining.

Piliocolobus foai is listed as Endangered under criterion A2cd due to a 70% decline in its extent of occurrence (EOO) in the recent past and hunting for bushmeat. The causes are not reversible, have not ceased, nor will they in the foreseeable future.
habitat: Piliocolobus foai occurs in primary montane and submontane forest from 800 to 2,270 m asl. In Itombwe, it is restricted to evergreen closed forests; in Kabobo, it also occurs in adjoining gallery forests on the escarpment above Lake Tanganyika. It is not known to range far into gallery forests or the forest islands west of the escarpment (Plumptre et al. 2008).
threats:
Piliocolobus foai populations have been reduced or extirpated from over 50% of the species’ range by hunting and by range loss due to habitat conversion and degradation during the past 30 years. Hunting certainly contributed to the loss of the taxon from KBNP, and remains a threat in Itombwe Nature Reserve, where the species is now apparently almost extirpated.

For the past two decades, eastern DRC has been the theatre of entrenched conflict promulgated by a multiplicity of rural militias, a number of whom are based in the region’s protected areas, including Itombwe Nature Reserve and the Kabobo Massif. This has not had an entirely negative impact. Rebels based in the Kabobo Massif prevented widespread occupation by farmers, herders and miners for two decades from the late 1970s through the fall of the Mobutu regime in 1997 (Plumptre et al. 2008, 2010). As security returned, incursions in the landscape increased (Plumptre et al. 2016). Elsewhere, however, occupation by militias and brigands has made management and protection of these protected areas difficult or impossible, favouring resource extraction and use by hunters, miners and pastoralists.

Outside protected areas, habitat loss and degradation are due primarily to shifting cultivation and smallholder farming, small-scale logging, charcoal production and conversion of forest to pastures. Deforestation in DRC increased by a factor of 2.5 between 2011 and 2017 (Harris et al. 2017). Forest loss and associated degradation has been particular severe in the range of P. foai, the region of DRC where human population densities are highest.

Small-scale (artisanal) and industrial-scale mining threaten the remaining forests in eastern DRC. Notably in the Itombwe Massif, where artisanal miners have reached even the most remote areas of this site. Since 2011, a major Canadian-registered, international gold mining company, Banro, has been operating concessions totalling 2,616 km² in and around Itombwe, and the company has outstanding requests for prospection within the boundaries of the Nature Reserve (Thierry Regards 2019).

In the Kabobo Massif, fires set for hunting and to clear land for agriculture are among the main threats to the evergreen montane forests favoured by P. foai (Plumptre et al. 2016).
population:
No population estimates are available for P. foai, which has a restricted range that is threatened by habitat degradation and hunting.

The species was described as uncommon in the Itombwe Massif in the early 1990s (Doumenge and Schliter 1997). It was recorded in 1996 in lower montane formations between 1,220 and 1,850 m asl by Omari et al. (1999), who noted low overall encounter rates of primates in the massif (0.1 groups/km) and widespread evidence of hunting. Subsequent surveys and patrols between 2003 and 2019 yielded only a single observation of P. foai from Itombwe (Plumptre et al. 2010, D. Kujirakwinja pers. comm. 2019).

Rahm and Christiaensen (1963) and Rahm (1964) reported the species in what are now the highland sector and corridor of Kahuzi-Biega National Park (KBNP). Specimens attributed to P. foai were collected in this same region (Colyn 1991); however, there are no recent records of this species from surveys in this area (Inogwabini et al. 2001, Spira et al. 2015).

The last remaining stronghold for P. foai is the Kabobo Massif Reserve Complex, where it was recorded several times during surveys conducted in 2008 (Plumptre et al. 2008). It is threatened here, nonetheless, and rare in the Luama Hunting Reserve (Plumptre et al. 2010).
range:
Endemic to the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Piliocolobus foai (sensu stricto, Colyn 1991) is restricted to montane forest habitats and does not occur west of the Albertine Rift highlands in areas of lower elevation. Historically, the species’ ranged through montane and submontane forests (900–2,800 m asl) in the Albertine Rift, from Kahuzi-Biega National Park (KBNP), south through the Itombwe Massif to Mt Kabobo (Rahm 1964). Colyn (1991) suggested, although without confirmed specimens, that P. foai ranged south to the Lukuga River (800 m asl); however, there is now very little if any remaining suitable habitat in this region, which borders on the city of Kalemie. Specimens from Irangi, west of the KBNP highlands, have been attributed to P. ellioti (Rahm and Christiaensen 1963). West of the Albertine Rift highland forests, red colobus populations show intergradation between P. foai and P. lulindicus and possibly other forms, and are considered to be hybrids (Colyn 1991).

Piliocolobus foai is currently known from only two widely-separated locations.
