By the late 1800s the species' range was restricted to the eastern rainforests, with collecting records from ca. 1870 to 1913 recording it from the Bay of Antongil in the north-east to Nandihizana in the south-east (Godfrey and Vuillaume-Randriamanantena 1986, Schwarz 1931). In the mid-1900s some authors believed that the species may have become extinct (Napier and Napier 1967), until it was rediscovered in the south-east in the 1960s and 70s (Meier and Rumpler 1987, Petter et al. 1977). Until recently these south-eastern populations were thought to be the last remaining of the species (Mutschler and Tan 2003). Recent range extensions based on confirmed sightings illustrate that the present-day range is not as diminished as previously thought (Dolch et al. 2008, King and Chamberlan 2010, Ravaloharimanitra et al. 2011, Rakotonirina et al. 2011, King et al. 2013a), and indirect evidence suggests the species may still be widely distributed through much of eastern Madagascar (Dolch et al. 2010, Rakotonirina et al. 2011, 2013, 2017, King et al. 2013a). The latitudinal range of sites with confirmed sightings as of May 2018 is 18°06’S (near Didy in the Ankeniheny-Zahamena Corridor; The Aspinall Foundation, unpubl. data) to 22°26’S (near Karianga, north of Vondrozo; Johnson and Wyner 2000, Wright et al. 2008). The elevation range for confirmed sightings is 20 (Bonaventure et al. 2012) to 1,600 m (Goodman et al. 2001 in Wright et al. 2008). Confirmed sightings have been made in recent years in the remaining mid to high altitude rainforest corridors from Didy to Andasibe (Dolch et al. 2008, Ravaloharimanitra et al. 2011, Randrianarimanana et al. 2012, 2014, Olson et al. 2012) and from the Ranomafana National Park to the Andringitra National Park (Petter et al. 1977, Wright et al. 2008, Delmore et al. 2009), and in lowland degraded landscapes in the Brickaville District (Ravaloharimanitra et al. 2011, Bonaventure et al. 2012, Lantovololona et al. 2012, Mihaminekena et al. 2012, Randriahaingo et al. 2014, Ralison et al. 2015), the Vatomandry District (Rakotonirina et al. 2011, Ravaloharimanitra et al. 2017), at the confluence of the Mangoro and Nosivolo rivers in the Mahanoro District (Rakotonirina et al. 2011, Andrianandrasana et al. 2013), in the Ifanadiana District east of Ranomafana National Park (Rakotoarinivo et al. 2017a), around Kianjavato in the Mananjary District (Andriaholinirina et al. 2003, Wright et al. 2008, McGuire et al. 2009, Frasier et al. 2015), and near Karianga in the Vondrozo District (Wright et al. 2008, 2009).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted for food, using slingshots, spears, and snares (Wright et al. 2008). They are occasionally kept as illegal pets within Madagascar (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
conservationActions:
Prolemur simus has recently been considered to be one of the most endangered primates in the world (Wright et al. 2008, 2009). This assessment prompted the creation in 2008 of the “Saving Prolemur simus” project, initiated as the first priority of The Aspinall Foundation’s Madagascar Programme in collaboration with various partners in Madagascar to realise five principle objectives: 1) facilitating communication and collaboration; 2) surveying for new sites supporting the species; 3) ensuring effective conservation management of known sites in the remaining forest corridors; 4) ensuring effective conservation management of known sites in isolated habitats outside forest corridors; and 5) when appropriate, ensuring the survival of individuals in sites that can not be protected through translocation or captive breeding (King and Chamberlan 2010). Collaborative community-based surveys undertaken in 2009 and 2010 by The Aspinall Foundation, Association Mitsinjo, GERP Conservation International and others led to the discovery of several previously unknown populations and significant extensions to the known range of the species (King and Chamberlan 2010, Ravaloharimanitra et al. 2011, Rakotonirina et al. 2011, 2013). Building on the ongoing P. simus conservation work initiated in and around Torotorofotsy by Association Mitsinjo (Dolch et al. 2008, 2015), community-based conservation activities were immediately initiated at many of the newly discovered sites by The Aspinall Foundation with various partners, especially in the northern (Ankeniheny-Zahamena Corridor, Andriantantely and surrounding areas; Ravaloharimanitra and King 2012; Chamberlan et al. 2013; King et al. 2013a, 2013b, 2013c; Ravaloharimanitra et al. 2013a, 2013b, 2015) and central (Nosivolo; Andrianandrasana et al. 2013, Rakotonirina and Chamberlan 2014) parts of the known range. Further south, similar site-based P. simus conservation projects were also being developed, including at Kianjavato by the Madagascar Biodiversity Partnership and Omaha’s Henry Doorly Zoo (Manjaribe et al. 2013; Frasier et al. 2015), at Vohitrarivo-Tsaratanana by Helpsimus and partners (Rakotoarinivo et al. 2017a, 2017b), and at Ivato-Mahasoa by MICET/ICTE (P. Wright, pers. comm.), in addition to the long-term research and conservation activities in the Ranomafana National Park (Wright et al. 2008, Eronen et al. 2017). The combined efforts of these projects led to the recovery of the known population of P. simus from about 100 to over 1,000 individuals in just under a decade. Whilst this is a remarkable collaborative conservation achievement, based primarily on community-based conservation, the situation of the species remains very fragile and dependent on the continued commitment of this small number of organisations to its survival; indeed over half the known population is protected by community-based projects facilitated by just one organisation (The Aspinall Foundation), roughly a third by one other (Helpsimus), and the rest by a small number of organisations including MBP/Omaha’s Henry Doorly Zoo, Association Mitsinjo, Conservation International, MICET/ICTE and Madagascar National Parks. Apart from the known groups protected and monitored by these projects, populations or groups elsewhere are likely to be continuing to decline due to habitat loss (Morelli et al. 2019) and hunting, and even where they are protected the effects of climate change are predicted to have negative implications for the suitability of the habitats they currently occur in (Eronen et al. 2017).       

Prolemur simus is listed on Appendix I of CITES. A small number are held in captivity, in Europe and Madagascar, totalling less than 30 individuals representing very few founder animals (Roullet 2012).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered as the species has been observed to have undergone a population reduction of ≥80% over a period of 27 years (three generations), due primarily to continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure.<span class="apple-converted-space"> These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible.
habitat: The Alaotran Reed Lemur Hapalemur alaotrensis is found only in the marshes of Lake Alaotra, located in the central-eastern highlands of Madagascar. It is the only primate taxon in the world that lives exclusively in a wetland habitat. This species feeds on the marsh vegetation. Papyrus and reeds seems to be the staple food source. Hapalemur alaotrensis is a cathemeral species, although nocturnal activity levels are reduced. They live in family groups of up to a dozen members and defend territories ranging in size from less than one hectare to eight hectares. Young are born from September through February and twins are common (Mittermeier et al. 2008, and references therein).
threats:
Conversion of marsh habitat to rice fields has been the most severe threat to the survival of this species, although the remaining marsh habitats are difficult to convert due to regular flooding. However, a major drainage project would pose a major threat if this were realized in the region. Burning of the remaining marshlands takes place to catch fish and to graze cattle. The resulting increase in aquatic plants is choking fishing areas and driving further burning and may also limit marsh regeneration after flooding.

Hunting for food and capture for pets (Reuter and Schaefer 2017) also have reduced its numbers through the years. Local people employ a variety of hunting and trapping methods. Direct pursuit by dogs is the most common, but they may also be captured by using a harpoon, a snare, a stick to knock them out or into the water, or by burning their reed bed habitat, causing them to flee into the hands of waiting hunters. More than 1,000 lemurs have been hunted annually in some years (Mutschler et al. 2001).
population:
Populations are inferred to have undergone a population decline of ≥80% over a period of 27 years (three generations), due primarily to continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible.

Hapalemur alaotrensis is a small folivorous primate that lives in family groups of 2 to 9 individuals occupying territories of 1 to 2ha. The population plunged by 60% from around 7,500 individuals in 1994 to around 3,000 individuals in 2001. The latest survey carried out in 2018 estimate the total population around 2,500. The main causes of its decline have been transformation of its marshes habitat to rice fields, widespread and repeated burning of remaining areas of marsh and hunting for local consumption. The species is also kept as a pet (Reuter and Schaefer 2016).
range: This species is known only from the papyrus and reed beds surrounding Lac Alaotra, Madagascar's largest lake located in the eastern rain forest region (Mutschler and Feistner 1995). The species occurs as two subpopulations: a small one in the northern part of the lake around the Belempona Peninsula; and a larger one in the adjoining marshlands along the lake's south-western shores bounded by the villages of Anororo, Andilana Sud, Sampananefatra, Ambodivoara Andreba Gare and Andilana-Sud (Mutschler et al. 2001). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 519 km2, and it occurs only up to elevations of 750 m.
useTrade: This species is hunted for food and captured for the pet trade.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. Lac Alaotra was declared a Ramsar site in 2003, and covers the entire watershed, 722,5000 ha, with the aim of conserving biodiversity and the wetland ecosystem. Thanks to the efforts of Durrell, a new 42,478 ha protected area was created there in 2007. This includes both a strict conservation area of 8,000 ha, and an adjacent 5,200-ha core zone of marsh where controlled activities (e.g. fishing) are permitted. Public awareness campaigns have focused on the benefits of habitat conservation to the half million or more people who live by the lake erosion control, the biological filtering of agricultural pollutants, flood prevention. A regional fishing convention bans lemur hunting and marsh burning. There is a small, but self-sustaining, captive population in a number of European zoos.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable as the species is suspected to have undergone a population decline of ≥30% over a period of 24 years (three generations), due primarily to continuing decline in the area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of dry deciduous forest and humid forest containing stands of bamboo and areas of bamboo vines (Tattersall 1982). The species also occurs in marginal, degraded habitats in the Sambirano River valley, as well as in patches of bamboo surrounded by agricultural land and rice fields (Martinez 2008, Rakotonarivo et al. 2011, Razanatsila 2012). It is reported as being cathemeral (Eppley pers. obs.), and in Marojejy, groups as large as 10 individuals occur near Camp 1 (Patel pers. obs.).  Individuals have been observed eating fruits, bamboo, liana flowers, fungi, and soil. In the northern highland regions of Marojejy and Tsaratanana the bamboo species Valiha diffusa is a key food species inside primary forests (Marojejy NP) while in nearby degraded forest fragments non-native Phyllostachys aurea and Dendrocalamus strictus are important food sources (Patel et al. 2014). The birth season is roughly October–January, following a gestation of 137–140 days, with an  interbirth interval of one year (Pollock 1986, Mutschler and Tan 2003).
threats: This species is threatened mainly by habitat loss due to the regular burning of forest to clear pasture for livestock and shifting agriculture; illegal timber harvesting from protected areas; and mining. Hunting is also a major threat; in both Makira and Masoala, hunting primarily takes place using slingshots, found objects, and snare traps (Golden 2005, Borgerson 2015, Brook et al. 2018). Note that bamboo lemurs are able to survive in degraded habitats and this species is presumably edge tolerant. Furthermore, the species is known to crop-raid which puts them at further risk from humans attempting to protect their crops (Martinez 2008). This species is also kept as a pet in Madagascar (Reuter et al. 2016, Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
population:
The species is suspected to have undergone a population decline of ≥30% over a period of 24 years (three generations), due primarily to continuing decline in the area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. In particular, this species is shown to be negatively impacted by habitat fragmentation (Eppley et al. 2020).

Densities are 50 individuals/km2 in Nosy Faly peninsula, and 71 individuals/km2 in Manongarivo Special reserve (Rakotonarivo et al. 2011). Total number of remaining adults in the wild is estimated between 262,285 and 302,888 (Herrera et al. 2018).
range:
This species is found in north Madagascar, in a number of discontinuous pockets. It is known (at least formerly) from the forests of Ankarana and Analamerana in the far north (and possibly in the Ankarana Massif as well); the Sambirano region (from south of Maromandia north through Beramanja and other areas west), the Ampasindava Peninsula, and the Sahamalaza region (north of the Andranomalaza River) in the north-west; Makira Natural Park, Masoala National Park, Farankaraina Reserve, and Ile Roger (Aye-aye Island) in the north-east; and as far south as Mananara-Nord National Park (Tattersall 1982, Schmid and Smolker 1998, Sterling and Rakotoarison 1998, Banks et al. 2007, Rabarivola et al. 2007, Rakotoarinivo et al. 2011, Murphy et al. 2016, T.M. Eppley pers. obs., C. Schwitzer pers. obs., E. Louis Jr. pers. comm.).
 
Razanatsila (2012) reports that the species is easy to see in Nosy Faly Peninsula and Manongarivo Special reserve. Recent surveys demonstrate the presence of the species in many unprotected forests in the northern area of the island including the regions of Sava, Sofia and Diana: Beramanja, Ileviky (Ambilobe), Antsakay-Kalabenono, Bobakindro, Fanambana, Andrakata and Antalaha. The species is also seen in Bealanana corridor.

It has been estimated that there will be a 98% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is unsustainably hunted for food (Golden 2005, Borgerson 2015, Brook et al. 2019) and occurs in the pet trade in Madagascar (Reuter et al. 2016).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It is reported to occur in five national parks (Ankarana, Mananara-Nord, Marojejy, Masoala, Sahamalaza-Iles Radama), Makira Natural Park, one strict nature reserve (Tsaratanana), four special reserves (Analamerana, Anjanaharibe-Sud, Manongarivo, and Marotandrano), and COMATSA (Goodman et al. 2003, Nicoll and Langrand 1989, Schmid and Smolker 1998, Sterling and Rakotoarison 1998, Rabarivola et al. 2007, Rakotoarinivo et al. 2011, Murphy et al. 2016, T.M. Eppley pers. obs., C. Schwitzer pers. obs.). Previous surveys, however, did not encounter any animals in Analemarana or Ankarana, but only in a single patch of unprotected forest in the corridor that connects these reserves (Banks et al. 2007). Although this species exists in a number of protected areas, a large proportion of its population lives in unprotected sites. There should be a specific conservation strategy for marginal habitats to conserve woody bamboo stands, to ensure the survival of the species’ population. Efforts to ensure the food security of remote villages near protected areas will also be essential to the species long-term survival (Brook et al. 2018). As of 2018, there were 11 individuals in captivity, in three European zoos. It is not a self-sustaining population, with only three of these individuals being female (C. Schwitzer pers. comm.).

rationale: There is a suspected population reduction of ≥80% ongoing and into the future over a three generation time period (33 years) for this species, based on a continuing and projected decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to continuing and projected exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat:
The Indri is an extremely vocal lemur (Maretti et al. 2010, Torti et al. 2013) that inhabits tropical moist lowland and montane forests. Songs may travel as far as 2 km (Powzyk and Thalmann 2003). The species is considered to be the most diurnal lemur (Powzyk and Thalmann 2003). Indri social groups comprise a monogamous reproductive pair (with monogamy shown to be the norm through genetic paternity testing in several groups; Bonadonna et al. 2019) plus up to four other individuals, usually offspring. Changes in group composition can be quite frequent (V. Sorrentino in Mittermeier et al. 2010), and changes in partners can occur although usually only after a mate dies (Powzyk and Thalmann 2003). Groups in fragmented habitat tend to be larger than those in more extensive, undisturbed areas (Pollock 1979, Powzyk 1997). Females give birth every two to three years (Powzyk and Thalmann 2003). Reproduction is highly seasonal, with the birth of a single offspring occurring in May or June. Reproductive maturity is reached between seven and nine years of age (Pollock 1977). Both males and females disperse and the sex ratio at birth is approximately 1:1 (Kappeler 1997).

The diet consists primarily of immature leaves supplemented by flowers, fruit, seeds and bark, which vary in proportion according to season (Powzyk 1997, Powzyk and Thalmann 2003). They occasionally descend to the ground to eat earth, perhaps to detoxify seeds that have also been consumed (Powzyk 1997, Britt et al. 2002, Powzyk and Thalmann 2003).

Indris range evenly within exclusive territories with little or no spatial overlap between territories of neighbouring groups (Bonadonna et al. 2017). Mean territory size in fragmented mid-altitude rainforests has been calculated as 13.10 (±5.31) ha, ranging from 5.05-25.91 ha (Bonadonna et al. 2017), and in the more pristine forests of Mantadia as up to 40 ha (Powzyk 1997, Powzyk and Thalmann 2003). In the lowland rainforest of Betampona mean home range size has been estimated as 27 ha (Glessner and Britt 2005). Indris are capable of traversing their entire territories in a few minutes but are usually fairly sedentary, moving only a few times during the day (Bonadonna et al. 2017).

Intergroup encounters are rare (Bonadonna et al. 2017). Most (87%) encounters are resolved by territorial songs, only rarely do the disputes result in physical fights between the males (Bonadonna et al. 2017). Encounters occur at the periphery of group territories, between 0 and 82 m from the boundary (mean 22 ± 27 m, Bonadonna et al. 2017).
threats: The principal threat to this species is habitat destruction for slash and burn agriculture, logging and fuelwood gathering, all of which take place even within protected areas. Increasing levels of illegal hunting is also a major problem for the Indri (Jenkins et al. 2011). Habitat fragmentation is leading to genetic isolation of some Indri populations (Nunziata et al. 2016).
population:
Overall population size is unknown, although a figure of 1,000-10,000 has been quoted as a “reasonable estimate” (Andriaholinirina et al. 2014). Population size is decreasing due to habitat destruction and hunting. It is suspected that the rate of decline has surpassed 80% and that this rate of decline will continue over three generations (33 years) into the future due to a combination of habitat loss/degradation, climate change, and the wildlife trade. This species is shown to be negatively impacted by habitat fragmentation (Eppley et al. 2020).

Madagascar has lost 37% of its natural forest cover over the period 1973–2014 (Vieilledent et al. 2018), with deforestation rates in moist forests of Madagascar increasing to 1.2% per year from 2010 to 2014 (Vieilledent et al. 2018). Projected rates are also alarming. Morelli et al. (2020) modelled several scenarios of climate change effects and deforestation and found that rainforests across Madagascar could be reduced by up to 93% by 2070 (14–75% reduction due to climate change alone, 29–59% due to deforestation alone, or 38–93% from a combination of both). For the specific range of the Indri, Brown and Yoder (2015) estimated that the species range will decrease 39.5% from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone, without taking deforestation into consideration.

In most sites, population densities are low, with site-specific density estimates ranging from 5.2 individuals per km2 in relatively pristine forest in Mantadia (Powzyk 1997 in Powzyk and Thalmann 2003), 6.9–13.2 individuals/km² in Betampona (Glessner and Britt 2005), 27.7 (± 4.0) individuals per km² in Maromizaha, 26.7 (± 10.5) individuals per km² in Analamazaotra Special Reserve, and 24.2 (± 12.2) individuals per km² in Analamazaotra Forest Station (Bonadonna et al. 2017).

Elsewhere, Indri can be quite abundant in some forests, for example the species is the most frequently observed diurnal lemur in the Andriantantely lowland rainforest (Seaman et al. 2018). It also appears to be edge-tolerant, although this might lead to a higher likelihood of suffering from increasing anthropogenic activities at the edges of forest fragments (Seaman et al. 2018). Indeed a subsequent study in the mid-elevation Ankeniheny-Zahamena rainforest corridor suggested that Indri here were edge-intolerant (B. Thompson/University of Kent/The Aspinall Foundation, unpubl. data); this is an area where the traditional taboos against hunting of Indri have been eroding in recent years (Jenkins et al. 2011) and might be an indication of the rapidly increasing level of threat to the species.
range:
This highly distinctive lemur is endemic to the island of Madagascar where it inhabits the eastern rainforests from Anjanaharibe-Sud and Antohaka Lava (15 km SE of Andapa) in the north, south to Anosibe An'ala Classified Forest. It has not been found on the Masoala Peninsula or in Marojejy (Mittermeier et al. 2010). It usually occurs at low and mid elevations, but ranges up to 1,800 m (Goodman and Ganzhorn 2004). Populations in the north of the range are generally of black colouration, whilst those in the south are generally of black-and-white colouration, with populations in the centre of the range exhibiting both colour forms and clinal forms (Brenneman et al. 2016).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018). Projected rates are also alarming. Morelli et al. (2020) modelled several scenarios of climate change effects and deforestation and found that rainforests across Madagascar could be reduced by up to 93% by 2070 (14–75% reduction due to climate change alone, 29–59% due to deforestation alone, or 38–93% from a combination of both). For the specific range of the Indri, Brown and Yoder (2015) estimated that the species range will decrease 39.5% from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone, without taking deforestation into consideration.
useTrade: Illegal hunting is a major problem for the Indri in certain areas. Although long thought to be protected by local fadys (traditional taboos), these do not appear to be universal and the animals are now hunted even in places where such tribal taboos do exist. In many areas these taboos are breaking down with cultural erosion and immigration, and local people often find ways to circumvent taboos even if they are still in place. For example, a person for whom eating the Indri is forbidden may still hunt the animals for sale to others, while those who may be forbidden to kill Indris can purchase them for food. Recent studies of villages in the Makira Forest indicate that Indri have also been hunted in the past for their skins (which were worn as clothing), that Indri meat is prized and fetches a premium price, and that current levels of Indri hunting are unsustainable (Golden 2005, 2009, Jenkins et al. 2011, R. Dolch pers. obs.). There is evidence that small numbers of live Indris have been traded within Madagascar in recent years, and others may have been smuggled out of Madagascar.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It occurs in 18 protected areas (Rylands et al. 2018), including three national parks (Mananara-Nord, Mantadia and Zahamena) one natural park (Makira), two nature reserves (Betampona and Zahamena) and five special reserves (Analamazaotra, Mangerivola, Ambatovaky, Anjanaharibe-Sud, and Marotandrano) (Mittermeier et al. 2010). A significant population, comprising dark and black-and-white individuals, is found in the Andriantantely lowland rainforest, part of the Ankeniheny-Zahamena Corridor protected area but separated from the main corridor by an area of deforested agricultural land (King et al. 2013a, Seaman et al. 2018). Andriantantely is the focus of community-based conservation activities facilitated by The Aspinall Foundation to protect this high-priority lowland rainforest which supports major populations not only of Indri but also of other Critically Endangered species such as Black-and-white Ruffed Lemurs and Greater Bamboo Lemurs (King et al. 2013a, Ravaloharimanitra et al. 2015a,b). Much of the Ankeniheny-Zahamena rainforest Corridor also benefits from community-based conservation of sites supporting Indri and other lemurs (King et al. 2013b, Rasolofoharivelo et al. 2013, Ravaloharimanitra et al. 2015b), as do the adjacent sites of Analamazaotra Forest Station and Torotorofotsy-Ihofa complex through the activities of Association Mitsinjo (Dolch et al. 2013, 2015). The new protected area at Maromizaha also supports a population of Indri, where GERP runs conservation and research projects (eg. Torti et al. 2018, Bonadonna et al. 2019). A major region wide conservation education campaign to eliminate hunting is recommended (eg. Randrianasolo et al. 2013), for which the Indri could be promoted as the flagship species. This species has never successfully been kept in captivity and thus captive breeding programs are highly doubtful.

rationale: Despite the large range and flexibility of this species, population density is often very low and populations are largely restricted to isolated fragments throughout the geographical range. There is a suspected population reduction of ≥50% in this species over a three-generation period (36 years, estimating the generation length to be 12 years). This time period includes some time in both the past and the future. Causes of this reduction (which have not ceased) include continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, severe forest fragmentation, and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting and live-capture for the illegal in-country pet trade. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered, though it will likely be considered Critically Endangered in the near future.
habitat: The Ring-tailed Lemur’s marked ecological flexibility allows this species to colonize a diverse range of habitats in southern, south-west, and south-central Madagascar including gallery, littoral, and dry deciduous forests, spiny bush, brush and scrub, high-altitude ericoid bush and rocky outcrop vegetation (Sauther et al. 1999, Goodman et al. 2006, Gould 2006, Cameron and Gould 2013, Gould and Gabriel 2014, LaFleur et al. 2014, LaFleur and Sauther 2015). Indeed, at the upper portion of its elevation range on Andringitra, the species occurs in a zone above the forest line and in a vast expanse of vertical rock, with up to 400-m tall talwegs, surrounded by ericoid savanna. It encounters the most extreme climatic conditions on the island from the hottest and driest (Tsimanampesotse) to the coldest (Andringitra Massif). It has a varied diet, and does not seem to be constrained by available water sources (Goodman et al. 2006), although when available does drink water daily (LaFleur, per obs.). Ring-tailed Lemurs are cathemeral and can be active at any time of the day or night, although they seem to avoid night time activity when overnight temperatures are low (Donati et al. 2013, LaFleur et al. 2014). This is the best-studied of Madagascar's lemurs; its biology and ecology have been summarized most recently by Jolly et al. (2006), Gould (2006), Mittermeier et al. (2008), Gould et al. (2011), Gould and Gabriel (2014), and Fardi et al. (2018).
threats:
Habitat loss, hunting, and live-capture for the illegal in-country pet trade are the greatest causes of concern. The Ring-tailed Lemur has a strong preference for gallery forests for Euphorbia bush, and rocky outcrop rupicolous forest, but these habitats are already restricted in southern and south-central Madagascar and continue to diminish due to annual burning practices that help create new pasture for livestock. Subsequent over-grazing and harvesting of Euphorbia for livestock, and the felling of trees for charcoal production further impact wild populations. This species is also hunted for food in certain areas and frequently wild-captured and kept as a pet.

Furthermore, due to more frequent droughts in the southern regions compared with past decades, this species is increasingly threatened. Hannah et al. (2008) predicted that a mean temperature increase of 2.6°C will occur in southern Madagascar in the 21st century, and that arid regions in southern Madagascar will become further desiccated, which will have important and largely negative biological consequences for flora and fauna inhabiting this geographic area. Cyclones, severe storms and flooding also affect this species (see LaFleur and Gould 2009). Moreover, range shift predictions based climatic models for Madagascar suggest that ring-tailed lemurs will experience a net loss of 63% of available habitat simply due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).
population:
The population of this species is suspected to be undergoing decline, with individuals are now largely restricted to completely isolated or relatively isolated fragments throughout their geographic range, and overall population densities have been noted as low (Sussman et al. 2003, Gould and Sauther 2016). There is a suspected population reduction of ≥50% in this species over a three-generation period (36 years, estimating the generation length to be 12 years). This time period includes some time in both the past and the future. Causes of this reduction (which have not ceased) include a continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, severe forest fragmentation, and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting and live-capture for the illegal in-country pet trade.

There are only eight remaining known populations that have more than 100 individual Ring-tailed Lemurs (LaFleur et al. 2018). These are: 1) Amoron’i Onilahy Protected Area, 2) Andringitra National Park, 3) Anja Community Reserve, 4) Berenty Private Reserve (and surrounding forest fragments), 5) Beza Mahafaly Special Reserve (Parcels one and two), 6) Isalo National Park, 7) the “Lost Forest” (Ihorombe Region of the Ihosy District), and 8) Tsimanampesotse National Park. Some of these populations are well-protected and unlikely to be extirpated (e.g. Berenty Private Reserve, Anja Community Reserve), or are relatively safe from localized extinction because of the difficult nature of the landscape (i.e. Andringitra National Park). However, other locations are subject to pressure from hunting (i.e. Amoron’I Onilahy), and live-capture for the within country pet trade (i.e. Tsimanampesotse). Fire also presents a risk to Ring-tailed Lemurs (e.g. Isalo, Tsaranoro Valley, and Lost Forest), as does the loss of genetic diversity resulting from population isolation. This species is shown to be negatively impacted by habitat fragmentation (Eppley et al. 2020).


The following lists population counts and/or densities at sites where ring-tailed lemur populations have recently been counted. These sites represent only a fraction of the geographic range, yet give a ‘snapshot’ of the status of some of Ring-tailed Lemur populations in 2018 and illustrate that the overall population of this lemur is low, and that most populations occur in small fragmented forests (see Gould and Sauther 2016, LaFleur et al. 2017).

In Berenty Reserve, the population density is 2.5 individuals/ha in the gallery forest, 5.0 individuals/ha at the tourist front, and 1.3 individuals/ha in the scrub and spiny forest (Jolly et al. 2002, 2006, Koyama et al. 2002, Pride 2005, Gould et al. 2011). A total number of 280 individuals in approximately 20 ha have been counted in Berenty Reserve (Razafindramanana 2011, Jolly et al. 2006). In the Bealoka fragment of Berenty Reserve, the population density is 1.67 individuals/ha (Razafindramanana 2011). A total number of 167 individuals in approximately 100 ha have been counted in this fragment (Razafindramanana 2011).

In Cap Ste. Marie, the population density is approximately 0.017 individuals/ha (Kelley 2011). It is not known if this population still exists. At the last confirmed sighting (2018) there were fewer than 50 animals and they were subsisting in extremely degraded habitats and subject to hunting pressure or possibly retaliatory killings (Kelley, pers comm.)

In Tsimanampetsotsa National Park, the population density is 0.10 individuals/ha. Two groups inhabit a 195 ha area of the park (LaFleur 2012). Eleven groups have been counted, though the total number of individuals is unknown (M. LaFleur pers. comm.)

In Beza Mahafaly Reserve, the population density is 0.23 individuals/ha. A population density of 1.3 individuals/ha has been recorded in Parcel 1 of the Reserve. In 2001, 104 individuals were counted in a 80 ha area (Parcel 1 of the Reserve) (Gould et al. 2003). In 2006, 225 individuals were counted in a 980 ha area (Sauther and Cuozzo 2008).

On the western edge of Andringitra National Park, WWF guides estimated in 2009 that ~100 lemurs may range in a large area of the park, and 12 were counted at the summit of the Diavolana circuit.

A 2013 census at the 34 ha Anja Community Reserve revealed a total of 210 animals and a population density of 6.2 individuals/ha (Gould and Andrianomena 2015).

In Tsaranoro forest, the population density in 2013 was 1.47 individuals/ha, with a total of 78 animals in 53 ha (Gould and Andrianomena 2015).

In Andranobe community reserve, population density in 2013 was 1.7 individuals/ha. with a total of 30 individuals in 17.4 ha (Gould and Andrianomena 2015).

In the 20.3 ha Samisorany community reserve, 21 animals were noted in 2013 with a density of 1.03/ha (Gould and Andrianomena 2015).

The Lemur catta population at the 7.7 ha Sakaviro community reserve, was 30 individuals in 2013 (density= 1.03/ha) (Gould and Andrianomena 2015).

Five additional populations of L. catta were counted in small forest fragments in the south-central region (250 sq km area), with populations ranging from 6-28 animals, and densities of 0.28 to 5.3/ha. Two of these fragments were seriously compromised by tree cutting and firewood extraction, and the L. catta populations within were considered at serious risk of extirpation (Gould and Sauther 2016).

In the Ambatotsirongorongo fragment, the population density is 1.5 individuals/ha. In 2010, approximately 50 individuals in a 30 ha area were counted (Razafindramanana 2011).

In the Petriky fragment, the population density is 0.004 individuals/ha. In 2012, four individuals were counted in a 920 ha area (N. Malone pers. comm.), but the population is now likely extirpated (Gould and Sauther 2016).
range:
The Ring-tailed Lemur is found in the dry forests, spiny bush, montane forest, mangroves, rocky outcrops, and one rainforest in southern and south-western Madagascar, and in one humid forest in south-eastern Madagascar. The north-western boundary may be Toliara, although this is currently unknown. Populations north of Toliara and west of Isalo may have been locally extirpated, or have at least become extraordinarily rare due to intensive and prolonged bushmeat hunting (see Goodman et al. 2006, Moniac and Heitmann 2007, Siers 2007, Gardner and Davies 2014). The south-eastern limit ends at the divide between the western and eastern watersheds, which is aligned with the division between western dry and eastern humid vegetation types. All records from the Andohahela National Park are from the extreme western portion, at the ecotone between dry and humid forests. Intensive hunting has taken place here and threatens any remaining individuals or populations of ring-tailed lemurs. The currently known north-eastern limit is Sakaviro Community Reserve, 9 km north-west of the town of Ambalavao. A population also occurs at altitudes up to 2,600 m in the mountains of Andringitra on the south-eastern plateau (Goodman and Langrand 1996, Yoder et al. 1999). A newly discovered population inhabits the humid rainforest, or “Lost Forest”, of the Ihosy District (Ihorombe Region, Wright and Buono, pers comm). A very small population was recorded in the extreme southern region of Cap Sainte Marie in 2007; but it is unknown if this population is currently extant. Throughout the range of this species, its distribution is best described as patchy.

Range shift predictions based climatic models for Madagascar suggest that ring-tailed lemurs will experience a net loss of 63% of available habitat simply due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).
useTrade: This species is hunted for food (Goodman 2003, Moniac and Heitmann 2007, Siers, 2007, Gardner and Davies 2014) and frequently kept as a pet (LaFleur et al. 2015, 2019, Reuter et al. 2016). In several regions, such as costal and in-land forests north of Toliara ring-tailed lemurs have likely been hunted to extirpation (see LaFleur et al. 2018). Additionally, Toliara, Anakoa, and Fort Dauphin appear to be “hotspots” for sightings of wild-captured pet ring-tailed lemurs (LaFleur et al. 2019).
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. There are eight known remaining populations with more than 100 Ring-tailed Lemurs in them: 1) Amoron’i Onilahy Protected Area, 2) Andringitra National Park, 3) Anja Community Reserve, 4) Berenty Private Reserve (and surrounding forest fragments), 5) Beza Mahafaly Special Reserve (Parcels one and two), 6) Isalo National Park, 7) the “Lost Forest” (Ihorombe Region of the Ihosy District), and 8) Tsimanampasotse National Park. Of these, two are National Parks, five are protected areas, and one is not protected but will likely be protected in the near future. Historically Ring-tailed Lemurs also occurred in other protected area such as Kirindy Mitea National Park, Ranobe PK-32 Protected Area, and Zombitse-Vohibasia National Park, but it is possible that they have now been extirpated in these areas or are at least very rare due to prolonged unsustainable hunting.

As of 2009, there were an estimated 2,500 Ring-tailed Lemurs in zoos around the world, in addition to many more in smaller roadside collections, laboratories, and the pet trade. The species is not only the most common lemur in captivity, but indeed the most common of all captive primates (ISIS 2009, I.J. Porton pers. comm.).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers 4,745 km<sup>2</sup>. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. This is leading to suspected declines in population numbers. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species has been the subject of only brief field studies. It inhabits humid forests that are subject to a short dry season each year, as well as sub-humid forests that are subject to a long dry season. In dense primary forest it appears to favour tree holes for daytime sleeping, but it will seek out vegetation tangles in more open deciduous forest. Births occur from August through November, mothers typically producing a single offspring. It is presumably largely folivorous (Mittermeier et al. 2008 and references therein). The resolution of the taxonomic locality of the holotype of L. dorsalis will certainly impact all conservation and management of this species.
threats: The main threats are believed to be habitat loss due to rice, cocoa, and coffee cultivation, as well as illegal logging and hunting. If the taxonomic resolution of the Lepilemur dorsalis holotype results in placing the geographic distribution on Ampasindava will also present further threats to its habitat from mining concession for rare earth metals.
population: Population densities for this species have been recorded to range between: 0.16-0.3 individuals/km2. Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss (Mittermeier et al. 2008) at a suspected rate of 30% in the past with this increasing to a suspected rate of 50% in the future due to increases in threats. Habitat fragmentation due to deforestation and agricultural shifts has impacted population numbers and densities in the geographic range of this species.
range:
This species has a highly restricted distribution. It is found in the Sambirano region of north-western Madagascar, centering on Ambanja. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 4,745 km2 with an elevation range from 100-370 metres (avg. 154 metres).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is sometimes hunted for food.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It is known to occur in the Manongarivo Special Reserve, and possibly Tsaratanana Strict Nature Reserve. The resolution of the holotype locality of Lepilemur dorsalis should be considered a priority conservation narrative for this species due to the number of potential taxonomic concepts.

rationale: There has been a suspected population reduction of ≥50% in this species over a three-generation period (estimating the generation length to be 7 years), and this is suspected to continue into the future. Causes of this reduction (which have not ceased) include continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting. Therefore, this species has been assessed as Endangered.
habitat: This species occurs in tropical dry deciduous lowland forest (up to 450 m above sea level). Leaves are a dietary mainstay and make up 70–100% of the diet. Small amounts of fruits, flowers, and fleshy seeds are also eaten. This species eats lower quality leaves at Ankarafantsika than at other field sites, a difference that appears to be due to food competition with Avahi. Lepilemur edwardsi eats older leaves, and even the leaves that are dead or dying of Tabernaemontana modesta (Apocynaceae). Home ranges appear to be about one hectare and are vigorously defended with loud vocalizations and displays of branch-shaking. Several individuals can be found sleeping in the same shelter during the day, but they tend to be solitary foragers during the night (Mittermeier et al. 2008, and references therein). Infanticide has been reported in this species.
threats: The major threat to this species is habitat loss due to fires set to create new pasture for livestock, and it is also hunted for food in some areas.
population:
This species has been extensively studied in the dry deciduous forests in and around the Ankarafantsika National Park, where it has been reported at an approximate density of 60 individuals/km² (Warren and Crompton 1997). 

There has been a suspected population reduction of ≥50% in this species over a three-generation period (estimating the generation length to be 7 years), and this is suspected to continue into the future. Causes of this reduction (which have not ceased) include continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting. 

A recent genetic and demographic study showed signs of a demographic collapse of about two orders of magnitude in the Lepilemur edwardsi populations at two sites. Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss, and the species has already disappeared from several larger sections of habitat (Mittermeier et al. 2008 and references therein). Lepilemur edwardsi is also found in high densities in Mariarano Classified Forest (E. E. Louis pers. comm.), but habitat loss is also increasing over the same period documented in Ankarafantsika National Park.
range:
This species is found in the dry deciduous forests of western Madagascar. Populations range from north of the Betsiboka River to the Bay of Loza and the Mahajamba River. Further study is needed north of Ankarafantsika National Park to determine the northern extent of the range. It is found in elevations ranging from 14 – 54 metres (avg. 27.9 metres above sea level).

It has been estimated that there will be a 68% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted for food, surveys from 425 households in 2013 revealed 0.03% used blowguns and dogs to hunt the sportive lemurs (C. Borgerson, pers. comm.).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It is currently known to occur in Ankarafantsika National Park and Mariarano Classified Forest, north of Mahajanga.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers 2,315 km². This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. The number of mature individuals is also suspected to be in decline. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: The species is found mainly in spiny Didiereaceae forest and bushy areas, as well as gallery, riverine and subtropical dry lowland forest (from sea level to 300 m). There has been no published information on this species since the description of Lepilemur petteri (Louis et al. 2006, Lei et al. 2016). Assuming that it has similar life histories and behavioral traits as the closely related L. petteri, this species is largely folivorous, as well as nocturnal and arboreal (Mittermeier et al. 2010). In the spiny forest, leaves of the spiny Alluaudia procera and A. ascendens trees (Didiereaceae) are common food items of their diet, with flowers providing supplementary food during the dry season. Tree holes in A. ascendens have also been observed as habitat/shelter for the species. In other forest habitats, leaves from Tamarindus indica (Fabaceae), Euphorbia tiruculli (Euphorbiaceae), and various liana species are consumed. The flowers of Tamarindus indica are also eaten (Dröscher and Kappeler 2014). Furthermore, the spiny forest of southern Madagascar is one of the driest and most unpredictable habitats in Africa. As such, small-bodied nocturnal primates like sportive lemurs have a very small scope to unfavourable conditions, making them vulnerable to climate change (Bethge et al. 2017).
threats: The main threats to this species are habitat loss due to annual burning practices to create new pasture for livestock, and harvesting of trees for charcoal production (Scott et al. 2006) and timber/planks.
population: Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss and degradation.
range:
This species is found in south Madagascar, from east of the Mandrare River in the west to the spiny forest portion of Andohahela National Park (near Tolagnaro) in the east. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 2,315 km2. 

It has been estimated that there will be an 88% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).
useTrade: This species is not threatened substantially by hunting.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It is known to occur in the dry spiny forest and transitional forest of Andohahela National Park. There is a need for further survey work to determine the full distribution, population status, ecology, and threats to Lepilemur leucopus. The new protected areas (NAPs) of Nord-Ifotaka, Ankodida, Behara-Tranomaro and Vohidava-Betsimalaho contain populations of Lepilemur leucopus, but there is a need for ensuring the effective management of these four NAPs. It is not being kept in captivity (C. Schwitzer pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 160 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. The number of mature individuals is also suspected to be in decline. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of densely vegetated eastern rainforests. It is primarily nocturnal and folivorous (Rowe and Meyers 2016). Like other species within the Lepilemur genus, holes in large trees serve as sleeping sites (Rowe and Meyers 2016). Groups of 1-3 individuals (2 adults, 1 juvenile) have been seen sleeping in tree holes together (P.C. Wright pers. obs.). Home range size is less than 1 hectare (Porter 1998).
threats: The main threat is slash and burn agriculture causing forest loss in the eastern forests. This species is occasionally hunted with spears and by chopping down trees known to have nest holes (Porter 1998).
population: Lepilemur microdon has an estimated density of 0.99 individuals/km2 with a total estimated population of 327 within Ranomafana National Park (Wright et al. 2012). There are many sites within the park where it has never been sighted. Overall, population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss and hunting (Mittermeier et al. 2008 and references therein).
range: This species is found in south-eastern Madagascar. The range of this species currently may extend from Ranomafana National Park to Andringitra National Park (Louis et al. 2006). However, with the recent descriptions of several new species of Lepilemur from eastern Madagascar, this postulated range should be considered tentative, and would benefit from further study. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be less than 160 km2.
useTrade: This species is hunted and its habitat is fragmented due to slash-and-burn agriculture.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It occurs in two national parks (Andringitra and Ranomafana). Phenotypic evidence suggests that Lepilemur betsileo may be mistaken for L. microdon in high-elevation areas of Ranomafana National Park (e.g. Vohiparara). If confirmed, this would further decrease the range and population size of L. microdon. Therefore, further studies are needed.

rationale: This species is suspected to be declining in numbers due to a decrease in available habitat, habitat degradation, and unsustainable hunting pressure. The EOO (extent of occurrence) is approximately 18,661 km2 and is severely fragmented. Lepilemur mustelinus is listed as Vulnerable because of the expected continued reduction in extent of occurrence, reduction in the extent and/or quality of habitat, and expected reduction in number of mature individuals due to hunting pressure.
habitat: Lepilemur mustelinus inhabits eastern rainforests of Madagascar. This species can co-exist with other Lepilemur spp. although the mechanisms of niche differentiation are not well understood. The folivorous diet of L. mustelinus is lower in nutritional value and higher in alkaloids than that of sympatric Avahi (Mittermeier et al. 2010 and references therein).
threats: Threats include habitat loss and degradation, in addition to hunting. Hunting is done with spears or by cutting down trees with nests inside.
population: Though this species’ range and distribution is not well understood, the taxon appears to be widespread throughout its range. Population densities in some areas are estimated to be 3-5 individuals/km2 (Mittermeier et al. 2010 and references therein), though these are likely in decline because of habitat loss and degradation, and hunting pressure.
range:
Lepilemur mustelinus is found in eastern Madagascar from the Onive and Mongoro rivers at least to the Maningory river (Mittermeier et al. 2010 and references therein). Survey work is needed to determine the north/south extent of L. mustelinus’ extent of distribution. It has been estimated that there will be a 3% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015). Fragmentation of populations is suspected.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: The species is hunted for food.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. Lepilemur mustelinus occurs in two National Parks (Mantadia and Zahamena), two Special Reserves (Analamazaotra and Mangerivola), and two Strict Nature Reserves (Betampona and Zahamena). Though the species is still relatively widespread and common in some areas, more work is needed to understand their range and niche parameters.

rationale: The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is 23,325 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing a devastating decline in extent of occurrence and area, extent and quality of habitat due to agricultural shifts to corn and peanut cultivation. As a result, the species is suspected to be undergoing a population decline of 80% and that this rate of decline will continue into the future. The number of mature individuals is also suspected to be in decline. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat:
This species is found in subtropical and tropical dry lowland deciduous forest (from sea level to 900 m), as well as gallery forest and bush. This species has been described as a leaf-eater, although it also feeds on fruits in season, especially Diospyros (Ebenaceae) during the summer months. In the Kirindy Forest, where Avahi are not sympatric with it, it feeds on leaves of high nutritional value. Whereas the chemical composition of leaves chosen by males and females does not seem to differ, females in one study chose fruits with lower fibre content than did the males. Mating occurs from May to July, and a single infant is born between September and November. The infant is initially transported by the mother's mouth, and “parked” on a branch or in a tree hole while she forages. Infants are weaned at about 50 days. Fathers provide no parental care (Hilgartner et al. 2008).

This species has one of the lowest resting metabolic rates recorded for any mammalian species. Indeed, in areas where their habitat has been logged these animals will frequently die simply because they lack the dietary energy necessary to move to more distant trees. The animals reduce their nightly travel distances in the cold dry season (Mittermeier et al. 2013).

Home range sizes are at or below one hectare, and do not differ between males and females. Adults are organized into pairs, but they rarely interact and spend very little time near each other. Home ranges of the pair partners coincide, with little overlap with the home ranges of neighbouring pairs. The animals spend the day in tree holes and can often be seen sunbathing at the entrance. Nightly travel distances are 100–1,000 m (Mittermeier et al. 2013).
threats: The primary threat to Lepilemur ruficaudatus and other regionally endemic biodiversity in the Menabe-Antimena and other regions in western Madagascar is habitat loss to agricultural shift to corn and then peanuts before the land is abandoned. Between 2000 and 2009, deforestation was around 1,000 hectares (2,500 acres) per year; by 2014, it was 4,000 hectares per year. By 2017, it is estimated that 29.7% was lost. Because 2017 and 2018 were catastrophic with a record number of fires, it is now predicted that the loss could be as high as 44.9% in 2020 and 83.1% by 2025 (Filou 2019). This species is heavily hunted for food.
population:
Population numbers are suspected to be undergoing decline, given that the geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing a devastating decline in extent of occurrence and area, extent and quality of habitat due to agricultural shifts to corn and peanut cultivation. As a result, the species is suspected to be undergoing a population decline of 80% and that this rate of decline will continue into the future.

Population densities of 180–350 individuals/km2 have been estimated in the Marosalaza forests, and 88–160 individuals/km2 in Kirindy (Zinner et al. 2003). Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss (Mittermeier et al. 2010). The habitat loss has increased dramatically since 2009 where the loss at Menabe-Antimena was estimated at only 4.1%; however, as of 2017, the loss had increased to 29.7% due to immigration and agricultural shifts to corn followed by peanuts.
range:
This species is found in central coastal western Madagascar. At present, Lepilemur ruficaudatus is known to occur in the Menabe-Antimena Reserve and in the Andranomena between the Morondava and Tsiribihina Rivers, Kirindy Mitea, just south of the Morondava River between the Kambatomena and Mangoky Rivers (Bachmann et al. 2000), and Kasijy Special Reserve which is bordered by three rivers; in the north is the Andranomaitso River, the Mahavavy-Sud River in the east and the Mahiarere River to the south. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is 23,325 km², calculated by Minimum Convex Polygon. However, the total area estimated by the protected areas this species is located is 1,637 km2 at an elevation of 13 – 48 metres above sea level (avg. 31 metres; only calculated from individuals from Kirindy and Beroboka (i.e. Menabe-Antimena).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is heavily hunted for food.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. Protected areas where it is known to occur include in two national parks (Menabe-Antimena and Kirindy Mitea, and two special reserves (Andranomena and Kasijy). Durrell and FANAMBY are actively working with the Malagasy government and local communities to decrease the current forecasted loss of habitat to conversion to agricultural within the strict conservation zone.

The distribution of Lepilemur ruficaudatus, both north and south of its current geographic distribution (just south of the Morondava River to the Tsiribihina River) need to be studied to establish the species boundaries in western Madagascar. Additionally, species status must be confirmed to areas north and south of this range (i.e. Kasijy), considering the number of new sportive lemurs described since 2006 (Louis et al. 2006).

rationale: Currently, there are approximately 50-70 remaining individuals, in total, of this species. Lepilemur septentrionalis has undergone a population reduction of ≥80% over the past 21 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of 7 years) due primarily to continuing decline in the area of occupancy, the extent of occurrence, the quality of habitat, and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting. These causes have not stopped or has not diminished enough and will to a large extent not be easily reversed. Its geographic range is severely fragmented and is undergoing continuing decline in area and quality of habitat (Dinsmore et al. 2016). Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: This species inhabits tropical dry deciduous and gallery forest fragments.
threats: The major threat is forest loss due to illicit firewood and charcoal production. This species is also hunted for food incidentally during these illegal charcoal enterprises. Direct surveys of historical region in 2012-2013 determined that species has been extirpated from the western portion of its range including Andrahona, Sahafary and Analalava forest fragments, observing species only in the forest habitat of Montagne des Français.
population:
Currently, there are approximately 50-70 remaining individuals of this species (including adults, juveniles, and infants) in the wild. With data collected through weekly field monitoring, Lepilemur septentrionalis is inferred to have undergone a population reduction of ≥80% over the past 21 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of 7 years) due primarily to continuing decline in the area of occupancy, the extent of occurrence, the quality of habitat, and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting. These causes have not stopped or have not diminished enough and will to a large extent not be easily reversed. Its geographic range is severely fragmented and is undergoing continuing decline in area and quality of habitat (Dinsmore et al. 2016). The number of subpopulations and mature individuals is also known to have declined. 

This species has a decreasing population, as established through direct field monitoring. Although there are fluctuations in the mature number of individuals, it is not known if this is because of direct loss or migration from the area by the monitored individuals. The habitat is considered severely degraded and spread over a number of patches, due to the loss of forest to illegal charcoal enterprises, which also results in incidental poaching. All individuals of this species are now considered to be found in only one subpopulation in the Montagne des Français region of which is decreasing in size due to illicit activities despite active patrols by local authorities.

Due to the topography of karst mountains and the deforestation due to the charcoal enterprises, forest habitat has become more and more disconnected in Montagne des Français which limits migration and gene flow of the current population.
range:
This species of sportive lemur occurs in Madagascar's far northern region, north of the Irodo River, where it is now believed to be restricted to remaining forest habitat of Montagne des Français. Originally believed to be distributed across the north of Madagascar, from Montagne d’Ambre south to the Mahavavy River close to Ambilobe (Hawkins et al. 1990, Rumpler et al. 2001), the designation of Lepilemur ankaranensis as a unique species, reduced the range of L. septentrionalis to a few small forests in the Sahafary region (Rumpler et al. 2001, Ravaorimanana et al. 2004, Mittermeier et al. 2010, Wilmet et al. 2014). In 2007, a survey in the forests of Sahafary and Analalava estimated a population size of 100 L. septentrionalis individuals (Ravaorimanana et al. 2009). Unfortunately, a follow-up survey in 2012 and 2013 conducted by Omaha’s Henry Doorly Zoo and Aquarium and Madagascar Biodiversity Partnership located only three individuals in the forests of Sahafary and Analalava, suggesting that these populations have since been completely extirpated in these two western parts of its range, existing only in Montagne des Français (Louis and Zaonarivelo 2015). Lepilemur septentrionalis is found between 160 – 537 metres above sea level (avg. 409 metres).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is sometimes illegally hunted for food.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. This species exists only as small populations in Montage des Français region. It is one of the most geographically restricted and least protected of all lemurs. The species was listed as one of the world's 25 Most endangered primates in 2008-2016 (Ravaorimanana et al., 2009, Louis and Zaonarivelo 2014, 2015). This is a species on the verge of extinction, and in need of special attention. This could include a last-ditch effort to save a piece of remaining habitat, with the Montagne des Français the only opportunity. Although undertaking a captive breeding programme is normally considered an option, all members of the genus Lepilemur have always proven difficult to keep in zoos. Continuing direct surveys linked to random patrols by government authorities are considered mandatory and vital for this species’ survival over the next 10 years or until the protective status of the forest habitat of Montagne des Français is realised.

rationale: Given the impact of habitat loss within the range of this species, in addition to live capture, it is likely that Microcebus murinus is currently in decline. The geographical range of this species is currently relatively extensive, and so despite these threats, the species is still thought to be widespread, common and adaptable. Based on these premises, M. murinus is listed as Least Concern. Further information on hybridization, population status, habitat loss, and threats may warrant listing this species in a more threatened category in the future.
habitat: Microcebus murinus inhabits lowland tropical dry forest, sub-arid thorn scrub, gallery forest, spiny forest and secondary forest formations. They are also present in plantations and degraded habitats (Ganzhorn and Schmid 1998). Studies at Ampijoroa also indicate that individuals may take shelter in three to nine different tree holes within their range and remain in a given shelter for several days in succession. Females tend to share nests with several conspecifics, while males tend to sleep alone (Radespiel et al. 1998). The sexes also differ in home ranges, as male home ranges tend to be larger, especially during the mating season (Buesching et al. 1998, Radespiel 2000, Eberle and Kappeler 2002). After a gestation of approximately 60 days, typically two young are born.
threats: In the west of the range, habitat is being lost due to yearly burning for slash-and-burn and cattle grazing. Although Microcebus murinus is reported to inhabit secondary forests and degraded habitats, there is some evidence that decreased habitat quality may have adverse effects on population dynamics. According to Ganzhorn and Schmid (1998), fewer large tree holes in secondary forests result in fewer opportunities to save energy through periods of torpor, and may increase levels of stress and mortality. Live capture to supply the local pet trade is also a threat to this species, especially in the southern and northern parts of its range. Mining also poses a threat to this species. The species is occasionally kept as a pet within Madagascar (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
population:
Microcebus murinus is adaptable, widespread, and abundant, making it one of the least threatened of Madagascar’s lemurs. Density estimates range from 167 individuals/km2 (Ampijoroa forestry station adjacent to Ankarafantsika National Park) to 180 individuals/km2 (Kirindy Forest/CNFEREF), suggest that this species remains one of Madagascar’s most abundant small mammals (Radespiel 2000, Eberle and Kappeler 2002, P. Kappeler pers. comm.).


M. murinus hybridizes with M griseorufus in southeastern Madagascar in two ecologically different contact zones. One hybrid zone is located in the transitional zone between dry spiny bush and humid littoral forests south of the southern tip of the Anosy Mountain Range west and east of Ankilivalo (S 25.112 ,E 46.689) (Gligor et al. 2009). The second hybrid zone is located in the western rainshadow of the Anosy Mountain Range where there is a mosaic of dry spiny bush and gallery forests. Most hybrids in this area have been observed at Mangatsiaka (S 24.9660, E 46.5574) (Hapke et al. 2011).

It is suspected that the population is declining.
range:
This species is distributed from about the Onilahy River along the entire western coast to the north as far as Ankarafantsika National Park. A disjunct population is also found in the southeast up to the littoral forests of the Mandena Conservation Zone (Mittermeier et al. 2008). 

It has been estimated that there will be a 37% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).
useTrade: This species is captured for the local pet trade. Medical research still uses a small number of this species (I.J. Porton pers. comm.).
conservationActions: This species is listed on CITES Appendix I. It is present in eight national parks (Andohahela, Ankarafantsika, Baie de Baly, Isalo, Tsingy de Namoroka, Vohibasia, Kirindy Mitea and Zombitse), five special reserves (Andranomena, Bemarivo, Beza-Mahafaly, Kasijy, and Maningoza), the Berenty Private Reserve, and other privately-protected forests within the Mandena Conservation Zone. Also occurs in Kirindy Classified Forest (Mittermeier et al. 2008). According to ISIS (2009), this species is maintained in a number of captive collections in Europe and the United States, the international studbook held by the Duke University Primate Center.

rationale: Mirza coquereli is listed as Endangered as the species is suspected to have undergone a population decline of ≥50% over a period of 15 years, due primarily to continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, but it is also hunted. These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. A population reduction of ≥50% is also suspected to be met in the future (over a period of 15 years) due to the same causes.
habitat: Mirza coquereli inhabits dry deciduous and gallery forests. The species is able to subsist in secondary forests, including coffee plantations. Individuals are typically solitary, with the exception of mother and offspring, who nest and forage together (Kappeler 2003). During daylight hours this species inhabits spherical nests of up to one-half metre in diameter, usually placed 2-10 m high in the fork of a large branch or among dense lianas. Mating behaviour of M. coquereli in the Kirindy Forest begins in November. Gestation lasts about three months and two infants (occasionally one) leave the nest after about three weeks (see Mittermeier et al. 2008 and references therein).
threats: Mirza coquereli is threatened by habitat loss and fragmentation due to slash-and-burn agriculture and charcoal production. It is also hunted for food in some parts of its range in western Madagascar.
population:
Population densities range from 30-50 individuals/km2 in dry forests to 210 individuals/km2 in gallery forests (see Mittermeier et al. 2008 and references therein). Furthermore, densities of 100 individuals/km2  have been recorded in Tsimembo forest (Ausilio and Raveloarinoro, 1993), and 120 individuals/km2 in Kirindy (Kappeler, 1997). The Kirindy population underwent a significant decline for unknown reasons. This species’ population distribution is patchy due to high levels of fragmentation in its known region (Ganzhorn 1994). 

The species population is suspected to have undergone significant decline in the past, which is ongoing. In the past three generations, a population decline of 50% is suspected as this species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss (Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014) and is hunted. Given that deforestation is ongoing, and compounded with the human population growth (e.g. Madagascar's human population increased by 26% from from late 2012/early 2013 to 2020), it is suspected that a species population reduction will continue at 50% for three generations into the future (15 years into the future). In the longer term, the species is expected to be impacted by climate change as well.
range:
Mirza coquereli is found in lowland (sea level to 700 m) dry forests of western Madagascar. The species is found between the Onilahy and Tsiribinha rivers, in both Zombitse-Vohibasia and Isalo National Parks. They have also been reported from north of the Tsiribinha river in Andranomena Special Reserve, Tsingy de Bemaraha National Park, Tsingy de Namoroka National Park, and in the regions of Sahamalaza (see Mittermeier et al. 2008 and references therein).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted for food.
conservationActions: Mirza coquereli is listed on Appendix I of CITES. The species is believed to be present in two or three National Parks (Tsingy de Bemaraha, Zombitse-Vohibasia, and possibly Kirindy Mitea National Park), in Tsingy de Bemaraha Strict Nature Reserve, and in Andranomena Special Reserve. It is also present in the Kirindy Forest (part of the Menabe-Antimena Protected Area) and in Ampataka Classified Forest. It is adaptable, in that it can survive in secondary forest, and occurs in fairly high densities in some parts of its range.

rationale: This species is suspected to have undergone a population decline of ≥50% over a period of 21 years (three generations) as determined by direct observations within its historic range, due primarily to continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Although the exact cause of its decline is not readily apparent, habitat loss and poaching are suspected. It is reasonable to infer that these causes will continue to impact this species as these causes have not diminished and will to a large extent not be easily reversible in the next 21 years. Therefore, considering these premises and limited direct observations of this species over its large EOO (42,440 km2), this species is listed as Endangered. Note that there have been a lack of direct sightings of this species in the wild by scientists working in the species’ range since approximately August 2004.
habitat: Phaner furcifer inhabits tropical moist lowland and highland montane forests. It is nocturnal and arboreal and highly territorial, and gums undoubtedly form a major part of the diet (Mittermeier et al. 2010 and references therein).
threats: With the lack of direct sightings, it is difficult to define direct threats; however, this species’ distribution is in regions which have undergone significant habitat loss, major illegal mining booms (i.e. sapphire), and high levels of hunting (i.e. bushmeat) which is continuing.
population: Although this species appears to occupy a relatively wide distribution according to previous sightings and reports, there is no data available on its densities in the wild or other basic natural history information. There have been a lack of direct sightings of this species in the wild by scientists working in the species’ range since approximately August 2004. Where the species is suspected to persist, there has been significant habitat loss, illegal mining booms (i.e. sapphire mining), and hunting pressure. Given all of these threats, it is suspected that the population has declined by 50% in the past three generations, and that this population decline will continue at the same rate for the next three generations (21 years). For context, Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
range:
This species is historically found in north-eastern Madagascar from Zahamena National Park as its southern extent to the Antainambalana River to the north, extending into the Masoala Peninsula. It ranges from sea level to 1,000 m (Mittermeier et al. 2010). Despite multiple expeditions to determine its presence within its historical range or extent of occurrence (EOO) over the past 15 years, this species has only been directly observed in August 2004 at a single locality, Zahamena National Park and Reserve, approximately 50 metres from the Andasimakota (Sahamaloto) base camp (GPS: S17º44.078’; E048º42.094’; Elevation:  886 metres). Expeditions returned to this site in 2007, 2012, and in 2014; however, no individuals or vocalizations were seen or heard from this species.
