Other expeditions to Andaparaty in 2011 (north of the Antainambalana River, Mangabe in 2012 (south of the same river in northern Makira), Farankaraina (east of Maroantsetra) in 2012; three sites in Masoala (Andranobe in 2017 and 2018, Ambatoledama in 2004 and 2006, and Masiaposa in 2002 and 2006), Ambatovaky in 2011; Manakana-Nord (Ivontaka-Sud in 2004, Ambavala in 2008, Verezanantsoro in 2005 and Ambinanin'ny Be Orana in 2008), Befingotra near Anjanaharibe-Sud 2009, and Antsahatsimiditra in Marojejy in 2009 did not record this species either. Given that Phaner is considered an easily identified lemur vocally, especially at dusk, these expeditions which centered around nocturnal surveys, would have expected to have had direct or even indirect vocal observations, which have not been found since the 2004 expedition to Zahamena (E. Louis, pers. comm.).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Phaner furcifer is found in areas which have high levels of hunting; however, there is no known trade of this species.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It has been reported from two national parks (Masoala and Zahamena), two nature reserves (Betampona and Zahamena), the Ambatovaky Special Reserve, and the forests of Makira (which are slated for official protection), and it may occur in the Mananara-Nord National Park (Mittermeier et al. 2010). It may also occur in Marotandrano Special Reserve. Taxonomic studies to determine the status of the species, and further surveys on population numbers and range.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 2,360 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat primarily due to slash-and-burn agriculture and in some places from growing Cannabis. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This nocturnal and arboreal species is found in lowland tropical moist forests. It has also been documented in surveys of cacao plantations near Ambanja, north-west Madagascar (Webber et al. 2019). The ecology and behaviour of this species have yet to be the focus of systematic field research, but as with other members of the genus they occur high up in the canopy of tall trees. Population surveys of the species in Manongarivo Special Reserve noted that individuals observed were feeding 60% of the time, resting 20% of the time, and grooming 20% of the time, when observed during surveys (Forbanka 2018). Undoubtedly gums form a major part of the diet (Mittermeier et al. 2008). When observed in cacao plantations, the species was observed sitting in jackfruit, silk trees, mango, and marula trees, and feeding in marula, banana, jackfruit, and silk trees (Webber et al. 2019). The species weighs approximately 360 grams and has a head-body length of c. 24 cm (Salmona et al. 2018).
threats: This species is threatened mainly by habitat destruction due to slash-and-burn agriculture, in some instances for the illegal growing of Cannabis. Hunting poses less of a threat to this species due to its bitter taste.
population: This species is suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss. Population surveys of the species in Manongarivo Special Reserve resulted in an encounter rate of 2.4 individuals/km (Forbanka 2018), while in cacao plantations near Ambanja, the encounter rate was calculated as 0.4 individuals/km (Webber et al. 2019). In cacao plantations, the species were seen in pairs on several occasions and there was one sighting of four individuals together (Webber et al. 2019).
range:
This species inhabits the Sambirano region of north-western Madagascar, south of Ambanja, its range including the Ampasindava Peninsula and extending south to the Andranomalaza River. It occurs from sea level to 800 m (Mittermeier et al. 2013). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is less than 2,360 km2.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Hunting is less of a threat to this species, due to its bitter taste.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It is reported to occur in the Tsaratanana Nature Reserve and the Manongarivo Special Reserve, but these require strengthened protection. The corridor between Tsaratanana and Marojejy and Anjaharibe-Sud forest block should be maintained. Remaining forest in Ampasindava should be included in a Conservation Site. Additional surveys to the east of the range in existing forest blocks would be useful. Efforts should focus on increasing and linking existing protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Endangered as the species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of ≥50% over the past 21 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of 7 years) due primarily to observed continuing decline in densities, area, extent and quality of habitat from charcoal production, illegal logging, and annual burning to create land for agriculture and pasture for livestock. These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. A future population reduction of ≥50% over a 21-year period is also suspected due to the same causes.
habitat:
The Pale Fork-marked Lemur is an arboreal, nocturnal primate, that lives in the dry western forests of Madagascar (Schülke 2003a, Mittermeier et al. 2008). It is easily distinguished from other primates by the fork-marked black strips that extend from its nose over each eye, meeting behind the animals’ ears, and extending as a single line down the animal’s back. Like other forked-marked lemurs, the Pale Fork-marked Lemur has an unusual diet which is primarily comprised of tree exudates (85% of all foraging time is spent eating tree saps and gums), and is supplemented with insects, insect secretions, fruits, flowers, and flower nectar (Schülke 2003b). The species relies heavily on only five species of trees (Schülke 2003b), which have comparatively protein-rich gums (Dammhahn and Kappeler 2014), and are both rare and patchily distributed. Feeding-trees are typically monopolized by a single individual and two lemurs rarely feed simultaneously (Schülke 2003b). Pale fork-marked lemurs have pointed, keeled nails which allow them to easily navigate up and down the large, smooth-barked tree trunks. If both these rare, large, trees and a contiguous canopy cover are present, the species can adapt to living in human-modified habitats (Forkbana 2018b).

Pale fork-marked lemurs are a pair-living, monogamous species that exhibits low social cohesion within the pair's shared territory (Schülke 2005, Schülke and Kappeler 2003). The adult pair and their offspring occupy and defend a single well-defined and stable territory that can range in size from 3–10 ha. Adults spend only 20% of their time within 25 m from each other to avoid direct feeding competition (Schülke and Kappeler 2003). The pair communicates using four calls, the hon, ki, kiu, and kea (Charles-Dominique and Petter 1980), and Pale Fork-marked Lemurs can distinguish their loud-calls from other allopatric fork-marked species (Forkbana 2019).

Females are dominant and mating occurs in October-November, with offspring born from late January into early March. Reproductive rates are extremely low, with an average of only 0.3 offspring per female and year (Schülke 2003b).
threats: Threats to this species include habitat loss from charcoal production, illegal logging, and annual burning to create both land for agriculture and pasture for livestock. Pale Fork-marked Lemurs are particularly sensitive to habitat-loss because of their low densities, extremely low birth rates, and their heavy reliance on five, rare and patchily distributed, species of trees (Schülke 2003, Schülke and Kappeler 2003, Forbanka 2018a,b).
population:
Pale Fork-marked Lemurs are only found in the dry western forests of Madagascar (Schülke 2003a), where their population is declining because of habitat destruction. Recent estimates of the population density of pale fork-marked lemurs in Zombitse National Park, were 3.3 individuals/km2 (Forkbana 2018a), a sharp decline from estimates a few decades ago of 50-70 individuals/km² in the Kirindy Forest and Marosalaza (Charles-Dominique and Petter 1980), 300-400 individuals/km² inn the forests of Tsimembo (Ausilio and Raveloarinoro 1993). 

This species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of ≥50% over the past 21 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of 7 years) due primarily to observed continuing decline in densities, area, extent and quality of habitat from charcoal production, illegal logging, and annual burning to create land for agriculture and pasture for livestock. These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. A future population reduction of ≥50% over a 21-year period is also suspected due to the same causes.
range:
This species, which has the largest range of any Phaner species, is patchily distributed along a narrow strip of western Madagascar forests from just south of the Fiherenana River, including the Forêts de Mikea, north to Soalala, from sea level to 800 m (Mittermeier et al. 2008). The northerly populations appear isolated and may possibly represent distinct taxa.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: While hunted for subsistence consumption by local people, hunting is opportunistic and current rates are suspected to be low.
conservationActions:
Pale Fork-marked Lemurs are listed on Appendix I of CITES. They can be found in one IUCN category I strict nature reserve (Tsingy de Bemaraha Strict Nature Reserve), four IUCN category II national parks (Tsingy de Bemaraha, Tsingy de Namoroka, Kirindy Mitea, and Zombitse-Vohibasia), one IUCN category IV management area (Andranomena Special Reserve), as well as in the Kirindy Forest (part of the Menabe-Antimena Protected Area) and the Tsimembo Classified Forest. They may also be found in Andohahela National Park, where fork-marked lemurs have been recorded calling in and around Parcel 2 of Andohahela, but it is not known whether the form in question is Phaner pallescens or an as-yet undescribed species.

This species is not being kept in captivity (ZIMS 2018).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is estimated to be just under 5,000 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Therefore, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: Phaner electromontis is a nocturnal and arboreal lemur, inhabiting both tropical dry and moist forests. It occurs at both low and high elevation, between 0 and 1,400 m of altitude. Phaner species are thought to have a preference for trees with high canopies and may be reliant on primary forest habitat in comparison to degraded, low canopy forests (Petter et al. 1975). Phaner species are known to have a diet based on gums (Charles-Dominique and Petter 1980, Génin et al. 2010). The ecology and behaviour of this species have yet to be studied systematically (Mittermeier et al. 2010).
threats: The main threat to this species is habitat loss due to slash and burn agriculture, charcoal production, targeted logging, uncontrolled bushfires and mining for gold and sapphires. The species may also suffer from occasional poaching.
population: Population density estimates are still not available, but mean encounter rates suggest 0.20 – 1.90 ind./km in Montagne d’Ambre National Park (Ganzhorn et al. 1997), 0.67 ind./km in Bekaraoka forest (Meyler et al. 2012) and 1.50 ind./km in Bobankora forest (both Loky-Manambato Protected Area) and 3.10 ind./km in Analamanara forest (Manambato-Manambery inter-river system) (derived from Hending et al. 2018). Acoustic surveys suggest that population numbers may be exceptionally high in Ankarana National Park (Salmona 2014). Populations are suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss.
range:
This species is known to occur in northern Madagascar and is restricted to the Montagne d’Ambre National Park, Foret d’Ambre, Analamerana Special Reserve, Ankarana National Park, Andrafiamena-Andavakoera Protected Area, Ankarongana and the Sahafary forests (Nicoll and Lagrand 1989, Hawkins et al. 1990, Groves and Tattersall 1991, Mittermeier et al. 2010, Salmona 2014), where it inhabits moist tropical and dry forests from 0 to 1,400 m of altitude (Salmona 2014). This species also occurs in the Loky-Manambato Protected Area and in the isolated forests of the Manambato-Manambery and Manambery-Fanambana inter-river systems (Meyler et al. 2012, Hending et al. 2018), although this population may represent a separate species (Groves and Tattersall 1991, Mittermeier et al. 2010). Moreover, Salmona et al. (2018) presented mitochondrial genetic data of a juvenile Phaner sp. from Analafiana forest south of the Manambato, suggesting that it is a closely related sister lineage to Phaner electromontis. This could extend the southern limit of its known geographic range to the Fanambana river. This could mean that Phaner individuals observed in the Analamanara forest, south of the Manambato River (Hending et al. 2018) also belong to P. electromontis. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be just under 5,000 km2.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: The species may suffer from occasional poaching.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES.  It is known to occur (or potentially occur) in the Ankarana and Montagne d'Ambre National Parks, two Special Reserves (Analamerana and Forêt d'Ambre) and two protected areas (Andrafiamena-Andavakoera and Loky-Manambato) (Nicoll and Langrand 1989, Hawkins et al. 1990, Groves and Tattersall 1991, Mittermeier et al. 2010, Salmona 2014). It is possible that the Phaner sp. individuals in the Loky-Manambato Protected Area and south of the Manambato river represent a new species (Groves and Tattersall 1991, Mittermeier et al. 2010, Salmona et al. 2018).

rationale: The total population in 2006/2008 was estimated ~18,000 (Quéméré, Champeau et al. 2010). While this is higher than an estimate by Vargas et al. (2002; estimated 6,000-10,000 animals remained) this discrepancy is likely a matter of methods (line transects vs. point counts) and not an indication of population growth. Populations appear to be in decline as recent, unpublished estimates are around 11,000 animals (B. Semel, unpublished data). Both linear and exponential decline models meet the qualifications for Critically Endangered under Criterion A2acd + 4acd.
habitat:
Sifakas persist across a gradient of forest types, from sub-humid rainforest to dry deciduous forest. Individuals have been observed crossing open grassland and forest matrix areas. The diet varies by forest type, but generally consists of leaves, seeds, fruits, flowers, and buds (Meyers 1993). Unlike other sifakas, this species is not known to consume soil.

Golden-crowned Sifakas are restricted to forest fragments south of the Loky River and north of the Manambato River in north-eastern Madagascar. Forest fragments are separated by a matrix of altered savanna, dry scrub, agricultural, and pasture lands (Quéméré et al. 2013).  A small population is known to inhabit the forest fragment on the west side of the Loky River, near Maromokotra. Groups of sifakas have been found in coastal forests near Ampisikina, but confirmed sightings are lacking from coastal forests to the south.
threats: Forest loss due to slash-and-burn agriculture, uncontrolled grass fires, wood extraction for housing and fuelwood/charcoal, mining activities, and logging of precious hardwoods remain the top threats for this species (Vargas et al. 2002, Mittermeier et al. 2010, Quéméré, Champeau et al. 2010). Forest loss continues not only along fragment edges, but within forest interiors, presumably to evade detection from potential thieves or authorities (especially for vanilla farmers). Recent resource selection analysis (using ranging and dietary data from six Golden-crowned Sifaka groups) suggests that lemurs avoid foraging in parts of their territories that are adjacent to local villages (M. Semel, unpublished data). Mining continues to pose a threat to the species, as the mining footprint continues to grow and excavations become more sophisticated. Furthermore, itinerant miners do not follow local taboos against hunting this species. Construction of a Chinese-backed mining outpost (largely for gold) suggests that this threat will continue to grow. Paving the national road began in 2019 with funds from China. This will likely increase resource extraction across the region, and facilitate increased human migration to and through the area.
population:
The population is suspected to have undergone a population decline of at least 80% in the past three generations. Given that threats facing the species have not ceased, it is expected that this population decline is ongoing at the same rate.

Current best population estimates are from 2016/2018, with a total population of 12,000 (including all adults, juveniles, and infants; 95% CI: 9,026-15,956; B. Semel, unpublished data). Previous surveys in 2006/2008 using the same line transect method estimated a total population of 18,000 (11,000-26,000; Quéméré, Champeau et al. 2010). A study conducted in 2000 estimated that only 6,100 to 10,000 sifaka remained, though this study did not use the same reliable method as the more recent studies, and covered a much smaller area (Vargas et al. 2002). Two recent studies have evaluated the effective population size for this species from genetic data (current Ne ~430-795: Quéméré et al. 2012; current Ne ~1,250: Salmona et al. 2017). Using sex ratios, population age structure, and reproduction statistics from the closely related Verreaux's sifaka (Propithecus verreauxi; Richard et al. 2006, Lawler 2007), we estimate that the number of mature Golden-crowned Sifakas is 4,000-5,000 individuals.

Sifaka densities vary widely across forest fragments. They are highest in Bekaraoka near the town of Andranotsimaty  (78.1 indivs/km2) and lowest in Antsahabe (6.8 indivs/km2) with an average of 20.6  indivs/km2 in forests across their range (B. Semel, unpublished data). This species is shown to be negatively impacted by habitat fragmentation (Eppley et al. 2020).

Group size ranges from 3-10, with an average of five. Groups consist of multiple males and females. Territories are 9-12 ha (Meyers, 1993), though recent home range estimates range from 3 ha in moderate deciduous forests and up to 49 ha in dry forests. Home range size also differs greatly between the rainy and dry seasons, with territories being over twice the size in the rainy seasons (M. Semel, unpublished data). Mating occurs in late January with infants commonly seen in July and August (Meyers 1993).
range:
Golden-crowned Sifakas are restricted to forest fragments south of the Loky River and north of the Manambato River in north-eastern Madagascar. Forest fragments are separated by a matrix of altered savanna, dry scrub, agricultural, and pasture lands. A small population is known to inhabit the forest fragment on the west side of the Loky River, near Maromokotra. Sifakas persist across a gradient of forest types, from sub-humid rainforest to dry deciduous forest. Groups of sifakas have been found in coastal forests near Ampisikina, but confirmed sightings are lacking from coastal forests to the south; its presence in coastal forests to the south (near Lake Sahaka) awaits confirmation. It has been estimated that there will be a 5% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. Currently there is no known use or trade of this species, though incidents of hunting were reported around 2009 (Barrett and Ratsimbazafy 2009). While recent interviews of bush meat consumption in the area indicated several other local lemur species are consumed, locals insisted that the consumption of Golden-crowned Sifakas remains taboo (M. Semel, unpublished data). The influx of itinerant gold miners who do not share this taboo is grounds for serious concern, especially with the improvements to the national road.
conservationActions:
The Malagasy NGO, Fanamby, currently manages the Loky-Manambato Protected Area (57,000 ha), which encompasses the global range of this species. The reserve was established in 2005 and education, reforestation, agricultural, and silvicultural improvement efforts all remain ongoing. While terrible road conditions kept many tourists from viewing this species, ongoing road improvements may improve tourism to the area.

No individuals currently are held in captivity. Three individuals were held at the Duke Lemur Center until the last individual died in 2008.

rationale: This species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of ≥80% over the past 30 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of 10 years) due to observed and inferred continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat caused by the logging of the spiny, riparian or gallery forest; slash-and-burn agriculture (this practice is done to harvest cassava which is a system applied in primarily southern Madagascar or for corn and then peanut cultivation before land is abandoned which is implemented primarily in western Madagascar) and charcoal and fuel wood production; deliberate and accidental fires due to deliberate burning to create savannah for feeding cattle; selective logging for dugout canoes and schooner construction; and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting. These numerous actions have not ceased and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. A future population reduction of ≥90% over a 30-year period is also suspected due to the same reasons. Inferring population reductions to continue, based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: Verreaux’s Sifaka is a diurnal lemur that inhabits tropical dry lowland and montane forest, including spiny bush, brush-and scrub thickets, and riparian forests, and is also recorded in lowland rainforest in the south-eastern Madagascar; however, most likely introduced in this forest habitat. The diet is seasonally variable but consists mainly of young and mature leaves, fruits and seeds, supplemented with bark, dead wood, and termite soil (Mittermeier et al. 2010, and references therein), and invertebrates (R.J. Lewis, unpublished data). Propithecus verreauxi tends to live in small to medium, single and multi-male, groups that range from 2-14 (average five to six individuals), with home ranges varying from 4-20 ha depending on habitat. Breeding is seasonal, with mating taking place in January through to early March. Infants are almost completely independent at six months (Mittermeier et al. 2010, and references therein). The age of first reproduction is typically 5 or 6 years but can occur as early as 3 years. A single offspring is born in June to September after a gestation of 162–170 days (Mittermeier et al. 2010, and references therein).
threats: Despite its wide distribution, the two principal habitats upon which this species depends for survival (spiny forest and riparian or gallery forest), are under continual threat because of logging, slash-and-burn agriculture (habitat loss has increased dramatically since 2009 where the loss at Menabe-Antimena was estimated at only 4.1%; however, as of 2017, the loss had increased to 29.7% due to immigration and agricultural shifts to corn followed by peanuts) and charcoal and fuelwood production. The habitat in southern Madagascar has been altered with the introduction of Opuntia prickly pear cactus in the 1700s .Fires due to deliberate burning to create savanna for feeding cattle, as well as accidental burning due to the dry nature of the forest are also a major cause of habitat loss in some areas especially the long-term drought in southwestern and western Madagascar. The boat-making industry in the southern Menabe region is a source of substantial selective logging of food and sleep site resources. Although hunting is both illegal as well as fady (taboo) to several of the tribes living within its range (e.g., Antandroy, Mahafaly); it is nevertheless hunted for food by other tribes (e.g., Sakalava) and by immigrants to the region. In the Isalo region, this lemur is known as “sifaka-bilany” (“sifaka of the cooking pot”), but it is unclear whether this is because of its popularity as a food item or because of the sooty black appearance of individuals from this part of the species’ range. Populations are also genetically impoverished in terms of heterozygosity in some areas (Mittermeier et al. 2010, and references therein).
population:
Overall population numbers are in decline due to habitat destruction. This species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of ≥80% over the past 30 years (three generations) due to observed and inferred continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat caused by the logging of the spiny, riparian or gallery forest; slash-and-burn agriculture (this practice is done to harvest cassava which is a system applied in primarily southern Madagascar or for corn and then peanut cultivation before land is abandoned which is implemented primarily in western Madagascar) and charcoal and fuel wood production; deliberate and accidental fires due to deliberate burning to create savannah for feeding cattle; selective logging for dugout canoes and schooner construction; and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting. These numerous actions have not ceased and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. A future population reduction of ≥90% over a 30-year period is also suspected due to the same reasons.

There is significant variation in population densities noted in different forest types (Mittermeier et al. 2010, and references therein). In general, densities are lower in areas of degraded habitat which includes protected and nonprotected areas, but even very small forest patches can support sizeable numbers of this species. Reported estimates include 41 individuals/km² in Kirindy Mitea National Park, 150–200/km² at Berenty, and 400–500/km² at Antserananomby.

Furthermore, although this range including the EOO would be normally considered quite large, the spiny forest habitat in south-western Madagascar has become severely fragmented, decreasing in area by 28% from 1950 to 2000 and undergoing the highest annual rate of deforestation (1.2%) during the 1990’s than any other forest type or region in Madagascar (Harper et al. 2007). This trend has persisted between 2000 to present, continuing the decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Moreover, the primary threat to Propithecus verreauxi and other regionally endemic biodiversity in the Menabe-Antimena and other regions in western Madagascar is habitat loss to agricultural shift to corn and then peanuts before the land is abandoned. Between 2000 and 2009, deforestation was around 1,000 hectares (2,500 acres) per year; by 2014, it was 4,000 hectares per year. By 2017, it is estimated that 29.7 percent was lost. Because 2017 and 2018 were catastrophic with a record number of fires, it is now predicted that the loss could be as high as 44.9 percent in 2020 and 83.1 percent by 2025 (Filou 2019). 

Furthermore, the habitat in southern Madagascar has been altered with the introduction of Opuntia prickly pear cactus in the 1700s. With its current use as a cheap, quick growing, and readily available option as a living fence, the spiny forest is cleared for cassava and corn which the productivity of the land is short term. Large international mining concessions in southern Madagascar and the subsequent immigration from other ethnic groups into the region have also driven the deterioration of the regional cultural taboos or fady which further threatens this species’ long term survivability.
range: Verreaux’s Sifaka is distributed in southern, south-western and western Madagascar. The Tsiribihina River is considered the northern limit of the range in the west. The south-eastern extent is formed by the western slope of the Anosy mountain range which has its boundary formed by the Andohahela National Park and World Heritage Site transitional forest parcel of Tsimelahy and the spiny forest parcels of Ihazofotsy and Mangatsiaka. There is also a private reserve, Nahampoana, east of the Andohahela National Park parcels and just north of) Tolagnaro (= Fort-Dauphin) which has a small population of Verreaux’s Sifaka; however, this population was probably introduced there as it is not a part of its historical range. The range limit in the southern Madagascar which represents the Spiny Forest Ecosystem includes the Mahafaly Plateau as its western portion and the spiny and gallery forests of the Mandrare Valley and its hinterland (Amboasary, Ifotaka, Angavo, Ankodida and Anadabolava) as its eastern portion. In summary, the regional distribution of the Verreaux’s sifaka extends from the Tsiribihina River south through Menabe-Antimena Protected Area, across the Morondava River to Kirindy Mitea National Park between the Kambatomena and Mangoky Rivers, extending southward from the region north of the Onilahy River which includes the Makay Mountain Protected Area and the Zombitse-Vohibasia and Isalo National Parks, then courses through the Beza-Mahafaly Protected area, Tsimanampetsotse National Park, Mahafaly Plateau Protected area and eastward to Mandrare Valley Protected area, Berenty Reserve and Andohahela National Park. It occurs from 7 metres below sea level to 1,770 metres above sea level (avg. 364 metres).
useTrade: Although hunting is both illegal as well as fady (taboo) to several of the tribes living within its range (e.g. Antandroy, Mahafaly), it is nevertheless hunted for food by other tribes (e.g. Sakalava) and by immigrants to the region. In the Isalo region, this lemur is known as “sifaka-bilany” (“sifaka of the cooking pot”), but it is unclear whether this is because of its popularity as a food item or because of the sooty black appearance of individuals from this part of the species’ range. The species is occasionally kept as an illegal pet (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
conservationActions: Propithecus verreauxi is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It is known to occur in five national parks (Andohahela, Isalo, Tsimanampetsotsa, Kirindy Mitea and Zombitse-Vohibasia), two special reserves (Andranomena and Beza-Mahafaly), and two private reserves (Analabe and Berenty) and several large Protected Areas (Menabe-Antimena, Mahafaly, Mandrare Valley, Makay Mountain Protected Areas). Despite its presence in multiple protected areas and a large Extent of Occurrence, these sites are significantly impacted by the numerous threats listed above and burgeoning human population growth. As of 2010, there are no animals held in captivity (I. J. Porton pers. comm.).

rationale: Listed formerly as Endangered A2acd (circa 2012), this species is suspected to have undergone a population decline of ≥80% over a period of 30 years (three generations), due primarily to observed continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat due to slash-and-burn for agriculture, annual burning to generate new pasture for livestock, and forests cut to produce charcoal, in addition to exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. These causes have not ceased and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. Inferring population reductions to continue due to habitat loss, Propithecus coquereli has been uplisted to Critically Endangered.
habitat: Coquerel’s Sifaka, Propithecus coquereli, is a diurnal vertical clinger and leaper, which is most commonly found in mixed deciduous and evergreen forests, and often in brush-and-scrub and secondary formations as well (e.g. Salmona et al. 2014); also sighted in coastal mangroves on Baie de Mahajamba. They occasionally descend to the ground. In the forests of Ankarafantsika, this species is seen in groups of three to 10 with home ranges of 4-9 ha (Petter 1962, Albignac 1981). Sexual maturity is reached at roughly 2.5 years of age for both genders. Births are clustered in the months of June and July. A gestation period of 162 days normally leads to a single offspring born (Richard 1978, 1987). Infants become completely independent by about six months of age and reach adult size by one year (Mittermeier et al. 2010, and references therein).
threats: Propithecus coquereli is severely threatened by habitat destruction and hunting (Salmona et al. 2014). Its restricted distribution makes it particularly susceptible since the threats are ongoing regardless of the protective status of the habitat. Slash-and-burn agriculture and annual burning to generate new pasture for livestock are the principle causes of forest loss, but charcoal enterprises are also occurring in this part of Madagascar. Hunting for food is increasing has the burgeoning population struggle to exist in western Madagascar. Even though local traditions also place taboos on hunting; however, immigration to the region in search of income is changing these beliefs.
population: Population figures are suspected to be in steep decline due to severe habitat loss due to slash and burn activities and agricultural shifts and hunting. It is suspected that, in the past, the population declined by 80% (over a three generation period of 30 years) due to habitat loss and degradation and human population growth. An estimated 200,000 individuals were thought to remain as of Mittermeier et al. 2010; however, severe fragmentation and loss of habitat in the protected areas of Ankarafantsika National Park, Anjiamangirana and Bora represents a significant shift over the past thirty years. In Ankarafantsika, the population (considered to be the largest remaining across its range) was recently estimated to have declined to around 47,000 individuals (Kun-Rodrigues et al. 2014), with this decline likely have continued since then. Habitat loss documented in Région Sofia from 1990 to 2000 was 10% or 75,000 ha which decreased from 2000 to 2010 to 3% or 20,000 ha. Unfortunately, habitat loss increased again since 2009 due to political crisis and lack of law enforcement. Future declines are likely to accelerate due to increased human population pressure, with a population growth of 2.7% annually, growing from an overall population of 9 million in 1999 to over 26 million in 2019. As such, it is suspected that the rate of future population reduction will increase to over 90% due to continued loss of habitat due to slash and burn, annual uncontrolled burns of grasslands for cattle, and the demands of unchecked human population growth. This species is shown to be negatively impacted by habitat fragmentation (Eppley et al. 2020).
range:
This species is reported to be distributed throughout the forested areas of north-western Madagascar from north and east of the Betsiboka River with its most southerly occurrence reportedly to the south-east of Maevatanana along the east bank of the Betsiboka (Rakotonirina et al. 2013); its western boundary coastal forest of Mariarano (north of Mahajanga); its northern limit is reported to be near Bealanana; and its eastern boundary is near Antetemasy, (just west of Befandriana Nord (Mittermeier et al. 2010). A recent field survey confirmed the presence of the species in many of the remaining forest fragments within the species range (Salmona et al. 2014). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 27,662 km2, occurring from 7 metres to c. 380 m above sea-level (avg. c. 100 metres). Furthermore, this species has lost significant portions of its EOO due to habitat loss, including Bora Special Reserve where this lemur species is suspected to have been completely extirpated as Bora is no longer listed as part of the protection network due to severe slash and burn practices and agricultural shifts. Even Anjiamangirana Protected Area, located south of Antsohihy, has lost ≥50% over its forest habitat in the past 15 years due to uncontrolled burns.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Hunting for subsistence food has increasingly become a problem. The species is commonly held in captivity in Madagascar, legally and illegally (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. The three protected areas in which it is known to occur are the Ankarafantsika National Park, Anjiamangirana Protected Area, and Anjajavy Reserve; however, habitat loss and hunting pressure on sifakas are significant in Ankarafantsika (Garcia and Goodman 2003) and Anjiamangirana (E. Louis, pers. obs.). Once found in Bora Special Reserve, Omaha’s Henry Doorly Zoo and Aquarium and the Madagascar Biodiversity Partnership, NGO collected molecular genetic samples from 23 individuals during sedations in 2002 within the only remaining habitat which were primarily mango trees; extensive fires were also documented and reported during this expedition (E. Louis, pers. obs.). Due to the continued pressure over the next five years, the Bora Special Reserve became so seriously degraded that the Malagasy government delisted the site as a protected area. Most if not all lemur species have been considered extirpated from what remains of this forest. Populations of Propithecus coquereli have also been reported from the forests of, the Narinda Peninsula, and Mariarano (Mittermeier et al. 2010). An initial prioritisation of sites suitable for conserving the species has been presented by Salmona et al. (2014). As of 2019, 61 individuals of this species are represented in a small number of zoos in the United States (ZIMS 2019). There are over 50 held in registered captive facilities in Madagascar (E. Robsomanitrandrasana, in. litt. 2016), and the species is regularly held in illegal captivity in Madagascar (T. King, pers. obs.).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered as the species is suspected to have undergone a population decline of ≥80% over a period of 30 years (three generations), due primarily to observed continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat from burning of forests to provide pasture for livestock and logging for charcoal production, in addition to exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. Given the likely continuing population decline, the species has been uplisted to Critically Endangered.
habitat: Propithecus coronatus is diurnal, mainly arboreal, and primarily folivorous. The species inhabits tropical dry forests and also enters coastal mangroves (Mittermeier et al. 2010). Along the central highlands of the country habitats are mainly characterised by fragmented zones of gallery forests, riparian forests, dry deciduous forests and primary forests (GERP 2011). It is present higher in bigger trees and is found in tree crowns frequently. The species visits many food patches and its diet is composed of young leaves, mature leaves, ripe and unripe fruits and a great quantity of flowers (Honess et al. 2012). The diet is seasonal, with young leaves and flowers dominating the diet in the wet season in Antrema, and mature leaves and any available young leaves providing the staple food source in the dry season (Pichon et al. 2010). Fruit accounts for 6-9% of the diet, the higher figure being recorded in the dry season (Pichon et al. 2010). Fruit consumption increases for up to 28% of the diet during the rainy season (Rakotondrabe et al. 2017). Group sizes usually range from 2-8 individuals, with mean group sizes reported as 3.6 (n=331) in the north of the species range (Salmona et al. 2014), 4.3 (± 1.8, n=16) in the Badrala forest of Antrema (Pichon et al. 2010), 4.2 (± 1.72, n=11) in Ankirihitra (King et al. 2012), 4.2 (± 1.83, n=18) from Ambato Boeny south to Andasilaikatsaka (Rakotonirina et al. 2014) and 3.2 (± 1.48, n=5) in the extreme south-west of the range (King et al. 2014). Group home ranges of 1.2 to 1.5 ha have been reported from Anjamena (Mittermeier et al. 2010), within the Mahavavy-Kinkony protected area, while a population and behavioral study from Mandrava forest demonstrated a group size of 3 to 7 individuals and home ranges from 1.2-2.3 ha with small overlap between groups (Sifaka Conservation 2018). Within groups a social hierarchy is maintained, with females dominant over males (Ramanamisata et al. 2014). Intergroup encounters are often peaceful but sometimes result in aggressive defense of territory (Ramanamisata et al. 2014).
threats: Habitat loss is the principal threat faced by this species (Andriamasimanana and Cameron 2014). Forests within its range have declined dramatically over the last few decades, and continue to be burned to provide pasture for livestock, cut for charcoal production, and logged. There is also a shift from forest to agriculture. Habitat destruction of varying degrees was reported at every single Propithecus coronatus sites surveyed by Rakotonirina et al. (2014) and King et al. (2014). Although traditional taboos exist at some sites, hunting for meat occurs at many sites, and was reported at 82% of P. coronatus sites surveyed by Rakotonirina et al. (2014) and King et al. (2014). Some live capture for the illegal pet trade has also been recorded (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
population:
Overall, population figures are in decline due to habitat loss, hunting and other threats. The species is suspected to have undergone a population decline of ≥80% over a period of 30 years (three generations), due primarily to observed continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat from burning of forests to provide pasture for livestock and logging for charcoal production, in addition to exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. This species is shown to be negatively impacted by habitat fragmentation (Eppley et al. 2020).

Forest cover within the geographic range of Propithecus coronatus is very fragmented, and was estimated at between 1,600 and 2,850 km² (King et al. 2014; based on a refined interpretation of the forest cover estimates provided by Salmona et al. 2014). Many forest fragments have been completely lost in recent memory, and even in some remaining small fragments P. coronatus has been driven to local extinction (Salmona et al. 2014). In sites where they persist, an extensive transect survey in the northern part of the species range found variable densities from 46 to 309 individuals per km² (Salmona et al. 2014). In the relatively well-protected and well-studied Badrala forest fragment, within the Antrema new protected area, densities have been estimated at 350 individuals per km² (Salmona et al. 2014). Further south, line transects undertaken from 2017 to 2019 at various sites including Mahajeby, Mandrava and Ankirihitra provided estimates from 197 to 287 individuals/km2 (Rakotondrabe et al. 2019). Although the total population size extrapolated from field surveys (>100,000 individuals; Salmona et al. 2014) and inferred from genetic data (Female Ne >10,000; Sgarlata et al. 2016) suggests that the species may have had a large population size in the recent past, the recent and ongoing deforestation rates in western Madagascar indicate a much lower current population size.
range:
Propithecus coronatus is endemic to western and western-central Madagascar. There have been various confusing and sometimes erroneous descriptions of the precise geographic range of P. coronatus in the past, which have been recently summarized by Thalmann et al. (2002), Rakotonirina et al. (2014) and King et al. (2014). Field surveys organized to resolve this confusion were undertaken in 2010 and 2011 in order to better inform conservation decision-making for the species (The Aspinall Foundation 2009, King et al. 2012), and showed that the distribution of P. coronatus was limited to forest patches in the area between the Mahavavy and Betsiboka Rivers in the north of its range, and between the Manambola, Tsibirhina (east of 45°E), Mania and Sakay Rivers in the extreme south of its range (Razafindramanana and Rasamimanana 2010, Rakotonirina et al. 2014, King et al. 2014). There is only one reported record east of the Ikopa River (of an extirpated population in the Ambohitantely Special Reserve), but this is considered to have arisen from an error in translation (S. Goodman in Rakotonirina et al. 2014), so the species distribution in the central part of the range should be considered to be between the Mahavavy and Ikopa Rivers rather than between the Mahavavy and Betsiboka Rivers as further north (Rakotonirina et al. 2014). Melanistic sifaka occur in some populations of typically-coloured P. coronatus in the extreme south of the species range (Paulian 1953, cited by Petter and Peyrieras 1972, Razafindramanana and Rasamimanana 2010, King et al. 2014), possibly resulting from historic gene-flow with P. deckenii for P. coronatus populations located between the Manombolo and Tsibirhina Rivers, or with P. verreauxi for the most southerly known population located between the Mahajilo and Mania Rivers (King et al. 2012, 2014). P. coronatus populations have been reported to occur from sea-level to almost 1,100m elevation (Rakotonirina et al. 2014). Forest cover within the geographic range of P. coronatus is very fragmented, and is estimated at between 1,600 and 2,850 km² (King et al. 2014; based on a refined interpretation of the forest cover estimates provided by Salmona et al. 2014).   

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is illegally hunted for food (King et al. 2012) and for recreation (J. Salmona pers. obs.), and is occasionally captured for the illegal pet trade (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
conservationActions:
This species is included on Appendix I of CITES. The species occurs in three new protected areas (Antrema, Mahavavy-Kinkony Wetland Complex, and Bombetoka-Belemboka; Andriamasimanana and Cameron 2014, Salmona et al. 2014), all located in the north of the species range. Previous reports of its occurrence in two special reserves (Ambohijanahary and Kasijy) are considered erroneous (Rakotonirina et al. 2014, King et al. 2014). The new protected area (NAP) of Antrema manages and protects the coastal forests neighboring Katsepy, since 2000 (Ancient RFUM), where Propithecus coronatus benefits from a strong traditional protection (Fady). Approximately two-thirds of the species range within protected areas occurs in the Mahavavy-Kinkony Wetland Complex (Andriamasimanana and Cameron 2014), a new protected area promoted by Asity Madagascar.

There is a European captive breeding programme, with very few founders, but apparently showing some success (C. Schwitzer pers. comm.). There were 16 individuals (11.5) reported to be in captivity in Europe and 4 individuals can be found in the Lemur's Park, near Antananarivo (D. Roullet pers. comm. 2019).  Increased captive management of this species in Madagascar is recommended (C. Schwitzer pers. comm.); a properly established sifaka population would also be valuable for other future sifaka in captivity for ex situ conservation.

South of these three new protected areas, several of the formerly unprotected forest fragments supporting the species identified recently by Razafindramanana and Rasamimanana (2010), King et al. (2012, 2014) and Rakotonirina et al. (2014) are now the focus of community-based conservation projects run by The Aspinall Foundation (Anaboazo-Mangidirano, Kamotro-Liolava and Komadio-Ikay) or by Sifaka Conservation (Mahajeby, Ankirihitra-Mariarano, Dabolava and Mangabe-Mandrava forests). Several of these forests are now under the process of New Protected Area creation. The Sifaka Conservation project aims to establish a metapopulation management strategy to the conservation of the small and fragmented crowned sifaka populations and their habitats in Madagascar (Razafindramanana and Roullet 2011).  The European captive population is included in this programme to ensure its long-term viability as a reserve population for possible future reintroduction (Roullet 2014), but also as a model for the wild populations. This is a multidisciplinary strategy that involves many partners including members of EAZA and the EEP (MEF/GERP/TAF 2011).

rationale: This species is listed as Critically Endangered as it is suspected to have undergone a population decline in the past, and is suspected  to undergo a future reduction of ≥80% over the next 30 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of 10 years) due primarily to inferred continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat due to burning of forests to provide pasture for livestock, logging for charcoal production and fragmentation and also due to inferred levels of exploitation through increased hunting for food with changes in values and breakdown of the taboo system. These causes of decline will to a large extent not be easily reversible. The species was previously listed as Endangered but an increase in the projected rate of habitat loss and therefore population decline justifies the uplisting to Critically Endangered.
habitat:
Propithecus deckenii is an inhabitant of dry deciduous forest patches in western Madagascar. The species is well-known for living in areas of tsingy, the needle-like limestone karst formations present at Bemaraha and Beanka, and also occurs in other dry deciduous forests in the region. P. deckenii is folivorous and seems to be fairly resilient to degradation of habitat; individuals have even been observed in Eucalyptus trees in the middle of Soalala town (Mittermeier et al. 2010). 

A species distribution model for the year 2000 estimated a distribution area for P. deckenii of 9,356 km² (Brown and Yoder 2015). Interestingly these authors suggested that climate change could result in a potential increase in distribution area for this species by 2080; however their model only considered climate change, and deforestation due to anthropogenic activities is reducing forest habitat throughout Madagascar (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
threats: Deforestation rates have increased in recent years across Madagascar (Vieilledent et al. 2018). Habitat loss is the principal threat faced by this species (Andriamasimanana and Cameron 2014). Forests within its range have declined dramatically over the last few decades, and continue to be burned to provide pasture for livestock, cut for charcoal production, and logged. Habitat destruction of varying degrees was reported at every single Propithecus deckenii site surveyed by Rakotonirina et al. (2014) and King et al. (2014). Although traditional taboos exist at some sites and were previously considered to offer protection across much of the species range, hunting for meat does occur at many sites, and was reported at between 66 and 83% of P. deckenii sites surveyed by Rakotonirina et al. (2014) and King et al. (2014). Some live capture for the illegal pet trade has also been recorded (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
population:
Propithecus deckenii can be fairly common in suitable habitat, but we are not aware of abundance or density estimates for the species. Density estimates for the closely-related P. coronatus range from 46 to 309 individuals per km² (Salmona et al. 2014). Reported group sizes of P. deckenii in the south-east of the species range are of one to six individuals in and around Ambohijanahary (mean = 3.4, sd = 1.22, n = 22; Rakotonirina et al. 2014) and of two to five individuals in the same general area by Petter and Peyrieras (1972; mean = 3.7, sd = 1.07, n = 12). Similar group sizes were reported by King et al. (2014) in the south-west of the species range, between the Manombolo and Manambaho Rivers of two to five individu­als (mean = 3.5, SD = 1.05, n = 6), and by Dammhahn et al. (2013) in the Beanka Forest of four to six individuals. In the north-east of the species range, Curtis et al. (1998) reported mean group sizes of 4.9 (n = 28) at Analabe, 3.0 (n = 6) at Ambinany-Analabe, and 4.8 (n = 18) elsewhere in the MKWC. Groups usually have only one reproductive female. 

The species is suspected to have undergone a population decline in the past, and is suspected  to undergo a future reduction of ≥80% over the next 30 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of 10 years) due to: inferred continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat due to burning of forests to provide pasture for livestock; logging for charcoal production and fragmentation; and to inferred levels of exploitation through increased hunting for food with changes in values and breakdown of the taboo system.
range:
Propithecus deckenii is endemic to western Madagascar, occurring in highly fragmented deciduous forest from sea-level along the west coast (Wilmé et al. 2006) to 1,250m elevation on the Bongolava massif (Rakotonirina et al. 2014). There have been various confusing descriptions of the precise geographic range of P. deckenii in the past, which have been recently summarized by Thalmann et al. (2002), Rakotonirina et al. (2014) and King et al. (2014). Field surveys organized to resolve this confusion were undertaken in 2010 and 2011 in order to better inform conservation decision-making for the closely-related P. coronatus (The Aspinall Foundation 2009, King et al. 2012), and showed that the distribution of P. deckenii is limited to remaining forest patches of western Madagascar west of the Mahavavy River and north of the Manambolo River (King et al. 2014, Rakotonirina et al. 2014). Previous occasional reports of P. deckenii individuals just outside this range (i.e. east of the Mahavavy River or south of the Manambolo River) amongst otherwise P. coronatus populations (Tattersall 1982, 1988, Thalmann and Rakotoarison 1994) can probably be explained by rare and localized events of P. deckenii individuals crossing rivers or other biogeographical barriers by natural or human-induced methods such as releases or escapes of pet sifaka captured elsewhere (Rakotonirina et al. 2014), and certainly do not represent the existence of established P. deckenii populations outside the range described above.

Melanistic forms of P. deckenii occur in several populations close to the Mahavavy River (see map in King et al. 2014). These forms vary from light forms with pale heads and only limited patches of dark colouration, through intermediate forms with darker heads and pelage coloration similar to that of typical P. coronatus to very dark forms which are very dark brown on large areas of the head, back, arms and legs, and which are unlike any typical sifaka species (Rakotonirina et al. 2014). Towards the source of the Mahavavy River, in the south-east of the P. deckenii range, 20% of individuals of the P. deckenii populations surveyed in and around the Ambohijanahary Special Reserve by Rakotonirina et al. (2014) exhibited varying degrees of intermediate to dark melanism, and Petter and Peyrieras (1972) reported 17% were melanistic in the same general area.  In the north-east of the species range, Curtis et al. (1998) reported that 25% of individuals of the P. deckenii population at the single site of Analabe within what is now the Mahavavy-Kinkony Wetland Complex (MKWC) were melanistic, and similarly Thalmann et al. (2002) reported melanistic individuals made up 25% of the sifaka population at the nearby Anktotrakotraka site. Other surveyed forest fragments within the MKWC consist only of typical white individuals (Curtis et al. 1998, Thalmann et al. 2002). Melanistic individuals have also been reported from Kasijy Special Reserve; located approximately half-way between Ambohijanahary and MKWC, but appear to be few in number (Randrianarisoa et al. 2001). Melanistic infants have so far only been observed with melanistic adults, whilst typical white infants have been observed with both typical and melanistic adults (Rakotonirina et al. 2014). Given that all localities where P. deckenii populations exhibit melanistic tendencies are close to the eastern limit of the species range, and therefore close to the range of P. coronatus, it is plausible that the underlying cause of the melanism is occasional gene flow with P. coronatus, however other hypotheses have been suggested and further work is clearly required (King et al. 2012, 2014; Rakotonirina et al. 2014). 

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Hunting for subsistence food is increasingly becoming a problem, despite traditional taboos protecting them from hunting. Some live capture for the illegal pet trade has also been recorded (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It is known to occur in three national parks (Baie de Baly, Tsingy de Bemaraha, and Tsingy de Namoroka), the Tsingy de Bemaraha Strict Nature Reserve, and four special reserves (Ambohijanahary, Bemarivo, Kasijy, and Maningoza). A significant proportion of the remaining habitat for the species occurs in the Mahavavy Kinkony Wetland Complex (Andriamasimanana and Cameron 2014), a new protected area managed by Asity International. The species also appears to be fairly abundant in the Beanka new protected area (Dammhahn et al. 2013), a site where significant anthropogenic threats appear to be restricted to areas close to the major road running through it (King et al. 2014).

There are only about ten captive Propithecus deckenii in registered facilities in Madagascar (E. Robsomanitrandrasana in. litt. 2016), plus a few others in unregistered situations (Reuter and Schaefer 2017), and there are none in captivity outside of Madagascar (ZIMS 2019).

rationale: A population reduction of ≥80% is suspected to be met in the future (over a three-generation time period of 30 years), and a time period of 30 years representing both past and future. This is based on a continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat due to slash-and-burn agricultural practices and timber extraction (including destructive utilisation of sifaka food trees in some areas), as well as exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: The species is found in the eastern rainforests, and persists in some degraded forest and smaller forest fragments (down to ~30 ha). The diet consists mainly of ripe fruits, seeds, flowers, and young leaves, their respective proportions varying according to seasonal abundance (Irwin 2008b). In the rainy season (November-April) ripe fruit and/or seeds can contribute more than 80% of the diet; in the lean season (May-October) this drops to about 20% and the majority of the diet is composed of leaves and/or flowers (Irwin 2008b; Irwin et al., 2015; Kerker Oliver 2017; Powzyk 1997). Females are sexually receptive for very few days (perhaps only one day) out of the year, sometime between November and January. A single young is born between May and July, after a gestation of 179 days. Individuals may live up to 25 years in the wild. This species is diurnal and arboreal. In one study, these animals spent 54.5% of their time resting, 32.3% feeding, 5.7% moving, and 5.0% in social behaviour. This species has only twice been studied for a significant period of time (by Powzyk at Mantadia and Irwin at Tsinjoarivo). It lives in female-dominated, multi-male/multi -female groups of 2 to 8 individuals, consisting of 1–3 adult females and 1 or 2 adult males, and multiple females may breed within the same group. Home ranges of 20–80 ha are defended by means of scent-marking, although there is little home range overlap and little aggression over boundaries. Compared to the sympatric, similar -sized Indri indri, P. diadema spends more time actively patrolling and defending its territories. The mean daily path length of 987– 1629 m for P. diadema can be compared to 774 m for I. indri (Powzyk 1997). As one of the largest lemurs, it is likely that their only natural predator is the fosa (Cryptoprocta ferox), though it is possible that some large raptors may pose a risk, especially for younger animals. Predation by fosa may be an important threat to this species, especially in fragmented or degraded areas where other prey species may be reduced (Irwin et al. 2009). Males emigrate at roughly age five, often to a neighbouring group while females may either emigrate or remain in their natal group; most animals breed after five years of age but occasionally females that stay in their natal group have given birth at 4 years old (Mittermeier et al. 2010 and references therein; Irwin unpublished data).
threats: Continued destruction of rainforest habitat in eastern Madagascar due to slash-and-burn agricultural practices and timber extraction is the principal threat to this sifaka’s survival. However, hunting for food also can have a very serious impact on remaining populations, even within existing protected areas (Mittermeier et al. 2010). Reports of hunting have increased dramatically since the last assessment, particularly in regions surrounding Andasibe and the Corridor Ankeniheny-Zahamena, as well as northern parts of the species range. Furthermore, illegal rum production, necessitating the planting of sugar cane fields and destructive utilization of sifaka food trees, is a threat to populations in Tsinjoarivo (Irwin and Ravelomanantsoa 2004). The species is occasionally kept as a pet within Madagascar (Reuter and Schaefer 2017). Finally, the isolated nature of some protected but small populations (especially Betampona and Andriantantely) means that these populations might be non-viable over the long term without restoring gene flow or undertaking translocations.
population:
This species is rare. It occurs only at very low densities wherever it is found: at Tsinjoarivo densities of roughly 7 individuals/km2 were recorded in less-disturbed, continuous forest, with higher local densities (14-20 individuals/km2) in some smaller isolated fragments (Irwin 2008a). A more recent study in a different intact forest camp at Tsinjoarivo yielded even lower densities (4.77 individuals/km2; Rakotomalala et al. 2017). All estimates from Tsinjoarivo reflect an area where this species is not hunted; true densities elsewhere in its range may be lower. This species is shown to be negatively impacted by habitat fragmentation (Eppley et al. 2020).

Population figures are in decline due to habitat destruction and hunting. A population reduction of ≥80% is suspected to be met in the future (over a three-generation time period of 30 years), and a time period of 30 years representing both past and future. This is based on a continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat due to slash-and-burn agricultural practices and timber extraction (including destructive utilisation of sifaka food trees in some areas), as well as exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure.
range:
This species is found in rainforests of eastern and north-eastern Madagascar and is thought to be one of the most widely-distributed of the sifakas. Its southern limit is well-known to be at the Onive River, but its northern range limit is poorly known. Current evidence suggest that its northern range limit is the Mananara River, based on its recorded presence at Marotandrano Special Reserve, Ambatovaky Special Reserve, and Mananara-Nord National Park, but its absence in the Makira National Park. Historically, its range extended farther north to just south of the Antainambalana River, but it has not been found in recent years during fairly extensive studies of that region (Mittermeier et al. 2013).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Hunting for its meat and fur has a very serious impact in many parts of its range. The species is occasionally kept as a pet within Madagascar (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. This species occurs in three national parks (Mananara-Nord, Andasibe-Mantadia, and Zahamena), two strict nature reserves (Betampona and Zahamena), three special reserves (Ambatovaky, Mangerivola, and Marotandrano) and other newer protected areas in lower protection categories (Corridor Ankeniheny-Zahamena, Maromizaha, and Mangabe) (Mittermeier et al. 2010). Additional populations have been identified in the Tsinjoarivo Classified Forest, the Marokitay Forest Reserve, and in the unprotected forests of Anosibe an’ala, and Anjozorobe-Angavo, (Mittermeier et al. 2010).

Between 2006 and 2008, 25 individuals were translocated into Analamazaotra (part of Andasibe-Mantadia National Park), where they had previously been extirpated; as of 2016 this population has grown to roughly 60 individuals (E. Louis pers. comm.). As of 2018 this species was not represented in captivity but individuals are sometimes kept at the “Lemur Island”, part of the Hotel Vakona in Andasibe, Madagascar.

rationale: This species is suspected to have undergone a population decline of ≥50% over a period of 30 years (three generations), due primarily to hunting and habitat destruction (e.g. slash-and-burn agriculture and logging). These pressures continue as evidenced by recent local extinctions north of Ranomafana to the Onive River. Although populations are well-protected in Ranomafana, populations elsewhere are on the brink of extinction. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is also 1,543 km², and severely fragmented. Therefore, the species is overall listed as Endangered.
habitat: Propithecus edwardsi is found in primary and slightly degraded rainforests at middle to high elevations. This species is diurnal and primarily folivorous, though fruits, flowers, and seeds constitute major portions of its diet. Like other species within the Propithecus genus, P. edwardsi obtains protein from seed predation (Wright et al. 2012). The typical group size ranges from three to nine individuals, with territories of approximately 50 ha. Both males and females disperse, though males disperse three times throughout their lifetime while females disperse just twice (Wright et al. 2012). Dispersal distance varies between individuals, with an observed maximum distance of 12-km by a male in Ranomafana National Park (P.C. Wright pers. obs.). Individuals are poor dispersers across fragmented habitats (Pochron et al. 2004, Gerber et al. 2012). Infants are typically born in June and July every other year after six months of gestation. High infant and adult mortalities are also noted in this species. Predation, especially by Fossa (Cryptoprocta ferox) is a significant cause of mortality, but some infant losses are also attributable to infanticidal males. Infant mortality has been calculated at almost 50% before the age of one year, but it is particularly high in disturbed forests (Mittermeier et al. 2008, and references therein). In the longest demographic study of this species, the maximum lifespan of an individual reached 31 years (King et al. 2011, 2012, Wright et al. 2012). P. edwardsi reproduce slowly; however, older females continue to give birth until death (Wright et al. 2008).
threats: Habitat destruction due to slash-and-burn agriculture, logging, gold mining, and illegal rum production represents the principal threat to this species’ survival. In addition to reducing this species’ range, habitat disturbance increases parasitism, which impacts lemur health and decreases population size (Wright et al. 2009). Fragmentation and forest destruction also increase predation risk by large-ranging predators, including Fossa (Irwin et al. 2009). On a larger-scale, it has been shown that this species is impacted by climate change, as infant mortality increases and fecundity decreases during ENSO years; this is significant, given recent predictions that cyclones and droughts will continue to increase in severity and frequency throughout Madagascar (Wright 2006, Dunham et al. 2008). Hunting represents an added anthropogenic pressure, as Propithecus edwardsi is a favoured prey item among hunters, who use slingshots, blowguns and firearms. Over an 18-year study, Dunham et al. (2008) showed that these threats have already negatively impacted survival and fecundity rates.
population:
Nearly half of the total population is thought to occur in Ranomafana National Park, which has an estimated population size of 1,561 individuals at densities of 4.73 individuals/km2 (Wright et al. 2012). In other localities, Propithecus edwardsi is thought to occur in densities no higher than 3 individuals/km2 (Irwin et al. 2005, P.C. Wright pers. obs., M.E. Donohue pers. obs. D. Andrianoely pers. comm.), bringing the total population to approximately 3,500 individuals—though, this may be an overestimate due to coarse sampling; therefore, more surveys are needed. P. edwardsi has not been observed in the northern part of its geographic range, Marolambo-Fandriana National Park, within the last 20 years (S. Lehman pers. comm.). This local extirpation provides further evidence for steady population decline over the last 20 years (Lehman et al. 2006), and this species is shown to be negatively impacted by habitat fragmentation (Eppley et al. 2020).

This species is suspected to have undergone a population decline of ≥50% over a period of 30 years (three generations), due primarily to hunting and habitat destruction (e.g. slash-and-burn agriculture and logging). These pressures continue to augment, as evidenced by recent local extinctions north of Ranomafana to the Onive River. Although populations are well-protected in Ranomafana, populations elsewhere are on the brink of extinction. Without further protection, a future population reduction of ≥50% over a 30 year period is suspected. Adding to these pressures, this species has a slow life history (1 offspring every other year) and high infant mortality (Pochron et al. 2004, Irwin et al. 2009, Wright et al. 2012).
range:
This species is endemic to Madagascar, where its historical range spanned from the Mangoro and Onive Rivers, south to the Iantara River in Andringitra National Park (ANP). No Propithecus edwardsi has been seen in the northern part of its range (what is now Marolambo-Fandriana National Park) within the last 20 years (S. Lehman pers. comm., M.T. Irwin pers. comm.). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,543 km². However, the estimated area of occurrence (AOO) could be smaller, as P. edwardsi have been extirpated from much of the COFAV corridor connecting Ranomafana National Park (RNP) and ANP, according to data from over 100 transects conducted by the Centre ValBio research team from 2009-2018. Our current AOO estimate ranges from 500 to 1,004 km2, though further research on distribution is needed south of RNP. P. edwardsi is found in rainforests that range from 600-1,600 m.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forests (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Hunting is a problem, with shotguns, blowguns and slingshots all used as weapons to bring individuals down.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. Propithecus edwardsi is known to occur in two national parks, Andringitra and Ranomafana. Although surveys conducted by the Centre ValBio research team have only detected P. edwardsi in in two sites south of Ranomafana, unexplored forest fragments between these parks may still harbor viable populations. Many of these fragments have been included within COFAV, a conservation corridor linking Ranomafana and Andringitra National Parks, which received official protection in 2015 (decree 2015-755). As of 2020, no animals are known to be held in captive breeding programmes (I.J. Porton pers. comm.). Establishing captive populations may serve as a second line of defence against extinction for this species.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered as the species is estimated to number less than 250 mature individuals, there is a continuing decline, and the number of mature individuals in any subpopulation is thought not to exceed 50 mature animals.
habitat: It is found mainly in tropical moist montane forest, predominantly in undisturbed primary forests above 700m of elevation.  Group sizes range from 2 to 9 individuals. Social structure is either polygynous with a single adult male and multiple adult females (seldom more than 2) or pair-bonded with one adult female. Home range sizes vary by site, and are smaller for the Marojejy Camp 2 group inhabiting undisturbed primary forest (100% MCP is 57 ha and 95% kernel is 41 ha) than in the more disturbed Makira (Andaparaty) site (100% MCP is 99 ha and 95% kernel is 68 ha). They are folivorous seed predators who consume seeds and fruits (41.8%), leaves (48.2%), and flowers (9.8%) from over 100 species of trees, vines, and epiphytes. Females mate only one day the whole year in late December or early January (Mittermeier et al. 2010, Patel 2014, Rajaonarison 2015, Sato et al. 2016). Their only known predator (aside from humans) is the fossa (Patel 2005). Their “Zzuss” alarm vocalizations are individually distinctive and differ between males and females (Patel and Owren 2012).
threats: Habitat destruction due to slash-and-burn agriculture and hunting are the primary threats. There is no taboo or “fady” against eating this species. Illegal logging of rosewood, pallisandre, and ebony also threaten this species as well as artisanal mining in Anjanaharibe-Sud Special Reserve. Recently, vanilla plantations inside Marojejy are a new source of disturbance.
population:
Recent density estimates from rapid surveys in Anjanaharibe-Sud Special Reserve are also extremely low at 1.9 indiv./km² (north-east near Ambodisatrana) and 0.29 indiv./km² (central-east near Camp Indri), though higher in the western extension at 2.59 indiv./km² (south-west near Ampoanaomby) (Patel 2016). Group encounter rates from a line-transect survey in northern Marojejy National Park are extremely low at 0.015 groups/km² (Loudon et al. 2016). Earlier population estimates are also extremely low. Sterling and McFadden (2000) encountered this species only 7 times during a 6 week survey in Marojejy. Similarly, Schmid and Smolker (1998) report only 2 encounters during a 6 week survey in Anjanaharibe-Sud.

The species is estimated to number less than 250 mature individuals, there is a continuing decline, and the number of mature individuals in any subpopulation is thought not to exceed 50 mature animals.
range: This species has a very restricted range in north-eastern Madagascar that includes the humid forest belt extending from Maroantsetra to the north-eastern edge of the Makira Natural Park (Antohaka Lava forest), Anjanaharibe-Sud Special Reserve, Marojejy National Park, and COMATSA-Sud/Betaolana (the corridor between Marojejy and Anjanaharibe-Sud). Additionally, at least one group is found in the unprotected Maherivaratra forest. Marojejy represents the northern limit of its known distribution while the Andaparaty forest in Makira just north of the Antainambalana River is currently regarded as the southern limit. They are patchily distributed at very low densities particularly within Makira and COMATSA-Sud where they are only found at a few sites (Patel, 2014, 2016, Rasolofoson et al. 2007). Although most of the remaining population is found in Marojejy and Anjanaharibe-Sud at elevations between 700m and 1,875m asl (Sterling and McFadden, 2000, Schmid and Smolker 1998), in the Adaparaty forest (Makira), two groups inhabit an unusually low elevation forest from 235m to 565m asl (Patel and Andrianandrasana 2008). It has been estimated that there will be a 64% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).
useTrade: This species is hunted for food.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. This species occurs in one national park (Marojejy), one special reserve (Anjanaharibe-Sud), as well as the Makira Natural Park and the COMATSA-Sud new protected area. Little is known about their distribution, abundance and threats in COMATSA-Sud. The populations at greatest risk are found in Makira and COMATSA-Sud where additional surveys and monitoring are needed.

rationale: This species has a very small remaining population. The number of mature individuals is about 125 and is continuing to decline. There is a restricted population structure with 90-100% of all mature individuals being in one subpopulation. The species is threatened mainly by habitat destruction through slash-and-burn agriculture, hunting and fire. In 2017, around 400-500ha was burned by fire in Andrafiamena-Andavakoera new protected area. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
