(2004) recorded it in the Saracá-Taquera National Forest (429,600 ha) on the right (west) bank of the Rio Trombetas e Röhe (unpublished data) recorded the species presence in the State Forest at Faro municipality.Saguinus m. ochraceus probably occurs in the APA Guajuma (28.370 ha), Nhamundá State Park (28,370 ha) and the Nhamundá State Environment Protection Area (195,900 ha), Amazonas.Nowadays, an ongoing long-term study is carrying out in FLONA Saracá-Taquera, PA. This project is coordinated by Dr Fabiano Rodrigues de Melo and his team. They are collecting data on the subspecies Saguinus martinsi martinsi. A master's project is also in guidance and its goal is analyse and understand their home range, population size, density, basic ecology and behaviour.There are no captive-breeding programmes for either subspecies.

rationale: With an extent of occurrence estimated to be 8,345 km2 and occurring only in higher elevations, the species is known from fewer than 10 locations in central and eastern Madagascar, representing a highly fragmented geographic range. A continued decline of the population is inferred, based on a continuing decline of the species' area of occupancy as well as a decline in area, extent and quality of its habitat. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: The species inhabits rainforests, although some individuals have also been observed in patches of old Eucalyptus plantations where they move through the understory without descending to the ground (Ganzhorn 1987). In the Central Highlands, the species persists in small to very small relictual forest fragments in a surrounding matrix of anthropogenically created and/or altered grasslands (Yoder et al. 2016). In Andasibe, the species is mainly solitary at night and is feeding on fruits and insects in shrubs and low trees as well as in the upper canopy of the forest (Ganzhorn 1988, 1989).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat destruction from unsustainable agricultural practices, charcoal production, logging, mining (both industrial and artisanal), and hunting. Repeated vegetation burning has starkly contributed to forest loss in the Central Highlands, whereas main threats to remaining rainforests further east mainly stem from slash-and-burn agriculture. Madagascar's largest mine is located within the species' range.
population: Home ranges in males (0.22–0.42 ha) are slightly smaller than in females (0.21–0.30 ha) (Randrianambinina 2001). Population densities estimated by Ganzhorn (1988) (when the species was still believed to be Microcebus rufus) were 110 +/- 34 individuals/km2 at Andasibe. At Tsinjoarivo, M. Blanco (pers. comm.) estimated population densities at 132 individuals/km2 in a forest fragment and 80 individuals/km2 in a continuous forest site. As other rainforest mouse lemurs, the species is believed to occur in lower densities than Microcebus species in western dry forest (Setash et al. 2017). A continued decline of the population is inferred, based on a continuing decline of the species' area of occupancy as well as a decline in area, extent and quality of its habitat.
range: The type locality of this species is the region of Andasibe, based on 9 animals caught in the Analamazaotra Forest Station in Andasibe (Kappeler et al. 2005, Roos and Kappeler 2006, Dolch 2008). Apart from occurring in other protected areas in the immediate surroundings (Analamazaotra Special Reserve, Mantadia National Park, Maromizaha Forest, Vohimana Forest), it also occurs as far west as Ambohitantely Special Reserve (Rasoloarison et al. 2013) and smaller fragments such as Ankafobe Forest (Blanco et al. 2016, Yoder et al. 2016). Analyses of samples from Tsinjoarivo classified forest have also been identified as Microcebus lehilahytsara (M. Blanco, D. Weisrock, pers. comm.), meaning that the southern limit of its distribution might be the Onive/Mangoro river complex. The northernmost collection locality lies at Riamalandy in Marotandrano Special Reserve (Yoder et al. 2016), but the species does not occur in the more southerly Zahamena Strict Nature Reserve and National Park, where it is replaced by M. simmonsi (Roos and Kappeler 2006). Its neighbouring species to the south, south-east and east are M. jollyae and M. rufus (Louis et al. 2006), M. marohita (Rasoloarison et al. 2013) and M. gerpi (Radespiel et al. 2012), respectively. M. lehilahytsara appears to be a “highland specialist”, restricted to higher altitudes and never found below 825 m asl (Weisrock et al. 2010, Radespiel et al. 2012). With most of the highland forests already gone, its extent of occurrence within its broader geographical range may be quite small. The EOO is estimated to measure less than 8,350km2.
useTrade: The species appears to be occasionally (and randomly) trapped for both food and the pet trade. Reuter et al. (2019), surveying the frequency with which lemurs are kept in country (including areas where Microcebus lehilahytsara occurs), found that Microcebus spp. only make up 2.2% of all lemurs kept as pets, but suspect them to be under-reported because of their "non-lemur like" appearance. Jenkins et al. (2011), in another household survey, found that Microcebus spp. were the seventh-most popular bushmeat in the Moramanga and Anosibe An’ala Districts (which are both within the geographical range of M. lehilahytsara).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It occurs in several protected areas (Rylands et al. 2018), including one National Park (Mantadia) and three Special Reserves (Analamazaotra, Ambohitantely, Marotandrano). Some sites where it occurs have recently been gazetted as new protected areas (e.g. Ankeniheny-Zahamena, Anjozorobe-Angavo, Mangabe-Ranomena-Sahasarotra, Tsinjoarivo, Maromizaha), are in the process of becoming protected areas (e.g. Ankafobe, Torotorofotsy) or are managed by local communities for conservation. The species is kept in only a few zoological institutions, with a significant breeding colony of several dozen individuals being kept in the Masoala exhibit of Zoo Zurich (Jürges et al. 2013, Karanewsky et al. 2015).

rationale: As of 2020, the extent of occurrence (EOO) of M. mamiratra has been updated to cover c.2,613 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and is undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: It is found in humid primary and secondary forests on the island of Nosy Be (Andriantompohavana et al. 2006, Hasiniaina et al. 2018) and humid forest fragments in mainland Madagascar.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss.
population: This species is rare within a very restricted and fragmented area, and in decline due to habitat loss and degradation.
range: Formerly this species was believed to be confined to the island of Nosy Be in north-western Madagascar and fragmented forest areas in Manehoka, inter river system VI, in north-western Madagascar (Olivieri et al. 2007). It is particularly known from the small Lokobe Strict Nature Reserve (Andriantompohavana et al. 2006, Hasiniaina et al. 2018). New surveys found evidence of this species in the riparian forest neighbouring Ambakirano, along the Mahavavy River, therefore widening its known distribution 29% to the east (Sgarlata et al. 2019).
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. It occurs in the Lokobe Strict Nature Reserve. Unfortunately, although the infrastructure of this reserve is good, it is small. Four individuals of this species are based in the Tsimbazaza Zoo in Antananarivo (E.E. Louis Jr. pers. obs. 2010). The species also found in forest fragments under no formal protection.

rationale: Given the continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to fragmentation throughout its range, this species is suspected to be in decline. Additionally, there have been anecdotal reports of Cheirogaleus crossleyi being kept in zoos or as illegal pets. This species has been reported to be hunted, with a rate of ~0.3 individuals per year/per household in places like Betampona (Borgerson et al. in review). Based on these premises (decline in habitat and observed exploitation) and using the precautionary principle, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: An inhabitant of rainforest on plateau margins, from sea level to 1,800 m, the species is abundant on plantations and in areas of degraded forest. Cheirogaleus crossleyi at Tsinjoarivo and Ambatovy use a number of different sleeping sites during the active period, including nest-like structures and tree holes, where all nests were located high up in trees. During hibernation periods, dwarf lemurs hibernate underground, though C. crossleyi can be found experiencing torpor behaviour while occupying nests in forests like Ambatovy (Blanco et al. 2018). This species is nocturnal and arboreal. Hibernation periods vary and are site-dependent, but usually extend 4-6 months between April to September. Although there are no studies of the behaviour and ecology of this species published under the name C. crossleyi, studies conducted on what was formerly referred to as C. major in Andasibe (= Périnet) would in fact be this species.
threats: Habitat loss and degradation is an assumed threat across the range. There is additional evidence of hunting in several rainforest sites, including Betampona (Borgerson et al., in review, Brook et al. in press), and anecdotal evidence at Tsinjoarivo (Blanco pers. obs.).
population:
Cheirogaleus crossleyi densities are 13.48 individuals/km2 for a total estimated population size of 4,448 individuals inside Ranomafana National Park, but this species assignation has been recently disputed (McLain et al. 2017). These data are from over 100 transects within the National Park from 2003-2009 (Wright et al. 2012), and a minimum of 30-40 individuals occur in Tsinjoarivo. More recent estimates from Marojejy NW, suggest densities between ~20 and 60 individuals/km2 (Tsilanizara 2019), and between ~20-90 individuals/km2 in Anjiabe Forest, COMATSA (Solofoniaina 2018). It is suspected that the species is is undergoing a population decline of at least 30% (over a 24-year or three-generation period) due to a continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to fragmentation throughout its range. For context, Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).

Additionally, there have been anecdotal reports of C. crossleyi being kept in zoos or as pets. This species has been reported to be hunted, with a rate of ~0.3 individuals per year/per household in places like Betampona (Borgerson et al., in review).
range:
This species is found in northern and eastern Madagascar. The range of this species remains to be fully determined. Known localities in northern Madagascar include Marojejy National Park, COMATSA, Makirovana-Tsihomanaomby complex; in central-eastern Madagascar, the high-altitude forest fragment at Ankafobe, Ambohitantely, the mid-high rainforests at Tsinjoarivo (Andasivodihazo and Vatateza sites) Mantadia/Andasibe, Ambatovy, Anjozorobe and Ankazomivady; south-eastern Madagascar including Ranomafana National park (though it is unclear whether there are multiple species at this site, see McLain et al. 2017, Groeneveld et al. 2009, 2010, Williams et al. 2019).

More generally, and despite its ability to persist in degraded areas, this species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is evidence of hunting in several rainforest sites, including Betampona (Borgerson et al., in review, Brook et al. in press), and anecdotal evidence at Tsinjoarivo (Blanco pers. obs.).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. Crossley's Dwarf Lemur is believed to be present in four national parks (Marojejy National Park, Mantadia, Ranomafana and Zahamena), in the Zahamena Strict Nature Reserve, in the Analamazaotra Special Reserve (Mittermeier et al. 2008), Ambohitantely Reserve, and Ankafobe forest (managed by Missouri Botanical Garden). Additional sites within protected areas include Makirovana-Tsihomanaomby complex (managed by Missouri Botanical Garden) and the COMATSA corridor (managed by WWF) in northern Madagascar (Williams et al. 2019). Taxonomic work is required to elucidate more clearly the taxonomic and geographic limits of the species. As of late 2018 there were two individuals housed at Tsimbazaza Zoo in Antananarivo, Madagascar (Blanco pers. obs.).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 2,200 km<sup>2</sup>. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. As a result, population declines above 50% are suspected to have occurred in the past and to continue occurring in the future. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of dry deciduous forest. Limited information is known about this species in the field, including its distribution, population number and densities.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from unsustainable agricultural practices.
population: Habitat loss continues to be the primary threat to biodiversity in western Madagascar with the remaining forest habitat being cleared for agricultural shifts to commercial crops such as peanuts. Population numbers, densities and habitat occupancy need to be established for this species. Nevertheless, population declines above 50% are suspected to have occurred in the past and to continue occurring in the future due to a decline in the species' extent of occurrence (EOO) and continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat.
range:
This species is found in central-western Madagascar. It is currently known from the type locality, Andramasay, two larger forest fragments north and east of this, as well as the Tsingy de Bemaraha National Park and adjacent Strict Nature Reserve. Randrianasolo's Sportive Lemur’s distribution includes the entire area between the Tsiribihina River in the south to the Manambolo River in the north (Andriaholinirina et al. 2006, Louis et al. 2006); however, more research is needed to confirm these proposed limits regarding Lepilemur ruficaudatus to the south and L. ahmansonorum to the north. Research should also define its western distribution. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as less than 2,200 km2 with the elevation from 47 – 139 metres above sea level (avg. 91 metres). 

It has been estimated that there will be a 87% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is no information on this species being used as bushmeat or being in the commercial trade (sportive lemurs do not survive in captivity).
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. This species is known to occur in two adjacent protected areas, the Tsingy de Bemaraha National Park and Strict Nature Reserve. There is an urgent need for this species’ distribution to be defined, along with population numbers and densities.

rationale: This species has a suspected Extent of Occurrence (EOO) of 2,532 km2. In addition it is suspected that there is severe fragmentation and continuing decline in extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, and area, extent, and quality of habitat. It is suspected that there is population decline of at least 40% over three generations (based on the decline of EOO). Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of rainforest regions in the south-east and it has been recently studied in the lowland rainforest of Ampasy, Tsitongambarika Protected Area (Campera 2018). This lemur is largely folivorous with the rest of the diet (35 %) including fruits and flowers (Campera 2018). The most important plant species included in the diet are Albizia spp., Brochoneura acuminata, Cynometra spp., Humbertia madagascariensis, Syzigium spp. and Uapaca thouarsii. The annual home range ranges between 2.59-5.28 ha in females and 7.85-7.89 ha in males. The Fleurete's Sportive Lemur is strictly nocturnal (Campera et al. 2019b) and solitary living with a suspected polygynous dispersed social system (Campera 2018).
threats: The Fleurete's Sportive Lemur is mainly threatened by significant habitat loss and degradation within its range. This species is also exposed to hunting in degraded areas considering that it does not show a flight response towards humans (Campera et al. 2017, Campera 2018). Drug production, mostly marijuana, has also been occurring within the species range (E. Louis pers. comm.).
population: Populations are highly restricted and in decline due to habitat loss. Densities are 7.4 ind/km2 in the Andohahela National Park (Feistner and Schmid, 1999) and 81.0 ind/km2 in the Ampasy valley, a relatively undisturbed lowland rainforest in the northern section of the Tsitongambarika Protected Area (Campera et al. 2019a).
range: This species is found in the humid forest of the south-eastern corner of Madagascar. Currently it is known to occur in the Manangotry region, specifically the rainforest (Parcel I) of Andohahela National Park (Louis et al. 2006). It is also known to occurr in the Tsitongambarika Protected Area. The species is not present in the contiguous littoral forests and was not found at Beampingaratsy Protected Area (ETC Terra 2018), which is north of Andohahela Parcel I. Further work is needed to confirm the limits of the range. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 2,532 km2.
useTrade: It is suspected that this species is exposed to hunting in degraded areas as it does not show a flight response towards humans (Campera et al. 2017, Campera 2018).
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. Present in the Andohahela National Park (Louis et al. 2006) and in the Tsitongambarika Protected Area (Campera et al. 2017). Further work is needed to clarify the northern distribution of this recently described species of Lepilemur. It is not being kept in captivity (C. Schwitzer pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: The taxon is suspected to be in decline due to continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. Eulemur rufifrons is suspected to have undergone a reduction of at least 30% over the past 24 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of 8 years). Recent data from line-transect surveys and monitoring programmes indicate population declines in eastern Madagascar in excess of these estimates: declines of 60% from 2009-2011 at Andringitra National Park (Rajaonson et al. 2014) and 30-68% from 2014-2019 at Kianjavato (S. Johnson, S. Holmes, P. Narváez-Torres, and E. Louis, unpubl. data). Due to suspected future increases in fragmentation, hunting and population decline, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: This species is present in moist lowland and montane forest in the east, and dry tropical forest in the west. It has been studied in western Madagascar in the deciduous forests of Antserananomby and Tongobato, in the Kirindy Forest, and in eastern Madagascar in Ranomafana National Park and Kianjavato (see Mittermeier et al. 2008, and references therein; Holmes et al. 2019). Based on these studies, the species has a very adaptable behavioural ecology. The species is also noted to move territory. Group size varies from four to 17 (with an average size of nine) in the west and from six to 18 (with an average size of eight) in the east. In the west, population density is reported to be very high and home ranges small; in the east, population densities tend to be lower and home ranges as large as 100 ha. Reproduction is seasonal. In western populations, one male typically monopolizes the females of the group, while in the east several males may participate in reproductive pairings. In the west, mating takes place in June, births occur in September and October, and the young are weaned by January.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss due to slash-and-burn agriculture, burning to clear pastureland, fuelwood gathering, and illegal logging. Fire and charcoal production are major threats in areas such as Kirindy Mitea National Park. Hunting and trapping are also threats throughout its range, and in fact this is one of the most commonly hunted lemurs in all of Madagascar. The species is occasionally kept as a pet in Madagascar (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
population:
Population numbers are suspected to be in decline due to continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. In particular, this species is shown to be negatively impacted by habitat fragmentation (Eppley et al. 2020). Eulemur rufifrons is suspected to have undergone a reduction of at least 30% over the past 24 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of 8 years). Recent data from line-transect surveys and monitoring programs indicate population declines in eastern Madagascar in excess of these estimates: declines of 60% from 2009-2011 at Andringitra National Park (Rajaonson et al. 2014) and 30-68% from 2014-2019 at Kianjavato (S. Johnson, S. Holmes, P. Narváez-Torres, and E. Louis, unpubl. data). 

Eulemur rufifrons has an estimated density of 6.75 individuals/km2 with a total estimated population of 2,228 within Ranomafana National Park (Wright et al. 2012). There is conflicting evidence for whether this species is found in higher abundances in more or less disturbed areas of the park (Herrera et al., 2011, de Winter et al. 2018). At Andringitra National Park, population numbers are lower (1.95-4.90 individuals/km2; Rajaonson et al. 2014). The total population size of E. rufifrons in eastern Madagascar was estimated to be 14,734-21,527 individuals in 2014 (Herrera et al.  2018), a marked reduction from 89,367-106,817 estimated in 2000 by Irwin et al. (2005); this discrepancy is likely due to a genuine decline, as well as a more refined species distribution model in Herrera et al. (2018). In the west, Sussman (1974) documented densities of 1,120 individuals/km2 at Antseranomby, but recent estimates have declined considerably to about 23.9/km2 (Kelley et al. 2007). In Kirindy Mitea, numbers are suspected to be 20-30 individuals/km2 (R. Lewis pers. comm.).
range: The Red-fronted Brown Lemur is found both in western and eastern Madagascar. In the west, it is known from the Tsiribihina River south at least to the Fiherenana River near Toliara. The limits of its distribution in eastern Madagascar are not as well defined, but it appears to occur from the Onive and Mangoro Rivers south to the Andringitra Massif, the southern limit of its range probably being the Manampatra River, which separates this species from Eulemur cinereiceps. South-east of the Andringitra Massif, there is an up to 70-km wide hybrid zone between E. rufifrons and E. cinereiceps at the Iantara River (headwaters of the Manampatrana) (Delmore et al. 2013). A small introduced population of Red-fronted Brown Lemurs (hybridized with E. collaris) also inhabits the Berenty Private Reserve in southern Madagascar. Ranges from sea level to 1,670 m. This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted for food. Snares have been found in Ranomafana and Menabe. The species is occasionally kept as a pet in Madagascar (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It is known to occur in a number of protected areas (Rylands et al. 2018). There is an additional introduced population of Eulemur collaris / E. rufifrons hybrids in the Berenty Private Reserve. The status of this species in captivity is difficult to determine, owing to taxonomic confusion with E. rufus. However, both E. rufus and E.rufifrons are found in a number of collections world-wide.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is currently under revision but it is calculated here as 3,596 km2 (but the occupied area is probably far smaller (Schuessler and Radespiel, unpubl. data)). This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of lowland and highland rainforest and sub-humid forest up to 1,760 m. This species has not been studied in the wild.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from shifting agricultural practices and locally by hunting.
population: At the 150 ha primary forest site of Antambato, the species occurs in densities of 2.2 individuals per hectare (Randrianambinina et al. 2010). Other abundance data are not yet available. Population numbers are suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss and degradation.
range:
Microcebus mittermeieri occurs in and around the Anjanaharibe-Sud Special Reserve (type locality at 1,056m, Louis et al., 2006), Marojejy National Park, COMATSA sud corridor in north-eastern Madagascar (Blanco pers. obs.) and in Antambato in central Madagascar (Randrianambinina et al. 2010). It also appears to be sympatric with M. macarthurii at Anjiahely near the Makira region, and it has recently been documented from a forest fragment north of the Mananara river (Schuessler and Radespiel pers. obs.). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) it is calculated here as 3,596 km2, but it could be smaller.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted locally.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. The only protected areas in which it is known to occur is the Anjanaharibe-Sud Special Reserve, Marojejy National Park and COMATSA sud (IUCN cat VI). It is known to be sympatric with Microcebus macarthurii in some of its range (Anjiahely). As of 2009, there were four individuals of this species in captivity, all in the Tsimbazaza Zoo in Antananarivo, Madagascar (Mittermeier et al. 2008, E.E. Louis Jr. pers. obs.).

rationale: A population reduction of ≥30% is predicted to occur over a three-generation time period (30 years) in the future, based on continuing and projected decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to ongoing and projected exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure. The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is 6,991 km² and extremely fragmented. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: Total length of 54.7- 66.6 cm and an average weight of 900g. Its dorsal fur is gray-brown, and ventral fur is white with a reddish-brown tail (Zaramody et al. 2006, Mittermeier et al. 2008). It is an inhabitant of primary humid lowland and montane rainforest, as well as secondary and disturbed forest formations. This species is nocturnal and arboreal. The diet consists mainly of mainly leaves (approximately 98%), along with some flowers and fruits (Faulkner and Lehman 2006). Young leaves of Harungana madagascariensis and Syzygium sp. made up 67.5% of their diet at Vato in Ranomafana (Faulkner and Lehman 2006). One study at Ranomafana showed that resting occupied 59.5% of nightly activity, feeding 22%, traveling 13.5%, and grooming 5%. Home range is estimated to be on average 1 ha (P. Wright pers. comm.).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation due to shifting agriculture, in addition to hunting.
population:
Population densities at Ranomafana tend to be higher in secondary forests and disturbed habitats (Lehman et al. 2006), though a more recent study found the opposite trend with encounter rates positively related to canopy height (Herrera et al. 2011).

Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss and degradation. A population reduction of ≥30% is predicted to occur over a three-generation time period (30 years) in the future, based on continuing and projected decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to ongoing and projected exploitation through unsustainable hunting pressure.
range:
This species occurs in south-eastern Madagascar. The precise limits of the distribution of this species, and in particular its relationship to Avahi meridionalis and A. ramanantsoavanai in the south, are as yet undetermined. It is currently known from south of the Mangoro / Nesivolo river systems in the forests of Manara, Vatoalatsaka, Sangalampona, Mahasoarivo and Ranomafana. The southern extent of the range remains unclear (Zaramody et al. 2006, Mittermeier et al. 2008).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is sometimes hunted for food; however, its bitter taste is not widely appreciated.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. Based on the description of Zaramody et al. (2006), this species is presumably present in three national parks including Ranomofana National Park, Andringitra, and Midongy du Sud. It is not being kept in captivity (C. Schwitzer pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers approximately 874 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. The number of mature individuals is also suspected to be in decline. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: Lepilemur wrightae is an inhabitant of mid-altitude rainforest. Currently, it is only known to occur in Kalambatritra Special Reserve and Beakora Forest. This species is primarily nocturnal and folivorous (Rowe and Meyers 2016). Like other species within the Lepilemur genus, holes in large trees serve as sleeping sites for L. wrightae (Rowe and Meyers 2016). Groups of 1-3 individuals (2 adults, 1 juvenile) have been seen foraging together. This species is known to defecate in communal areas known as latrines (Irwin et al. 2004).
threats: The entirety of this species’ known distribution is classified a “red zone” due to illegal activities, including Marijuana cultivation and cattle rustling (Rowe and Meyers 2016). Wild grassfires lit by humans are a threat. Beakora Forest is currently unprotected.
population: Population numbers are thought to be in decline due to habitat loss. There are an estimated 72 individuals per km2 (Rakotonirina et al. 2017).
range: This species is currently known from Kalambatritra Special Reserve in south-eastern Madagascar, west of the Mananara River and north of the Mandrare River (Louis et al. 2006), as well as the unprotected Beakora Forest (Irwin et al. 2001, Rakotonirina et al. 2017). Further studies need to be conducted to determine the precise limits of its distribution, especially relative to Lepilemur leucopus and L. fleuretae. The extent of occurrence (EOO) estimated at 874 km2.
useTrade: Little is known about whether this species is hunted.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. It is known to occur in Kalambatritra Special Reserve and the unprotected Beakora Forest (Irwin et al. 2001, Louis et al. 2006, Rakotonirina et al. 2017). Further work is now urgently needed to clarify the distribution and taxonomic limits of this Lepilemur species. Beakora Forest south of Kalambatritra Special Reserve should be protected, although densities in Beakora are lower than Kalambatritra. Because this region is considered a “red zone” security should be improved for the protection of this area.

rationale: The extent of occurrence of this species covers less than 500 km². This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. As a result, it is suspected that there has been a population reduction of 80% in the past, and that it will increase to between 80% and <90% in the future. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: Avahi cleesei occurs in sub-humid, dry deciduous forests close to the western Tsingy precipices, in the larger Tsingy crevasses or gorges, and forests along small seasonal rivulets and seasonal swamps close to the Bemaraha massif (Thalmann and Geissmann 2006). Avahi cleesei's total length ranges from 55.2 to 67.5 cm. Its average weight ranges from 750 to 1,300 g (Thanlmann and Geissmann 2005, Zaramody et al. 2006, Lei et al. 2008). Its woolly dorsal fur is brown-gray, and its thin ventral fur is light gray whilst the fur on the tail varies between individuals. White patches on the dorsal surface of the hindlimb is unique to this species.
threats: This species is primarily threatened by continued habitat loss. Thalmann and Geissmann (2005, 2006) noted that the disturbed forest close to the village of Ankinajao (outside the park), which supported a substantial number of individuals in 1994, had been cut completely by 2003. Continued loss of habitat within the borders of Tsingy de Bemaraha between 2002 and 2007 was noted near the village of Ambalarano (E. Louis, Unpubl.). The sub-humid forest at the base of the escarpment of the Tsingy de Bemaraha is under continuous pressure from bush fires that reduce it in many places every year. Such sub-humid forests are the only habitat in which Avahi cleesei is known to occur so far.
population:
Thalmann and Geissmann (2000) describe Avahi as being generally rare in the Bemaraha region, where the forests it inhabits tend to have a high proportion of evergreen trees (secondary forest growth). Ironically, local population densities appear to correlate negatively with levels of habitat disturbance, meaning that higher population densities seem to be found in disturbed habitats.

The extent of occurrence of this species covers less than 500 km². This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. As a result, it is suspected that there has been a population reduction of 80% in the past, and that it will increase to between 80% and <90% in the future.
range:
This species is known only from the Tsingy de Bemaraha region of western Madagascar, north of the Manambolo River (Thalmann and Geissman 2005). Currently, Avahi cleesei is known only from within Tsingy de Bemaraha National Park, where it has been sighted in two localities, in the forest of Ankindrodro (19°08′S, 44°49′E;) and the type locality (18°59′S, 44°45′E), a forest 3–4 km east-northeast of the village of Ambalarano at the base of the western Tsingy precipice (Thalmann and Geissmann 2006). The forest near where Avahi species was previously outside the reserve’s boundaries in 1994, is in the heavily disturbed forest in the surroundings of the village of Ankinajao (19°03′S, 44°47′E; Thalmann and Geissmann 2000). However, the forest was destroyed, and no woolly lemurs have been found there since 2003 (Thalmann and Geissmann 2006). The forest of Ambalarano has also seen a significant decline as documented from expeditions there between 2002 and 2007 (E. Louis, Unpubl.). The northern limit of its range is unclear; however, there has been no evidence offered of its occurrence between the Sambao and Betsiboka Rivers (Thalmann and Geissmann 2005). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is less than 500 km² at an elevation 27 – 82 metres above sea level (avg. 36 metres).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is no trade or general use of this species. It is quite rare with habitat loss being the most significant threat for this species.
conservationActions: Avahi cleesei is listed on CITES Appendix I. The only protected area in which it is known to occur is Tsingy de Bemaraha National Park and Strict Nature Reserve. Given the extremely small known range of Cleese’s Woolly Lemur, surveys that were recommended in 2012 are still urgently needed to identify additional populations and/or individuals. As with all Avahi species, it is not kept in captivity long-term successfully.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers 2,954 km². This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. The number of mature individuals is also thought to be in decline. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of the lowland rainforest and wet littoral forest. This species is mainly nocturnal but has its peaks of activity at twilight and exhibits sporadic diurnal activity in certain environmental conditions (Balestri 2018). This species has been studied in the Ste Luce Conservation Area and in the lowland humid forest of Ampasy in the northernmost portion of the Tsitongambarika Protected Area. Home range size varies from 2.5 to 3.5 ha at Sainte Luce (Norscia and Borgognini-Tarli 2008) and from 4.59 to 10.39 ha at Ampasy (Balestri 2018). This species is pair-living and has a strictly folivorous diet with a total of 43 plant species used over a 7 month period at Sainte Luce. The diet breadth was only slightly broader in Ampasy with 48 plants species used over a 10 month period (Balestri 2018). Young leaves are preferred over mature leaves and the species seems to tolerate tannins well. One of the main predictors of the species abundance in littoral forest fragments is tree size (Norscia et al. 2012).
threats: This species is mainly threatened by habitat loss and degradation from ongoing shifting agricultural practices and logging of precious wood. Opportunistic hunting is an additional minor threat for the species (Campera et al. 2017).
population: Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss and hunting (Bollen and Donati 2006). Densities in littoral forest fragments are relatively high ranging from 55 to 240 individuals/km² (Norscia 2008). In inland rainforest areas densities seem to be at the lower range of the previous figures. A density of 16.7 individuals/km2 has been reported in the wet portion of the Andohahela National Park (Feistner and Schmid 1999), while 32.0 individuals/km2 have been recently observed in the Northern part of the Tsitongambarika Protected Area (Balestri 2018). Densities between 24 and 95 individuals/km² have been recorded in the southern part of Tsitongambarika (Norscia et al. 2006, Asity Madagascar pers. comm.).
range:
This species occurs in the wet forests of south-eastern Madagascar. The southernmost  limit of the species seems to be the transitional littoral forest of Petriky, south of Tolagnaro, (G. Donati pers. obs.), north to Parcel 1 of Andohahela National Park, the Tsitongambarika Protected Area and the littoral forest fragments of Sainte-Luce Conservation Area and Mandena Conservation Area (Zaramody et al. 2006). Further studies are required to determine the exact northern distribution, and especially its limits in relation to neighbouring species (Avahi peyrierasi and A. ramanantsoavanai). A recent study suggests the possible presence of the species at the Beampingaratsy Protected Area (Ligue Pour la Protection de la Nature pers. comm.; ETCTerra, 2018). The EOO is estimated to be around 2,954 km².

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Opportunistic hunting is a threat for the species (Campera et al. 2017).
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. This species is known to occur in Andohahela National Park (Parcel 1), the Tsitongambarika Protected Area, the Sainte-Luce Private Reserve, and in the Mandena Conservation Zone, east of Tolagnaro (Fort-Dauphin). Further studies are required to determine the exact northern distribution range of this species. This species is not being kept in captivity (C. Schwitzer pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be less than 1,195 km2. This species geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. As such, a population reduction is thought to have occurred, be ongoing, and to occur in the future. Based on these criteria, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of dry deciduous forest. As with the genus Lepilemur, this species is presumably largely folivorous.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation of its habitat due to shifting agriculture.
population: Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss. It is suspected that a 50% reduction in the population has occurred in the past three generations (21 years) due to habitat degradation. Given that the threats facing the species have not abated, it is suspected that the rate of population decline will continue into the future as well.
range: This species is found between the Betsiboka and Mahavavy du Sud Rivers in western Madagascar. The southern extent of the range across the Mahavavy du Sud River is yet to be clarified (Andriaholinirina et al. 2006). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 1,195 km2. Lepilemur aeeclis is found from 12-63 metres above sea level (avg. 52.5 metres). This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is no use or trade for this species that is known, except possibly as an occasional food source.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. It is not known from any protected areas except at Antrema which offer some degree of protection; it is found in the Anjahamana and Antrema Classified Forests. Further work is now needed to clarify the distribution and taxonomic limits of the recently described Lepilemur species, especially in relationship to unknown holotype localities of Lepilemur dorsalis and Lepilemur grandidieri. There is an urgent need for field assessments of population numbers and basic biology of this species.

rationale: There is a suspected population reduction of ≥30% in this species over a three generation period. Causes of this reduction (which have not ceased) include continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, and exploitation through hunting. Between 1999-2005 habitat loss in the Tsitongambarika Protected Area has been 1.74% per year (Andriamasimanana 2008). A population reduction of ≥30% is also suspected to be met in the next 27 years (over a three generation time period) due to the same causes. These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. Of note, it has been estimated that there will be a 21% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015). Based on these premises, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat:
This species is an inhabitant of subtropical moist lowland and montane forest (up to 1,600 m). The species exhibits a cathemeral activity pattern and lives in small social groups ranging from 2 to 9 individuals, sometimes with one or two breeding adult females and one or two adult males (Eppley et al. 2015b, 2016b, 2017c, 2017d). Home range sizes are variable, ranging from 6.60 – 18.39 ha (Eppley et al. 2016b). At Kalambatritra Special Reserve and Mandena Conservation Area, individuals exhibit latrine behaviour (repeated group defecation at specific sites); groups defecate in turn, with adults going first followed by juveniles. It is thought that this likely serves some communicatory function, possibly for demarcating territory and mate-guarding (Eppley et al. 2016b).

Similar to other bamboo lemur species, Hapalemur meridionalis is classified as a folivore (Eppley et al. 2011, 2016a). In Mandena, groups have been observed to spend significant amounts of time on the ground, foraging terrestrially on various grass (Poaceae) and reed (Cyperaceae) species within the littoral forest, in open-canopy areas, and within marsh / swamp areas (Eppley et al. 2011, 2016a). These flooded forest and marsh habitats appear to be important for the individuals populating the littoral coastal forest (Eppley et al. 2015a), with groups even observed in the reed marshes along the estuaries by Evahtra. Within the littoral forest, this species has been recorded to feed on 72 different species from 37 plant families (Eppley et al. 2016a). Though the majority of their diet is composed of terrestrial grasses, piths, and liana stems/leaves, they also consumed 34 different fruit species (Eppley et al. 2011, 2016a). This species often selects for resting sites with large diameter at breast height (DBH) within the degraded littoral forest (Eppley et al. 2017b). Brief observations from more continuous humid forests (e.g., Andohahela National Park, Tsitongambarika Protected Area) have noted this species feeding on various woody and liana bamboo species (Feistner and Schmid 1999; T. Eppley pers. comm.).
threats: The principal threat is habitat loss due to slash and burn agriculture, illegal timber extraction, charcoal production, and large-scale mining. Hunting is also a threat, with locals targeting this species as it appears to crop-raid often in agricultural areas (Campera et al. 2019; Eppley pers. comm.). This species is occasionally kept as a pet (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
population:
The population size of this species is not known, but population is suspected to be undergoing decline. There is a suspected population reduction of ≥30% in this species over a three generation period. Causes of this reduction (which have not ceased) include continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, and exploitation through hunting. Between 1999-2005 habitat loss in the Tsitongambarika Protected Area has been 1.74% per year (Andriamasimanana, 2008). In addition, this species is shown to be negatively impacted by habitat fragmentation (Eppley et al. 2020). A population reduction of ≥30% is also suspected to be met in the next 24 years (over a three generation time period) due to the same causes. These causes have not ceased, and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. Of note, it has been estimated that there will be a 21% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).

Surveys in Andohahela National Park reported an encounter rate of 0.27 individuals/km (Feistner and Schmid 1999), while in the Tsitongambarika Protected Area reported encounter rates were 0.52 ind./km at Ivohibe, 0.23 ind./km at Antsiriky, and 1.10 ind./km at Ivorona (Birdlife International 2011). More robust surveys in the Ampasy valley, a relatively undisturbed lowland rainforest in the northern section of the Tsitongambarika Protected Area, indicate densities of 18±5 (10-33) individuals per km2 (Campera et al. 2019). The number of mature individuals is suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss and hunting (Mittermeier et al. 2010, Campera et al. 2019).
range:
This species is found in south-eastern Madagascar. The southernmost of the Bamboo Lemurs, the type locality is the forestry station of Mandena, located approximately 10 km north of Tolagnaro in coastal south-eastern Madagascar (Warter et al. 1987, Warter and Tattersall 1994). The precise range is unclear, but it is known from the forests of Mandena Conservation Area, Tsitongambarika Protected Area, Andohahela National Park (Parcel 1), and Ambatosirongorongo/Malahelo in the extreme south, while also inhabiting the Midongy du Sud National Park, Manombo, Kalambatritra, Pic d' Ivohibe, Andringitra and Ranomafana further to the north (Feistner and Schmid 1999, Mittermeier et al. 2010, Birdlife International 2011, Eppley et al. 2011, Nguyen et al. 2013, Rakotonirina et al. 2017). Rabarivola et al. (2007) noted that an animal from Atsimo appeared to be a heterozygote between this species and Hapalemur griseus, and it is possible that this species extends as far north as Ranomafana National Park (E.E. Louis Jr. pers. comm.). In Andohahela animals were observed at 1,500 m, but were absent at higher elevations (Feistner and Schmid 1999). Upper elevation limit are unclear as animals from 1,600 m on the Andringitra Massif are either H. meridionalis or hybrids between H. griseus and H. meridionalis. 

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be approximately 33,967 km2. It has been estimated that there will be a 21% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted for food (Nguyen et al. 2013; Campera et al. 2019). Through village interviews, it was reported that 75.4% participants had eaten this species within the Tsitongambarika Protected Area (Campera et al. 2019). This species is occasionally kept as a pet (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. This species is known to occur in four national parks (Andohahela,  Andringitra, Midongy du Sud, and Ranomafana), three special reserves (Kalambatritra, Manombo and Pic d' Ivohibe), the Tsitongambarika Protected Area, and in the Mandena Conservation Zone, east of Tolagnaro (Feistner and Schmid 1999, Rabarivola et al. 2007, Mittermeier et al. 2010; E.E. Louis Jr. pers. comm.). There is a need for further survey work to determine the full distribution, population status, and ecology of this species. This species is threatened mainly by habitat loss due to the regular burning of forest to clear pasture for livestock and shifting agriculture, as well as illegal timber harvesting from protected areas. Hunting should also be considered a major threat as this species is known to crop-raid which puts them at further risk from humans attempting to protect their crops (Campera et al. 2019, Eppley pers. comm.). Southern bamboo lemurs are able to survive in degraded habitats and this species is presumably edge tolerant (Eppley et al. 2015a,  2017a). It has been observed to utilize the invasive paper-bark tea tree (Melaleuca quinquenervia) within the littoral forest area of southeast Madagascar. It is not being kept in captivity (C. Schwitzer pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: The extent of occurrence of this species covers approximately 14,376 km². This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. The number of mature individuals is also thought to be in decline. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of the primary eastern humid rainforests. It is nocturnal and arboreal. This species has not been systematically studied in the wild.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation.
population: Population numbers are thought to be in decline due to habitat loss and degradation from shifting agriculture, timber harvesting, and frequent cyclones. In Manombo, very few infants and/or juveniles have been recorded over the past few years (GERP, unpublished report).
range:
This species occurs in south-east coastal Madagascar. Currently it is known only from the area of its type locality, the Manombo Special Reserve and Agnalahaza Forest (Zaramody et al. 2006; Andriantompohavana et al. 2007). Further studies are required to determine its exact distribution, and especially the limits with regard to neighbouring species (Avahi peyrierasi and A. meridionalis) (Mittermeier et al. 2008). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 14,376 km2.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. The only protected areas in which it occurs are the Manombo Special Reserve and the nearby Agnalazaha Forest (Zaramody et al. 2006; Andriantompohavana et al. 2007), which is now being managed by the Missouri Botanical Garden (Rylands et al. 2018 notes it is found in: Reserve Speciale de Manombo, Agnalazaha, Reserve de Ressources Naturelles d'Agnakatrika, and Reserve de Ressources Naturelles d'Ankarabolava). Further work is urgently needed to confirm the distribution, population status, ecology, and threats to this species. It is not being kept in captivity (C. Schwitzer pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 190 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and is undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. The species is also frequently hunted. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: Microcebus jollyae is an inhabitant of the south-eastern lower altitudinal, coastal rainforest. This landscape consists of fragmented forests varying in size and disturbance levels. This little-studied nocturnal lemur weighs just over 60 grams (Louis et al. 2006). Individuals have overlapping home ranges. Preliminary findings indicate they consume fruits from both native and exotic species in Kianjavato (N. Guthrie pers. comm.).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and hunting.
population: The population of Microcebus jollyae is presumably in decline due to habitat destruction and hunting.
range: Microcebus jollyae is found in south-eastern Madagascar, its range extending from just south of the Mananara River north to the north bank of the Mananjary River. According to Louis et al. (2006), populations of this species are reported to occur in the forests of Mananjary and Kianjavato. The type locality is at 71 m above sea level. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is less than 190 km2.
useTrade: Microcebus jollyae is hunted opportunistically and households in the Kianjavato region eat an average of 0.25 Microcebus jollyae per year (Borgerson et al. 2018).
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. This species occurs in the COFAV protected area (IUCN Category VI) and may be found in the Manombo Special Reserve. Kianjavato Ahmanson Field Station (KAFS; operated by the Madagascar Biodiversity Partnership) and the Conservation Credit Program (which includes the Education Promoting Reforestation Project; Manjaribe et al. 2013) are working in the region to support research, forest conservation, and local livelihoods.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 70 km2. This geographic range is undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. The number of mature individuals is also known to be in decline (though the number of births are increasing). Based on these premises, the species continues to be listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of moist lowland rainforest.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from shifting agricultural practices, as well as unsustainable levels of hunting.
population: Population densities in Manombo Special Reserve are 45 individuals/km2, and 23 individuals/km2 in Manombo Classified Forest. There is an approximate total known population size of 1,386 individuals (Ingraldi 2010). Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss.
range: This species currently is known from the Manombo Special Reserve region in south-eastern Madagascar. The precise northern and southern limits of the range are unknown, but it could range south of the Manampatrana River and north of the Mananara River (Louis et al. 2006). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is less than 70 km2.
useTrade: This species is hunted.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. Present in the Manombo Special Reserve (Louis et al. 2006). An ongoing research and conservation action are now active in the study sites to scale up the status of the Lepilemur jamesorum.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 1,100 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species inhabits dense primary forest fragments in mountainous areas.
threats: This species is threatened by deforestation in its already restricted distribution due to unsustainable farming practices, logging and hunting.
population: Almost all sampled populations of Microcebus bongolavensis show genetic evidence for a relatively rapid crash in population size. This crash is likely to have occurred within the last 500 years, thus coinciding with accelerated deforestation due to human population expansion in Madagascar (Olivieri et al. 2008). Present day populations are also suspected to be in decline due to declines in habitat quality and extent of occurrence.
range:
This species is known only from three small forest fragments in the area around Port-Bergé, between the rivers Mahajamba and Sofia in north-western Madagascar (Olivieri et al. 2007). Prior to recent taxonomic revisions, the mouse lemurs in this region were assumed to be Microcebus ravelobensis. It may also be present in the Bongolava Classified Forest. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is less than 1,100 km2.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forests (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted.
conservationActions: It is listed on CITES Appendix I. The species is found in the Ambodimahabibo Classified Forest, and may be present in the Bongolava Classified Forest as well. Consideration should be given to establishing a protected area that includes the latter, it being the only relatively large forest fragment left within the known range. Further surveys are needed to determine the full extent of its range and population status, and to confirm the taxonomic distinctiveness of this taxon. This species is not being kept in captivity (I.J. Porton pers. comm. 2010).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers 2,614 km<sup>2</sup>. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Although population totals and density estimations now available since the last assessment in 2012 are considered high compared to other sportive lemurs, there are discrepancies between the surveyed site densities that cannot be explained by purely environmental reasons; therefore, hunting could potentially be considered as a reason for these differences. A future reduction of >50% is suspected due to ongoing threats. Based on these premises, the species continued to be listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species inhabits primary and secondary tropical moist, gallery and dry deciduous lowland forest. It is presumably largely folivorous. As with all sportive lemurs, reproducing their diet in captivity is currently impossible; thus, no sportive lemurs have survived a permanent captive scenario.
threats: Habitat loss and hunting are the immediate threats to the sportive lemurs in the Daraina region, especially linked to the illicit mining for gold. Furthermore, the effects of mining activities on the forest should be evaluated and its effect of diurnal and nocturnal lemur species.
population:
Population declines are suspected, with a suspected 30% rate of decline in the past increasing to at least 50% population declines in the next three generations. These declines are suspected due to continued hunting and habitat loss, as well as illicit mining and deforestation activities in region.

In Salmona et al. (2014), the authors presented 2011 dry season survey data for the ten main forest fragments of the Loky-Manambato region, estimating Lepilemur milanoii densities and population sizes. Although the results suggest reasonably high sportive lemur densities in the region, there also revealed important discrepancies between forest fragments with densities ranging from 49.8 ind./km² in Antsaharaingy to 590.5 ind./km² in Ampondrabe. For the region Loky-Manambato, the authors estimated a population size of ~52,000 individuals, but this estimate does not include the forest cover populations between the Loky River and Andrafiamena, an area that has been reported to host both Ankarana and Milanoii sportive lemurs (Louis et al. 2006).
range:
This species is found in northern Madagascar, known primarily from the Daraina region, south of the Loky River. There is an additional population occurring in the Andrafiamena Forest, living sympatrically with Lepilemur ankaranensis in this now protected forest. Field studies are needed to determine how these two species share the same forest as this population is the only area where two Lepilemur species evidently occur in sympatry (Louis et al. 2006). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,614km2 at elevations 18 – 378 metres above sea level (avg. 167 metres).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: As sportive lemurs have been documented to remain part of the bushmeat frequently eaten by locals in other regions (Jenkins et al. 2011), Daraina and the Loky-Manambato region is no exception to this situation. Hunting in the region has been documented with not only crowned lemurs, but also with the sportive lemurs (i.e. in Solaniampilana; Salmona et al. 2014). The continued illicit gold mining efforts in the Daraina region should be considered linked to any potential hunting pressure. Therefore, as with the documented hunting of crowned lemurs for the restaurants in Sambava, hunting in this region should be taken seriously, particularly in areas with gold and rock mining activities.
conservationActions:
Listed on CITES Appendix I and is found within two protected areas.

This species is known to occur in the Loky-Manambato Protected Area (Daraina), as well as in the Andrafiamena (Anjahakely) Protected Area, which is slated to become a national park. Further work is now urgently needed to clarify the distribution and taxonomic limits of the recently described Lepilemur species, it would be important to determine whether the differences in Lepilemur densities observed in Daraina are due to the historical poaching since no simple environmental correlate could be linked to these discrepancies. It would be important to repeat these surveys in this region and extend it over other neighbouring regions. Furthermore, studies should be conducted on the sympatric L. milanoii and L. ankaranensis population to determine the extent of this dual existence within the forest habitat between the Loky River to Andrafiamena region.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers around 1,020 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Deforestation rate is increasingly high in the area: it has been evaluated at 2.27% per year between 2005-2010 and at 3.14% between 2010-2014. The number of mature individuals is also known to be in decline, with the development of the rare earth mining project (around 320 km2) and other factors (such as habitat degradation) leading to an expected reduction in population of ≥ 80% within the 21 next years (generation time is 7 years). Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: Lepilemur mittermeieri is an inhabitant of tropical dry deciduous primary and secondary forests. It is largely folivorous, feeding at least on 77 tree species but consume also fruits. Mean home range size is 2.01 ha (Kernel method) without significant difference between males and females. Home range overlap has been observed (even between males). Individuals have an average of 4.7 sleeping sites most of which are “tangle of branches”. L. mittermeieri may be found in edge areas of the forest.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss, fragmentation and degradation from unsustainable agricultural practices (slash-and-burn), illegal logging, charcoal production (a particular problem on the Ampasindava Peninsula), as well as mining (rare earth mining project) and hunting.
population: The population size is estimated at less than 10,000 individuals. Population numbers are suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss, forest degradation and fragmentation. The number of mature individuals is also known to be in decline, with the development of the rare earth mining project (around 320 km2) and other factors (such as habitat degradation) leading to an expected reduction in population of ≥ 80% within the 21 next years (generation time is 7 years).
range:
This species is known only from the Ampasindava Peninsula in north-western Madagascar. The precise limits of distribution are unclear, especially relative to Lepilemur sahamalazensis and L. dorsalis (Rabarivola et al. 2006). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 1,020 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. 

Deforestation rate is increasingly high in the area: it has been evaluated at 2.27% per year between 2005-2010 and at 3.14% between 2010-2014.
useTrade: This species may be affected by hunting.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. Currently known from the “Ampasindava protected area” which presents three core areas. Conservation action for Lepilemur mittermeieri should not aim only on core forested areas. It should also take into consideration all large fragmented forest patches and the connectivity between them. Surveys are required to evaluate if efficient corridors could be established between several forest patches. Population Viability Analysis and Minimum Viable Population analysis could help answering if some forest patches are large enough to maintain a viable population of the species. Further work is now urgently needed to clarify the distribution and taxonomic limits of the recently described Lepilemur species.

rationale: Given the impact of habitat loss within the range of this species, it is likely that Microcebus griseorufus is currently in decline. Despite this threat, the species is still thought to be relatively common within its range. Based on these premises, M. griseorufus is listed as Least Concern. Further information on hybridization, population status, habitat loss, and threats may warrant listing this species in a more threatened category in the future.
habitat: Microcebus griseorufus is found in spiny desert, dry thorn scrub, and gallery forest habitats (Rasoazanabary 2004). It is sympatric with M. murinus at Beza-Mahafaly and in the Mikea Forest, whereas in Berenty it is found in spiny forest patches but not in the immediately adjacent gallery forest that is occupied by the former species. It tolerates a wide range of habitats including coastal shrub (Steffens et al. 2017). This species feeds mainly on gums during the dry season, in arid habitats, and during periods of drought, but seems to bounce against the dry limits of its tolerance in the spiny bush (Bohr et al. 2011). In the wet season and in more humid forests it feeds on fruits and gums in equal proportions. Flowers and arthropods are also part of its diet, especially in arid habitats and in the dry season. Mating takes place during the rainy season (normally between September and November). Gestation in one wild female lasted 52 days. Females usually raise only one litter per year, consisting of only one or two offspring, although up to three young have been reported. Alloparenting has been observed. Young males disperse. Home range size varies from 0.33 ha in the dry season to 0.55 ha in the wet season (Génin 2008; Mittermeier et al. 2010 and references included therein).
threats: The most significant threats to this species include forest loss due to charcoal production and commercial maize production.
population:
This is a relatively common species. Hybridization between Microcebus griseorufus and M. murinus has been noted in south-eastern Madagascar in two ecologically different contact zones. One hybrid zone is located in the transitional zone between dry spiny bush and humid littoral forests south of the southern tip of the Anosy Mountain Range west and east of Ankilivalo (S 25.112 E 46.689) (Gligor et al. 2009). The second hybrid zone is located in the western rainshadow of the Anosy Mountain Range where there is a mosaic of dry spiny bush and gallery forests. Most hybrids in this area have been observed at Mangatsiaka (S 24.9660 E 46.5574) (Hapke et al. 2011).

Given the impact of habitat loss within the range of this species, it is likely that M. griseorufus is currently in decline. Despite this threat, the species is still thought to be relatively common within its range.
range: This species is found in southern and south-western Madagascar, where it ranges from Lamboharana south to the Toliara (= Tuléar) region, to the Beza-Mahafaly Special Reserve (south of the Onilahy River) in the south-east, and to Tsimanampetsotsa, Berenty, and Petriky in the extreme south (Mittermeier et al. 2010). The species occurs from sea level to 250 m.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It is known to occur in the Tsimanampetsotsa National Park, Beza Mahafaly Special Reserve, the Berenty Private Reserve, Mikea and Andohahela (Mittermeier et al. 2010; Rakotondranary et al. 2011). It may be present as well in two other national parks (Isalo and Zombitse-Vohibasia), but this has yet to be confirmed.

rationale:
This species is listed as Critically Endangered as it has been suspected to have undergone a population reduction of ≥80% over the past 21 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of seven years) due primarily to continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting (e.g., Seiler et al. 2010, 2012). This cause has not ceased and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. A future population reduction of ≥80% over a 21 year period is also suspected due to the same cause.

Furthermore, the area of occupancy of Lepilemur sahamalaza covers only between 12 and 472 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in extent of occurrence, area of occupancy and in quality of habitat of the remaining areas (Seiler et al. 2013a). The number of subpopulations and mature individuals is also suspected to be in decline.
habitat:
The Sahamalaza Peninsula is part of a transition zone between the Sambirano region in the north and the western dry deciduous forest region in the south. The species inhabits both primary and mature secondary forests. Irrespective of the differences in overall structure and habitat parameters of the forest fragments in Ankarafa, the microhabitat in sportive lemurs’ home ranges as well as around sleeping sites was similar in all measured habitat parameters, as were all measured parameters for the different sleeping trees (Seiler et al. 2013b, 2014). Sahamalaza Sportive Lemurs chose the locations of their home ranges on the basis of different habitat variables, with abundance of sleeping sites and feeding trees as well as tree density and canopy cover being the most important factors (Seiler et al. 2014). Tall trees with large crowns, a high density of small trees, and dense canopy were particularly important for sleeping site choice (Seiler et al. 2013b).

The Sahamalaza Sportive Lemur is a highly folivorous generalist herbivore and has been observed to feed on at least 42 different tree species, preferring the abundant species Clitoria lasciva, Mangifera indica, Garcinia pauciflora and Sorindeia madagascariensis and occasionally adding fruits of Ficus tiliaefolia, spiders, insects and insect larvae to its diet. It has prolonged periods of resting during its activity periods (Seiler et al. 2014). Home ranges covered an area of 1.4 ha (nightly ranges of 0.5 ha) and did not overlap between adult individuals (Seiler 2012). The very few sociopositive interactions between individuals took place between mother and kin. Although the small number of observed individuals makes it hard to finally conclude on the social organization of the Sahamalza Sportive Lemur, the low level of social interaction and cohesiveness suggest that the Sahamalaza Sportive Lemur has a very low degree of social complexity and is likely to be solitary (Seiler 2012).

During daylight hours the Sahamalaza Sportive Lemur rested alone (except mother-infant pairs) in tree holes or in tree tangles (Seiler et al. 2013b). Tree holes used as sleeping sites were usually found in Bridelia pervilleana, whilst tree tangle sleeping sites are mostly located in Sorindeia madagascariensis. Individuals resting in tree holes usually sat at the entrance rather than inside the hole, possibly to increase sun exposure. During diurnal observations, 5-14 % of the sportive lemurs’ behaviour was active, although the animals never leave their sleeping sites or feed. Comparing the proportion of active behaviour between individuals resting in tree holes and those in tree tangles, animals in tree holes to have significantly higher levels of activity (Seiler et al. 2013b).

Resting Lepilemur sahamalaza recognized predator vocalizations as indicators of increased predation risk, discerned vocalizations of different predators, and employed species-specific anti-predator behaviours (Seiler et al. 2013c). Furthermore, the studied Sahamalaza Sportive Lemurs were able to use information on predator presence and predator type in referential signals of different surrounding species, thereby taking advantage of the possibility of early predator detection through interspecific communication (Seiler et al. 2013d).
threats: Although some of the known distribution is within a protected area, forest clearing for agriculture, and timber-cutting for charcoal and construction continues at high rates, especially since the onset of the political crisis in Madagascar in 2009. The species is also subject to increasing levels of hunting (Seiler et al. 2012).
population:
Population declines are suspected. This species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of ≥80% over the past 21 years (three generations, assuming a generation length of seven years) due primarily to continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting (e.g., Seiler et al. 2010, 2012). This cause has not ceased and will to a large extent not be easily reversible. A future population reduction of ≥80% over a 21 year period is also suspected due to the same cause. The number of subpopulations and mature individuals are also suspected to be in decline. 

Olivieri et al. (2005) recorded an encounter rate of 4.17 individuals/km2 in the forest of Ankarafa. This high encounter rate could be due to recent loss of habitat, forcing all animals to concentrate in the few remaining forest fragments. Ruperti (2007) recorded a mean density of 280 individuals/km2 in Ankarafa. Most recent data on Lepilemur density (Seiler et al. 2013a) suggests densities ranging from only 7 to 23 individuals/km2 in the same area. The differences between density estimations are most likely due to different methods of data collection. Whereas Ruperti measured lemur density inside one-hectare plots (one for each fragment), Seiler et al. counted all individuals found during 12 months of field work. Another factor that may have contributed to the differences is ongoing habitat alteration. During the study period from 2009 to 2011, various observations were made of illegal logging (often hardwoods), slash-and-burn agriculture and poaching of the sportive lemurs on the Sahamalaza Peninsula (Seiler et al. 2010, 2012).
range:
Lepilemur sahamalaza is restricted to the Sahamalaza Peninsula. The precise range of this species is not known, but inferring from the biogeography of this area of Madagascar and from the distribution of the sympatric Eulemur flavifrons, the northern boundary of the range is likely to be the Andranomalaza (Maetsamalaza) River, and the southern boundary the Maevarano River (Mittermeier et al. 2010). While the extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 514 km2, the area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be between 12 and 472 km2.

The three remaining forest blocks of the Sahamalaza Peninsula and their unique fauna are in grave danger of disappearing, despite having been under official protection since 2007. The forests are already extremely degraded and highly fragmented; nonetheless, bush fires and tree-felling are activities that are routinely pursued and accepted within the local society (Seiler et al. 2010, 2012).
