In 2010, the Ankarafa Forest measured only about 185 ha, divided into six fragments (10, 10, 13, 22, 30 and 100 ha; Seiler et al. 2010). In 2014, the Anabohazo forest covered a total area of ~5,000 ha (Randriatahina et al. 2014).
useTrade: The species is hunted at increasingly high rates by the local human population since the onset of the political crisis in Madagascar in 2009, due to an almost complete lack of law enforcement. The level of hunting is likely to be unsustainable (Seiler et al. 2012).
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. The species is present in the Sahamalaza–Iles Radama National Park (Aire Protégée Terrestre, Marine et Côtière) which is part of the country's protected area network managed through Madagascar National Parks (MNP). The Sahamalaza Peninsula is also a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (declared in 2001). The Association Européenne pour l'Etude et la Conservation des Lémuriens (AEECL), together with MNP and the local communities, is carrying out a community-based natural resource management programme to ensure a better protection of the very few remaining forest fragments in the park (Schwitzer et al. 2006). Further work is needed to clarify the exact distribution and taxonomic limits of the recently described Lepilemur species.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 3,000 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: Lepilemur betsileo is an inhabitant of the eastern rainforests. This large sportive lemur has a head-body length of 25 cm, a tail length of 28 cm, and a total length of 53 cm (Mittermeier et al. 2010).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation due to ongoing agricultural practices, use and modification of biological resources, as well as unsustainable levels of hunting.
population: Population numbers are suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss. A population size of 2,315 was estimated based on the IUCN range by Herrera et al. (2018) but the species has not been studied in the wild (Mittermeier et al. 2010).
range:
This species is currently known from the Fandriana region in central-eastern Madagascar. The southern and northern extents of the range need to be confirmed, but are believed to be between the Mangoro/Onive and Namorona Rivers (Louis et al. 2006). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be less than 3,000 km2. Herrera et al. (2018) estimated the occupied area as 1,167 km2.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. Present in the Fandriana Classified Forest (Louis et al. 2006). Further work is still needed to confirm the distribution and taxonomic limits of the species.

rationale: The extent of occurrence of Lepilemur petteri is estimated at 32,647 km2. This EOO is based on new information, establishing a much larger distribution than what defined in the original description in Louis et al. (2006). Furthermore, although this range would be normally considered quite large, the spiny forest habitat in south-western Madagascar has become severely fragmented, decreasing in area by 28% from 1950 to 2000 and undergoing the highest annual rate of deforestation (1.2%) during the 1990’s than any other forest type or region in Madagascar (Harper et al. 2007). This trend has persisted between 2000 to present, continuing the decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Past, and ongoing rates of decline in this species are suspected to be >30% over three generations, but trends in the future are suspected to get worse, and reductions in the next 3 generations could be >50%. Therefore, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: Petter’s Sportive Lemur is an inhabitant of spiny forest and dry forest in south-western Madagascar. As with other sportive lemurs, Lepilemur petteri is presumably largely folivorous, nocturnal and arboreal. At Beza-Mahafaly, L. petteri has been found to spend roughly 50% of the night resting and/or self-grooming, 30% feeding and 10–15% travelling. They rest significantly more and travel significantly less in the cooler, dry season. Social behaviour, vocalizing, and other behaviours make up 5% of their nocturnal active time. The activity of this species does not seem to be correlated with nocturnal illumination, although the animals seem to use the highest stratum of the forest less frequently during full-moon nights (Nash 1998, 2000, 2007).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from shifting agricultural practices.
population: Population numbers are suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss and the agriculture shift of habitat. It is suspected that the population has undergone a 30% reduction in the past three generations (21 years) due to extensive habitat loss (observed/documented by satellite imagery). The spiny forest habitat in south-western Madagascar has become severely fragmented, decreasing in area by 28% from 1950 to 2000 and undergoing the highest annual rate of deforestation (1.2%) during the 1990’s than any other forest type or region in Madagascar (Harper et al. 2007). Looking forward, it is suspected that population reduction rates will be greater than 50% in the next three generations, due to ongoing threats faced by the species.
range:
Located in south-western Madagascar, this species was initially described in 2006 from a single locality, the Beza-Mahafaly region, which then set the species distribution from south of the Onilahy River and west of the Linta River (Louis et al. 2016). Further distribution studies (unpublished data; E. Louis pers. comm.) were completed over the following eight years, determining the western extend of Lepilemur petteri to be south of Toliara (Onilahy River), the eastern distribution defined as west of the Mandrare River, the northern extent from the Onilahy River, bordering the northern extent of the Mahafaly Plateau to the Linta River, extending easterly in the forest fragments to the Mandrare River. Due to deforestation, L. petteri has been essentially extirpated from the coastal forest south of the Mahafaly Plateau.

Petter’s Sportive Lemur's distribution previously included a major portion of the distribution of L. leucopus which is now found in the Nord-Ifotaka NAP, Ankodida NAP, and the two Andohahela National Park spiny forest parcels, east of the Mandrare River, continuing westward into the Andohahela NP intermediate transitional zone parcel, and finally easterly bounded by the Anosy Mountain which includes the Andohahela National Park’s humid eastern rain forest parcel (L. leucopus does not extend into the eastern rain forest of Andohahela. But L. fleuretae occupies this ecosystem).  

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 32,647 km2 at an elevation range from 146 – 169 metres above sea level (avg. 157 metres).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is no suspected trade or general use, including active bushmeat or hunting of this sportive lemur.
conservationActions: Lepilemur petteri is listed on CITES Appendix I. This species is known to occur is the protected areas of Beza-Mahafaly Special Reserve, Tsimanampetsotsa and the Mahafaly Plateau Protected Area, along with the adjacent classified forests within its distribution. Further efforts to determine population numbers and densities, along with restoration of the spiny forest which it continues to reside, especially using advanced techniques for the Alluaudia and other spiny trees that this species utilizes.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers 10,335 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. As a result, it is suspected that the population has declined by at least 30% in the past, and that this rate of decline continues into the future. The number of mature individuals is also suspected to be in decline. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of the eastern humid rainforests; limited research has been committed to this species and population and density information is not available.
threats: Hunting of this species is unsustainable (Golden 2005). Surveys documented 0.15 Lepilemur seali per household per year with 1,155 households in the region. The density of sportive lemurs is unknown, and they have a low reproductive rate; therefore, sustainability cannot be evaluated. Population numbers need to be defined based on regional densities due to the high hunting. Habitat degradation due to slash and burn agriculture is also a threat.
population:
Population numbers are suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss across its currently known distribution. It is suspected that the population has declined by at least 30% in the past, and that this rate of decline continues into the future.

Hunting of lemurs is high in this region (Golden 2005) and the geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. It has been estimated that there will be a 8% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).
range:
This species is found in north-eastern Madagascar. Known only from the Anjanaharibe-Sud region, ranging south of the Antainambalana River at least as far as the Fananehana River and including the Makira region (Craul et al. 2008). Additional surveys are needed to determine the northern and southern extents of the distribution (Louis et al. 2006). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 10,335 km2 at an elevation from 982 – 1,047 metres above sea level (avg. 1,013 metres). 

It has been estimated that there will be a 8% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is no commercial trade of this species; however, subsistence hunting is active and high in this region of Madagascar.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It occurs in Anjanaharibe-Sud Special Reserve and northern Makira Protected Area. Further work is now urgently needed to clarify the distribution and taxonomic limits of the recently described Lepilemur species both north and south of its current known distribution (Ramaromilanto et al. 2009).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of Lepilemur tymerlachsonorum covers less than 75 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. As a result, population declines of at least 80% are suspected to have taken place in the past and to continue into the future. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: This species inhabits primary and secondary tropical moist lowland forests that are subject to a dry season each year. It appears to be more common in secondary forest. In dense primary forest this species favors tree holes for sleeping; however, it was determined in a recent study in Lokobe that they spend more time resting in vegetation tangles in more open deciduous forest (Sawyer et al. 2015). It feeds on leaves, supplementing with some fruit, and bark. Births occur from August through November, mothers typically producing a single offspring. Predators include the Madagascar Harrier-hawk Polyboroides radiatus and the Madagascar Buzzard Buteo brachypterus (Mittermeier et al. 2010 and references therein).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from unsustainable agricultural practices, as well as unsustainable levels of hunting.
population:
The extent of occurrence (EOO) of Lepilemur tymerlachsonorum covers less than 75 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. As a result, population declines of at least 80% are suspected to have taken place in the past and to continue into the future.

Population density has been estimated at 63.2 individuals/km2 in Lokobe National Park (Bederu 2014).
range: This species is found in north-western Madagascar, its range currently confined to the Lokobe National Park region and agricultural fragmented forests on the island of Nosy Be. Furthermore, this may or may not be the species that formerly occurred on the island of Nosy Komba as well; in any case sportive lemurs have not been observed there in recent years (Roberts and Daly 2014). Zinner et al. (2007) found that some specimens from the mainland were identical in mitochondrial DNA sequence data to the type of Lepilemur tymerlachsonorum; however, this study only utilized partial d-loop or control region sequence data, truncated from the dataset which was utilized to describe this species. Mitogenomic studies did not support this finding (E. Louis, unpublished data). The locations of the holotypes of L. dorsalis and L. grandidieri still need to be determined so that the distribution and taxonomic designations of sportive lemurs on Nosy Be and other regions in north-western Madagascar can be established. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is highly restricted, estimated to be less than 75 km2 in elevations from 12 – 35 metres above sea level (avg. 15 metres).
useTrade: Individuals are caught by locals for illegal sale to tourists; unfortunately, this practice is lethal to sportive lemurs as they do not survive captivity due to diet restrictions.
conservationActions:
Listed on CITES Appendix I. In areas where logging has reduced the availability of sleeping sites, researchers have provided nesting boxes. Individuals are still frequently caught by locals for illegal sale to tourists. The only protected area in which it occurs is the Lokobe Strict Nature Reserve.

Further work is now urgently needed to clarify the distribution and taxonomic limits of the recently described Lepilemur species.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers 2,350 km². This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Therefore, there are thought to be declines in population (both in the past and in the future) at a rate of >50% over three generations. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species occurs in dry deciduous forests and in moist evergreen forest. The natural history of this species remains poorly studied by comparison to that of sportive lemurs inhabiting western and southern Madagascar. Adults seem to remain solitary during nightly bouts of foraging for leaves. Tree holes and vine tangles are preferred daytime shelters. The Madagascar ground boa is known to prey upon sportive lemurs in their sleeping sites. A study of this species in degraded secondary forest fragments south of Montagne d’Ambre National Park found that the animals eat a high proportion of fruits during the rainy season when fruits are abundant, whereas they only eat leaves during the dry season. The fruits of five plant families were consumed: Moraceae, Verbenaceae, Rubiaceae, Pittosporaceae, and one that was not identified. The species has also been observed to feed on latex (Mittermeier et al. 2008 and references therein).
threats: The major threats to this species are forest loss, particularly for charcoal (such as in Analamerana and Andrafiamena), and hunting (exacerbated by mining in the region for sapphires). It is occasionally kept as a pet within Madagascar (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
population: A past population decline of 50% (over the last three generations) is suspected due to loss of habitat (confirmed through site visits and drone footage) and hunting. It is suspected that this rate of population decline will continue three generations into the future. Population densities have been variously estimated between 150 and 550 individuals/km² (Ratsirarson and Rumpler 1988, Hawkins et al. 1990), the higher figures coming from more humid forest environments such as Ankarana. However, utilizing these population densities from three decades ago to calculate current projected population numbers based on the Area of Occupancy (AOO) values are most likely going to grossly overestimated, given the observed declines in habitat area and quality (Mittermeier et al. 2008).
range: This species is found in northern Madagascar in the forests of Ankarana, Andrafiamena, and Analamerana, from 5 - 434 metres in elevation (avg. 167 m). This species has been documented to be sympatric with Lepilemur milanoii in the Andrafiamena or Anjahakely Classified Forest (Louis et al. 2006, Salmona et al. 2014). Field studies are needed to determine how these two species share the same forest. This population represents the only area where two Lepilemur species evidently occur in sympatry. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 2,350 km2. It has been estimated that there will be a 6% reduction in the species' range from 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015). This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted for food. Hunting has become more serious in recent years, with the appearance of large numbers of itinerant sapphire miners in the Ankarana region and the charcoal enterprises for Analamerana. It is occasionally kept as a pet within Madagascar (Reuter and Schaefer 2017).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. The species is found in the surrounding areas west of Montagne d’Ambre National Park and in three special reserves (Analamerana, Ankarana, and Fôret d’Ambre), as well as in the Andrafiamena Classified Forest (Mittermeier et al. 2008, Louis et al. 2006, Salmona et al. 2012). Improved management and protection of Analamerana is urgently required, and long-term scientific presence within the existing reserve is encouraged. Andrafiamena included within a protected area with excellent management will provide an opportunity to study Lepilemur ankaranensis and L. milanoii. Surveys to determine densities and population numbers should follow the studies from the early 1990’s.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 2,850 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of the eastern lowland rainforest. It has not yet been studied in the wild. There have been reports of this species being hunted in Betampona, and individuals being sold to tourists (on RN2) (Borgerson pers. comm.).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from shifting agriculture. There have been reports of this species being hunted in Betampona, and individuals being sold to tourists (on RN2) (Borgerson pers. comm.).
population: This species is in decline due to habitat loss and destruction.
range:
Microcebus simmonsi is known only from the regions of Betampona, Zahamena and Tampolo in north-eastern Madagascar, the type locality is at 965 m asl (Louis et al. 2006, 2008). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be restricted to less than 2,850 km2. 

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: There have been reports of this species being hunted in Betampona, and individuals being sold to tourists (on RN2) (Borgerson pers. comm.).
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. It is currently known only from two strict nature reserves (Betampona and Zahamena) and Zahamena National Park. In 2009 there were four individuals of this species in captivity, all in the Tsimbazaza Zoo in Antananarivo, Madagascar (E. E. Louis Jr. pers. obs.).

rationale: This species’ extent of occurrence (EOO) is limited to Zombitse-Vohibasia, an area less than 276 km². It has been estimated that there will be a complete loss of the species' range by 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015). Moreover, this geographic range is severely fragmented, undergoing continued decline in area and quality of habitat due to subsistence harvesting of natural materials, artisanal mining, and frequent fires. Lemurs in this region are subject to significant hunting pressure. The species has been assessed as Endangered, but it is likely that with new information this species will be considered Critically Endangered.
habitat: No field studies are known for this recently described species (Lei et al., 2009). They inhabit the dry and deciduous forests of the Zombitse region and are presumed to be folivorous, as with other Lepilemur spp. Individual(s) return daily to the same tree roost to sleep during the daytime and so can be consistently observed if the roost is located. They are sympatric with the Red-tailed Sportive Lemur (Lepilemur ruficaudatus), which has only recently been observed in the same range as L. hubbardorum (Fanomezantsoa Andrianirina pers. comm.).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from shifting agriculture, subsistence resource use and small-scale mining, frequent forest/agricultural fires, as well as unsustainable levels of hunting. Shotguns, spears, hatchets, and dogs are used to hunt wildlife in this area. It has been estimated that there will be a complete loss of the species' range by 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).
population: Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss and significant hunting pressure (see Siers 2007). One individual Lepilemur hubbardorum was seen (by Bornbusch, S.) during a walking tour of the Zombitse-Vohibasia National Park. National Park guides stated that sightings are rare, with only a handful of individuals observed in the park within the areas that they frequent. In the 2 years mid-2016 to mid-2018, eight L. hubbardorum roosts have been identified in an approximately 40,000 m² area of the National Park (Fanomezantsoa Andrianirina pers. comm.). It is not known how many animals use one roost or if all roosts identified were occupied by L. hubbardorum. An adult individual L. hubbardorum was seen and photographed at a known tree roost in the park during July 2018 (LaFleur, M. pers. obs. 2018).
range: This species is only known to occur in the Zombitse-Vohibasia region, an area of south-western Madagascar that is north of the Onilahy and south of the Fiherena river. Surveys are needed to confirm the east/west boundaries of the species. The EOO (extent of occurrence) is estimated as less than 276 km². It has been estimated that there will be a complete loss of the species' range by 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).
useTrade: This species is hunted for food.
conservationActions: This species is listed in Appendix 1 of CITES. The only area where the species is known to occur is in the Zombitse-Vohibasia National Park. Data are needed on the ecology, distribution, and density of the species.

rationale: The extent of occurrence of this species covers less than 1,470 km². This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of the eastern humid rainforests. It is nocturnal and arboreal. Primarily it differs from other members of the Avahi genus by having a reddish-brown dorsal coat and grey underline. It has a total length of 48-58.9 cm with an average weight of 900-1,200 g (Andriantompohavana et al. 2007, Mittermeier et al. 2008).
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation.
population: Population numbers are suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss.
range:
Currently Avahi betsileo is known in the Bemosary Classified forest (Fandriana), from high altitudes only. The regional distribution is tentatively set from south of the Mangoro River and north of the Mananjary River until its full distribution can be confirmed (Andriantompohavana et al. 2007, Mittermeier et al. 2008). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be less than 1,500 km².

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
conservationActions: It is listed on CITES Appendix I. This species is not known to occur in any official protected areas but is found in Bemosary Classified forest (Fandriana), which provides some degree of protection (Andriantompohavana et al. 2007, Mittermeier et al. 2008). There is a need for further survey work to determine the geographic range and population status of this species. It is not being kept in captivity (C. Schwitzer pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers 143 km<sup>2</sup>. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing extensive decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. This is leading to suspected population declines that are above 80% both in the past and in the future. The number of mature individuals is also suspected to be in decline. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: This species inhabits dense primary forest fragments in mountainous and coastal areas.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation due to urbanization, agricultural practices, livestock farming, as well as unsustainable levels of hunting.
population: A population decline is suspected in this species due to an extensive decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. This is leading to suspected population declines that are above 80% both in the past and in the future. The number of mature individuals is also suspected to be in decline. Encounter rates in forest fragments near Anjajavy and between Antsohihy and Analalava are low. In 2010, Lepilemur grewcockorum were found to be present in only 3 of 11 sites (Anjajavy, Ambarijeby, and Bekofafa) in the Région Sofia. If present, its abundance ranged from 0.8 to 1 individual per km (Randrianambinina et al. 2010). The population is declining due to habitat loss and degradation as well as hunting. Forest loss in Région Sofia from 1990 to 2000 was 10% or 75,000 ha; from 2000 to 2010: 3% or 20,000 ha. Thus, forest lost during three generations of L. grewcockorum was 13% or 95,000 ha. Forest loss has increased again since 2009 due to political crisis and lack of law enforcement. Hunting is not quantifiable, but likely to be unsustainable due to high human population pressure (population growth of 2.7% annually). Future decline is likely to accelerate due to higher human population pressure and political instability. If the decline rate were to grow back to 1990-2000 levels, it would equal 20% loss during three generations through forest loss alone, not including hunting. The total population is divided into several isolated subpopulations without any genetic exchange. Subpopulations are likely to be small due to a high degree of habitat fragmentation (Mittermeier et al. 2008 and references therein).
range: It is currently known from the Anjiamangirana region in north-western Madagascar. Louis et al. (2006) gave the range as north of the Mahajamba River and south of the Maevarano and Sofia River. Formerly, the sportive lemurs found in this part of Madagascar were thought to be Lepilemur edwardsi. More recently, Craul et al. (2007) have described L. otto from between the Mahajamba and the Sofia, making the Sofia River effectively the southerly limit of L. grewcockorum. Clearly, the limits between L. edwardsi, L. otto, and L. sahamalazensis remain unresolved. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 143 km2 with an elevation of 172-361 metres above sea level (avg. 279 metres above sea level).
useTrade: The species is hunted at increasingly high rates by the local human population since the onset of the political crisis in Madagascar in 2009, due to an almost complete lack of law enforcement. The level of hunting is likely to be unsustainable.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. This species is known to occur in the Anjiamangirana Classified Forest as well as in a proposed 50,300 ha conservation area on the Bongolava Massif; however, there is no effective protection due to lack of enforcement. Management authority of either site should be directed at a strong organisation well versed in working with communities, leveraging the biodiversity to restore the habitat for mutual benefits. Restoration and timber use forest need to be mutually inclusive programmes, tied to the forestry department and local government agencies. Population evaluations of the primary sites should be conducted immediately.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is 3,770 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. The number of mature individuals is also thought to be in decline, partly due to hunting. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of dry deciduous forests.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss, bushfires, habitat degradation from unsustainable agricultural practices and from hunting.
population: Population numbers are thought to be in decline due to habitat loss, fragmentation and hunting.
range:
So far it is known from its type locality of Ambodimahabibo and from three other sites in north-western Madagascar (Craul et al. 2007, Mahaboubi et al. 2015). The distribution is limited by the Mahajamba River in the west and the Sofia River in the north (Craul et al. 2007). The species is bounded by Lepilemur grewockorum to the north (north of the Sofia), and by L. edwardsi to the west (west of the Mahajamba). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 3,770 km2.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. It occurs in the 60,589-ha conservation area “Forest corridor of Bongolava”. More surveys are required in this heavily deforested and fragmented region to obtain information about the location, connectivity and viability of the remaining populations, so that appropriate local conservation measures can be proposed.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is 289 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Therefore, it is suspected that the population has undergone a rapid decline of >80% over three generations, and that this will continue into the future. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of dry deciduous forest. As with the genus Lepilemur, this species is presumably largely folivorous.
threats: This species is threatened by dramatic habitat loss and degradation due to ongoing shifting agricultural practices in this region of western Madagascar.
population:
Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss and severe fragmentation of the habitat. It is suspected that there was an 80% reduction in the population in the past, with the extent of occurrence (EOO) now covering 289 km2, with drone footage and site visits confirming drastic habitat decline over the past 15 years. It is expected that population declines will continue at rates of 50% to 80% into the future.

As with most sportive lemurs, social groups are composed of male and female pairings or single female with offspring, using holes and vine tangles as nest during the daylight times. Population numbers and densities are uncertain.
range:
This species is located in western Madagascar, currently known from the Tsiombikibo region, west of the Mahavavy River. The southern extent of the range is unknown (especially relative to the recently described Lepilemur randrianasoloi). The southerly limit is here rather arbitrarily taken as the Maningoza (with L. randrianasoloi to the south), but obviously this requires further investigation. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 289 km2 with an elevation between 12-18 metres above sea level (avg. 15 metres).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is no use or trade for this species that is known, except possibly as an occasional food source.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. This species is not known to occur in any protected areas, though Rylands et al. (2018) lists is as being found in Mahavavy Kinkony and Parc National de Namoroka. It is found in the Tsiombikibo Classified Forest. Further work is now urgently needed to clarify the distribution and taxonomic limits of the recently described Lepilemur species. Furthermore, efforts to determine baseline population numbers and densities, areas of available habitat which can be set aside as locally protected areas as a community-based organisation responsible for forest management, known as a Vondron’Olona Ifototra or VOI.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 1,100 km². This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is known to inhabit the Antafondro Classified forest and perhaps the high elevations of the Tsaratanana Special Reserve (Louis et al. 2008). Research should be done on their ecology, as no specific information is available. They are thought to be nocturnal and arboreal but have not yet been studied in the wild.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from unsustainable agricultural practices.
population: This species is suspected to be in decline due to habitat degradation and loss.
range:
This species is mainly found in the Antafondro Classified forest, in north-west Madagascar (Andriantompohavana et al. 2006, Louis et al. 2008). Its distribution is thought to range from the south of the Andranomalaza River to the north of the Maevarano River, but further research is required in order to establish its exact range (Louis et al. 2008). This species used to be misidentified with Microcebus sambiranensis in the past. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is less than 1,100 km2. 

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forests (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
conservationActions: This species is not known to occur in any protected areas, but is found in the Antafondro Classified Forest and perhaps also at high-elevations in the Tsaratanana Special Reserve (Louis et al. 2008). It is not known to be kept in captivity (I.J. Porton pers. comm. 2010).

rationale: Microcebus arnholdi's area of occupancy (AOO) covers between 500 and 1,004 km2, and its extent of occurrent (EOO) covers 13,577km2. Its geographic range is severely fragmented and covers about 8 locations, and is undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. It is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: This species inhabits northern rainforest (Louis et al. 2008, Sgarlata et al. in prep). It has not yet been studied in the wild, hence no specific information is known on their ecology nor behaviour, except that they are nocturnal and arboreal.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from various sources, including slash and burn agricultural practices.
population: The population density of Microcebus arnholdi is estimated to vary between 124 and 200 individuals/km2 (Sgarlata G.M., Le Pors B., Chikhi L., unpublished data). The population is likely to be in decline due to habitat loss.
range:
After its discovery, Microcebus arnholdi was thought to occur exclusively in the montane forest of Montagne d'Ambre National Park and Foret d’Ambre Special Reserve (Louis et al. 2008). However, Weisrock et al. (2010) reported that an individual sampled close to Ambanja, further south of Montagne d’Ambre, was genetically associated to the Microcebus species occurring in Montagne d'Ambre. Now, new unpublished mitochondrial genetic data suggest that M. arnholdi exists also in one forest fragment close to Montagne d’Ambre and in several forests between the Loky and Fanambana Rivers, south-east of Montagne d’Ambre (Sgarlata et al. in prep). The area of occupancy (AOO) is now estimated to be between 500 and 1,004 km2. It occurs between 56 and 990 m of altitude (Sgarlata et al. unpublished).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forests (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
conservationActions: It exists in four protected areas: Montagne d'Ambre National Park and Foret d’Ambre Special Reserve (Louis et al. 2008), Northern COMATSA Protected Area and in the Binara forest, part of the Loky-Manambato Protected Area (Sgarlata. et al., in prep). It is not being kept in captivity.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is estimated at 1,183 km². This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing a continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland rainforests. It has not yet been studied in the wild, so little is known about its behaviour and ecology.
threats: Habitat loss due to the rapid rate of deforestation from unsustainable agricultural practices in the region is a major threat to this species. Hunting does occur locally.
population: Population numbers are suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss and degradation.
range:
This species is found in north-east Madagascar. This recently-described species is known from its type locality near the village of Anjiahely in the Makira region, about 26 km west of Maroantsetra (Radespiel et al. 2008) and from the island Nosy Mangabe (Louis and Lei 2016). The precise limits of its distribution and its relationship to neighbouring taxa remain to be determined. It occurs sympatrically with Microcebus mittermeieri at Anjiahely (Radespiel et al. 2008). It has a restricted extent of occurrence (EOO) estimated at 1,183 km2.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forests (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: The species is hunted locally.
conservationActions: This species is found in the Nosy Mangabe Special Reserve (IUCN cat IV) and Makira Natural Park (IUCN cat II), which is currently under Wildlife Conservation Society management. This species is not kept in captivity (ISIS 2009).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 400 km². This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Even though the region where Lepilemur hollandorum is located has a human occupancy of approximately 223,000 people in approximately 30,000 households, the bushmeat survey of households that exploit the sportive population in the form of hunting revealed that 0.22 L. hollandorum/household in 2013 which converts to as many as 6,765 L. hollandorum may be eaten each year. As a result, the species is suspected of undergoing declines of at least 80% in the past and into the future. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland rainforest. There is a significant decline in forest habitat and quality due to agricultural shifts to vanilla, palm and other cash crops in the region. Although there is no specific information available, it is presumed that this species largely folivorous as is the case with other sportive lemurs.
threats: Habitat loss to agricultural shifts and hunting are the major threats to the lemur biodiversity in the Mananara-Nord Biosphere Reserve in north-eastern Madagascar. A mean of 0.22 Lepilemur hollandorum are eaten per household per year (Golden and Borgerson, unpubl. data); therefore, an estimated 64 L. hollandorum were eaten by members of 287 households during the prior year. The Mananara region is home to a human population of approximately 223,000 people (INSTAT 2015). Excluding all major cities, this is a rural human population of 120,000 individuals or approximately 30,000 households (given a local median household size of 4 individuals per household). Therefore, as many as 6,765 L. hollandorum may be eaten each year. While this hunting is likely unsustainable, we currently lack the information on L. hollandorum density necessary for sustainability analysis.
population: The species is suspected to be undergoing population decline. The northern two of three parcels that form the Mananara-Nord Biosphere Reserve, Ivontaka and Ivontaka-Sud, are heavily damaged by agricultural shifts and deforestation. Therefore, surveys have documented this species only in Ivontaka-Sud and Verezanantsoro parcels. Population numbers continue to decline due to habitat loss and hunting. Hunting estimates for bushmeat are estimated to be over 6,000 sportive lemurs per year. Although these estimates are seemingly unsustainable, the humid environment of this region precludes a sustainable agriculture of domestic fowl as livestock. Therefore, the utilization of lemur populations, especially the easily hunted sportive lemurs which sleep during the day in tree holes and vines, creates the potential for dramatic declines in this species’ densities and overall population numbers. Given these threats, and that the extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 400 km², the species is suspected of undergoing population declines of at least 80% in the past and into the future.
range: This species is found in north-eastern Madagascar and is known from the Mananara-Nord region, with the only confirmed reports so far coming from the Ivontaka-Sud and Verezanantsoro (Ambinanibeorana) parcels of the Mananara-Nord Biosphere Reserve. The northern and southern limits of the range are still undefined, though they are tentatively assumed to be the area south of the Fahambahy or Mananara Rivers and north of the Simianona, Sandratsio, or Maningory Rivers, respectively (Ramaromilanto et al. 2009). Additional surveys are required to determine the full extent of the distribution. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is still estimated to be less than 400 km2, at elevations between 279 – 374 metres above sea level (avg. 299 metres).
useTrade: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from shifting agriculture, as well as unsustainable levels of hunting.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. The only area in which this species is known to occur is the protected Mananara-Nord Biosphere Reserve. Further work is urgently needed to confirm the distribution, population status and densities, and ecology of this Lepilemur species and to verify if hunting is occurring at the estimated rate, along with any other threats in the region.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is estimated to be 2,544 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. The number of mature individuals is also thought to be in decline. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat: Lepilemur scottorum inhabits primary lowland and littoral rainforest, but can also be found in selectively logged habitats despite potentially being negatively affected by high levels of habitat disturbance (Sawyer et al. 2017, Fenosoa et al. 2018). Its abundance was highest in the primary lowland forest where Garcinia commersonii was abundant. As rosewood (Dalbergia spp.) has been recorded as a key dietary resource for Lepilemur spp. (Ganzhorn et al. 2001), it may be that the continued illegal extraction of Dalbergia spp. from the Masoala peninsula is negatively impacting L. scottorum abundance (Sawyer et al. 2017). It is presumably largely folivorous and nocturnal. In primary forest habitat, they use tree holes as sleeping sites.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation due to ongoing shifting agricultural practices and illegal timber harvesting, in addition to relatively low levels of subsistence hunting.
population: Population numbers are in decline due to habitat loss from shifting agriculture (including fires) and illegal logging, in addition to hunting pressure and frequent cyclones. Density estimates were recorded at 25.2 individuals/km2 near Ambodiforaha (Sawyer et al. 2017), compared to 33 individuals/km2 recorded by Sterling and Rakotoarison (1998).
range:
This species is found in north-eastern Madagascar. It is currently known only from Masoala National Park (Lei et al. 2008; Mittermeier et al. 2010). Additional surveys are needed to determine the eastern and northern limits of its range. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 2,544 km2.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: While generally not targeted by hunters because of their bitter taste, Lepilemur scottorum is occasionally opportunistically hunted using slingshots and found objects (Borgerson 2016).
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. The only protected area in which this species is known to occur is Masoala National Park. Further work is urgently needed to confirm the distribution, population status, ecology, and threats to Lepilemur scottorum throughout the Masoala National Park and adjacent unprotected habitats. It is not being kept in captivity (C. Schwitzer pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is 2,544 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. The number of mature individuals is also suspected to be in decline. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Endangered.
habitat:
Avahi mooreorum has a distinct white patch on the posterior surface of the hindlimb is the main visual characteristic for this species. Its total length ranges from 57.8 to 70.3 cm, with an average weight of 920 g, it is lighter than A. laniger. Its overall pelage is a mix of different browns with gradual lightening towards the base of the tail (Andriantompohavana et al. 2007, Lei et al. 2008). A. mooreorum inhabits primary lowland and littoral rainforest, selectively logged habitats as well as agricultural mosaics, it is currently only known from lowland rainforest (up to 274 m asl) (Sawyer et al. 2017). High density of this species is positively associated with high abundances of Garcinia commersonii and Eugenia spp. in the primary lowland rainforest (Sawyer et al. 2017). In areas of increased disturbance, they use lower forest stratum, which may increase the threat of hunting pressure (Fenosoa et al. 2018). It is presumably largely folivorous, as well as nocturnal and arboreal as individuals have not been observed active during daylight hours or exhibiting terrestrial activity.

Avahi mooreorum have been observed in groups of up to 4 individuals. In disturbed areas, solitary individuals are seen frequently, whereas pairs are most frequently observed in undisturbed habitat. This is possibly a response to lower resource availability in areas of high disturbance (Sawyer et al. 2017). In primary forest areas, they sleep in clumps of dense foliage during the daytime.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation due to ongoing shifting agricultural practices and illegal timber harvesting, in addition to relatively high levels of subsistence hunting.
population: Density estimates were recorded at 93.8 individuals/km2 near Ambodiforaha (Sawyer et al. 2017), compared to 25 individuals/km2 recorded by Sterling and Rakotoarison (1998). These contrasting findings may be an indication of the localized success that the creation of Masoala National Park in 1997 has had on the Avahi population. Despite the localized high density in the main tourist area, this species is in decline due to habitat loss from illegal logging and shifting agricultural practices, frequent cyclones and fires, as well as unsustainable levels of hunting.
range:
It is found in north-eastern Madagascar, where it is currently known only from Masoala National Park (Lei et al. 2008, Mittermeier et al. 2010). Further surveys are required to confirm the northern extent of this species within this protected area and, possibly, in intervening forest fragments between Makira Natural Park (where Avahi laniger has been confirmed to occur) and the Masoala Peninsula (Mittermeier et al. 2010). The Extent of Occurrence is estimated to be 2,544 km2.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Avahi mooreorum is hunted opportunistically using slingshots and found objects (Borgerson 2016, unpub. data).
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. It is known to occur in one protected area (Masoala National Park). It would appear that the Avahi mooreorum population around Ambodiforaha is quite healthy and likely the result of the creation of Masoala National Park (Sawyer et al. 2017). As this village is the park’s main tourist entry point, lemur populations here are abundant. Further work is needed to confirm the distribution, population status, ecology, and threats to Avahi mooreorum throughout the Masoala National Park and adjacent unprotected habitats. It is not being kept in captivity (C. Schwitzer pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: Given that Cheirogaleus medius’ geographic distribution is now considered to be constrained to western dry deciduous forests and given the fact the Menabe region has been undergoing unprecedented rates of deforestation, it is very likely that C. medius is currently in decline (Hudson et al. 2019). Therefore, the species is assessed as Vulnerable based on a suspected future decline of 30% due to decline in habitat quality and EOO, as well as due to potential exploitation. Further information on population status, and threats may warrant listing this species in a more threatened category in the future.
habitat:
Cheirogaleus medius inhabits western dry deciduous forests. Fruits, flowers, seeds and the tender parts of plants are dietary staples, with invertebrates being eaten in small amounts and small vertebrates taken on occasion. C. medius, like other dwarf lemur species, accumulates large quantities of fat within weeks in preparation for hibernation. At Kirindy, during the prehibernation fattening period, dwarf lemurs consume mostly fruits with high sugar content, which is then converted to fat deposits, thus the name fat-tailed dwarf lemur (Fietz and Ganzhorn 1999). Individual home ranges approach 1-2 ha. Small family groups consist of the reproductively active female-male pair and their offspring from one or two breeding seasons. During the day, which is the resting period, individuals occupy tree holes with up to five individuals occupying a single shelter (Fietz and Dausmann 2006). The breeding season occurs from September to November, leading to a gestation period of about two months. One to four (usually two) offspring are born in December or January. Full sexual maturity is reached during the second year of life (Mittermeier et al. 2008).

Longevity record in captivity is 29 years at the Duke Lemur Center, NC, USA (Blanco and Zehr 2015).
threats: Threats include habitat loss, primarily due to slash-and-burn agriculture, charcoal extraction, and bushfires; in addition to hunting.
population:
Although Cheirogaleus medius was considered to be a widespread and abundant species, there has been recent concern about low densities and lack of sightings at sites under protection, where this species has been studied long term, e.g. CNFEREF Kirindy. Given that C. medius’ geographic distribution is now constrained to western dry deciduous forests and given the fact the Menabe region has been undergoing unprecedented rates of deforestation, it is very likely that C. medius is currently in decline (Hudson et al, 2019). As such, it is suspected that, due to a decline in habitat quality and Extent of Occurrence (as well as due to potential exploitation of the species), that a population reduction of at least 30% will occur over the next three generations (21 years).

Prior estimates ranged between 40-400 individuals/km² (see Mittermeier et al. 2008 and references therein). In central Menabe, densities were recorded at 140 individuals/km2. C. medius co-occurs with Microcebus berthae; they are found in higher densities when together. C. medius is able to live in fragments of 200-300 ha.
range:
The updated geographic range of this species is limited to the dry forests of western Madagascar, from Tsingy de Bemaraha to the north to Zombitse to the south. Ranges from sea level to 800 m. 

More generally, this species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES.

Its presence is reported at Tsingy de Bemaraha National Park, CNFEREF Kirindy, Kirindy Mitea National Park, Analalava and Zombitse. There are ~25 individuals of Cheirogaleus medius housed at the Duke Lemur Center, North Carolina, USA as of 2019.

rationale: Given the continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to fragmentation throughout its range, this species is assumed to be in decline. This species has been reported to be hunted, most severely in the northern range. Based on habitat decline and actual levels of exploitation, and using the precautionary principle, Cheirogaleus major is listed as Vulnerable. Further studies into population status, geographic distribution, and threats may warrant listing this taxon as Endangered in the future.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of Madagascar’s eastern lowland forests where conditions of water and food availability are not as seasonally severe as in the drier western deciduous forests. During the active season, this species occupies tree holes or nest-like structures (Blanco, per.obs., Lahann 2007). The species prepares for hibernation by storing excess fat in its tail, but they have shorter hibernation periods than other dwarf lemur species. Cheirogaleus major hibernates inside tree holes and/or underground burrows (Blanco et al. 2018). Home ranges of adult females extend ~4 ha and appear to include those of adult males and juveniles as well (Lahann 2007). Sleeping groups of up to three adult animals have been observed both in tree holes and clumps of vegetation. Mating behaviour ensues shortly after emergence from torpor in October and November, females giving birth to two to three infants in January after a gestation of about 70 days (Petter-Rousseaux 1964). However, a number of observations of this species, cited here and elsewhere in this account, were made in Andasibe (= Périnet), and probably refer to C. crossleyi.
threats: This species is presumably undergoing localized declines due to habitat loss from slash-and-burn agriculture. There is also evidence of hunting, with particularly high hunting pressure in northeastern Madagascar, at a rate of ~0.38 per year/household in places like Masoala, Makira, Mananara and <0.01 individuals per year/per household in Kianjavato forest (Borgerson, 2016, Borgerson et al. 2018, Brook et al. in press).
population: Population densities have been estimated at 59–110 individuals/km2 in different locations. However, it should be noted that a number of these observations were made in Andasibe (= Périnet), which would mean that they may refer to Cheirogaleus crossleyi. It is suspected that population numbers are declining. C. major shows a negative edge effect (densities are lower in closer proximity to the forest edge) (Lehman et al. 2007). It is suspected that this species is undergoing a population decline (over a 24 year period) of at least 30% due to continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, in addition to fragmentation throughout its range. For context, Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018). In addition, this species has been reported to be hunted, most severely in the northern range.
range:
This species is found in north-eastern, eastern-central and south-eastern Madagascar. In the north-east, Cheirogaleus major has been found at Marojejy National Park, Makirovana-Tsihomanaomby complex, Masoala and Makira (Blanco, pers. obs., Brooke et al. in press, Williams et al. 2019). In the eastern rainforests, it has been found in Mananara, Tampolo, Sahafina and Andasibe (Lei et al., 2014, McLain et al, 2017, Razafindrasolo, pers. obs.) According to Groeneveld et al. (2009), C. major is found from the south-eastern tip of the island near Tolagnaro (= Fort-Dauphin) potentially all the way up to near the northern tip, with an additional, small population isolate in the central-west. The southern limit of its distribution is particularly interesting, since two other dwarf lemur species can also be found in the same general region, although not to date in the same forests. Andreas Hapke has found C. major in the humid forests of the Vohimena and Anosy mountains and the littoral forest at Mandena, and believes it might also occur in Sainte-Luce, but this has yet to be confirmed (Hapke et al. 2005). C. major generally occupies low elevation rainforests, whereas C. crossleyi can occupy low as well as high elevation sites. These species can be found to live in sympatry (Williams et al. 2019).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018). C. major shows a negative edge effect (densities are lower in closer proximity to the forest edge) (Lehman et al. 2007).
useTrade: There is evidence of hunting, with particularly high hunting pressure in north-eastern Madagascar, at a rate of ~0.38 per year/household in places like Masoala, Makira, Mananara and <0.01 individuals per year/per household in Kianjavato forest (Borgerson, 2016, Borgerson et al. 2018, Brook et al., in press).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. This species is relatively widespread but additional taxonomic revision is pending. It is reported to occur in four national parks: Andasibe-Mantadia, Mananara-Nord, Marojejy, Masoala, one strict nature reserve, Betampona and Makira Natural Park, as well as in the Mandena Conservation Zone, east of Tolagnaro. More recently, based on genetic analysis, Cheirogaleus major has been found in Makirovana/Tsihomanaomby (NE Madagscar) living in sympatry with C. medius-like and C. crossleyi. The population of C. major at Tsihomanaomby, however, differs morphologically from that of Marojejy National Park, particularly in fur coloration, with more grey-brownish coat in the former compared to reddish-brownish in the latter (Blanco, pers. obs., Williams et al. 2019). Population densities in some of these locations seem to be comparatively low, and C. major shows a negative edge effect (densities are lower in closer proximity to the forest edge) (Lehman et al. 2007).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species covers less than 5,200 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and undergoing continuing decline because of human pressures, including slash-and-burn agriculture. Even though this species is found in three protected areas, Ranomafana National Park, Andringitra National Park, and the COFAV corridor, it can also be found in unprotected forest fragments that are decreasing in area. This species seems to be abundant at forest edges. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: Microcebus rufus is reported to occur in rainforests, and also in secondary forest formations, bamboo forests, old plantations and even Eucalyptus groves. This species sleeps in tree holes and leaf nests during the day and has been observed to use old bird nests. Mating takes place in September and October, and 1-3 young are born following a two month gestation period (see Mittermeier et al. 2008, and references therein). The majority of females go into oestrus the first week of October and have 2-3 offspring which are kept in leaf nests (Blanco 2008). One male travelled over 1 km one night and returned the next night (P.C. Wright pers. obs.). Genetic evidence shows that individuals can disperse across a road and a river, a distance of 1 km (C. Karanewsky per. obs.).
threats: The principal threat to this species is habitat loss due to slash-and-burn agriculture.
population: Microcebus rufus has an estimated density of 23.52 individuals/km2 with a total estimated population of 7,762 within Ranomafana National Park (Wright et al. 2012). Population numbers are suspected to be in decline due to habitat loss.
range:
The range of this species was tentatively considered to include much of the eastern rainforest, at least from Tolagnaro in the south to Tsaratanana in the north. However new studies have led to the discovery of new eastern mouse lemur species, thereby reducing the range of Microcebus rufus (Louis et al. 2008). The range is now assumed to extend from Ranomafana National Park to Andringitra National Park only (E.E. Louis Jr. pers. obs.). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to measure less than 5,200 km2.

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. This species is present in Andringitra National Park, Ranomafana National Park (Feistner and Schmid 1999, Wright and Porter 2004, Louis et al. 2008). Some individuals are in captivity (Zurich Zoo, University of Hanover, Stanford University, etc).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species has been updated to be 6,934 km2. This geographic range is severely fragmented and is undergoing continuing decline in area of occupancy, extent of occurrence and in quality of habitat. The number of subpopulations and mature individuals is also known to be in decline. It has been estimated that there will be a complete loss of the species' range by 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015). Based on these premises, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of intact and degraded forest fragments from sea level to 780 m. The species has been found in fragments of between 50 and 400 ha in size.
threats: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation from unsustainable farming practices, logging and hunting.
population: Population densities vary between 2.2 and 5.0 individuals/ha (which is low compared to other mouse lemur species), and the highest densities are found in disturbed forest fragments which may be due to crowding or edge effects (Randrianambinina et al. 2010). Almost all sampled populations of Microcebus danfossi show genetic evidence for a relatively rapid crash in population size. This crash is likely to have occurred within the last 500 years, thus coinciding with accelerated deforestation due to human population expansion in Madagascar (Olivieri et al. 2008). It is suspected that there is a declining population, including a decline in the number of mature individuals in the population, due to a decline in extent and quality of habitat.
range:
It is known from sixteen forest fragments between the rivers Sofia and Maevarano in north-western Madagascar (Olivieri et al. 2007, Randrianambinina et al. 2010). Although this species was already reported to occur at Anjajavy on the basis of census data, recent genetic analysis confirmed this species assignation (Blanco, unpublished). Prior to taxonomic revisions in 2007, the mouse lemurs in this region were assumed to be Microcebus ravelobensis. Randrianambinina et al. reported an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of ~7,600 km2 in 2000; however, forests have been severely fragmented over the last 8 years, and it EOO is estimated to be 6,934 km2. It has been estimated that there will be a complete loss of the species' range by 2080 due to climate change alone (Brown and Yoder 2015).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forests (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: This species is hunted.
conservationActions: It is listed on CITES Appendix I. It is known to occur in the Bora Special Reserve, as well as in the Anjiamangirana and Andalirano Classified Forests. However, it is believed that it will have little chance for long-term survival without additional conservation measures; such efforts should include the strengthening of infrastructure within Anjiamangirana I Forest, and the establishment of other protected zones in the forest fragments at Marosakoa, Anjajavy, Ambarijeby and Bekofafa. The species does also occur in Anjajavy forest, an area comprising ~10,000 hectares (including private Reserve ~1,200 ha and ~8,000 ha of recently protected area). Further surveys are needed to determine the full extent of its range and population status, and to confirm the taxonomic distinctiveness of this taxon. According to I. J. Porton, this species is not being kept in captivity (Mittermeier et al. 2010 and references therein).

rationale: There is a suspected population reduction of ≥30% in this species over a three-generation period (around 15 years, estimating the generation length to be 5 years). This time period includes both the past and the future (2009-2027). Causes of this reduction (which have not ceased) include continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting, both of which have accelerated in the recent past. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat:
Mirza zaza is a nocturnal lemur of approximately 300 g (Rode-Margono et al. 2016). An inhabitant of dry forests and the transition area to the more humid Sambirano area; also recorded from secondary forest, old banana plantations, gallery forests and abandoned cashew orchards. In contrast to the solitary Mirza coquereli, the gregarious M. zaza sleeps in groups of 2 to 8 animals including several males with fully developed testes (Kappeler et al. 2005, Rode 2010). Only 1–3 nests were used in a 50-day observation period, which indicates a high preference for and/or a scarcity of nest sites (Rode 2010). Tall trees with many lianas were preferred as nest sites, but microhabitat used during nightly activity consisted of tall trees and showed high forest density compared to random microhabitat (Rode 2010).

Individual home ranges were estimated to range from 0.5 to 2.2 ha, while group home ranges were between 1 ha and 2.4 (MCP method) (Rode 2010; Rode-Margono et al. 2016). When observed in the wild, animals are often found at a median height of 7 m (range 0-25m; Rode-Margono et al. 2016), and occasionally forage on the ground.

M. zaza is suggested to be the primate with the largest relative testis size (Rode 2010) and seems to be highly promiscuous (Kappeler et al. 2005, Rode 2010). It has been suggested that reproduction takes place throughout the year as opposed to a strict mating season in M. coquereli (Stanger et al. 1995, Rode 2010), though in other cases, it has been suggested that the mating season is believed to fall between July and August (Kappeler et al. 2005). Feeding on the sugary secretions of the larvae of homopteran Flatidae in the dry season may enable the species to reproduce aseasonally (Rode 2010). The species feeds on fruits, insect secretions, and plant ecudates (Rode-Margono et al. 2016).
threats: This species is at risk from forest clearance and slash-and-burn agricultural activities. Although individuals have been noted to survive in secondary and degraded forests, the dry forests where it lives are one of the fastest declining habitats of the island, with a decrease in forest cover of 40% from 1975 to 2000 (Moat and Smith 2007).
population:
The species lives in dry forests in north-western Madagascar, one of the fastest declining habitats of the island, with a decrease in forest cover of 40% from 1975 to 2000 (Rode et al. 2010). Survey efforts have failed to detect Mirza zaza in several regions within the species’ area of occurrence. It is likely that the species is concentrated in isolated forest fragments (Rode et al. 2010).

Within these forest fragments, Andrianarivo (1981) and Kappeler et al. (2005) both recorded high population densities for M. zaza. Their estimates of 385 individuals/km2 and 1,086 individuals/km2 are several times higher than those obtained for M. coquereli in the Kirindy Forest. The concentration of animals in more isolated forest fragments and the presence of mango, cashew, and other introduced food tree species in the Ambato region may help explain the higher densities, but further research is needed (Mittermeier et al. 2008).

Using data on group home range size and group size, Rode et al. (2010) indicated a range of population size from the maximum (occupancy of 80% of total area covered in dry forest approximately 1,650 km2) of 177,500 to a minimum (only fragments ≥1 km2 and smaller fragments closer than 500 m to other, larger fragments, that covers 955 km2) of 16,500. Rates of population decline mean that the species is now understood to be in sharp decline. Given the threats facing the species, it is suspected that the species is undergoing a population decline over a three-generation period (15 years) of at least 30% due to ongoing habitat loss and degradation.
range:
The geographic distribution of Mirza zaza appears to be limited by two large rivers: the Maevarano River in the south and the Mahavavy in the north (Markolf et al. 2008). It may be further separated by the Sambirano River, which crosses through the species’ distribution (Craul et al. 2007).

Specimens of M. zaza come from the region of the Ampasindava Peninsula in northwestern Madagascar, specifically from Ambato and Pasandava (Kappeler et al. 2005). Surveys and the genetic analysis of further specimens confirmed their presence at Ankiabe and Andranobe near Befotaka, in the Sahamalaza region at Ambendrana and Ankarafa forest and on Nosy Be (C. Schwitzer pers. comm., Markolf et al. 2008, Ramaromilanto 2009). Surveys in the province Mahajanga failed to confirm the presence of Mirza (Randrianambinina et al. 2003, Olivieri et al. 2005). Markolf et al. (2008) could confirm with genetics that individuals from Tsingy de Namoroka National Park are Mirza coquereli.

The species is found in dry forests in north-western Madagascar, one of the fastest declining habitats of the island, with a decrease in forest cover of 40% from 1975 to 2000 (Rode et al. 2010). Brown and Yoder (2015) estimated that the total distribution area of the species would decline 95% from the year 2000 to 2080 due to climate change alone.
useTrade: Little is known about the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: Listed on CITES Appendix I. The species is currently known to occur in only one national park (Sahamalaza-Iles Radama), but it may also be present in the foothills of the Manongarivo Special Reserve as well as in a few classified forests that lie within its distribution range (Antafondro, Andranomatavy, Anjanazanombandrany, Antsakay Kalobenono). Detailed surveys throughout the proposed area of occupancy are needed to determine the distribution and abundance of this species. Although the ISIS does not record this species to be held in captivity, there may be cases of misidentification of Mirza coquereli (A. Katz pers. comm.).

rationale: Due to high levels of habitat conversion and fragmentation, and illegal killing, Pongo tapanuliensis is estimated to have experienced a significant population reduction in recent decades. Forest loss data indicate that orangutan habitat below 500 m asl of both P. tapanuliensis and P. abelii was reduced by 60% between 1985 and 2007 (Wich et al. 2008, 2011). It is thought that this reduction will continue for the Tapanuli Orangutan as forests within its range remain under considerable threat (Wich et al. 2016). Significant areas of the Tapanuli Orangutan’s range are seriously threatened by habitat conversion for small-scale agriculture, mining exploration and exploitation, a large-scale hydroelectric scheme, geothermal development, and agricultural plantations. Approximately 14% of the geographic range of the Tapanuli Orangutan is not protected, nor even allocated as forest estate, and even the protected areas are not immune from the above threats (Wich et al. 2008, 2011, 2016). The Tapanuli Orangutan is also hunted (Wich et al. 2012). Due to their slow life history, with a generation time of at least 25 years (Wich et al. 2004, 2009), orangutans on Sumatra are unable to sustain substantial and continual loss of individuals. A quantitative population viability analysis estimated that in 1985 there were ~1,489 individuals of the Tapanuli Orangutan, and that these would decline to only 257 over a 75-year period to 2060 (Sumatran Orangutan Conservation Programme unpublished data). With current management, the key threats of loss of lowland habitat and hunting are not being effectively reduced, and we therefore predict an 83% decline over the course of three generations. The species therefore qualifies as Critically Endangered under criterion A4.
habitat:
Despite a complex geological history, the underlying parent material within the geographic range of Pongo tapanuliensis consists primarily of recent (i.e., Quaternary, <2.588 Ma) igneous rock, most of which is acidic volcanic rock from the Toba super-eruption of ~74 ka (Subardja et al. 1990, Oppenheimer 2002, Barber et al. 2005). This is in stark contrast to the north Sumatran Orangutan population that persists in forests atop older (i.e., Tertiary and above, >2.588 Ma) igneous and sedimentary rock (Darul Sukma et al. 1990a, 1990b, 1990c, 1990d, Hidayat et al. 1990, Hikmatullah et al. 1990, Wahyunto et al. 1990, Barber et al. 2005). While comparative data in the format analysed for Sumatra are lacking for Borneo, previously published reconstructions of Borneo’s geology highlighted a complex geological history that was in general different from that of Sumatra. This includes large swaths of landscape with pre-Cenozoic and Cenozoic sedimentary rock, with comparatively fewer areas characterized by igneous rock formations (Hall et al. 2008).

Using freely available WorldClim data (Hijmans et al. 2005), P. tapanuliensis can be differentiated from P. abelii by a highly narrow ecological niche, including a restricted upland elevation range (P. abelii: 701.7±454.8 m asl; P. tapanuliensis: 834.4±219.3 m asl), cooler average temperatures (P. abelii: 23.3±2.5°C; P. tapanuliensis: 22.1±1.2°C), and relatively high levels of average yearly rainfall (P. abelii: 2,435.1±460.5 mm/year; P. tapanuliensis: 2,607.5±231.2 mm/year).
