There is a particular need for field guides for this and other nocturnal Indonesian primate species especially in local languages, as they are often confused in rescue centres and elsewhere.

rationale: Nycticebus borneanus is listed as Vulnerable as there has been a more than 30% reduction in population over three generations (approximately 21-24 years) based on harvesting for the pet trade and extensive habitat loss. Although it is adaptable to anthropogenic change, forest loss has been so severe that it is likely to have had some negative impacts, with Borneo losing a third of its forest in less than 25 years, as also due to extensive fires.
habitat: As for other as other slow lorises (Nycticebus spp.), this species is nocturnal and arboreal. It has been observed in dipterocarp forest at Bukit Batikap Protected Forest, Central Kalimantan (Van Berkel 2011). Slow Lorises in Borneo are found in a range of habitats from heavily degraded to pristine rainforest, plantations, and lowland and montane forests (Nekaris et al. 2008, Thorn et al. 2009).
threats:
Burning and habitat conversion, especially to oil palm plantations, almost certainly represents a threat to this species. The Slow Loris species studied so far are relatively adaptable to anthropogenic change, although forest loss has been so severe that it is likely to have had some negative impacts, with Borneo losing a third of its forest in less than 25 years (Rautner and Hardino, 2005). Forest fires of 2015 in Borneo have been the worst since 2004, and acres of forest have been burned, leading to a significant decrease in the habitat of this species. In Indonesia, habitat fragmentation, deforestation and the lack of data available on the species habitat requirements are seen to be the most significant risks to this species.

The occurrence of Nycticebus menagensis in the illegal wildlife trade suggests that N. borneanus is also at risk of exploitation by the illegal wildlife trade. The species has not yet appeared in photographs of rescued individuals (Nekaris, pers. obs.). Legal penalties for illegal hunting, trafficking or selling lorises across their range are often not enforced, and the current penalty is not seen as a significant deterrent. In Indonesia, this species has specific uses in traditional medicine and ceremonies. Hybridization poses a real threat to this species both in the wild and for confiscated individuals in rescue centres.

Lack of law enforcement further threatens slow loris species across their range (Starr and Nekaris 2015, Nijman et al. 2014).
population: The only survey data available to date for this species is from a survey in Bukit Batikap Protected Forest, Central Kalimantan, where the species was recorded at densities of 0.05 individuals/km (Van Berkel, 2011). This species is believed to be in decline due overexploitation and loss of habitat from deforestation and forest fires.
range: Nycticebus borneanus is found in central south Borneo (West, South, and Central Kalimantan, but excluding the extreme southwest), south of the Kapuas River, extending as far east as the Barito River. This species may occur sympatrically with N. kayan or with N. menagensis (Munds et al. 2013).
useTrade:
In Indonesia, this species has specific uses in traditional medicine and ceremonies. Hybridization poses a real threat to this species both in the wild and for confiscated individuals in rescue centres. Legal penalties for illegal hunting, trafficking or selling lorises across their range are often not enforced, and the current penalty is not seen as a significant deterrent.

Lack of law enforcement further threatens slow loris species across their range (Nekaris and Starr, 2015; Nijman et al., 2014).
conservationActions:
This species is protected by Indonesian law and is included in Appendix I of CITES. Following the description of three new species on Borneo, surveys to assess the status of this species are required. Some forest fragments where the species is likely to occur remain protected. There is a particular need for field guides for this and other nocturnal Indonesian primate species, as they are often confused in rescue centres and elsewhere.

Long-term monitoring of populations, and increasing available data on the species ecology, behaviour and habitat requirements should be a top priority for this species. There are currently no existing education programmes for this species across its range and establishing education across its range are also important in order to address issues with the illegal use of Slow Lorises in the illegal wildlife trade.

rationale: Sumatran Slow Loris is listed as Endangered as there has probably been a more than 50% reduction in population over three generations (approximately 21-24 years), based on their past and predicted future abundance in the pet trade and extensive habitat loss throughout Sumatra.
habitat:
This species occurs in areas that are characterised as lowland forest, sub-montane forest, and montane forest in the Ulu Masen (Kasia et al. 2011). The species has been mentioned in several studies taking place in the Gunung Leuser ecosystem. In the Katembe area in Gunung Leuser they have been observed in primary rain forest and selectively logged forest (Rijksen 1978, van Schaik and Mirmanto 1985). They also occur in forests around Bukit Lawang.

During a field study in Aceh Sumatran slow lorises were observed catching insects and consuming bland fruits (Nekaris and Nijman, 2007). The diet of slow lorises generally consists of insects, nectars, and gums supplemented with occasional fruit and small vertebrates; exudates have emerged as a key resource and are most likely a key resource in the Sumatran slow loris’ diet as well, a prediction supported by their stout dentition and other morphological adaptations to this dietary specialisation (Das et al. 2014, Nekaris et al. 2010, Wiens et al. 2006).
threats: A key threat to the Sumatran Slow Loris is habitat loss (Kasia et al. 2011). Slow lorises are easy to catch when forest is converted. For example, in Aceh, local residents reported that when a large area of trees was cut for a transmigration of people scheme, a ‘loris man’ came to the area to collect lorises, which cling to cut trees rather than flee, for the pet trade (Nekaris and Nijman 2007, Nekaris and Munds 2010).
population: Surveys of northern Sumatra have found this species to occur at low densities. Nekaris and Nijman completed a 2007 survey in Aceh and found individuals in patches within the Ulu Masen forest complex. In the SP Limon one deceased loris was found along a transect and a small number of individuals were found in Jantho (0.39/km).  Local residents reported large-scale removal of lorises from this area just before the survey, which could explain the low encounter rates. Utami and Van Hooff (1997) reported three instances of Sumatran orangutans in the Ketambe area of Gunung Leuser consuming Sumatran slow lorises, and van Schaik et al. (2009) reported two instances of Sumatran orangutans consuming Sumatran slow loris in Suaq Balimbing.
range: This species occurs on the Indonesian island of Sumatra north of the Batang Toru River. It may occur on small surrounding islands, but this remains unknown.
useTrade:
Shepherd (2010) recorded heavy impact of the pet trade on the Sumatran slow loris, recording it as the most traded protected primate in Medan markets; it is also common in the markets of Java (Nijman et al. 2015). Similar to other Nycticebus species found in the pet trade, traders remove the teeth of the Sumatran slow loris to prevent them from biting owners, but this gruesome act regularly results in infection and death. Those with removed teeth are no longer eligible for reintroduction and those who are eligible for reintroduction are often released with a poor understanding of their taxonomy and geographical range. This species, which is limited to north Sumatra, has been haphazardly released in the southern regions of Sumatra and in Java.  

Since 2009 slow lorises have become increasingly popular on social media (Nekaris et al. 2013). Their exposure in this globalised market has increased their demand and has created a more accessible marketplace (Nekaris et al. 2015), further threating their wild populations and increasing rescue centre populations. This species has appeared on a number of viral videos outside of Indonesia, with a notable viral video emanating from Japan. No slow loris from Sumatra was ever legally traded to Japan, providing direct evidence of illegal international trade (Musing et al. 2015).
conservationActions:
The species occurs in protected areas throughout its range. In Indonesia, slow lorises are protected under Decree of Agriculture Ministry No. 66 of 1973, the Government Regulation No. 7 of 1999 concerning the Protection of Wild Flora and Fauna and Act No. 5 of 1999 concerning Biodiversity Conservation (Nekaris and Starr, 2015). Furthermore, Indonesia supported the 2007 up-listing of Nycticebus to CITES I (Nekaris and Nijman, 2007b).

Despite this protection, enforcement is challenging, and penalties issued in the rare instances when lorises are confiscated are meagre (Shepherd et al. 2005). Surveys and studies on the Sumatran slow loris are needed to confirm population densities and conservation threats.

Several rescue centres have been opened to receive Sumatran Slow Lorises from the illegal trade. Unfortunately, most of these centres do not distinguish between any slow loris species, and Sumatran forms (either N. hilleri or N. coucang) have been: released in the wrong location; released without health checks; released with no post release monitoring; released in large numbers in a single location (Collins et al. 2008). The last criterion is particularly dangerous since slow lorises are venomous. Venom is used as a defence against conspecifics. As slow lorises have very large highly defended ranges, this form of reintroduction is dangerous not only to the release but also to resident slow lorises. It is highly recommended that such well-meaning organisations follow the IUCN Recommendations for Translocations, as such reintroductions probably do more harm than good.

Some conservation education programmes are in place, but not systematic. For example, the Green Hill Biodiversity Project at Bukit Lawang has put into place conservation education packs regarding slow lorises for local residents and tourists.

rationale: This species' area of occupancy (AOO) covers between 500 and 1,272 km2. Moreover, its extent of occurrence covers about 4,359 km2. Within its known range the species' distribution is severely fragmented and it is undergoing habitat loss and fragmentation. Cheirogaleus shethi is categorised as Endangered.
habitat:
Cheirogaleus shethi inhabits dry deciduous, semi-humid and littoral forests, human-altered habitats (e.g. vanilla plantations) and savannah scrub forests (Hending et al. 2017, 2018). Several individuals have been observed feeding on fruit trees (Hending et al. 2017). No other information is available about its ecology and behaviour, nor is it known if/when this species enters seasonal torpor (as seen in other Cheirogaleus species). However, from fieldwork surveys they have been seen in activity between: i) March, May, July – December in Ankarana, Analamerana and Andrafiamena-Andavakoera (Frasier et al. 2016; J. Salmona pers. obs. 2012, 2013); ii) October, November, January – April in Loky-Manambato region (Hending et al. 2017, 2018; J. Salmona pers. obs. 2011).

It is the smallest (approx. 115 g) of the currently described Cheirogaleus species (Frasier et al. 2016).
threats: Threats to this species include energy production and mining, hunting, habitat degradation, and slash-and-burn agriculture.
population: Observation data are not sufficient to estimate population density. However, Hending et al. (2017) provided encounter rates suggesting that Cheirogaleus shethi population density may be high in the surveyed forests of the Loky-Manambato Protected Area. They estimated encounter rates ranging between 1.43 and 5 individuals per kilometre.
range:
This species occurs in northern Madagascar, between the Ankarana Special Reserve, Andrafiamena-Andavakoera Protected Area, Analamerana Special Reserve and Loky-Manambato Protected Area (Frasier et al. 2016, Hending et al. 2017, J. Salmona and B. Le Pors pers. obs.). A recent survey (Hending et al. 2017) found Cheirogaleus shethi individuals south of the Manambato River in a small semi-humid forest (Analamanara) and in vanilla plantations on the outskirts of a village (Mahasoa). The available data suggest that C. shethi ranges between 18 – 540 m in altitude (altitude data extracted from GPS points in Frasier et al. 2016 and Hending et al. 2017).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forests (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Little is known about the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: Cheirogaleus shehti occurs in several northern Madagascar protected areas: Ankarana Special Reserve, Analamerana Special Reserve, Andrafiamena-Andavakoera and Loky-Manambato Protected Areas (Category V). This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES.

rationale: Cheirogaleus andysabini is classified as Endangered as the extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is 650 km2. It is mainly known from one locality (<5 locations) (Montagne d’Ambre National Park), which is undergoing a continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits the Montagne d’Ambre rainforest (Lei et al. 2015). No other information is available about its ecology and behaviour.
threats: Habitat loss is due to production of khat, subsistence farming and charcoal production. Subsistence hunting is an additional threat to this species.
population: Currently there is insufficient data to estimate the population density for this species. However, we suspect population numbers to be in decline due to the loss of habitat occurring at Montagne d’Ambre National Park.
range: Cheirogaleus andysabini is endemic to northern Madagascar and known to occur in Montagne d’Ambre National Park and areas near the town of Joffreville, north-west of the Irodo River (Lei et al. 2015). Based on one museum sample collected in 1940 by Austin Rand, the species could be present in some forest fragments south of Montagne d’Ambre, at 15 km southwest of Tsarakibany (Lei et al. 2015). It ranges between 540 – 1,073 m in altitude. The estimated area of occurrence (AOO) is between 500 and 628 km2 and the species is known from less than 5 locations. More generally, this species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forests (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Subsistence hunting is a threat to this species.
conservationActions: The species inhabits the Montagne d’Ambre National Park (Lei et al. 2015). This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES.

rationale: This species is found in Ranomafana and Andringitra Parks. The species' description is based on 4 samples, two from Ranomafana (Talatakely and Vatoharanana) and two from Andringitra. Three additional samples listed in Groeneveld et al. (2010) were included in this species. It appears, however, that other samples from Ranomafana do not cluster with newly described Cheirogaleus grovesi, and sympatric dwarf lemur species may be present at Ranomafana. Additional morphological and genetic data are needed to fully characterize the species. Given that species' range is unknown, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Ranomafana and Andringitra contain montane rainforest, and this species is reported to occupy areas between 700 and 1,000 m. More studies are needed to find out whether this species also occupies areas within the corridor between Ranomafana and Andringitra, at lower elevations.
threats: The presence of this species within National Parks indicates it is more secure than other lemur species. Additional research is needed to determine the conservation status of this species (McLain et al. 2017).
population: No ecological studies have been conducted on this species.
range: This species is restricted to areas within Ranomafana National park and Andringitra.
conservationActions: Unknown.

rationale: This species is found in very small forest fragments on the Lavasoa Mountains, south-eastern Madagascar. Given that the EOO is less than 2,000 km2 and because this species occupies forests already highly fragmented and undergoing habitat loss and fragmentation (particularly in the Lavasoa area), we expect this species to be in decline. Based on these premises, Cheirogaleus lavasoensis is listed as Endangered.
habitat: This species was originally found in very small forest fragments on the Lavasoa Mountains, southeastern Madagascar, in habitats “situated within a transitional zone between dry spiny bush, humid littoral forest, and humid forest” (Thiele et al. 2013). There is no description of this species’ habitat in the Kalambatritra forest (Lei et al. 2014).
threats: The distribution of this species is very restricted geographically, and the main threat for this species is habitat loss and fragmentation.
population: Preliminary estimates by Thiele et al. (2013) reported less than 50 individuals left in the Lavasoa area. The population estimates of C. lavaoensis in the area recently included (Kalambatritra forest) is currently unknown.
range:
This species was thought to be restricted to forest fragments on the southern slopes of the main part of the Lavasoa mountains: at Grand Lavasoa, Petit Lavasoa and Ambatotsirongorongo. Most recently Lei et al., (2014) extended the northern range of this species to the Kalambatritra (Sahalava) forest (dwarf lemurs living in this forest were previously assigned to C. crossleyi).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
conservationActions: Habitat loss and fragmentation are a major threat for this species. More studies are needed to document the whole geographic range of this species.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 1,215 km². The species' distribution is severely fragmented, in particular the Sainte Luce area. The area and habitat where the species occurs is suspected to be declining and forests are being degraded. Mining activity proposes to further reduce the existing Sainte Luce littoral forest habitat. Given the expected impact of habitat loss, the species is suspected to be in decline. This species has been assessed as Endangered.
habitat: The species is frugivorous and insectivorous. It exhibits periods of reduced activity during the austral-winter and during August and September, activity increases in synchrony with forest productivity. In the littoral forests, important food resources include Vaccinium emirnense (Ericaceae) and Sarcolaena multiflora (Sarcolaenaceae) (S. Hyde Roberts pers. comm.). In both Sainte Luce and Ampasy (Tsitongambarika Protected Area), the species exhibits a preference for the forest edge (S. Hyde Roberts pers. comm., Balestri 2018).
threats: The main threat to this species is the rapid and extensive habitat loss due to slash-and-burn cultivation and harvesting of trees for construction and fire-wood. In the littoral forests of Sainte Luce, proposed mining operations pose also a threat to the remaining populations (Bollen and Donati 2006, Vincelette et al. 2007). Opportunistic hunting still occurs in Sainte Luce (S. Hyde Roberts pers. comm.).
population: Density estimates in the Sainte Luce littoral forests range between 0.2 and 3.2 individuals per hectare (Ganzhorn et al. 2007), while in the lowland rainforest of Ampasy (Tsitongambarika Protected Area) the values range between 0.7 and 1.3 (95% CI) (Balestri 2018). In the humid forest of Andohahela (Parcel 1) Microcebus tanosi occurs from 440 m to 1,875 m above sea level with encounter of up to 2.3 individuals per km transect (Feistner and Schmid 1999). Capture rates at the western edge of the species’ range are high compared to capture rates in Sainte Luce, indicating either very high population densities in this area, or lower food availability (Rakotondranary et al. 2011). The species is suspected to have a declining population due to a decline in habitat extent and quality.
range:
This species occurs in the wet forests of south-eastern Madagascar. The southern limit of this taxon seems to be the region of Manantantely in the southernmost portion of the Tsitongambarika Protected Area, west of Tolagnaro (Rasoloarison et al. 2013). The species is known to occur in the northern part of the Tsitongambarika Protected Area (E.E. Louis pers. comm., Campera et al. 2017) and in the littoral forest fragments of Sainte-Luce Conservation Area (S. Hyde Roberts pers. comm.). In Sainte Luce the species occupies all assessed forest fragments, and presently persists in even small forest remnants. South of Lokaro the species is replaced by Microcebus ganzhorni and the Lokaro River (Abizy) likely represents a boundary between the two species (S. Hyde Roberts pers. comm.). Based on phenotypic characteristics, M. tanosi is likely to extend to the western edge of the humid forest of Andohahela (Parcel 1).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
useTrade: Opportunistic hunting occurs in Sainte Luce (S. Hyde Roberts pers. comm.).
conservationActions: This species is known to occur in two newly protected areas: the Sainte Luce Conservation Area and the Tsitongambarika Protected Area, and likely also occurs in Parcel 1 of Andohahela National Park. Despite their status of protection, these areas are under heavy anthropogenic pressure with the former being also threatened by future mining plans. Thus, there is a need for further survey work to determine the full distribution, population status, ecology, and threats to Microcebus tanosi.

rationale: This species has been assessed as Endangered as the area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be between 12 and 260 km², and the extent of occurrence is estimated to be 458 km². The forests are severely fragmented with the largest fragments measuring less than 4 km². The size of most forest fragments is declining and forests are being degraded. The species does not seem to tolerate forest degradation and thus does not occupy all forest fragments of the region (Ganzhorn et al. 2007). Given the impact of habitat loss, the species is thought to be in decline.
habitat: The species is found exclusively in the littoral forests of south-eastern Madagascar. The forests range from the dry forest of Petriky (800 mm rain/year) to the wet forests of Ste Luce (around 2400 mm / year). The species is mainly frugivorous, living in pairs and hibernating for about several months per year between May and October. The need for large-sized trees as hibernacula might explain the dependency on intact forests with large trees that are no longer available in degraded forests. The species also uses Eucalyptus plantations to feed on Eucalyptus flowers. This might open up options to restore connectivity between isolated fragments of natural forests. Home ranges vary between 0.8 – 2.4 ha in the evergreen littoral forest of Mandena. Population densities are estimated at about 1 animal / ha, resulting in a few isolated populations, each with 50 – 300 individuals at the most. Females give birth to 2-4 young per litter. In these publications the species has been considered to belong to C. medius (Ganzhorn et al. 2007, Lahann 2007, 2008, Lahann and Dausmann 2011).
threats: The main threats to this species are habitat loss due to annual burning practices, harvesting of trees for charcoal production, clear-felling for agriculture and mining (Rasolofoharivelo 2007, Vincelette et al. 2007b). These threats seem to be under control at Mandena but continue over the rest of the species’ range.
population: Population densities are estimated at about 1 animal / ha, resulting in a few isolated populations, each with 50 – 300 individuals at the most.
range: The species is restricted to the littoral forest fragments of south-eastern Madagascar ranging from Petriky to Ste. Luce. It seems to be restricted to the coastal plain below 40 m altitude. The need for large-sized trees as hibernacula might explain the dependency on intact forests with large trees that are no longer available in degraded forests. The minimum estimated Area of Occupancy is 12 km<sup>2</sup>. The maximum estimated Area of Occupancy (AOO) is 260 km<sup>2</sup>.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES. It is known to occur in three new protected areas (nouvelles aires protégés): Petriky (126 ha, continuous forest), Mandena (231 ha, two connected forest fragments), Ambato Atsinanana (Sainte Luce) (1310 ha; several fragments including non-forested areas) and in the privately owned littoral forest of Lokaro. Given its restriction to littoral forests with very different ambient conditions, there is a need for further survey work to determine the full distribution, population status, ecology, and threats to Cheirogaleus thomasi. Conservation measures in the nouvelles aires protégés of Mandena seem to be very effective but conservation implementation at Petriky and Ste. Luce seems fragile. Even if the three nouvelles aires protégés will be protected efficiently, the total population would be subdivided in distinct subpopulations without the possibility to exchange individuals between populations.

rationale: Up to 2016, the south-eastern subpopulation of Grey Mouse Lemurs has been considered to represent a disjunct population of Microcebus murinus (Mittermeier et al. 2010). Based on samples from the littoral forest of Mandena a new form has been separated from M. murinus and been named as M. ganzhorni based on genetic grounds (Hotaling et al. 2016). Morphologically M. ganzhorni is indistinguishable from M. murinus and difficult to distinguish from M. griseorufus (M. griseorufus has a white belly with white underfur while M. murinus and M. ganzhorni have greyish underfur) and thus, taxonomic assignments in the field remain uncertain without genetic analyses. Given these uncertainty, the Extent of Occurrence was unclear at the time the species was described. New genetic analyses showed that M. ganzhorni does not occur in Andohahela National Park (Tiley, Poelstra, Yoder et al., unpubl. data) and does not move up the coastal mountains as this is the range of M. tanosi and M. manitatra (Rasoloarison et al. 2013, Donati et al. 2019). M. ganzhorni thus seems to be restricted to littoral forests east and possibly west of Fort Dauphin. In any case, the area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be above 10 km² but below 500 km². These forests are severely fragmented with the largest fragments measuring less than 2 km². The size of most forest fragments is declining and forests are being degraded. The species tolerates forest degradation and occurs in a wide range of different habitats, including gardens. The population east of Fort Dauphin seems panmictic (Montero et al. 2019). Forest fragments outside the protected area decline rapidly due to mining, thus reducing the AOO predictably. It is considered Endangered based on the AOO.
habitat: The species is frugivorous and insectivorous, promiscuous, and can go into hibernating for variable periods of time. Home ranges are less than 1 ha for females and can increase to up to 5 ha for males in the evergreen littoral forest of Mandena. Females have 2-3 litters per year and give birth to more than 2 young per litter. Density estimates in Mandena range between 2.6 and 21.4 individuals per hectare, while in Petriky between 3.0 and 9.3. In these publications, the species has been considered to belong to Microcebus murinus (Lahann et al. 2006, Ganzhorn et al. 2007, Lahann 2007, 2008, Schmid and Ganzhorn 2009, Malone et al. 2013). In Mandena the effective population size has been estimated to be around 200 individuals (Montero et al. 2019).
threats: The main threats to this species are habitat loss due to annual burning practices, harvesting of trees for charcoal production and clear-felling for agriculture and mining (Rasolofoharivelo 2007, Vincelette et al. 2007a,b). These threats seem to be under control at the “Nouvelle Aire Protégée” Mandena but continue over the rest of the species’ range.
population: It is suspected that the population is declining due to a decrease in habitat extent and quality.
range:
The species is known from the littoral forests of south-eastern Madagascar. The forests range from the dry forest of Petriky (800 mm rain/year; west of Fort Dauphin) to the wet forests of Mandena (around 1,600 mm rain / year). Based on mtDNA analyses, it is unlikely (though not entirely excluded) that the animals at Petriky belong to Microcebus ganzhorni. Also, it is unknown whether or not the species extends west of Petriky; though there are hardly any forests left. If so, these forests have to be classified as spiny forest where the species is unlikely to occur. Towards the east of Fort Dauphin, an individual with the same haplotype as found in Mandena has been described from Lokaro (Gligor et al. 2009, Hapke et al. 2011). North of Lokaro the species is replaced by Microcebus tanosi. The form occurring in the transitional forests of Andohahela was depicted as representing a continuous population including Andohahela and the littoral forests. New genetic analyses show that the form of the dry forest of Andohahela is as distinct from M. ganzhorni in Mandena as it is from M. manitatra (Tiley, Poelstra, Yoder et al., unpubl. data).

This species is likely affected by national trends in forest habitat loss: Madagascar lost 37% of its forest cover from 1973 to 2014, with an annual deforestation rate of 1.1%/year from 2010 to 2014. Almost half of Madagascar's forest (46%) is now located within less than 100 metres from the forest edge (Vieilledent et al. 2018).
conservationActions: This species is known to occur in two “New protected areas” (nouvelles aires protégés): Petriky (126 ha, continuous forest) and Mandena (231 ha, two connected forest fragments) and in Lokaro (private reserve). Though Microcebus ganzhorni occur in a wide range of habitats (Andriamandimbiarisoa et al. 2015, Eppley et al. 2015, Montero et al. 2019), the Area of Occupancy is estimated to be between 10 and 500 km² and the effective population size is only around 200 individuals in the Mandena region. There is a need for further survey work to determine the distribution, population status, ecology, and threats to Microcebus ganzhorni at the western limits of its range.

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of Microcebus mamiratra covers less than 50 km2. The site of the holotype is a forest patch of ~25 ha in the Ambatotsirongorongo forest. It is a smallest of a complex of fragments (the others known as Grand Lavasoa and Petit Lavasoa), remnants of a large forest block in the southern part of the Lavasoa mountains characterized by spiny bush on the west, humid lowland to the north and littoral humid forest to the east (Donque 1972). Historical land cover maps indicate that these forests have not been directly connected to other forests for more than 40 years (Donati, pers. comm.). According to Hapke et al. (2012) the ecological complexity of the Lavasoa–Ambatotsirongorongo mountains and the close geographical proximity of several mouse lemur species in the area (M. griseorufus on the west, M. tanosi on the north, and M. ganzhorni on the east in the Mandena littoral forest) can be regarded as a micromodel of the retreat and expansion of various forest types and their resident mouse lemur species. This area is severely fragmented and is undergoing continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat:
This species is found in the humid forest fragment at Ambatotsirongorongo and possibly in the littoral forest of Petriky, ~ 5 km to the East (Hapke et al. 2012).

Microcebus manitatra is a relatively large mouse lemur characterized by its size (total length of 270–276 mm and body mass of 58 g), long tail with dense, short fur (150 mm), relatively short hind feet (33 mm) and long ears (25–26 mm). The dorsal pelage is uniformly greyish brown on the back and tail and the underside is a greyish beige with dark grey underfur. This contrasts with M. murinus which has a variable greyish-brown to brownish-grey back and tail with a dull reddish-brown or cinnamon mid-dorsal stripe, as well as a mixed beige and grey underside (Hotaling et al. 2016).
threats: The greatest threats for the survival of Microcebus manitatra are habitat loss and degradation driven by wood extraction, slash-and-burn cultivation, and fires (Hapke et al. 2012). The forest is surrounded by agriculture fields and cattle pastures, and the forest conversion for manioc (cassava) and banana production is a threat (Ramanamanjato et al. 2002). The forest is managed by local communities via an association of neighbouring villages (FIMPIAA). Its conservation value has long been recognized and several conservation projects have been conducted over the last years. However, the extremely small size of the forest left in the area and the increasing anthropogenic pressures due to the proximity of the town of Fort Dauphin call for further and immediate conservation actions.
population: This species is rare within a very restricted area across different patches of habitat, and in decline due to habitat loss and degradation. Neither census estimates nor eco-ethological data are available for Microcebus manitatra. Currently its distribution is only officially confirmed within the 25ha Ambatotsirongorongo fragment, thus population size is expected to be very small.
range: The species is only officially confirmed within the 25 ha Ambatotsirongorongo fragment, thus population size is expected to be very small. However, it is likely that the Microcebus sp. cf. murinus present in the other two fragments within the Nouvelle Aire Protégée of Ambatotsirongorongo is also manitatra resulting in a total area of 105ha. mtDNA analyses indicate that the mouse lemur population in Petriky, a 300 ha littoral forest 5 km east of Ambatotsirongorongo, clusters within the same clade of M. manitatra (Hapke et al. 2012). If this result should be confirmed by future analyses, this would increase several times the population size of this highly threatened mouse lemur species. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be less than 50 km2.
conservationActions: The holotype comes from the Nouvelle Aire Protégée of Ambatotsirongorongo, which contains an unusual and highly diverse mixture of lemurs including one species of dwarf lemur previously listed (2014-16) in the World’s 25 most endangered primates publication, Cheirogaleus lavasoensis. This makes these tiny transitional forest fragments in the south-eastern corner of Madagascar a very high conservation priority.

rationale: Microcebus boraha was identified as a new species by Hotaling et al. (2016) but little is known about this species other than its range, which is limited to Nosy Boraha (Ile St Marie) in eastern Madagascar. Though this species is likely to be declining in population (as a result of habitat degradation and destruction, as well as hunting and the pet trade), it is assessed as Data Deficient pending further studies. Nothing is known about the species’ population or ecology.
habitat: This species is found only on Ile St Marie. The type locality is 68 metres above sea level (Hotaling et al. 2016). This species is considered relatively large, compared to other mouse lemurs (Hotaling et al. 2016).
threats: There is no known information regarding threats facing this species. However, given that this species is found across the Ile St Marie, it is possible that threats include habitat degradation and destruction, as well as hunting and the pet trade.
population: There have been no field studies on this species that can provide this kind of information.
range: This species is limited to Nosy Boraha (Ile St Marie) in eastern Madagascar and has a maximum EOO of 237 km2.

rationale: Aotus miconax is listed as Endangered based upon a suspected population decline of more than 50% due to a corresponding decline in extent of occurrence and habitat quality, as well as ongoing exploitation that has impacted one previous generation (2010-2018) and will likely impact at least two subsequent generations (2019-2035).
habitat:
This species occurs in the humid and very humid lower montane and montane cloud forests of north eastern Peru, white sand forests and Podocarpus spp. and Alzatea verticillata dominated forests. (Shanee et al. 2015). Aotus miconax occurs in primary and secondary forest (including disturbed forest, selectively logged and agroforestry ecosystems) (Cornejo et al. 2008, Shanee and Shanee 2011, Shanee et al. 2015, Shanee et al. 2013).

As with most night monkeys, this species is nocturnal with an activity peak at the beginning of the night (Shanee et al. 2013). In one study this species averaged 54% of their time travelling, 13% resting and 33% feeding; their diet consists of fruits (42%), flowers (5%), leaves (6%), buds (25%) and insects (19%). Favourite arboreal food sources include Styloceras laurifolium, Cercropia montana, C. utcubambana, Hyeronima andina, Ficus eximia, Casearia decandra, Chrysophyllum venezuelanense, Ceroxylon peruvianum, Neosprucea montana, Solanum sp., Inga feuillei, Bunchosia armeniaca and Styrax sp.(Shanee et al. 2013).

They are socially monogamous, living in small groups of up to six individuals (Shanee et al. 2013), consisting of an adult pair and offspring of different ages (infant, one or two juveniles and sometimes a sub-adult, with solitary individuals of both sexes found (Shanee et al. 2011), possibly sub-adults that have left their natal groups or older adults which have been evicted from their groups by competitors (Fernandez-Duque and Huntington 2002; Fernandez-Duque 2004). Both sexes disperse. Males carry and care for the infants (Rotundo et al. 2005).
threats: The Andean Night Monkey (Aotus miconax) is endemic to Peru, where it is threatened by deforestation, habitat disturbance and hunting. Shanee et al. (2015), conducting field surveys from 2009 to 2013 and using combined GIS and ecological niche modelling, estimated the species’ original extent of suitable habitat at close to 33,000 km², the third lowest of the 11 Aotus species. Of this, approximately 17,700 km² of suitable habitat remained at the completion of those surveys, representing a loss of close to 50% (up to 2013). Habitat loss within three of the four provinces in which A. miconax is found—Amazonas, Huanuco and San Martin—has been disproportionately high, accounting for nearly 40% of Peru’s total deforestation during the period 2010-2014, this within only 14% of the national land surface (Ministerio del Ambiente – Peru 2015). Forest loss and fragmentation continue, especially within the peripheral areas of this species’ range, with an expansion of mining and large-scale monocultures reaching higher into the Andean foothills. Hunting for food follows immigration into new areas, with young night monkeys also routinely taken as pets in the process. Given that this species appears to adapt to shrinking habitats, it's rate of decline may not be as precipitous, but is still sufficiently significant to qualify it as threatened.
population: Little is known about the population characteristics of Aotus miconax. In some areas it appears to remain fairly common in forest patches and even able to persist in agroforestry ecosystems and shade coffee plantations (Shanee et al. 2015, Shanee et al. 2011, Shanee et al. 2013). However, rates of habitat loss approaching 50% throughout large portions of its distribution undoubtedly have negatively impacted populations to significant degrees.
range: Aotus miconax is endemic to the Peruvian Andes, occurring south and east of the Río Marañón and west of the Río Huallaga in the departments of Amazonas, Huánuco, La Libertad, San Martin and possibly areas of Loreto (Hershkovitz 1983; Aquino and Encarnación 1994a; Shanee et al. 2015). Shanee et al. (2015) suggested distributional limits for this species as the highlands of La Libertad and the Río Marañón to the west, the lowlands of the Río Marañón in Amazonas to the north and the lowlands of Loreto to the north-east, the lowlands of the Rio Huallaga valley to the east. The southern limit of this species distribution is still not well defined but A. nancymaae is present to ~1,000 m asl. in this area (Shanee et al. 2015). Aquino and Encarnacion (1994) suggest this species is found south to the Rio Aguaytia. This species has been recorded at elevations from 800 to 3,100 m asl. (Campbell 2011; Shanee et al. 2015).
useTrade: This species is traded illegally in the local markets for pets (Shanee 2012).
conservationActions:
This species occurs in several protected areas:
  • Abiseo National Park (274,500 ha) (Aquino and Encarnación 1994)
  • Cordillera de Colán (Butchart et al. 1995)
  • Bosque de Proteccion Alto Mayo ((Delukyer 2007, Shanee 2011).
  • Zona Reservada Rio Nieva (S. Shanee  unpubl.)
This species also occurs in several private and communal protected areas ranging in size from 3,000 to 50,000 ha. It is listed on Appendix II of CITES.

rationale: Listed for the first time, this species is classified as Data Deficient, as the present geographic range is poorly known. No specific threats are known, but the taxon is suspected to be declining owing to continuing habitat conversion to agriculture and the development of new human settlements. In addition, there is evidence that an illegal live animal trade exists.
habitat: North of the Blue Nile, the species is known from typical arid woodland (Alatish National Park; Mengesha and Bekele 2008). South of the Blue Nile, in the Benishangul-Gumuz National Regional State, the species has been observed in a mosaic of bamboo forest, woodland, riparian forest and cultivated land (Yirga et al. 2010).
threats:
Resettlement schemes in the Western Ethiopia carried out in the 1980s are reason for concern regarding the future of wildlife of the region (Herrmann et al. 2007, Heckel 2009). 

Illegal trade in live animals may also be a threat.
population: No detailed information available. The paucity of historical data and absence of museum voucher specimens from Ethiopia suggest that the species was never at particularly high densities there.
range: Restricted to the region between the Nile and the Western Ethiopian Escarpment. Known northern limit is around Metemma, while the southern limits are the Sudd swamps, including Gambela swamp, and the Ethiopian highlands, which extend to the Sudanese border north of Gambela. Although no definitive record is known, the species may well occur in present-day South Sudan along the border with Sudan and Ethiopia.
useTrade: The presence of this species in some zoos in China and the Arabian peninsula suggests that a trade of live individuals exists. This was confirmed by some photos showing several young Blue Nile patas monkeys offered for sale by a Sudanese animal trader.
conservationActions:
The genus is listed on CITES Appendix II. 

Conservation activities should, at the moment, be centred around the Dinder-Alatish protected area system. However more extensive surveys are needed, as a project of citizen-science asking local people in Western Ethiopia (but also Sudan and South Sudan) of reporting the local presence of this distinctive primate. Additionally, selection of further conservation areas in Benishangul-Gumuz Region is urgently needed.

rationale: Galagoides kumbirensis is listed as Near Threatened due to an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of just over 20,000 km², the species being known from fewer than 10 locations, and an inferred continuing decline in the area, extent and quality of the habitat. Therefore, it nearly qualifies for a threatened listing under criterion B1ab(iii). The species is currently confirmed to occur in four locations on the Angolan Escarpment (Bersacola et al. 2015, Svensson et al. 2017), where habitat loss due to commercial timber harvesting, farming and charcoal production is rapidly increasing. Severe habitat loss is occurring at key forest sites in the range of G. kumbirensis (Bersacola et al. 2015, Cáceres et al. 2016). A priority taxon for further survey work.
habitat: This nocturnal species is poorly known. Galagoides kumbirensis has been found in moist, tall forest (primary and secondary) and semi-arid baobab savanna woodland, in areas where tree-lined water courses allowed access. The species was observed using mid to high strata, at an average height of 12.5 m (range 3–18 m) (Bersacola et al. 2015, Svensson et al. 2017).
threats:
The habitats where Galagoides kumbirensis has been observed are under great pressure from commercial timber logging and deforestation for farming and charcoal production (Hansen et al. 2013, Bersacola et al. 2015, Cáceres et al. 2016). Bersacola et al. (2015) classified pressure on habitats by scoring disturbance levels from none and low (indication of human presence, e.g., cut branches, small tree stumps, gun cartridges) to (>60% of the vegetation appeared affected/damaged due to human activity, e.g., recent heavy logging). Forests along the central and northern parts of the Angolan Escarpment, where this species occurs (Svensson et al. 2017), are disappearing at alarming rates of late (Hansen et al. 2013, M. Mills, pers. comm. 2017).

Additionally, with oil prices currently decreasing, the government's plans are to increase efforts in harvesting wood for commercial timber (M. Mills pers. comm. 2017). Hansen et al. (2013) highlight Angola as a country with increasing forest cover loss. Data from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations indicate that Angola lost an estimated 5% of its forest cover in the period 1990–2015, with an annual loss rate of 0.2% (FAO, 2015). More studies are needed to assess the impacts of habitat alteration on this species.
population: No population information is available for this species. However, Bersacola et al. (2015) report an encounter rate of 0.17–2.67 individuals/km in northwestern Angola.
range: Galagoides kumbirensis is likely to be endemic to the Escarpment areas in northwestern Angola (Svensson et al. 2017). It is possible that the species range extends to the southern parts of Democratic Republic of Congo, near the border with Angola (Bersacola et al. 2015); however, further research is needed to confirm this.
useTrade: There is no known trade or use of this species.
conservationActions:
Galagoides kumbirensis is included on CITES Appendix II, as all Primates are listed on Appendices II.

The known range of G. kumbirensis does not fall under any protected areas, but more distribution surveys are needed on the species to confirm its real range.

rationale: Hoolock tinxiang is considered Endangered A4cd. A suspected population decline caused by significant and accelerating rates of deforestation is projected to continue and perhaps accelerate. Combined with the facts that more than 90% of the population is believed to occur outside of protected areas, and the species continues to be hunted for food and medicinal purposes, a population loss equalling or exceeding 50% can be anticipated over three generations (between the years 2000 and 2045).
habitat:
This gibbon is a forest-dweller that inhabits primary evergreen, scrub and semi-deciduous hill forest, as well as mountainous broadleaf forest, but it cannot survive in pine-dominated forest. It ranges up to 2,700 m in elevation in Mt. Gaoligong (P.-F. Fan et al. 2013). The annual mean temperature is 13.3 °C and 13.1°C at two sites of Mt. Gaoligong. Gibbon habitat can be covered by snow in cold winters.

Two habituated groups are well studied by Fan Peng-Fei. and his team. Annual diet of a group in Mt. Gaoligong comprised 49.1% fruit (non-fig fruit 35.6%and fig 13.5%), 43.3% leaves (buds, young and mature leaves), 5.3% invertebrates and bird chicks, 1.8% flowers, and 0.6% others. Individuals prefer ripe fruits when they are available. They shift their diet to leaves and buds and  increased feeding time when fruits and figs are not available (P.-F. Fan et al. 2013). Groups use large home ranges (93 and 178 ha for two groups), and use different sections monthly (P.-F. Fan et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2014). Their daily travel distance varied from month to month (group BB: mean = 1,308 ± SD 735 m, range = 272–3,705 m, N = 60 days; group NA: mean = 1126 ± SD 488 m, range = 345–2,606 m, N = 52 days (P.-F. Fan et al. 2017), mostly depends on their diet and food availability. They decrease travel distance when they eat more leaves (Zhang et al. 2014).

Adults live in pairs and coordinate their singing to produce duet bouts that lasted for an average 25.5 min. Paired adults never produce solo bouts unless they are separated by human disturbances. The singing rate (number of bouts/number of monitoring days) of four groups in Mt. Gaoligong range from 7.5% to 31.4% which was lower than other gibbon populations, presumably due to low group density and prevalence of hunting at the study site (Yin et al., 2016).  One group stop calling for 68 days after at least 30 gunshots were heard from its home range.

Like other gibbons, Skywalker Hoolock Gibbons sleep in tall trees, and rarely use the same tree on consecutive days. They travel very fast to enter sleeping trees 2-3 hours before sunset. They mostly sleep on branches of diameter less than 10 cm and close to tree tops. Anti-predation is an important factor that affects Skywalker Hoolock Gibbon’s sleeping behavior (P.-F. Fan et al. 2017).

Neighbouring groups rarely fight along territory borders. Only one inter-group conflict was recorded in four years (Yin et al. 2016).
threats:
In China, although commercial logging has been banned, Hoolock tinxiang is threatened by small-scale habitat loss, degradation, fragmentation, and hunting (Fan et al. 2011, Yin et al. 2016). Local people believe that the brain of hoolock gibbons can be used to cure epilepsy. Nearly half of the remnant population now live in agro-forestry complexes (e.g., cardamom cultivation). Although cardamom cultivation causes some negative effects on gibbons, these agro-forestry complexes provide important gibbon habitat provided they are not too fragmented and hunting is prohibited (Zhang et al. 2014).

In Myanmar, H. tinxiang remains threatened by habitat loss due largely to slash-and-burn agriculture, gold mining and logging, and secondarily by hunting for food and medicinal purposes (Ni et al. 2018).  Unfortunately, the species is not known to occur in any protected areas in this country.  According to the most recent Global Forest Watch (2019) data for Myanmar, the six administrative divisions in which H. tinxiang is believed to occur - Shan, Mandalay, Kayah, Bago, Kayan and Mon - have lost nearly 9% of their forest cover since 2000, are collectively losing forest at a rate above the national average, and that rate has accelerated significantly in recent years. The previous gibbon generation (2000–2015) could have been expected to decline at a corresponding rate, and the present generation (2016–2030) and subsequent generation (2031–2045) can be expected to decline at a corresponding rate as well - this would result in a population decline related to habitat loss of at least 30%.  Should the current rate of loss continue to accelerate, which it appears to be doing, and hunting continue as well, a decline in population approaching or exceeding 50% can easily be anticipated.
population:
In China, the population is estimated to be approximately 200 individuals in nine (9) subpopulations (Fan et al. 2017).

In Myanmar, population estimates have ranged between 10,000 and 50,000 individuals (Geissmann et al. 2013). Even at the lower end of that range, the Myanmar population would represent at least 98% of the species' total.

Based on deforestation data for Myanmar since 2000, the region inhabited by this species has already experienced a significant and accelerating loss of forest. It is not known to occur in any protected areas of that country. Continued deforestation over the current and subsequent generation (2019 to 2045), combined with hunting for food and medicinal purposes) could plausibly result in a population reduction exceeding 50%.
range: In Myanmar, this species is found between the Irrawaddy-Nmai Hka River and the Salween River (P.-F. Fan et al. 2017). In China, wild individuals are confirmed to occur on Mt. Gaoligong. Historical museum specimens are also known from further south at Gokteik, Shan States, northern Myanmar (P.-F. Fan et al. 2017).
useTrade: In Myanmar, commercial logging is ongoing, and hunting is serious problem. Nearly every year, a few small juveniles and infants of hoolock gibbons (mostly H. leuconedys) are illegally exported to China (Ni et al., 2018).
conservationActions:
Half of the remnant Chinese population of Hoolock tinxiang  occurs in the Gaoligong National Nature Reserve (P.-F. Fan et al. 2017). A small NGO (Cloud Mountain Conservation) is working with local governments and forestry bureaus to protect this species and its habitat in China. Cloud Mountain Conservation educate local residents, especially school children, around Skywalker Hoolock Gibbon habitat, and support reserves to increase patrol.

Although a number of wildlife sanctuaries can be found within the range of Hoolock tinxiang in Myanmar, none are reported to harbor this species.

rationale: Piliocolobus tholloni is considered Vulnerable A2cd+3cd. A suspected population decline of >30% over the course of the last two generations (2000-2017), caused by a dramatic increase of unregulated commercial bushmeat hunting since the Congo wars, is likely to continue over the course of the current generation (2018-2026), as this species is still preferred by many hunters. Although no detailed population data exists, the species has not been observed recently in three of the six protected areas in which it is previously reported to have occurred (Iyondji Community Bonobo Reserve, Kokolopori Bonobo Reserve, Luo Scientific Reserve), raising questions regarding its possible or eventual extirpation in those protected areas. Ongoing habitat loss also contributes to the presumed population decline.
habitat:
To date, there has been one detailed study of Piliocolobus tholloni ecology at the Botsima study site along the Lomela River in SNP (Maisels et al. 1994). Botsima was protected from hunting pressure, and contained patches of swamp, seasonally-flooded and terra firma forest habitat. The habituated study group included over 60 individuals and ranged throughout the 250 ha study site. Maisels et al. (1994) collected feeding data for 12 months and reported that the group’s diet consisted of 60.7% leaves (54.3% young, 6.4% mature), 30.8% seeds, 7.1% ripe fruit, and 1.4% flowers. P. tholloni in the study ate mostly legumes, and the leaves and seeds came from species in the Caesalpinioideae subfamily. In the Etate Surveillance Zone of SNP, an area with active poaching patrols, maximum group sizes were 45 individuals (n = 73 group sightings, average group size = 12.6 individuals) and 31 individuals (n = 28 group sightings, average group size = 13.9 individuals) for two different patrol survey periods in 2014 (Reinartz pers. comm. 2016).

In the Lukuru study area at the southern limit of the species’ range, P. tholloni ranges in upland dry forest, utilising the middle canopy (Thompson 2000). At the eastern edge of the range in LNP, the species is common in terra firma forests characterized by clay soils and small rivers that cut narrow valleys across the landscape, but it avoids seasonally-inundated forest. At the Losekola study site in LNP, 39 groups of P. tholloni were encountered during transect walks (total transect length = 143 km) and group size counts ranged from 5-63 individuals (average group size = 29.9 individuals), including two groups each estimated to have over 90 individuals (J. Hart unpublished survey data, 2008). P. tholloni is reported to occur frequently in mixed-species groups of primates in Lukuru and in LNP (Thompson 2000, Lukuru Foundation 2015). The species appears to be limited to closed canopy forests and has not been recorded in gallery forests south of the main forest block.
threats:
Across its range, P. tholloni is vulnerable to hunting, which has increased markedly since the Congo wars (1996-2003). Observations during wildlife surveys in the upper Tshuapa Basin, between the Tshuapa and the Lomami rivers, suggest that P. tholloni may be one of the first primate species hunted out, because they are large and slow to flee (A. Vosper pers. comm. 2007). In some areas, for example Lukuru, P. tholloni appears to be targeted by local hunters because they have a preference for its meat, and some hunters say that church teachings attributed the flavour of P. tholloni to divine intervention (Thompson 2000). However, hunting threats are not uniform, and the species does not always appear to be selected for. For example, before the establishment of the LNP, in the Obenge sector where P. tholloni is common, six shotgun hunters who were monitored on 17 hunting trips, killed P. tholloni only twice (a total 4 individuals; J. Hart pers. obs, 2009). These hunters killed other primate species (total 14 individuals, mostly Cercopithecus spp.), as well duikers and pigs. Five bow hunters in the same sector were monitored on nine hunts, and killed P. tholloni five times (a total of 7 individuals), which represented the entire kill for these hunters (J. Hart, pers. obs.). Market surveys, where groups of similarly-aged fresh carcasses are displayed together, suggest multiple kills at the same event (Thompson 2000, Thompson and Hart 2015). P. tholloni carcasses represented 36% of 229 carcasses recorded over a one-month period at the Basankusu markets (Dupain and van Elsacker 1999, cited in Thompson 2000). A market survey in Lusambo in 2011 recorded P. tholloni accounting for 5% of total carcasses (G. Paluku and E. Mpaka, Lukuru Foundation pers. comm. to via J. Hart, 2016).

Although hunting is the main conservation threat, habitat loss and degradation due to logging and conversion of forest to agricultural landscapes is a growing threat to this species (Harris et al. 2017). For example, the Sankuru Reserve and Lusambo region, important forest areas in the southeast of P. tholloni’s range, have been identified as new hot spots of forest loss from 2000-2014 (Harris et al. 2017).
population:
There are no overall population estimates for this species; however, the species can be locally abundant if not hunted.

The large forest blocks and the corridor region of Salonga National Park (SNP) harbour an important population of P. tholloni; however, hunting occurs throughout the region (Liengola et al. 2010, Maisels et al. 2009, 2010, WCS 2015, WCS 2016). Recent surveys conducted in the northern and southern blocks of SNP and the corridor between the two document that P. tholloni is widely distributed in the protected area, but rare (Maisels et al. 2009, 2010, WCS 2015, WCS 2016). In 2016, field researchers conducting bonobo and elephant surveys in the Watsi Kengo sector of SNP (an area ~4,443 km² between the Yenge and Salonga rivers) recorded opportunistic sightings of P. tholloni and estimated that ~600 individuals occurred over two-thirds of the sector (pers. comm. to Reinartz 2016).

In the eastern part of the range, P. tholloni is widespread in Lomami National Park (LNP) and adjoining buffer zone, ranging from the southern limit of the closed forest (3°S Latitude) northwards to the vicinity of Opala (0.5°S Latitude), west of the Lomami River. P. tholloni is common in some sectors of the park, notably Obenge and Losekola (0.27 groups/km, J. Hart unpublished survey data, 2008).

The species was not detected during multiple surveys of the northern Maringa-Lopori-Wamba (MLW) landscape between 2000 and 2014 (Likondo Lokonga 2006, Omasombo and Mpiana 2006, Lushimba 2012, Maputla 2014, Kasa et al. 2015), although there is evidence that P. tholloni occurred historically in the greater Wamba area (Colyn 1991, Thompson 2000). In 2009, P. tholloni was present but very rare in the western Sankuru Nature Reserve, an area where hunting occurs (Liengola et al. 2009). There may be a small population in the Kokolopori Bonobo Reserve; however they have not been detected recently within the ~50 km² bonobo study area of the reserve (M. Surbeck pers. comm. 2016). P. tholloni has not been recorded in the Luo and Lomako reserves (Thompson 2000). It was not encountered during recent surveys of the Luo Scientific Reserve and adjacent Iyondji Community Bonobo Reserve, although rare sightings have been reported in the Iyondji area in the past (Sakamaki et al. 2016).
range: Piliocolobus tholloni is a little-known taxon endemic to the Democratic Republic of Congo. The species has a patchy distribution in the forests south of the Congo River and west of the Lomami River (Thompson 2000). The southern limits are bounded by the Kasai and Sankuru rivers (Struhsaker and Grubb 2013, Thompson 2000). The only other Red Colobus taxon to range south of the Congo River is Piliocolobus parmentieri, and the ranges of these two allopatric species are separated by the Lomami River. Piliocolobus tholloni has not been found at a number of sites where primate surveys have been conducted, and where the species was expected, suggesting that variation in the age and floristic composition of the forests, along with differences in human disturbance and hunting pressure, may be important in determining the current distribution of the species (Thompson 2000). In addition, rivers bisecting forest regions across the basin likely contribute to the patchy distribution of P. tholloni; for example, this species is known to be absent on the right bank of the Lomela River, but present on the left bank.
useTrade: Hunted for bushmeat
conservationActions:
Piliocolobus tholloni is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. The species is present in the Lomami National Park, Salonga National Park and the Sankuru Nature Reserve. It is also known to have occurred in the Iyondji Community Bonobo Reserve, Kokolopori Bonobo Reserve and the Luo Scientific Reserve.  However, recent surveys in these areas have not encountered red colobus monkeys, so its status is questionable. The species was originally provided total protected status in 1937 by the colonial administration. This was repealed in 1985, leaving the species protected only by local or provincial based hunting seasons (Thompson 2000). As of 2006, P. tholloni is included in the protected species list by the Ministry of the Environment of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and thus is fully protected by national law (Enerunga 2006). However, the unregulated hunting that occurs throughout its range, including the killing of P. tholloni, indicates that there is currently inadequate enforcement of this law.

Efforts to control the killing of P. tholloni can have an impact if multiple points along the bushmeat chain are targeted consistently (Hart and Hart 2011). Before the wildlife laws were enacted, P. tholloni represented > 3% of 4,382 animals arriving in the urban bushmeat markets of Kindu (Hart and Hart 2009). In 2010, following enactment and enforcement of hunting laws, numbers of carcasses dropped, and in 2015 P. tholloni was not found among 6,155 animals recorded (Kabongo 2016; Lukuru Foundation, TL2 Project, unpublished data, 2009, 2016).

rationale: Piliocolobus oustaleti is listed as Vulnerable, despite having a large geographic range, as this genetically, morphologically and ecologically variable taxon has declined over the past decade or more, and the decline is expected to accelerate in the future. Like all other red colobus species (Struhsaker 2005), Oustalet’s Red Colobus is slow moving and is easily hunted. Hunting threatens populations in a number of areas, including portions of the range with low human population densities. At the northern and eastern edges of its range, the primary threat to this species is habitat loss and degradation. Large areas of the range comprise areas of rapidly advancing deforestation and agricultural expansion (Harris et al. 2017) and the species now appears to be absent in a number of locations where it was recorded historically. Further loss, degradation and fragmentation of the species’ range are expected into the foreseeable future. Projected to 2035, it is suspected that the population decline will exceed 30% over 30 years (equivalent to three generations), thus qualifying P. oustaleti as Vulnerable under criterion A4cd.
habitat:
Oustalet’s Red Colobus shows at least three distinct ecological modes, each covering significant portions of the range. It is found in contiguous, mature primary lowland tropical moist forest; seasonally- or permanently-inundated swamp forest, and in gallery forest and isolated forest islands in savanna woodland.

Large contiguous lowland forest blocks that contain important populations of this red colobus are found in Ituri, Rubi Tele and Aketi in DRC and in northern Congo. In these areas, this red colobus is recorded mostly in primary evergreen forest, though it also uses older secondary forest, and appears to prefer riversides and swamp forests. The species uses a range of mature forest types. In the Okapi Wildlife Reserve, they are found in monodominant stands of Gilbertiodendron dewevrei, where they feed on flower buds and immature seeds during periods of mast flowering and fruiting (J. Hart, unpublished observations 2007). They do not occur in younger secondary forest. In lowland evergreen forests, P. oustaleti can form large groups where they are not hunted. Counts of up to 70 animals were made in some groups in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve in the past (Hart et al. 2008); up to 50 in 2011, but the more recent dataset (which only covers about a quarter of the reserve at the time of writing) suggests that group sizes are now smaller (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2018).

In the Ngotto Forest in CAR, this species only occurs in flooded riverine forests (Gautier-Hion & Brugière 2005). Galat-Luong & Galat (1979) reported that they spent 30% of their time below 10 m above ground and regularly enter into water to collect bulbs of aquatic plants. Large blocks of seasonally- or permanently-inundated forest are found in the west of the species range, in the confluence region of the Congo, Sangha and Ubangi rivers, including Lac Télé in Congo.

The eastern-most populations of P. oustaleti occupy small isolated forest islands and galleries on the Lake Albert escarpment. Semi-deciduous tree species dominate the high elevation gallery forests where P. oustaleti has been studied recently (Laudisoit et al. 2016, Scholier 2017). Home range size in some of these blocks is highly constrained, suggesting that these populations, which have no means of dispersal, are likely under periodic resource stress.
threats:
Habitat loss and hunting are the primary threats to this species. Habitat loss is particularly severe for the populations that occur in small forest islands and galleries at the northern and eastern limits of the range. Sources of deforestation in this environment include growing numbers of small holder farmers, expansion of nomadic pastoralism, small-scale logging and charcoal production. These latter threats are growing in a zone where ready sources of timber and fuel wood are scarce. Even low levels of firewood, house pole collection and timber harvest could have severe impact on populations in these areas, as they are constrained to very small home ranges and may be exposed to periods of stress exacerbated by the removal of key resources.

In parts of DRC, in portions of the range originally covered by contiguous forest, there are growing halos of deforestation around the population centres of Bunia, Isiro, Buta, Lisala and Gemena. A band of forest loss and degradation up to 100 km wide now isolates P. oustaleti populations in the Abubumbazi forest block. Commercial scale oil-palm plantations established in the Lisala area have led to permanent loss of habitat. Areas showing high rates of deforestation affect about 25% of P. oustaleti’s range (Harris et al. 2017). Forest loss in the current geographic range of the taxon totaled around 15,000 km² between 2001 and 2016 (Global Forest Watch/WRI 2018).

Hunting, usually with shotguns, is a threat to P. oustaleti in a number of areas, including Buta and the Rubi-Télé Hunting Domain (T. Hart, pers. comm. 2007), and across the whole of northern Congo and southwestern CAR outside the areas protected by wildlife guards. Though hunting is not yet common in the Ituri forest, it appears to be a growing threat in the Ituri landscape, in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve and the adjacent, unprotected Mai Tatu forest (R. Mwinyihali, pers. comm. 2018). Widespread hunting was recorded in the Abubumbazi Forest in the northwest extreme of the species range in DRC, where no red colobus were recorded during a brief survey (J. Hart pers. obs. 1989). The bushmeat trade is active around Buta-Aketi (Hicks et al. 2010). Two red colobus were amng 169 monkey carcasses recorded for sale during 2007 and 2008 surveys (Hicks, unpublished data). One red colobus was among 21 identified monkey carcasses encountered between Banalia-Buta-Titulé in 2012 (Hicks 2014).
population: Given the size of its geographic range, Oustalet’s Red Colobus is likely to be among the more numerous of the red colobus taxa (Struhsaker and Grubb 2013). No estimates of P. oustaleti density are available; however, it has been recorded as common by a number of large-scale surveys. Piliocolobus oustaleti was the third most observed species in the flooded forests of Ngotto in southwestern CAR (Brugière et al. 2005), and was classified as common at eight of 12 survey sites covering the central portion of its range (Buta-Aketi Region) from 24 to 26° E (Hicks 2010, 2014, unpublished data). The species was among the most commonly recorded primates in surveys of the Okapi Wildlife Reserve between 1993 and 2011 (Grossman et al. 2008, Hart et al. 2008, Vosper et al. 2011) although the most recent information shows that its abundance has fallen relative to other species (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2018). A large area in the eastern Ituri forest (Mai Tatu) also harbours this red colobus, although again it is now one of the least commonly recorded (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2008, 2014).
range:
Piliocolobus oustaleti occurs in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and Republic of Congo (Congo), and has been recorded historically or marginally in South Sudan. It is also present in the extreme southwest of the Central African Republic (CAR). Its extent of occurrence (EEO) is estimated at 766,035 km². The eastern limit of its range is at about 31°E and includes the gallery forests and forest islands on the escarpments above Lake Albert. The northernmost record for the species is 4.50 N is northeastern DRC (Garamba National Park; Groves 2007). North of the Uélé River headwaters, the species has been historically recorded sporadically in gallery forests and forest islands in savanna from northern DRC to southern South Sudan. The Uélé River defines the northern limit of the range from about 210 through 270 E.  Historically, the species was recorded near the forest-savanna boundary between Lisala and Gemena (M. Collet unpublished data 1983). The southern limits of its range are the Aruwimi (Ituri) River and the Congo River to its confluence with the Sangha river at 1013’ S. The western limit is the Sangha River up to the savanna-forest ecotone. P. oustaleti ranges from 350 m elevation at the confluence of the Sangha and Congo rivers, to 1,850 m in the gallery forests above Lake Albert.

The species appears to be absent from a number of locations at its northern and eastern limits, where it was known historically, including Garamba National Park (K. Smith pers. comm. 2018). Contrary to Gautier-Hion et al. (1999), P. oustaleti does not occur north of the Uélé River west of 27 0 E. This includes large undisturbed blocks of closed forest in the Bili-Gangu region where recent surveys documented a rich forest primate fauna, but failed to find this species (Hart 2012; Hicks 2010, 2014). It appears that the populations that have been documented in small forest islands and galleries in the northern Uélé headwaters, never ranged west across the open savannas of the Ango-Digba region to reach these closed forests. The Uélé River, at this longitude, apparently represents a major barrier to dispersal by populations from the forest blocks to the south.
useTrade: This species is hunted illegally. Its meat is eaten and traded.
conservationActions:
All red colobus are classed as totally protected species at a national level in CAR, Congo and DRC (Central African Republic 1984, MEFDD 2011, Enerunga 2006).

Piliocolobus oustaleti is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

The largest populations of P. oustaleti remaining occur in national parks and reserves that protect large blocks of habitat, including in DRC: Okapi Wildlife Reserve, Rubi-Télé Hunting Domain and the Reserve Naturelle de Ngiri; in Congo: Nouabalé-Ndoki National Park and Lac Télé Community Reserve; and in CAR: Dzanga-Sangha Protected Areas complex and the Mbaéré-Bodingué National Park (Ngotto Forest).

Protected areas where hunting is controlled are the most important mechanisms for protection of this species.

rationale: Piliocolobus rufomitratus is listed as CR A3c. This species is endemic to forests along a 60-km stretch of the lower Tana River. The current population is estimated at ca 1,000 individuals. Future population reduction of 80% or more is possible should the rate of decline in forest cover approach levels reached several years back and continue for the next three generations (2019-2048). This is especially likely if the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR) is officially annulled, an action now being considered by national authorities. The entire population lies in a politically insecure area over which there is a low level of conservation activity, and much unplanned, unregulated, and unsustainable exploitation of natural resources.
habitat: Piliocolobus rufomitratus occupies riverine and flood-plain forests. This folivorous species has a home range of ca 4–19 ha (Decker 1994). Mean group size is ca 13 individuals (Butynski and Mwangi 1994) with generally one adult male (Marsh 1979, Decker 1994, Mbora 2003). Piliocolobus rufomitratus is arboreal, but must come to the ground (rarely) to move between, and colonise, distant forest patches.
threats:
Piliocolobus rufomitratus has declined as a result of several causes, including: (a) drastic changes in vegetation due to dam construction, irrigation projects, and water diversion, which affect the water table and the frequency and severity of flooding which, in turn, affect the amount and quality of habitat; (b) forest clearance for agriculture; (c) fires that destroy forests; (d) habitat degradation due to livestock and the unsustainable collection of wood and other forest products; (e) selective felling of fig trees for canoes; and (f) corruption, inter-ethnic violence, and insecurity (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000; De Jong and Butynski 2012; Struhsaker and Grubb 2013; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013; Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016; Butynski and De Jong 2019). Because all remaining forests inhabited by P. rufomitratus are small and seriously threatened, the long-term survival of the species is in question.

There has been considerable alteration of river flow volume and the flood cycle by five hydroelectric power dams up-river (Butynski 1995). A sixth dam, the High Grand Falls Dam, is under construction (Hamerlynck et al. 2012, Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016). The High Grand Falls Dam, the second largest dam in Africa, will be accompanied by large-scale irrigation schemes and water transfer to the ‘Lamu Port and Lamu Southern Sudan-Ethiopia Transport Corridor’. The establishment of this dam is expected to have additional negative impacts on the forests of the Lower Tana River and, therefore, on P. rufomitratus.

One special concern is the rapidly growing human population in the region. Another is the possible annulment of the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR; 169 km²) which the High Court of Kenya ordered in January 2007. According to the Kenya Wildlife Act 2013, Section 37, change of boundaries or revocation of a National Reserve can only be published by the Cabinet Secretary and approved by Parliament. Change or revocation can only be recommended if they do not endanger any species or critical habitat. As such, it seems unlikely that annulment will occur, despite the court ruling in 2007.

About 35% of P. rufomitratus occur in the TRPNR. Even with the continued existence of the TRPNR the long-term survival of P. rufomitratus is not certain, as the high level of insecurity and inadequate law enforcement in the region is expected to continue (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Struhsaker and Grubb 2013; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000; Butynski and De Jong 2018).

According to Global Forest Watch data, Kenya's Tana River region has lost 16% of its forest cover since the turn of the century, tropical forest habitat being reduced from approximately 60,000 to 50,000 hectares. Although the annual rate of loss has remained fairly consistent throughout this period (530 ha/yr avg), it has spiked several times to more than double or triple that rate. Should the TRPNR be annulled and/or peak rates of deforestation be reached again, it is conceivable that this species could lose 80% or more of its habitat by mid-century.
population:
Total number of Piliocolobus rufomitratus estimated at 1,100–1,300 individuals in 1994 (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995). Total population today ca 1,000 individuals and is expected to continue to decline (Mbora 2003, Karere et al. 2004, Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016, T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2018).
