Although the annual rate of habitat loss of this species has remained fairly consistent (530 ha/yr avg), it has spiked several times to more than double or triple that rate. Should the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR) be annulled and/or peak rates of deforestation be reached again, it is conceivable that this species could lose > 80% of its habitat by mid-century.
range:
Piliocolobus rufomitratus is a medium-sized monkey that occurs along the lower Tana River and in the Tana Delta, north coast of Kenya. It occurs along a 60-km stretch of the lower Tana River from Kipende in the north to Mitipani in the south where the Lamu-Garsen Road crosses the Tana River floodplain. A small number of individuals may still exist in the Tana Delta. This species lives in about 34 distinct, small (1–500 ha) forests, some of which are isolated. Some of the more important forests are Guru South, Sifa East, Baomo South, Mnazini East, Bubesa West 1 and Hewani South 2 (Butynski and Mwangi 1994).

Piliocolobus rufomitratus is broadly sympatric with Cercocebus galeritus, Cercopithecus mitis albotorquatus, Paragalago cocos and Otolemur garnettii lasiotis, and narrowly sympatric on the forest edge with Papio cynocephalus ibeanus, Chlorocebus pygerythrus hilgerti and Galago senegalensis braccatus (De Jong and Butynski 2009, 2012; Butynski and De Jong 2019).
conservationActions:
Piliocolobus rufomitratus is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Given the current poor management of the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR), the continued clearing of forest and settlement of people within the TRPNR, and the low level of conservation activity in the region, the long-term survival of P. rufomitratus seems bleak. A small number of P. rufomitratus may still be present in the Tana River Delta. This delta became a Ramsar Site in 2012, but the forests there continue to be destroyed and, in any case, the number of P. rufomitratus there is small (Butynski and de Jong 2019). Otherwise, the Tana Delta holds no protected area.

Ndera Community Conservancy, established in 2010 with the help of the Northern Rangeland Trusts (www.nrt-kenya.org), aims to conserve 150 km² of the lower Tana River and to improve the viability of forest patches within and outside the TRPNR (Mbora and Allen 2011, J. King pers. comm. 2016). The Ndera Community Conservancy provides an opportunity for improved conservation of those forests upon which P. rufomitratus depends.

Stringent habitat protection is required for all forests of the Lower Tana River and Tana Delta. The Mchelelo Research Station in the TRPNR needs to be rehabilitated and re-established.

Piliocolobus rufomitratus is listed as one of the world’s 25 most threatened primates (Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016).

rationale: Assessed as Endangered, Piliocolobus bouvieri is suspected to have undergone a population decline of at least 50% over the past three generations (1990-2019),primarily due to poaching and to a lesser degree, habitat loss. This species is downlisted from Critically Endangered as its known geographic range now includes previously unknown populations in northern Republic of Congo. Bouvier’s Red Colobus was first recorded west of the Sangha in 2007, 2014 and 2015 (Devreese 2015). It has also been found in the Lesio-Louna Reserve (C. Ndzai and P. Malonga unpublished data 2016). The taxon was thought likely to have been wiped out since the 1970s in the southern part of its range. Hunting continues throughout its range, and habitat change (due to clearing of forests for charcoal) is intensifying in the south. Although surveys have been intensive, records of the continuing presence of this species are few and far between.
habitat: Bouvier’s Red Colobus is a largely arboreal species that lives in riverine and swamp (seasonally- or permanently-flooded) forests.
threats:
The major threat to Piliocolobus bouvieri is hunting. All red colobus species are slow-moving and easily hunted (Struhsaker 2005), as illustrated by a female observed with her infant in northern Congo who remained clearly visible for 15 minutes (Devreese 2015). During this same survey, Devreese (2015) reported evidence of a single hunter claiming to have killed more than 60 red colobus during a single hunting trip. Devreese also identified a substantial commercial trade along the Likouala and Sangha rivers, although this trade may have decreased in recent years due to a perceived threat of contracting Ebola virus disease (Devreese 2015). The immigration of a workforce into logging concessions and access facilitated by logging roads will lead to increasing hunting pressure on wildlife in the northern part of this species' range.

In the southern part of the range, Bouvier’s Red Colobus are hunted in and around the Lesio-Louna Reserve (C. Ndzai and P. Malonga unpublished data 2016). As yet, there is little habitat transformation, but this is likely to change over time, as there is a very high demand for charcoal from Brazzaville (the capital city) and perhaps also from Kinshasa (the capital of DRC, population 12 million).
population: Population size is unknown, but because Bouvier’s Red Colobus is a large-bodied, slow-moving, group-living species, it is certainly declining due to illegal hunting. Local decreases in numbers have been recorded in the south of their range, in and around the Lesio-Louna Reserve, where they are hunted (C. Ndzai and P. Malonga unpublished data 2016).
range: Piliocolobus bouvieri is found in the swamps of northern Republic of Congo and riverine forests in the south of the country. Previously, it was known to occur on the right bank of the Congo River, only along the lower reaches of the Alima to the mouth of the Likouala-aux-Herbes (i.e., west of the Sangha River), and the tributaries of the lower Congo River (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999, Butynski et al. 2013). However, in 2007, 2014 and 2015, the species was recorded on five occasions in the north, in a large logging concession of Ngombe and in Ntokou-Pikounda National Park, in the area west of the Sangha River and east of the Bokiba (Lingoue) and Likouala rivers in Congo (Devreese 2015). In 2016, a troop was recorded in the south of Lesio-Louna Reserve, in gallery forest along the Loubilika River, in the least accessible area of the reserve, about 45 km west of a main road that links Brazzaville to towns to the north and about 65 km east of a smaller road system south of the source of the Lefini River (C. Ndzai and P. Malonga unpublished data 2016; although earlier targeted surveys in the north of Lesio-Louna Reserve and the south of Lefini Reserve had failed to find this species; Downer 1998, Ikoli et al. 1998).
useTrade: Hunted illegally for local consumption and commercial sale at bushmeat markets.
conservationActions:
This taxon is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

The range of Piliocolobus bouvieri overlaps with the Lefini Reserve. This taxon is a priority for further survey work to determine whether it remains extant in the wild.

rationale: The principal threat to Cercopithecus wolfi is hunting for the commercial bushmeat trade across its geographic range. The nominate form C. w. wolfi has a large range covering much of the DRC’s central basin forested zone and can be locally common. Two other subspecies have much smaller ranges: C. w. elegans occurs only between the Lualaba and Lomami rivers in habitat that borders the city of Kindu, where it is threatened by both hunting and habitat loss. The fragmented range of C. w. pyrogaster is restricted to the area south of the Kasai River and is further constrained to gallery forests and small forest islands in an area dominated by savanna, where it is threatened by both hunting and loss of habitat to shifting agriculture. It is suspected that the species has undergone a population decline in the order of 20–25% over the past 30 years, so is listed as Near Threatened. These declines are expected to continue, and so the taxon almost qualifies as threatened under criterion A2cd.
habitat: Cercopithecus wolfi is a small, arboreal guenon found in a wide range of forest types. The nominate form occurs in both terra firma and flooded areas; less frequently in secondary forests (Gautier-Hion 2013), although groups in the Lomami-Lualaba interfluve are frequently encountered in secondary forests and even in the vicinity of settlements (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2007). Two subspecies, elegans and pyrogaster, occupy gallery forests south of the main forest block (Colyn 1988, Niehoff 2016). Omnivorous with a wide range of dietary items recorded across the diverse array of habitats used, including fruits, seeds, leaves and nectar (Gautier-Hion 2013). The nominate form frequently occurs in polyspecific groups of arboreal guenons (Gautier-Hion 2013).
threats:
Cercopithecus wolfi is threatened in a number of areas by subsistence and commercial shotgun hunters who target the species. Urban-based hunters in Kindu are known to hunt the species, and the C. w. elegans subspecies is exposed to higher levels of hunting than populations in more remote areas (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2015). Cercopithecus monkeys were found to comprise 45% of all exposed bushmeat for sale in one of the largest commercial bushmeat markets in the species’ range, with C. wolfi and C. ascanius being most abundant among them (Kabongo 2016).

Indices of relative abundance based on counts of dawn call are 20–35% higher in Lomami National Park, which is patrolled by park guards, than in an adjacent buffer zone where hunting occurs widely (Hart 2016). Nevertheless, there is no evidence that hunting has led to disappearance of populations of the nominate form in significant areas of its historically known range and the species is still widespread, despite hunting pressure.

Two subspecies, C. w. elegans and C. w. pyrogaster, are affected by habitat loss, habitat degradation and habitat fragmentation mainly caused by agricultural encroachment. The potential for increasing habitat loss poses the greatest threat to C. w. elegans as its range borders the expanding urban centre of Kindu.
population:
Cercopithecus wolfi is one of the most common guenons found in DRC’s central basin. In Salonga National Park, it is the second most common monkey, after Lophocebus aterrimus, encountered in both the Lokofa and Lomela sectors (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2015, 2016). The species was the most commonly recorded guenon on dawn call counts conducted by patrols in Lomami National Park (Hart 2016). Population densities of the nominate form, C. w. wolfi, range from 30 to >40 individuals/km² (Gautier-Hion 2013).

The geographic ranges of two subspecies, C. w. elegans and C. w. pyrogaster are small and fragmented. The range of the former subspecies is being reduced by expanding deforestation from the city of Kindu, Maniema Province. The range of the latter subspecies is restricted to small patches of suitable habitat: narrow gallery forests and forest islands in a predominantly wooded savanna environment.
range:
Cercopithecus wolfi is endemic to the central basin of DRC and is found from the left bank of the Congo/Lualaba River to about 7°S (Gautier-Hion 2013), a range of roughly 606,000 km². Three subspecies are recognised (Gautier-Hion 2013): 

Cercopitheus w. wolfi (Congo Basin Wolf’s Monkey) ranges from the Congo River south to the right banks of the Kasai and Sankuru rivers. The range is bounded on the east by the Lomami River (Colyn 1988). Southeastern limits of the range from the Lubefu River (right bank tributary of the Sankuru River) to the Lomami River, are not well defined (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2015). 

Cercopithecus w. elegans (Lomami River Wolf’s Monkey) is restricted to the Lomami-Lualaba interfluve. Southern limits are the gallery forests to about 4° S (Schouteden 1948, Colyn 1988). Schouteden (1948) gives the distribution of the form as the entire forested Lomami-Lualaba interfluve. Colyn (1988), however, considered the northern limits to be seasonally-inundated swamp forests on white sands (locally termed “sende” at about 2° S, suggesting that the nominate form occurred further north. Forms intermediate between elegans and nominate wolfi occur widely throughout the interfluve (Colyn 1988, Niehoff 2016). C. w. elegans (sensu stricto) are apparently limited to the south and east of the subspecies range, including the savanna ecotone of the upper Kasuku River basin (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2016).

Cercopithecus w. pyrogaster (Fire-bellied Wolf’s Monkey) is found in the southern Congo Basin from Kasai River south, following gallery forests and forest islands, to about 7° S (Schouteden 1948); the western limit is reported to be the Kwango River, whereas the eastern limit is the Lulua River (Schouteden 1948, Gautier-Hion 2013).

The nominate form occurs in closed primary forests up to 600 m asl in Lomami National Park (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2016).
useTrade: A study of bushmeat in one of the largest commercial bushmeat markets in the species’ range (Kindu) found that primates of the genus Cercopithecus comprised 45% of all exposed bushmeat, with C. wolfi and C. ascanius being the most abundant primate species (Kabongo 2016).
conservationActions: Cercopithecus wolfi is listed on Appendix II of CITES. Important populations occur in a number of protected areas including Salonga and Lomami national parks and Lomako-Yokokala Faunal Reserve. C. w. pyrogaster is reported to occur in the Swa-Kibula Hunting Reserve (Dino 2014). Lomami National Park protects populations of both C. w. wolfi and C. w. elegans.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened due to a projected population reduction of 25% or more over the course of the next three generations (48 years; 2019-2066) as a result of habitat loss, subsistence hunting, and live capture for the pet trade. The taxon almost qualifies as VU A3cd.
habitat:
Cebus cuscinus occupies lowland terra firma and seasonally inundated forests in the upper Amazon, as well as montane forest on the western slopes of the Andes up to 1,800 m asl (Aquino and Encarnacion 1994, Rylands et al., 2013). Capuchins are frugivores-insectivores, including a wide variety of fruits, seeds and arthropods, frogs, nestlings and even small mammals, supplemented by stems, flowers and leaves. They are extractive, manipulative foragers. Mean group size for Cebus albifrons is 19.8 individuals, with numbers of males exceeding the numbers of females, adult sex ratio of 1.08 (Fragaszy el al. 2004). Males disperse. Both sexes take up linear hierarchies, the top ranking male being dominant to the top ranking female. Subordinate males are often peripheral (Fragaszy et al. 2004). There is a peak birth season with an 18 month inter-birth interval (Fragaszy et al. 2005). Like other gracile capuchins, shock-headed capuchins prefer middle to upper canopy but can occasionally forage on the ground (Rylands et al. 2013).  Detailed studies on the species’ foraging ecology and behavior are available in Terborgh (1983) and Janson (1986).

Size (Cebus albifrons): Adult male 1.7-3.26 kg (mean 2.49 kg); adult female: 1.4-2.23 kg (mean 1.81 kg) (Ford and Davis 1992).
threats: Across its range, hunting is the major threat to Cebus cuscinus, combined with forest loss and fragmentation. Global Forest Watch data for the regions in which this species occurs show accelerating rates of forest loss for the last few years. Should forest habitat continue to decline at current rates, over the course of the next 48 years (three generations), more than 30% in the Brazilian state of Acre, approximately 15% in the Peruvian departments of Cusco and Madre de Dios, and approximately 10% in the Bolivian departments of La Paz and Pando will be lost. Cebus species are among the most common primates found in the illegal pet trade (18% of total primates found between 2000 and 2014) and as tourist attractions in illegal zoos and circuses, representing 33% of total primates recorded between 2000 and 2014 (Shanee et al. 2015). This combination of threats, and considering the fact that Cebus cuscinus is known to occur in only a handful of protected areas, leads experts to believe that species qualifies for Near Threatened status.
population: The population of this species is declining due to hunting and habitat loss. Global Forest Watch data for the regions in which this species occurs show accelerating rates of forest loss for the last few years. Should forest habitat continue to decline at current rates, over the course of the next 48 years (three generations), more than 30% in the Brazilian state of Acre, approximately 15% in the Peruvian departments of Cusco and Madre de Dios, and approximately 10% in the Bolivian departments of La Paz and Pando will be lost. This, in combination with hunting and live capture for the pet trade, is likely to result in a reduction of a least 25% over the next three generations.
range: As described in Rylands et al. (2013) and Aquino and Encarnacion (1994), the species’ distribution range is poorly known, but it is believed to reach from Peru (from the southern bank of the upper reaches of the Rio Purus in the southeast), west into the Río Urubamba Valley in the Cuzco Department (including the upper Río Madre de Dios), and south and east to the Tambopata Basin. The range further extends into northwestern Bolivia, and may extend into Acre State in Brazil.
useTrade: Illegal pet trade exists for this species.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on CITES Appendix II. It occurs in the following protected areas across its range:

Peru:
  • Manu National Park and Biosphere Reserve
Bolivia:
  • Madidi National Park
  • Manuripi-Heath National Reserve 
Brazil:
  • Unknown

rationale: Piliocolobus parmentieri is considered EN A4cd based on an anticipated population reduction of 50% or more over a 30-year period (three generations; 2009-2038). This is based on a combination of factors; continued unregulated hunting for the bushmeat market and continuing habitat loss at increasingly higher rates than in the past.
habitat:
There have been no field studies of Piliocolobus parmentieri and its ecology and behaviour are little known (Struhsaker 2010).

Piliocolobus parmentieri occurs in primary terra firma forest and possibly older secondary forest. The species has not been observed in and is not reported by local villagers to use younger secondary forest and re-growth following agricultural clearing. The species has a localized occurrence within its range as suitable upland habitats are constrained by swamp forest and areas occupied or modified by agriculture. The species was seen in primary forest in the upper Lutanga basin (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2008). Two specimens, acquired from hunters in Opala in 2008, were reportedly taken from this same area (Chaney et al. 2016). In 2016, the species was found again, unexpectedly, near the villages of Lokobekobe and Mokau, considerably south of its previously known range (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2016). These recent discoveries of P. parmentieri are all in areas that have been visited by field teams since 2007, yet the species was not previously reported. This suggests that P. parmentieri is indeed rare with a possibly widely-dispersed occurrence. Further field surveys are urgently needed to determine if other areas still harbour the species.
threats:
Piliocolobus parmentieri is threatened by both hunting and habitat loss.

Colyn (1991) reported the species to be common in a Kisangani bushmeat market in the 1980s. In a survey of the same market, as well as an inventory of bushmeat available in villages in the vicinity of Kisangani, Dauwe (2014) recorded just three carcasses of all colobine species out of a total 353 total carcasses examined.  More recently, Kyamakya et al. (2019) compiled data from 40 years of survey of the bushmeat trade in Kisangini (1976-2016), which identified red colobus monkeys as a highly favoured species, appearing at its highest numbers in the market in 2016.

Two hunters in Opala who killed individuals of this species in 2008 reported having to travel almost 40 km to find them (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2008). P. parmentieri carcasses were not seen for sale along the roadside during multiple trips in the species’ range, from Kisangani to Opala and Kisangani to Ubundu, between 2007 and 2016, further indication that population numbers are low (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2007-2016).

Over half the historic range of P. parmentieri has been affected by clearing for agriculture (Vancustem et al. 2006). Agricultural conversion is increasing, associated with the commercial production of upland rice for national urban markets. Active logging concessions cover about a quarter of the species’ range (MECNT 2013), with further artisanal-scale extraction of wood for national markets in Kisangani. Increasing logging and agriculture in the range of P. parmentieri is associated with repairs of the existing road network and the expansion of logging roads into the primary forest remaining in the areas under exploitation (Hart 2011).

According to Global Forest Watch data compiled from 2001-2018, annual forest cover loss in DRC's Tshopo region has nearly quadrupled since the turn of the century (from 36,000 ha/yr to 130,000 ha/yr) and continues to accelerate.
population:
No population estimates are available for Piliocolobus parmentieri. The species is now rare or absent in the northern half of its range, due to hunting and habitat loss to shifting agriculture. The area with depleted populations includes most of the Lobaye basin, which Colyn and Verheyen (1987) considered its stronghold less than 30 years ago. Colyn and Verheyen (1987) reported that the species also occurred in the Lutanga basin by in the 1980s, and small numbers were still present in 2008 (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2008). Based on interviews with villagers, the species’ occurrence appears to be highly fragmented (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2008).

Based on known or likely areas of absence and the large portion of its range degraded by shifting agriculture and logging, it can be inferred that the current population likely contains fewer than 2,500 adult animals.

It is suspected that over the three generations from 2009 to 2038, this species will undergo a reduction of at least 50% based on a combination of factors; bushmeat market survey data that indicates this species is favoured by hunters and will continue to be exploited at high levels wherever it occurs; and accelerating rates of forest cover loss within its range will likely result in forest cover loss of 20% or more over the course of three generations (2009-2038).
range:
This species is endemic to the Democratic Republic of Congo. The known historic range of P. parmentieri, estimated at 19,000 km², is located in the Congo (Lualaba)–Lomami interfluves. It is limited by the Congo (Lualaba) River to the north and east, and by the lower Lomami River to the west. The southern limit of the species’ range was originally thought to be defined by a major band of apparently unsuitable habitat dominated by seasonally-inundated forest on white sands (Colyn and Verheyen 1987). Struhsaker and Grubb (2013) report the southern limit as the Ruiki and Lutanga rivers. Local villagers report that the species occurs in the upper Ruiki basin. Discovery of new locations for the species in 2016 have extended the southern range limit to about 1.4° south latitude (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2016).

Piliocolobus parmentieri no longer occurs over large areas of its historic range, which have been converted to an agricultural landscape over the last three decades or more. The species is absent from the vicinity of Kisangani, Opala and Ubundu, all human population centres bordering its range. Field surveys in 2007 in the area between Kisangani and Ubundu, where the type specimen originated, failed to reveal any evidence of the animal and no local villagers could report its occurrence (Hart 2011).

Based on vegetation cover estimates (Vancutsem et al. 2006), the remaining area of undisturbed mature forest currently suitable for P. parmentieri comprises less than 10,000 km² of the species’ known historic range.
useTrade: Unregulated, illegal hunting occurs throughout the range.
conservationActions:
The Red Colobus are listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. As of 2006, P. tholloni is included in the protected species list by the Ministry of the Environment of the Democratic Republic of the Congo and thus is fully protected by national law (Enerunga 2006). However, the unregulated hunting that occurs throughout its range, including the killing of P. parmentieri, indicates that there is currently inadequate enforcement of this law.

Piliocolobus parmentieri is now known to occur in the recently established Lomami National Park. In 2016, groups of P. parmentieri numbering about 20 animals were seen at widely separated locations, at about 1.4° South latitude, considerably south of their originally ascribed range (J. Hart, pers. obs. 2016). Surveys continue to determine whether the species occurs at other locations in the park and its buffer zone.

rationale: Piliocolobus langi is assessed as Endangered based upon a suspected population reduction of 50% or more over the course of three generations (2005-2035) due to ongoing, significant hunting pressure and increasing forest loss. This strikingly bi-coloured and uniquely marked taxon has declined over more than 40 years, due primarily to hunting. Evidence of its decline has become more pronounced over the past two decades as habitat loss has accelerated. Hunting and habitat loss will continue to threaten this taxon into the foreseeable future. The range of Piliocolobus langi encompasses the city of Kisangani, with an estimated 1.6 million inhabitants in 2015. Kisangani has one of the largest bushmeat markets in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). A summary of market surveys (Laudisoit unpublished data 2018) suggests that P. langi likely made up the bulk of the colobus entering the Kisangani market and that numbers began to decline in the late 1970s through the 1980s. Piliocolobus langi are still hunted; however, today they are uncommon in the Kisangani market, and freshly killed animals are rarely seen. Habitat loss is increasing, with agricultural clearing and small-scale logging leading to deforestation and forest degradation along the road network emanating from Kisangani and crossing the species’ geographic range. Primary forest has been transformed into secondary and regenerating forest of various ages in a growing rural complex over nearly half of the taxon’s range (Vancustem et al. 2006). The remaining blocks of intact habitat are concentrated in the east of the range where P. langi reportedly intergrades with P. ellioti.
habitat: The species seems to be restricted to primary forests. Its range includes areas characterized by large stands of monodominant Gilbertiodendron dewevrei forest. The species may use older secondary forests, however, it does not occur in younger regenerating forest. There is no information on its use of selectively logged areas.
threats: Habitat loss and hunting are the primary threats to this species. Its geographic range is fragmented by a network of heavily-travelled national roads emanating from Kisangani, DRC’s second largest city, located on the Congo River at the south-central limit of the taxon’s range. The national highway (RN4) leading from Kisangani to Banalia on the Aruwimi River, at the northern limit of P. langi’s range, is bounded by deforestation and young regeneration produced by shifting cultivation, logging and small-holder farmers. This band of habitat loss ranges in width from 12 to 50 kilometres, and isolates the western third of the taxon’s range. Piliocolobus langi has been subject to heavy hunting pressure for at least four decades. Colyn (1991) characterized P. langi as common throughout the 1980s. Populations were present less than 100 km from Kisangani in the Uma River basin, even as recently as the late 1980s (Colyn 1991), but are now rare or extirpated. Commercial scale logging has been operating in the Tshopo basin, and in the central and western portions of the taxon’s range since the early 1980s. Hunters were known to use the network of logging roads laid out at that time (J. Hart pers. obs. 2000). Rates of conversion of primary forest for agriculture and timber are expected to continue to increase into the foreseeable future.
population:
There are no estimates of this taxon’s population size. Colyn (1991) reported that in the 1980s Piliocolobus langi was regularly seen in the field. Recent field surveys in minimally disturbed habitat near the eastern limit of the taxon’s range, where it purportedly intergrades with P. ellioti, have failed to record the taxon (E. Mpaka pers. comm. 2011). These surveys reported observations of Chimpanzees and their nests, as well as of other primates (Cercopithecus spp.), which suggests that P. langi is now uncommon, even in the remaining intact portions of its range.

It is suspected that over the three generations from 2005 to 2035, this species will suffer a reduction of at least 50%. Piliocolobus langi has been subject to heavy hunting pressure for at least four decades. Populations were present less than 100 km from Kisangani in the Uma River basin, but are now rare or extirpated. Commercial-scale logging has been operating in the Tshopo basin, and in the central and western portions of this species' range, since the early 1980s. Hunters were known to use the network of logging roads laid out at that time. Rates of conversion of primary forest for agriculture and timber are expected to continue to increase into the foreseeable future.
range: Piliocolobus langi ranges from the confluence of the Aruwimi and Congo Rivers, east, through the basins of the Tshopo and lower and middle Lindi Rivers. The taxon’s range is limited in the south by the Maiko River. The eastern limit is ill-defined, but is mapped at about 27 degrees longitude, in the upper watershed of the Maiko River (Colyn 1991). To the east, specimens attributed to this form show intergradation with P. ellioti, which ranges east from about 27 degrees longitude (Colyn 1991). A fresh, hunter-killed male showing typical coat colouration and pattern was photographed on the east bank of the Tshopo River (150 km east of Kisangani) in 2009 (Hart unpublished data 2009).
useTrade: This species is hunted for bushmeat.
conservationActions:
This taxon is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. This taxon is listed as totally protected by national law in DRC (Enerunga 2006); however, the law has not been widely or effectively enforced. 

Piliocolobus langi is not known to occur in any protected area.

There are no conservation efforts dedicated to protecting this taxon, or conserving its range.

rationale: Very little is known about the population status of Miopithecus talapoin, but recent information shows that, despite its small size, this primate is now hunted for bushmeat in Angola and Democratic Republic of Congo (Thompson 2000, Bersacola et al. 2014, C. Hines. pers. comm. 2017). In addition, habitat loss due to commercial timber harvesting is occurring at key forest sites in its geographic range, especially in Angola (Bersacola et al. 2015, Cáceres et al. 2016). The species is now rarely seen in the largest protected area where it occurs (in Angola) and which is being heavily encroached. It is suspected that the overall population decline since 2005 and projected to 2029 (a 24-year period, i.e. three generations) will exceed 30% and this taxon is therefore listed as Vulnerable A4cd.
habitat: The Southern Talapoin is a strictly riverine species, limited to dense evergreen vegetation on the banks of rivers that often flow through miombo (Brachystegia) woodland or, increasingly, cultivated areas (Gautier-Hion 2013, Kingdon 2015). The species has also been observed in deciduous forests in northwestern Angola (C. Hines pers. comm. 2016). Home ranges of this species are likely to be larger and densities lower than for the Northern Talapoin because in the drier southern part of its range, forest strips are narrower and resources scarcer. Longer dry seasons and less extensive flooding under generally cooler and drier climates may have favoured the Southern Talapoin's more terrestrial habits (Kingdon 1997). The diet is likely to be mainly fruits, seeds, young foliage and invertebrates.
threats:
In Angola, the species has been seen at roadside bushmeat stalls (Bersacola et al. 2014, C. Hines pers. comm. 2017), and these monkeys are certainly hunted in Quicama National Park (T. Ron pers. obs. 2018). In DRC, they have been reported to be accidentally caught in snares, but consumed nonetheless (Thompson 2000).

The Angolan forests where talapoins occur are rapidly being cleared for commercial timber harvesting (Bersacola et al. 2015, Cáceres et al. 2016). Hansen et al. (2013) highlighted Angola as one of the countries with the fastest increase in forest cover loss. Approximately 2.4% of tree cover in its range was lost between 2001 and 2016 (GFW-WRI 2018). However, because this species lives in narrow strips of riverine forests, the true loss of habitat may differ from this estimate. There is no particularly evident riverine pattern of forest loss on the GFW visualisation, but future analysis would clarify this.
population: Very little is known about the population status of Miopithecus talapoin, but it is thought to be decreasing across its range. Recent information from Angola shows that the species is being hunted for bushmeat. Plus this monkey is now rarely seen in the largest protected area in which it occurs, which is being heavily encroached.
range:
The Southern Talapoin lives in southwestern DRC and northern Angola, and its geographic range covers approximately 400,000 km². The northern limit of its range is the left bank of the Congo River up to about 3°S. It is found in the coastal watersheds south of the Congo River, notably the Mebridege River, Loge River, Cuanza River, Nhia River and Cuvo River (spilling over into the upper reaches of the Cuango River).

This species is found along the coast of Angola to about 13’S, and into DRC as far as the Cuango River and on both sides of the Kasai River (Thompson 2000, Groves 2001, Bersacola et al. 2014). Talapoins have been sighed at Lac Ma Vallée (Dinets 2009), which is close to the DRC capital of Kinshasa. One record near the village of Mimia at around 20°00’E, 2°29’S, southwest of Salonga National Park and roughly 160 km north of the Kasai River (Thompson 2000), suggests that the Southern Talapoin may also occur in the area between the Kasai River and the location noted by Thompson.
useTrade: This species is hunted for local consumption and sale at bushmeat markets.
conservationActions:
This species is listed under Appendix II of CITES, and as Class B on the African Convention. It is not known whether this species occurs in all protected areas in its geographic range. Those protected areas include: Quiçama (Kissama) National Park (officially documented as 9,960 km²) in Angola, Bombo Lumene Reserve (2,184 km²) and Swa-Kibula Reserve (1,003 km²) in DRC. It has been recorded in both Quiçama and Swa Kibula in the recent past (Dino 2014).

According to the range map, it may also occur in the Buffalo Partial Reserve (400 km²) in Angola) and the Mangai Reserve (1,903 km²) in DRC, but the former has not been under any protection or management for decades. The Quiçama National Park is by far the largest protected area in which it occurs, but park has lost 160 km² of forest cover since 2001 (Global Forest Watch 2018), and this loss is continuing apace (T. Ron pers. obs. 2018).

rationale: Allen’s Swamp Monkey is listed as Least Concern, despite increasing hunting pressure on this taxon, because the data needed to quantify this threat and any resulting decline are lacking. A population decrease is suspected as access has become relatively easy at the edges of the swamps and riverine forests where this species occurs, and demand for bushmeat in urban areas and even in the countryside is burgeoning. Currently habitat loss is not a major threat, as its swamp forest habitat is not yet being logged or cleared for agriculture.
habitat: This little-known species inhabits swamp forest and riverine habitat (Gautier 1995, Kingdon 1997, Malanda et al. 2004, Maisels et al. 2006, Gautier-Hion 2013). It usually forages on the ground and is omnivorous; animal matter comprises about 20% of the diet; it also eats fruit, seeds, young leaves and occasionally nectar from tall trees (Gautier-Hion and Maisels 1994). They have been reported to forage on crops. They sleep beside and over water, which is presumed to be an antipredator strategy. Groups consist of up to 57 individuals; one group of at least 85 has been seen (Gautier-Hion 2013). Females give birth to a single young.
threats:
It is threatened by hunting for bushmeat, for both subsistence and commercial purposes, and research is needed to assess to what degree. Almost all terra firma forests adjacent to its swamp forest habitat in Congo have been attributed as logging concessions, and this will likely happen within the next decade or two in DRC. With logging comes the creation of a network of access roads which, unless they are strictly controlled by antipoaching patrols, are used by commercial poachers to obtain bushmeat in previously inaccessible forests.

Habitat loss is unlikely to be a threat at present because this monkey lives in swamp forests that are not currently logged and generally not used for any kind of agriculture.
population: Although this species' abundance in unknown in most of its geographic range, it has been reported at high densities in Salonga National Park in DRC and is reasonably well distributed throughout the swamps of Likouala-aux-Herbes in Congo.
range: Allen’s Swamp Monkey occurs throughout the swamp forests of the central Congolian basin in Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) (both sides of the Congo River) and Republic of Congo (Gautier-Hion 2013). They are found throughout the Likouala-aux-Herbes swamps in Congo (Malanda et al. 2004); the most westerly records are from the upper Sangha River near the village of Bomassa in northern Congo (Maisels et al. 2006) and from a site north of Bayanga in Central African Republic (camera-trap image; Cassidy 2016; coupled with local hunters' knowledge: Remis and Jost Robinson 2012, Jost and Capel 2017). The Sangha forms the international border with Cameroon and it is therefore possible that the taxon occurs in Cameroon. Recent surveys in south-eastern Cameroon (Nzooh Dongmo et al. 2016) and southern CAR (N’Goran et al. 2016) do not mention the species, but swamp-dwellers are often overlooked by survey teams on foot (Maisels et al. 2006). Based on a combination of sightings, museum specimens and habitat availability, the known limits of its east-west distribution are from about 16°E to about 24°E, and its north-south distribution is from about 4°N to perhaps 6° S (Gautier 1985). Hart has searched intensively for this monkey but it seems not to occur east of 24° E.
useTrade: Sold as bushmeat in Congo and DRC. Occasionally live individuals are sold in markets as pets (seen in Kinshasa central bushmeat market).
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and in Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Studies into the impact of hunting are needed.

The species occurs in the following protected areas: Salonga National Park and Lac Tumba-Ledima Forest Reserve (DRC), Dzanga-Sangha Special Reserve (CAR) and Lac Télé Community Reserve (Congo).

rationale: Lophocebus albigena is suspected to have undergone a population decline exceeding 30% over the past ~30 years (ca three generations). It used to be widespread, occupying both primary and secondary forest. Now, the expansion of access infrastructure throughout its range, increasing consumerism (especially in the western part of its range) and increasing human population has led to more intense and widespread hunting pressure. Because it is large-bodied and brings a higher profit per cartridge than smaller species, it is preferentially selected by hunters and tends to be eliminated or at least greatly reduced in abundance before other, smaller monkey species. For example, it now appears to be extremely rare throughout Equatorial Guinea (Ruffler et al. 2012), extinct or almost extinct in eastern Nigeria since the 1990s, also extinct along the western border of Cameroon, and can be quite uncommon elsewhere except in well-protected national parks and wildlife reserves. In addition, habitat loss is resulting in population declines in the west and extreme east of its range. The taxon is listed as Vulnerable under criterion A2cd, as the decline has been ongoing for some time and will continue into the future; causes have not ceased, nor will they in the foreseeable future.
habitat: The Grey-cheeked Mangabey is found in both primary and secondary forest, although it occurs at low densities in the latter (Olupot & Waser 2013). It is arboreal, spending most of the time in the upper canopy (Waser 1977, Shah 2003). Diet is highly diverse and consists mainly of fruit and seeds (Waser 1977, Ham 1994, Olupot et al. 1994, Poulsen et al. 2001, Shah 2003). Populations in West-Central Africa (Gabon) eat most seeds – up to 58% in some forests (Ham 1994, Brugière et al. 2002), than groups studied in Uganda. This monkey lives in groups of 5–30 individuals, is non-territorial and has home ranges of 2–4 km², which overlap extensively (Waser 1977, Olupot et al. 1994, Shah 2003). It is large bodied (7-11 kg; Olupot & Waser 2013).
threats: This species is directly threatened by habitat loss and hunting, and indirectly by increasing human populations and the creation of easy access routes into huge areas of previously remote forests. Hunting is an increasing threat throughout the range of this taxon, which is eaten locally for food in villages and traded to urban populations. There are large areas of “empty forest” in its range, especially in the west, where the habitat is intact but the animals have been hunted out (see subspecies accounts for more detail). Human populations in the range states of the taxon continue to grow at roughly 2.7% annually and this rate will not slow down for several decades (UN 2015, World Bank 2016). Road access into once-remote forests – even around protected areas – has hugely increased over the last 20-30 years (Laporte et al. 2007), facilitating increased hunting and transport of bushmeat for commercial trade in both local markets and distant urban centres (Abernethy et al. 2013, Ziegler et al. 2016). In Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea, and in East Africa (including eastern DRC and Rwanda), the species is subject to habitat modification, as intact forest is converted to farmland and “farm bush” which can be seen clearly in Tyukavina et al. (2016). Historically, forest loss has been relatively low in the Gabon, CAR and Congo parts of this taxon’s range (Hansen et al. 2013) due to low human population densities and selective (as opposed to clearcutting) logging practices. However, in Congo, Cameroon, DRC and Equatorial Guinea, forest loss in the years 2014-2016 was higher than in all previous years (from 2001) (WRI 2017; Gabon’s figures not available), and this will greatly increase in the future as industrial agriculture expands further, removing habitat suitable for various forest-obligate species (Wich et al. 2014).
population: The Grey-cheeked Mangabey is widespread, but is targeted by hunters due to its large size. The species occurs at variable densities in protected areas; density is low in unprotected forests. Studies in areas that have not been hunted in the past (Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon, Gabon and Kibale in Uganda) showed densities of 10–22 individuals per km². The highest density recorded (133 individuals/km²) was in Ugandan forest patches surrounded by recent cultivation.
range:
The geographic range of Lophocebus albigena covers approximately 1,464,100 km². This is a forest-dwelling, primarily Central African taxon and occurs from Cameroon through to around 33°E, and includes Uganda, Rwanda and Tanzania and most countries in the forest zone in between. Historically, the western limit of its range was the Okwangwo Forest Reserve (now part of Cross River National Park) in Nigeria, but they have not been seen there since the 1990s, nor in the adjacent Takamanda National Park in Cameroon. A very small population may survive in Nigeria’s Gashaka-Gumti National Park (based on sightings of a single individual in 2004-08). The species is found mainly south-east of the Sanaga River to its confluence with the Mbam River at about 4°30’ N, 11°6’ E in Cameroon, and then east of the Mbam through to the Nile. The southern limit is the savanna zone of southern Gabon, central Congo, and the right bank of the Congo River and the Lualaba River, Democratic Republic of Congo. The northern limit is the forest-savanna boundary at about 4°N, except in central Cameroon where it is at about 6°N in Mbam et Djerem National Park. The eastern limit is the Albertine Rift with an extension into Uganda. Its range encompasses (possibly) south-east Nigeria, Cameroon, Congo, Gabon, mainland Equatorial Guinea, south-western Central African Republic, DRC, Burundi, Uganda and extreme north-western Tanzania. Although primarily a lowland species, it can be found up to 1,600 m in strictly equatorial zones.
See the L. albigena subspecies accounts for more details.
useTrade: Hunted illegally for local consumption and sale to bushmeat markets.
conservationActions: This species has been listed under CITES Appendix II since 1977 and as Class B under the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources since 1968. It occurs in many protected areas across its range, from Uganda to Gabon.

rationale: Lophocebus aterrimus is listed as Vulnerable under criterion A2cd. Poaching of this species for the bushmeat trade is intensifying, and much of the forest in its range is now almost “empty” of large mammals. Because of its relatively large body size, the Black Mangabey is more attractive to hunters than the smaller Cercopithecus monkeys with which it shares its range. The species is also threatened by habitat loss and is suspected to have declined by at least 30% over the past three generations (30 years).
habitat: This species is found in primary and secondary moist forests. In Salonga National Park, the Black Mangabey also uses swamp forests, but does not occupy swamp in Lomako (McGraw 1994). It uses all forest strata (especially the middle canopy layers), but seldom descends to the ground (Horn 1987, McGraw 1994). Its diet consists largely of fruits and seeds, with high rates of nectarivory in some months of the year. Foraging activity is concentrated in the early morning (Horn 1987, Gautier-Hion & Maisels 1994, McGraw 1994).
threats:
Little is known about the status of this species. However, it is subject to intense, uncontrolled poaching for its meat in most parts of its range. It is also threatened by loss of forest habitat in the south of its range. Bushmeat data collected along the Congo River suggest that very few of these monkeys have been sold at the markets during the past decade; implying that very few are left in the forest (Laudisoit, pers. obs. late 2010s). Black Mangabeys are large-bodied, and provide more meat per unit effort than the smaller guenons (Cercopithecus spp.) with which they share the habitat. They are, therefore, more attractive to hunters, especially if shotguns are used (a shotgun cartridge costs about US$1 in the region). Quantitatively, a recce survey between the two sectors of the Salonga National Park in 2009 (Maisels et al. 2009) showed that monkeys in general, and Black Mangabeys in particular, were very rare to the west of the park headquarters at Monkoto, and increasingly rare to absent at the western extreme (where the highest concentrations of people are located in the corridor). Overall encounter rate was 0.13 groups/km. A recce survey carried out at the same time and using the same survey method in the unprotected Sankuru Reserve (Liengola et al. 2010) recorded the species only 10 times in 400 km of survey effort – an encounter rate of only 0.025/km walked, and one-fifth of that recorded in the Salonga corridor, which was (and still is) at least partially protected by forest guards.

In Salonga in 2016–2017, encounter rate of groups on transects varied between 0.2 (southern sector of the park) to 0.3 (northern sector) (Wildlife Conservation Society unpublished data 2016 and 2017, Ikati et al. 2017), so still an order of magnitude greater than encounter rates outside the park. It is likely that most unprotected forests in the range of this species are defaunated of the larger-bodied species, including Black Mangabeys. They had completely vanished from the Swa-Kabula Reserve in the southwest of the country before 1990 (Dino 2014). The same is likely to have occurred throughout their range, especially where human populations can travel freely and rapidly through the habitat (the case in savanna-forest mosaics south of the Kasai River).

Rates of forest loss differ in the geographic ranges of the two subspecies. In the 130,000 km² range of L. a. opdenboschi, about 99,500 km² has forest cover (this area is the savanna-forest mosaic south of the Kasai River). A total of 3.7% of the forest cover that existed in 2001 was lost between 2001 and 2016 (GFW/WRI 2018). In L. a. aterrimus range, in the more closed-canopy continuous Congo Basin forests further north, the forest cover loss was only 2% during the same period – just over half of the rate of loss further south (of the subspecies' total range of 585,300 km²).
population: Although Lophocebus aterrimus is widespread, its total population size is unknown and surveys are needed. Several decades ago, densities of around 70 individuals/km² were recorded in Lomako and Lac Tumba in DRC (Horn 1987, McGraw 1994). The population is suspected to have undergone a reduction of at least 30% over the last 30 years (three generations) based on intensifying hunting pressure on this species for the bushmeat trade and habitat loss in the south of its range.
range:
Lophocebus aterrimus occurs south of the Congo River in Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), in lowland rainforest areas of the southwest Congo Basin. It is also found in gallery forests and more fragmented forests reaching down into northern Angola to about 8°45’ S (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999). The western, northern and eastern limits of the geographic range are the left bank of the Congo River. South of the Kasai River, the taxon is limited to the west by the Kwango River, and to the south by the forest-savanna boundary.

There are two subspecies (following Grubb et al. 2003): L. aterrimus aterrimus is found in the central Congo basin; L. a. opdenboschi is/was found in a very small area of northeastern Angola (Machado 1969, Gautier-Hion 2013), and in southwestern DRC. The two subspecies are separated by the Kasai River, which cuts diagonally across the range at roughly 3° to 4° S. The Black Mangabey was extirpated from the Swa-Kibula Reserve, a protected area on the Angolan border, before 1990 (Dino 2014). It is possible that it has been extirpated from Angola, and from much of the area south of the Kasai River.
useTrade: Illegally hunted for local consumption
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and as Class B of the African Convention. It is on the partially protected species list in DRC (Enerunga 2006). In Angola, all monkeys have been officially protected by Presidential Decree since 2005.

It is present in Salonga National Park (which is probably its main stronghold), Lomami National Park, where it is protected by wildlife guards (Hart et al. 2012), and has been recorded in Sankuru Natural Reserve (in very low numbers). It is also found in Lomako-Yokokala Wildlife Reserve (Lushimba 2012). In the west of their range, they still occur in the Tumba-Ledima Natural Reserve (Beudels-Jamar et al. 2015, Petre and Haggis 2017).

rationale: The species is listed as Least Concern mainly due to its wide distribution range and presumed large populations. However, further studies are required to verify the present status of its populations throughout its entire distribution range, especially in areas where the species continues to be taken for biomedical research (Brazil-Colombia-Peru border) and for illegal pet trade (north eastern Peru), and where deforestation has increased considerably during the past 10 years (Ecuador and Peru).
habitat:
Night monkeys typically occur in primary and secondary forests (including fragmented forest and selectively logged forest), seasonally flooded and terra firme forests, and in lowland and sub-montane forests (Hernández-Camacho and Cooper 1976; Aquino and Encarnación 1994a; Defler 2004; Tirira 2007; Maldonado and Peck 2014). In Ecuador, this species occurs in humid tropical forests between 200 and 900 m asl, and in subtropical forests up to 1,550 m (Tirira 2007).

Night monkeys are nocturnal and they are most active at dawn and dusk. During the day A. vociferans groups rest within holes in trees and old palms, mainly at heights of between 10-20 m. These nests are occasionally shared with other mammals (Puertas et al. 1995; Tirira 2007). Their diet includes fruit, nectar and flowers, leaves, and small animal prey such as insects (Wright 1989; Fernandez-Duque 2007).

As other Aotus species, A. vociferans are socially monogamous and live in small groups of between 3 and 5 individuals, composed of an adult pair and offspring of different ages, with an average group size of 3.3 individuals (Fernandez-Duque et al. 2008; Defler 2010). Males carry infants (Rotundo et al. 2002, 2005). Both sexes disperse. Night monkeys are territorial—groups occupy overlapping territories of 5-18 ha (depending on the species and location) (Wright 1978, 1981; Fernandez-Duque 2007). Fernandez-Duque et al. (2008) estimated a home range size of 6.3 ha for A. vociferans in Yasuní National Park, and observed groups ranging over their territories only at night, and more actively under a full moon.

The average weight of adult A. vociferans individuals is of 707.5 g for males and 698 g for females (Defler 2010). Captive male A. lemurinus reach sexual maturity at 2 years of age, and captive female A. vociferans and A. nancymaae first breed at 3-4 years. Single offspring are the rule (Fernandez-Duque 2007).
threats:
The species has been reported to be widely distributed in Ecuador and Peru (Aquino and Encarnación 1994a; Tirira 2007). However, deforestation has increased in its distribution range during the last 10 years, threatening these populations (De La Torre et al. 2011, Llactayo et al. 2013).

The status of A. vociferans populations in Ecuador is unknown. However, given the actual conditions of the habitat within its distribution (large extensions of forest converted to agriculture and silvo-pasture land), it is inferred that the species has been affected (De La Torre et al. 2011). Furthermore, in the Napo region of Peru, deforestation along river systems is high and increasing, as is deforestation from oil exploration and exploitation, together with associated immigration.

The long-term and systematic capture of large numbers of individuals for biomedical research in Colombia, and the release of individuals post-experimentation, are the main threats for A. vociferans populations in the Brazil-Colombia-Peru border. The species has not been reported in the north bank of the Amazon River in Colombia for the last seven years, where the species has been systematically taken since the early 1980’s for local malaria research (Maldonado and Peck 2014). Furthermore, Ruiz‐Garcia et al. (2013) and Maldonado and Peck (2014) suggested that the long term post-experimental releases of A. nancymaae in Colombia may have displaced wild populations of A. vociferans at release sites. However, long‐term population studies are required to precisely determine the current status of A. vociferans in the area, and to clarify the taxonomy of the genus at the Brazil-Colombia-Peru border area to allow environmental authorities to implement a management plan for local A. vociferans populations (Maldonado et al., 2009; Ruiz-García et al. 2013).
population: Aquino and Encarnación (1988) estimated a density of 33.0 individuals/km², and Heltne (1977) 7.9 individuals/km² in northeastern Peru. Aquino and Encarnación (1994b) reviewed population structure and densities for the genus. Maldonado and Peck (2014) reported a density of 24.9 individuals/km² in terra firme forests at the Amacayacu National Park, Colombian Amazon.
range:
Aotus vociferans occurs almost exclusively to the north of the Amazon River, extending to Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru. A small enclave population is found on the right bank of the Solimões River, near the lower Purus River. However, Vidal et al. (2013) reported a group 220 miles west of this enclave, suggesting a possible extension of the species distribution to the south of the Amazon River.

To the north of the Amazon River its distribution is limited by geographical barriers: to the north by the Guaviare river in Colombia, to the west by the Andean Ridge, and to the east probably by the Rio Negro in Brazil (Aquino and Encarnación 1988, 1994; Defler 2010; Groves 2005; Hernandez-Camacho and Cooper 1976).
useTrade: Aotus vociferans individuals are taken to be used in biomedical research in Colombia (Maldonado et al. 2009; Maldonado and Peck 2014). In 2015, the environmental authority Corpoamazonia authorised the capture of 1463 animals during a period of 566 days for malaria research. However, there is no information on the status of the local population to properly determine extraction quotas (Corpoamazonia 2015).
conservationActions:
The species is listed on Appendix II of CITES.

The species is classified as Near Threatened (NT) in the Red Book of Mammals of Ecuador (De La Torre et al. 2011).

The species is confirmed, or may occur, in a number of protected areas:

Colombia
Amacayacu Natural National Park (293,000 ha) ( Defler 2004, Maldonado and Peck, 2014)
Cahuinari Natural National Park (575,500 ha) (in range, Defler 2004)
Serrania de Chiribiquete Natural National Park (1,280,000 ha) (in range, Defler 2004)
Cordillera de los Picachos Natural National Park (286,600 ha) (in range, Defler 2004)
La Paya Natural National Park (442,000 ha) (Polanco-Ochoa et al. 1999)
Nukak Natural National Reserve (855,000 ha) (in range, Defler 2004)
Puinawai Natural National Reserve (1,092,500 ha) (in range, Defler 2004)

Ecuador
Yasuní National Park (982,000 ha) (Tirira 2007)
Sumaco-Napo Galeras National Park (205,249 ha) (Tirira 2007)
Cayambe-Coca Ecological Reserve (403,000 ha) (in range) (Tirira 2007)
Limoncocha Biological Reserve (4,613 ha) (in range) (Tirira 2007)
Cuyabeno Faunistic Reserve (603,380 ha) (in range) (Tirira 2007)
Cóndor National Park (2,440 ha) (Tirira 2007)


Brazil
Jaú National Park (2,378,410 ha)
Juamí-Japurá Ecological Station (832,078 ha)
Mamirauá State Sustainable Development Reserve (1,124,000 ha)
Amanã State Sustainable Development Reserve (2,350,000 ha)

Peru
Reserva Nacional Pucacuro (637,954 ha)

Parque Nacional Güeppí-Sekime (203,628 ha)


Given the increasing threats faced by A. vociferans and the lack of information on the present status of its populations, it is recommended that:

  • Population density estimations are undertaken in protected areas and areas where the species is most vulnerable (see Threats).

  • The effects of long-term extraction and post-experimental release of individuals on local populations are evaluated (see Threats).

  • The subspecies’ resilience to human impact, deforestation and hunting pressure is evaluated.

  • Suitable practices of landscape management are developed that contribute to the sustainable use of resources, minimizing the impact on primate populations and habitat.

  • National campaigns to prevent illegal trade are instigated.

rationale: Despite an ongoing study, the species is listed as Data Deficient as there is little information on the occurrence, distribution, population status and threats.
habitat:
Inhabits dense tropical rain forest. Marmosets and tamarins are distinguished from the other monkeys of the New World by their small size, modified claws rather than nails on all digits except the big toe, the presence of two as opposed to three molar teeth in either side of each jaw, and by the occurrence of twin births. They eat fruits, flowers, nectar, plant exudates (gums, saps, latex) and animal prey (including frogs, snails, lizards, spiders and insects). Marmosets have morphological and behavioural adaptations for gouging tree trunks, branches and vines of certain species to stimulate the flow of gum, which they eat, and in some species form a notable component of the diet (Coimbra-Filho and Mittermeier 1976; Rylands 1984). They live in extended family groups of four to 15 individuals. Generally, only one female per group breeds during a particular breeding season. The groups defend home ranges of 10-40 ha, the size depending on the availability and distribution of food and second-growth patches.

Neither behavioural nor ecological field studies have been carried out on this species.
threats: Siva et al. (in prep) reported that the main threat identified around the cities of Apuí, Novo Aripuanã and Manicoré (southern Amazon) is habitat loss due to selective logging and forest conversion for cattle ranching. In addition, the National Agency of Electric Energy of Brazilian Government approved the implementation of 7 hydroelectric schemes at the Aripuanã and Rosevelt Rivers. Just the reservoir of these hydroelectric plants will flood a forest area of 900 km². Silva et al. (in prep) reported that this marmoset species is kept as a pet.
population: There is no information reagarding the population status for this species.
range: Silva et al. (in prep.) collected data on the distribution of M. marcai between the Marmelos and Aripuanã Rivers. Ferrari (1993, 1994) reported the collection of an adult female “C. emiliae” on the east bank of the Rio dos Marmelos, opposite the Tenharin settlement on the west bank (07º57'S, 62º03'W; for the correct location of Tenharin see Ferrari 1994). Ferrari (1993) states that it is easily distinguished from M. nigriceps (collected on the west bank at the same location) by the lack of pigmentation on the facial skin. It seems that Ferrari (1993) presumed the identity of this animal to be C. emiliae based on Vivo (1985, 1991) who stated that C. emiliae occurred on the left (west) bank of the Rio Aripuanã. His interpretation is based on the identity of the marmoset from the Rio Castanho, here listed as Mico marcai (Alperin 1993). Silva et al. (in prep.) confirmed that the adult female reported by Ferrari (1993, 1994) is M. marcai based on morphological and molecular data from new specimens collected in the same region. The same authors recorded the species on both banks of Manicoré River confirming that this river is not a barrier for its dispersion. The geographical range of this species is limited by the Rivers Aripuanã (East), Madeira (North) and Marmelos/Jiparaná (West). The southern limit is unclear due to uncertain taxonomy of the marmosets located south of the savannah vegetation in the Campos Amazônicos National Park.
conservationActions: The species was confirmed by Silva et al. (in prep) and Röhe (2007) in the following protected areas: Campos Amazônicos National Park, Juma Reserve for Sustainable Development and in the Indigenous Land Tenharim Marmelos. It is listed on Appendix II of CITES (as Callithrix marcai).

rationale: Plecturocebus hoffmannsi occurs in the Abacaxis /Canumã-Tapajós interfluvium, between the states of Amazonas and Pará. It is a common species and is tolerant of environmental changes. There are no major threats. In addition, the species is present in large protected areas. Therefore, P. hoffmannsi is categorised as Least Concern (LC).
habitat:
No data on the ecology of this species are available. Members of the P. moloch and P. cupreus groups are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (van Roosmalen et al. 2002). In Resex Tapajós-Arapiuns, the species seems to be more common in disturbed habitats near human communities than in primary forest (A. Ravetta, unpublished data).
The diet of titis comprises mainly fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds (Kinzey, 1981). They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small home range up to 25 ha  and daily movements are relatively limited, with mean of 600-800m being typical (Ferrari et al. 2013).
threats: There are no major threats to the taxon but deforestation and habitat reduction occurs in the eastern part of the distribution. In addition, its distribution is cut by the Transamazônica highway (BR-230) and the implementation of the São Luís hydroelectric plant on the Tapajós River will result in habitat loss.
population: Recorded densities are from 1 to 3.3 groups /10 km, 0.81 to 2.43 groups / km², and 1.68 to 5.04 ind. /km² in the middle and lower Rio Tapajós region (A. Ravetta, unpublished data).
range: Plecturocebus hoffmannsi is endemic to Brazil, occurring in the Central Amazon, south of the Amazon River in the interfluvium Abacaxis/Canumã-Tapajós, states of Amazonas and Pará.The exact range of this genus in the Tapajós-Madeira interfluvium remains unknown (Silva Jr. and Noronha 2000). In a recent study (Noronha et al. 2007), a gray Plecturocebus was recorded with light spots on its throat (possibly P. hoffmannsi) near the Palmares River (06 ° 34`S, 58 28`W) in Maués Municipality, Amazonas. Van Roosmalen et al. (2002) confirmed that P. hoffmannsi and P. baptista are parapatrics, and it is suspected that the P. bernhardi, P. cinerascens and P. hoffmannsi distributions are possibly parapatric in the region of the Juruena, Aripuanã and Roosevelt rivers (Noronha et al. 2007).
conservationActions: This species occurs in Amazon National Park (1,084,895 ha), Amana National Forest (539,571 ha), Tapajós-Arapiuns Extractive Reserve (677,513 ha)  and  Andira Marau Amerindian Reserve. It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Olive Colobus (Procolobus verus) is listed as Vulnerable, compared to Near Threatened in the previous assessment, as this species is estimated to have undergone a decline exceeding 30% over the past three generations (approximately 27 years), mainly as a result of continuing habitat loss and hunting. Data summarised by FAO (2015) show that in the 1990–2015 period there was a 22.5% reduction of forest across the eight West African countries where the Olive Colobus occurs. When combined with evidence of continued heavy hunting pressure for the bushmeat trade, those data can be used to suspect at least a 30% reduction in population size in a 27-year period. The cryptic nature of the Olive Colobus, and its ability to survive in riverine forests and small forest fragments, and to adapt to some anthropogenic disturbance, have no doubt enabled the species to persist in many parts of their range. However, their decline is expected to continue in the future and, given an accelerating loss of forest habitat in West Africa (which already has one of the highest rates in the world) and continuing hunting pressure, both of which are related to continued high rates of human population growth in West Africa, Procolobus verus is evaluated as Vulnerable under both A2cd and A4cd.
habitat: This species, the smallest of all colobine monkeys, inhabits the forest zone of West Africa and is often associated with areas of secondary growth within high forest, and with swamp forests. The Olive Colobus has also been observed in forest galleries in dry forest regions. It can survive in quite small and degraded forest fragments. Olive Colobus are arboreal and most commonly occupy the lower and middle forest strata, but they will occasionally descend and move on the ground. They are cryptic in colouration and behaviour, live in small social groups, and typically associate closely with other forest monkeys, especially Cercopithecus species (Oates and Whitesides 1990, Nobimè and Sinsin 2003, Oates 2011, Oates and Korstjens 2013). The monkeys prefer dense growth below 20 m, but may ascend higher when feeding or moving in the company of other species. The diet of the Olive Colobus is comprised mainly of leaves and leaf parts (75-90%), especially young leaves, along with flowers and unripe seeds (Oates and Korstjens 2013).
threats: This species is almost certainly declining due to loss of its forest habitats and hunting. Although the Olive Colobus can live in disturbed forests, even secondary forest is being replaced by farms and plantations in many parts of West Africa, and other species of monkey with which the Olive Colobus typically associates are being eliminated by hunting. Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone are among three of 10 countries in the world that had the fastest annual acceleration of tree cover loss in the 2001–2014 period, based on an analysis of satellite imagery, with Sierra Leone (once a stronghold for this species) recording the world’s second greatest annual forest loss rate of 12.6% (Petersen et al. 2015). In Nigeria, in the most easterly part of the species range, P. verus can be considered Endangered as a consequence of heavy hunting pressure and escalating habitat loss (R. Ikemeh pers. comm. 2016); data from the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization show a 5% per annum loss of forest cover in Nigeria in the 2010–2015 period compared with 2.7% per annum in 1990–2000 (FAO 2015). The same data analysis (FAO 2015) shows that in the eight countries in which Olive Colobus populations have been found (Benin, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria, Sierra Leone and Togo) there was a combined total forest loss in the 1990–2015 period of 22.5%. A separate analysis by the U.S. Geological Survey’s EROS Centre shows a total forest loss in the Upper Guinea region (excluding Benin and Nigeria) of 25% between 1975 and 2013 (CILSS 2016). Given the continuation of uncontrolled hunting of monkeys across much of this species’ range, it is suspected that P. verus has suffered a population reduction of at least 30% in the last three generations, and that this decline will accelerate in the future.
population: Although quite secretive, Olive Colobus are still present in many parts of their range; however, they have naturally low population densities (McGraw 2007) and are almost certainly declining in numbers. Surveys in Kakum Conservation Area, Ghana, in 2009–2010 encountered this species at a lower rate than reported from surveys in 1993 (Wiafe 2016). Surveys in southwestern Ghana in 2012 reported its presence in the forest reserves of Krokosua Hills, Ayum, Subin, Bia North, Mpameso, Bia-Tano and Bokoni, at encounter rates of between 0.03 and 0.13 groups per km, and in Bia National Park at 0.23 groups per km (Danquah et al. 2012). In Côte d’Ivoire, recent surveys reported the presence of the species in several protected and unprotected areas, but at very low densities (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2014). In Côte d’Ivoire the most important populations occur in the Tanoé Forest and in Taï National Park, where estimated densities are 1.9 groups per sq. km (S. Gonedelé Bi pers. obs. 2009) and 2.65 groups per km² (Covey 2009) respectively. In the 1980s, the density in secondary and riverine forest at Tiwai Island, Sierra Leone, was 1.2 groups per km² (Oates et al. 1990). A recent survey of Benin found them to have a more widespread distribution than previously known (Djego-Djossou et al. 2014), but with a small total population; none were observed during a 2015 survey in neighbouring Togo (G. Segniagbeto pers. comm. 2016).
range: The Olive Colobus is confined to the forests of West Africa, and is discontinuously distributed from southern Sierra Leone and Guinea to south-east Nigeria (Oates 1981, 2011). The main discontinuity in their recent distribution appears to be in western Nigeria, between the border with the Republic of Benin and the River Niger; populations are known in the Niger Delta and in southern Benue State, Nigeria, just east of the Niger. However, the species’ distribution in eastern Ghana, and Togo and Benin also appears to be very patchy. In a few localities (e.g., Taï National Park, Côte d'Ivoire) it is relatively numerous.
useTrade: Procolobus verus and other forest monkeys species in West Africa are widely hunted to provide meat for local consumption, among families and communities.
conservationActions: The Olive Colobus is listed as a Class A species under the African Convention, and under Appendix II of CITES. It occurs in a number of protected areas.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern, despite increasing hunting pressure on this taxon. Cercopithecus cephus is under threat in large parts of Cameroon, Central African Republic (close to Bangui) and Democratic Republic of Congo, and has become rare in most of central and southern Congo, but remains common and widespread in Gabon and northern Congo. A population decrease is suspected; however, data needed to quantify the threats and any resulting declines are lacking.
habitat: This diurnal, arboreal species is largely associated with lowland tropical rainforest, preferring the lower levels; often in vegetation tangles; also be found in secondary habitat types and gallery forests (Gautier-Hion 2013). Common in mangroves along the coast of Congo (Maisels and Cruickshank 1996). Primarily a frugivorous species; also eats seeds, leaves, arthropods, fledgling birds and eggs (Tutin and White 1998). Density ranges from 4 to 66 individuals/km²; group size up to 22 individuals (Gautier-Hion 2013).
threats:
This species has been heavily impacted by habitat loss through deforestation and hunting for bushmeat. Improvements in the transport network across the species’ range have led to increased commercialisation of offtake from previously subsistence villages. Across the region, village hunters now regularly sell 40-60% of their offtake (Abernethy et al. 2013). C. cephus (along with other Cercopithecus species) is commonly traded in many rural markets across its range (Fa & Brown, 2009). In general, primates decline under sustained hunting pressure and increasing human populations (Fa et al. 2015).

Of the three subspecies, C.c. ngottoensis is likely to be under highest threat, due to its relatively small geographic range and a higher proportion of that range experiencing high hunting pressure and possible disruption from armed conflicts.
population: Cercopithecus cephus has become extremely rare due to intense hunting for bushmeat, especially the savanna-forest mosaics of central Congo, the forests of coastal Congo outside protected areas, and in DRC. Hunting pressure has resulted in the species becoming extremely rare in parts of southern Congo (Kouilou in Congo: Dowsett and Dowsett-Lemaire 1991; Lefini and Lesio-Louna: Nganga et al. 2006). A 2011 survey that covered the whole of Equatorial Guinea recorded this species only a handful of times. In northern Congo and much of Gabon, this monkey is still common and widespread. Data are lacking to quantify threats and resulting declines.
range:
Cercopithecus cephus ranges from the Sanaga River in Cameroon south and east to the Congo River, to the lower Congo in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The northern limit appears to be the forest-savanna ecotone at about 5 to 6 degrees North. The area covered by the species distribution is about 836,650 km². The 2008 Red List assessment did not include the areas of the Mayombe in Gabon and Congo near the Gabon-Congo border, but they are still present in southern coastal Gabon (Aba’a et al. 2011, Mackaya 2011, R.J. Parnell pers. obs.) and Congo (MDDEFE 2010), and in southern Republic of Congo (Inkamba-Nkulu 2005). They were also in the Dimonika area in southern Congo to at least 1995 (Feer 1990, Ihobe 1995) and may still be there. 

Three subspecies are recognised: C. c. cephus occurs within about 70% of the species’ range, in Cameroon, Gabon, Equatorial Guinea, Congo and Central African Republic (CAR). It is limited to the north by the Sanaga River in Cameroon and the Ogooué River in the south. C. c. cephodes occurs south of the Ogooué River in Gabon, Congo, Angola (Cabinda) and a small area of coastal DRC, where its southern limit is the Congo River. A third subspecies C. c. ngottoensis is found in CAR, where it is known from the Kadei-Mambéré region east to the Ubangui, occurring as far north as Bangui and northern Congo; the southwestern limit is unknown.
useTrade: This species is hunted illegally for local consumption and sale to bushmeat markets.
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES, Annex B of the EU Wildlife Trade Regulations and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

This widespread species is present in all of the protected areas in Gabon, Equatorial Guinea, most PAs in Congo, in the forested PAs of southwest CAR, and in PAs south of the Sanaga in Cameroon up to, and including, the southern sector of the Mbam et Djerem National Park (Maisels et al. 2009). Occurs in one PA in Cabinda (Mayombe National Park; Ron 2011) and used to be - and may still be found - in the Luki Reserve in DRC (Pendje and Baya 1992). 

The recently described ngottoensis subspecies is present in the proposed Mbaere-Bodingue park in CAR, but absent from the Dzanga-Ndoki National Park and the contiguous Nouabalé-Ndoki National Park in Congo, and has not been recorded in any other protected area in that region (Brugière et al. 2005).

rationale: This species is assessed as Near Threatened due to widespread heavy hunting pressure, combined with habitat loss and degradation. Increasing human population density, hunting intensity and deforestation make it unlikely that pressure on Cercopithecus nictitans will subside in the short term. It is suspected that the ongoing decline across the range will be in the order of 20–25% within three generations (ca 27 years), from 2003 projected to 2030. Therefore the taxon almost qualifies as threatened under criterion A4cd.
habitat: The Putty-nosed Monkey is an arboreal species present in lowland and mid-elevation montane tropical moist forest, gallery forest and secondary forest; it is less commonly found in swamp forest. This species generally lives in groups of between 12 and 30 animals. It prefers the middle and upper strata of the forest canopy, and is uncommonly encountered below 10 m or on the ground (Gautier-Hion 2013).
threats:
The Putty-nosed Monkey is threatened by bushmeat hunting and by habitat loss through deforestation for timber and agricultural land, especially in the west of its range.

Hunting is an increasing threat throughout its range, as monkey meat is consumed in villages or traded to urban populations.
