rationale: Miss Waldron's Red Colobus is listed as Critically Endangered as the species is estimated to have undergone a population decline of more than 80% in the 30 years (approximately three generations) up until the last authenticated specimen (killed by a hunter) was found in 2002. Calls of what are believed to be this animal were heard in early 2008, but no wild animal has been seen by an experienced field-worker for 40 years. Therefore this monkey is regarded as possibly extinct. Its disappearance from its former range in the forests of eastern Côte d’Ivoire and western Ghana was almost certainly caused by excessive hunting for the bushmeat trade, combined with a loss of mature forest habitat.
habitat: Miss Waldron’s Red Colobus was restricted to tropical moist and semi-deciduous forest, and swamp forest, where it typically used the upper canopy (Martin 1991). Two groups studied in Bia National Park in Ghana in the 1970s comprised 34 and 58 individuals, had home ranges of 100–140 ha, and had a diet consisting predominantly of leaves but also fruits, seeds and flowers (Martin 1991).
threats: The major causes of the decline of the species were hunting and habitat loss (Oates et al. 2000). Both subsistence and commercial hunting (for the bushmeat trade) heavily impacted populations of this species, and improved access to forest interiors via logging roads increased hunting pressure. Deforestation through logging, charcoal production, cocoa farming and clearance for agricultural land (including industrial oil palm and rubber tree plantations), occurred over much of the species range in the last 50-60 years.
population: There have been no confirmed sightings of Miss Waldron's Red Colobus in the wild since 1978 and surveys carried out from 1993 to the present have failed to produce a sighting of living individuals (Oates et al. 2000, McGraw 2005, Oates 2011). The last evidence for the survival of a small population came from the Tanoé Swamp Forest between the Ehy lagoon and the Tanoé River in extreme south-eastern Côte d'Ivoire (McGraw and Oates 2002, McGraw 2005, Gonedelé Bi et al. 2008), near which a skin was found in possession of a hunter in 2002 and where calls by what is believed to be Miss Waldron's Red Colobus were heard in March 2008 by a team of scientists from the Centre Suisse de Recherches Scientifiques en Côte d’Ivoire (I. Koné pers. comm. 2008).
range: Piliocolobus waldroni ranged from the Nzi-Bandama River system in south-eastern Côte d'Ivoire to south-western Ghana, but did not reach the Volta River (Oates et al. 2000, McGraw 2005, Oates 2011). Its numbers were declining in Ghana 60 years ago, when Booth (1956) predicted its extinction in the near future. The last evidence for the monkey’s survival came from swamp forests between the Ehy lagoon and Tanoé River in south-eastern Côte d'Ivoire (McGraw 2005, Gonedelé Bi et al. 2008).
useTrade: This species was known to be heavily hunted.
conservationActions: This taxon is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the  African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern, despite increasing hunting and persecution of this taxon. Cercopithecus agilis usually occurs at low density and a significant population decrease is suspected; however, data needed to quantify the threats and any resulting declines are lacking.
habitat:
In the west of its range, this species is generally found in riparian or periodically-flooded swamp forest (Gautier-Hion and Brugière 2005). In Odzala-Kokoua National Park in Congo, they use seasonally-inundated and riverine habitats and occasionally the Marantaceae-dominated terra firma forests (Maisels 1995, 1996). In the area east of Makokou in Gabon, they were found in riverine forests (Quris 1975). By contrast, a study group at Mondika in CAR spent most of its time in terra firma mixed forest, and was never observed along the Mondika River, nor in swamp forest along the Ndoki River (Shah 2003), whereas a group at Bai Hokou, also in CAR, spent some time along rivers and streams (N. Shah pers. obs. 2003). Cercocebus agilis also uses open-understorey Gilbertiodendron dewevrei dominated forest (Shah 2003, Devreese 2011). In the north of its range, the species will use the gallery forests in savanna-forest mosaics of northern CAR (Fay 1988), and in the east (e.g., Okapi Wildlife Reserve), it uses terra firma forests, but will sometimes forage on crops (Kambale Saambere 1999). These monkeys are usually active in lower strata (0–10 m) of the habitat (Quris 1975, Shah 2003), although they spend less time on the ground than other Cercocebus spp. (Shah 2003). Home-range size was estimated to be ca 3 km² in Dzanga-Sangha in CAR (Shah 2003), and 2 km² in Gabon (Quris 1975).

Agile Mangabeys have strong dietary preferences for fruit, seeds and monocotyledon shoots, and can bite through the hard shells of some fruits, such as Strychnos (Shah 2003). They also prey on animals up to the size of infant Peters’ Duikers (Knights et al. 2008, Shah 2013).

In CAR, mean group size was 21 at Mondika, but a habituated group at nearby Bai Hokou numbered 135 animals, and on occasion it reached 330 individuals (Devreese et al. 2013). In northeastern Gabon, group size ranged between 8 and 18 (Quris 1975). In Odzala-Kokoua National Park (Congo), group size was usually >20 (Maisels 1996). In Ituri (DRC), it was 24 (Kambale Saambili 1999), in Ngotto Forest (CAR) it was 20 (D. Brugière, pers. comm. 2013). Groups of 50–200 have been observed in southeast Cameroon (Usongo and Fimbel 1995), northeast Gabon (Quris 1975) and northeast DRC (Kambale Saambili 1999).
threats:
Cercocebus agilis is hunted throughout its range for bushmeat and sometimes persecuted for crop raiding. Because these monkeys spend a fair proportion of time on the ground, they are vulnerable to snaring – a method of hunting used throughout its geographic range. Snares are usually set for forest antelopes and rodents, but can catch any terrestrial animal.

At the western, northern and eastern edges of its range, this species is threatened by habitat loss caused by deforestation for timber and firewood. An analysis of forest loss suggests that 1.3% of the forest in its range was lost between 2001 and 2016 (13,368 km² of the 1 million km² range). However, because this taxon occurs primarily along rivers, this may be an underestimate of the true loss of habitat, as forest loss in the savanna-forest mosaic will be concentrated along rivers and galleries.
population:
Few data exist on abundance relative to human pressure, but even in 1996, in the more westerly part of its range (Lobéké NP, Cameroon), the abundance of C. agilis was an order of magnitude lower than the smaller-bodied, sympatric guenons at that site, and it was recorded only at distances of over 20 km from a road (an indicator of high hunting pressure), whereas smaller-bodied primate species still occurred close to the road (WCS unpublished data 1996). In the most easterly part of its range, in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve, encounter rates on surveys declined by an order of magnitude (WCS unpublished data 2018) over the last decade. This is attributed to increased hunting pressure, due to easier access along a much-improved main road, to the influx of large numbers of people into the area for artisanal mining, and to ongoing civil unrest in eastern DRC.

Densities of Agile Mangabeys appear to be highly variable, presumably influenced by both habitat type and hunting pressure. Population density in Gabon has been recorded at between 6.7 and 12.5 individuals/km² (Quris 1975). At Mondika in Nouabalé-Ndoki National Park (Congo), density was 6.9 individuals/km² (Shah 2003). In Odzala-Kokoua National Park (Congo), group size was usually at least 20, and there were between 0.5 and 2 groups/km² (10–40 animals/km²), depending on the habitat type (Maisels 1996). In the Ituri Forest (DRC), densities varied between 2 individuals/km² (Thomas 1991) and 38 individuals/km² (Kambale Saambili 1998). In the Ngotto Forest (CAR), densities varied between 7.2 and 41 individuals/km² – variation here was related to hunting intensity by humans (D. Brugière pers. comm. 2013).
range:
The geographic range of Cercocebus agilis is not well known, despite covering about 1,010,000 km². This species occurs in Cameroon, Central African Republic (CAR), the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), northeast Gabon and northern Republic of Congo. It remains to be confirmed whether it still occurs in Equatorial Guinea.

The most westerly subpopulation, which may be isolated, appears to be in Campo Ma’an in southern Cameroon, as recorded by three different surveys (Etoga and Foguekem 2008, 2009; Nzooh Dongmo 2015). The Agile Mangabey is, therefore, expected to occur in Equatorial Guinea; however, since the 1960s, when a single adult female was recorded by Sabater Pi and Jones (1968), no survey has re-confirmed the presence of this species (Larison et al. 1999, Puit and Ghiurghi 2004, Sunderland 2005, Ruffler et al. 2012).

The northerly range limit is the forest ecotone from north of the Dja Biosphere Reserve in Cameroon, perhaps at 5°N, across to the Ubangui River, the gallery forest areas in CAR, up to about 9° N (Fay 1988). East of 22° E, the northern limit is likely around 6° 45’ N across to about 30°E, including the area of DRC southwards to at least the Tshopo River.

The southern limit is the right bank of the Congo River, probably from its confluence with the Tshopo (J. Hart pers. obs.) westward to the Sangha-Congo confluence at 1°6’ S. The range is then limited by the southwestern edge of the swamp forests (around 0°18’S up to just south of Odzala National Park (NP) at about 0°30’ S, and continues westwards across Gabon to Cameroon – west of the Dja Biosphere Reserve, near Sangemelima at around 11°30’ E (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999).
useTrade: <span class="msoIns">This species is hunted throughout its range for bushmeat.
conservationActions:
Cercocebus agilis is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Nationally, it is listed as partially protected in Cameroon, Congo and DRC. The hunting, sale, and consumption of primates are forbidden in Equatorial Guinea by Presidential Decree. It is on List C of Annex 2 to Ordinance 84.045 of 1984 in CAR, and not mentioned in Gabon’s protected species list. Cameroon, Gabon and Congo are currently revising their protected species lists.

To determine the western limits of its distribution, it is recommended that people familiar with both the call and appearance of C. torquatus, C. agilis (and Lophocebus albigena) undertake surveys in Campo Ma’an National Park and the areas between there and Dja Biosphere Reserve to be sure whether or not the two Cercocebus spp. are indeed sympatric. If C. agilis is confirmed there, then it may well also still occur in Equatorial Guinea and efforts should be made to look for this species there also.

Agile Mangabeys have been recorded in a number of protected areas; here we cite only the most recent survey information available:

Cameroon: Lobéké NP (Nzooh Dongmo et al. 2016a); Boumba Bek NP and Nki NP (Nzooh Dongmo et al. 2016b); Mengame Gorilla Sanctuary (Ekobo 2006); Dja Biosphere Reserve – already uncommon in 2009 (Latour 2010) and not recorded in 2015 (MINFOF/IUCN 2015; Campo Ma’an NP (Nzooh Dongmo 2015). Not recorded in Abong Mbam or Deng Deng in 2001 (Fotso et al. 2002), nor in Deng Deng in 2012 (Maisels et al. 2013a).

CAR: Dzanga-Ndoki NP (N’Goran et al. 2016), Mbaéré-Bodingué NP (Brugière et al. 2005); Zemongo Reserve (Roulet et al. 2007), Chinko Reserve (R. Hickisch & T. Aebischer, unpublished data 2016).

Congo: Nouabalé-Ndoki NP and Lac Télé Community Reserve (Brncic et al. 2018); Odzala-Kokoua NP (Maisels et al. 2013b).

DRC: Bili-Uéré Hunting Domain (Hicks 2014), Garamba NP (Hillman-Smith et al. 2014), Okapi Wildlife Reserve (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2018).

Gabon: an early study of this species (Quris 1975) recorded its presence south of the Ivindo River (just to the east of what is now the north of Ivindo NP). C. agilis has not been recorded in protected areas of Gabon since. However, Shah (2013) mentions personal communications from well-informed scientists (L.J.T. White and S.A. Lahm) suggesting that Agile Mangabeys may still occur in Ivindo NP, Minkébé NP and Mwagna NP.

rationale: The Zanzibar Red Colobus has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of less than 5,000 km² and an area of occupancy (AOO) of less than 500 km² (376 km², Davenport et al. 2019). Low recruitment, forest loss, illegal killing, human population growth and economic development in the species’ geographic range all justify a projected reduction of the population, its EOO and AOO. Therefore, we apply a categorization of Endangered based on criteria B1 and B2.
habitat: This species lives primarily in areas of ground-water forest, and scrub forest on coral rag along the southern and eastern sides of the island; it is also found in mangrove swamp (Struhsaker and Siex 1998). Most (68.1%) occur in primary and secondary forest, 17.4% in scrub/thicket, 4.5% in shamba, 4.5% in mangrove, 3% mixed vegetation, and 2.6% (Davenport et al. 2019). The Zanzibar Red Colobus is not territorial and lives in multi-male groups, with a mean of 17.1 individuals per group. Mean group sizes are significantly higher in protected areas (20.6) than outside (12.8) (Davenport et al. 2019). Young leaves and leaf buds account for more than 50% of the diet. In forest-dwelling groups, unripe fruit accounts for an additional quarter of the diet, whereas for groups living in agricultural areas, leaves from herbaceous species are the second most eaten item (approximately 15% of the annual diet). Some groups feed on mangrove leaves, and populations on coral rag appear to subsist on a drier, coarser diet than recorded for any other red colobus (Siex 2003).
threats:
The species is increasingly threatened by habitat destruction from agricultural expansion, human development, timber felling and charcoal production. Forest destruction in protected areas remains a problem. Since the eradication of the Zanzibar Leopard, humans have been the main predator. Hunting of primates (the Zanzibar Red Colobus included) for consumption by humans and dogs, and in retribution for crop damage is widespread across Zanzibar (Davenport et al. 2019).

The species has been extirpated from Bambi, Jendele, Kichwele and Nungwi forests in the last 35 years. Only one group survives in each of Dunga, Kibele and Maji Mekundu.

Tourism and residential developments have destroyed habitat in Chwaka, Fumba, Jambiani, Kiwengwa, Mchangamle, Michamvi, Nungwi and Uroa.
population: The total population estimate—established by sweep census—is approximately 5,862 individuals (Davenport et al. 2019), some 3.4 times the mean of all previous estimates. The Jozani-Chwaka Bay National Bay population consists of 2,907 individuals and Kiwengwa Forest Reserve has 628, with 366, 344, 309, 234 and 200 animals in Mchangamle, Ukongoroni, Masingini Forest Reserve, Uzi/Vundwe and Kitogani respectively (Davenport et al. 2019). Only 103 individuals exist in the proposed Jambiani-Muyuni Forest Reserve, but 134 and 139 survive in thickets and shambas (gardens) of Jambiani and Pete (Davenport et al. 2019).
range: This species is endemic to Unguja Island in the Zanzibar Archipelago, where it occurs at elevations of 0–110 m asl (Siex and Struhsaker 2013). Zanzibar Red Colobus may once have occurred on the mainland, but certainly no longer. On Unguja, it is found mainly in the central part of the island in Jozani-Chwaka Bay National Park and nearby Ukongoroni, Kitogani and Dunga (Davenport et al. 2019); in the northeast in Kiwengwa Forest Reserve; and in the southern coral rag forests of Kizimkazi and Mchangamle, Muyuni and Uzi and Vundwe Islands. Also found in isolated populations in coral thickets along Unguja’s eastern coast from Uroa to Cheju, and Michamvi to Jambiani (Davenport et al. 2019). On the west coast there is a small isolated group in the mangroves of Maji Mekundu. A group of 23 individuals were translocated to Masingini Forest Reserve near Stone Town in 1974 (Struhsaker 2010). It is not known if the species formerly existed there. By 2015, this population had grown to 309 individuals (Davenport et al. 2019). In 1973, 14 animals were introduced to Ngezi Forest Reserve, Pemba Island (Struhsaker and Siex 1998), where there are now 35-40 animals; however, discussions are on-going about their removal due to their ‘exotic’ nature and limited genetic variability.
useTrade: Killed illegally as retribution for crop raiding, removal of wildlife to legitimise clearance of forest patches, and to make a political statement about benefit sharing. The carcasses are usually fed to domestic dogs.
conservationActions:
Listed on Appendix I of CITES and as Class A under the African Convention.

Piliocolobus kirkii is nominally protected under Tanzania’s Forest Resource Management and Conservation Act of 1996. About 69% of the total population lives in protected areas: 50% in Jozani-Chwaka Bay National Park (55 km²), 11% in Kiwengwa Forest Reserve, 5% in Masingini Forest Reserve, 1% in Bungi Usalaama army camp and 2% in Jambiani-Muyuni proposed Forest Reserve. The remaining 31% of the population is highly threatened, with most groups already isolated. Greater protection for Uzi and Vundwe islands and Mchangamle has been recommended.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern as it is widespread and abundant, and there are no major threats believed to be resulting in a range-wide decline of the species.
habitat:
The Chacma Baboon occupies all types of woodland, savanna, steppes and subdessert, montane regions (such as the high elevations of the Drakensberg), Cape Fynbos and Succulent Karoo. Cliffs, hills or large trees are necessary night-time retreats. In some habitats, such as in the Namib Desert, habitat choice is influenced by predation risk. This species is totally dependent on drinking daily, and water availability limits its overall range in Namibia. However, one troop in the Kuiseb Canyon, Namib Desert, balanced its water requirements with moisture from nearby plants and conserved water by resting and sleeping during the hottest part of the day. Through this adaptation to their arid environment they temporarily overcame restrictions imposed by the need for regular drinking and were observed to survive without water for up to 11 days and even longer. In dry localities, artificial water supplies have allowed substantial expansion of territory. This species is an opportunistic omnivore and shows a local preference for bulbs, shoots, roots, seeds or fruits. Invertebrates, small vertebrates, seashore life, fungi and lichen are eaten as and when available. Occasionally, they take small antelopes or the young of species like Impala Aepyceros melampus. Crops (maize, tomatoes, citrus and root crops) are raided in settled areas. Lambs and small stock are taken in some ranching areas. They are also known to predate on smaller monkeys. 

Troops average between 20 and 50 animals, but may total up to 130 individuals. Multi-male hierarchies are normal, though smaller troops may only have a single male (in one study in the Drakensberg, one-male groups made up 50% of groups recorded above 2,100 m).
threats: There are no major threats to this species, although problem animals may be shot as vermin. Local population extinctions are known from many farming areas. With changes in land use, populations are also becoming increasingly fragmented. Animals are also hunted and body parts of dead baboons are offered for sale in markets in South Africa for traditional medicinal use, but this is not considered a major threat.
population: This species is common and widespread. Densities can range from 3 or 4 up to 40/km² in some protected localities.
range:
This species ranges all over southern Africa, up to the Zambezi valley (and including south-west Zambia; see Kingdon 2013), Caprivi and southern Angola littoral. Altitudinal range is from sea level to >2,100 m. One region of exclusion is the central Kalahari Desert in South Africa.

There are two subspecies: P. u. griseipes occurs in south-west Zambia, Botswana (Okavango Delta), Zimbabwe and Mozambique, south of the Zambezi River; P. u. ursinus occurs in the remainder of the range south of the Limpopo River, in all provinces in South Africa and throughout Namibia.
conservationActions: It is listed under Appendix II of CITES. Occurs in numerous protected areas across its range.

rationale: Extensive habitat destruction, habitat degradation and intensive hunting throughout its geographical range have led to an inferred decline of more than 80% of the species’ population over the past 27 years (three generations, average generation time of nine years), based on evidence of an 87.2% reduction in encounter rates of C. vellerosus in six sites in Ghana in the last 31 years (Martin & Asibey 1979; Magnuson 2002; Gatti 2010) and the disappearance of the species from about 80% of known sites across its range in Côte d’Ivoire since 2004 (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2014). Between 1975 and 2013, the range countries of Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, Togo, Benin, and Nigeria have experienced an extensive (25-58%) loss of forest (CILSS 2016) and between 2000 and 2012 protected areas in three range countries (Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana and Nigeria) have seen a significant (4.0-6.7 % per annum) decline of forested areas (Spracklen et al. 2015). The high degrees of threat that this species is facing justify upgrading its threat status by two categories compared to the 2008 assessment.
habitat: Found in lowland rainforest, swamp forests, semi-deciduous forests and in gallery forests in the savanna zone. At Kikélé Forest in Benin, Djègo-Djossou et al. (2015) report that the diet of an habituated group consisted of 60.3% leaves, 33.3% fruits, 6.4% other items (seeds, flowers and  tree bark). At Boabeng-Fiema Monkey Sanctuary (BFMS) in Ghana, the species is reported to eat mainly leaves of trees and lianas, along with a small quantity of fruits and seedpods (Kankam and Sicotte 2013).  The Kikélé fissioned into two groups in 2018, one of which contains two adult males in a group of 19 individuals, while the other contains one adult male and one adult female (R. Chabi Ota pers. comm.). At BFMS and in Bia National Park (Ghana), groups were either one-male or multi-male and average group size was between 10 and 15 (range 3–38); home-range size varies between 11 ha and 48 ha (Wong & Sicotte 2006). Groups encountered during surveys in Togo in 2014-2015 varied in size between 4 and 20 (Segniagbeto et al. 2017) while surveys in Kwabre Swamp Forest found small groups of between 3 and 5 (Danquah and Tetteh 2016).
threats: Colobus vellerosus is threatened primarily by hunting and secondarily by habitat loss (McGraw 2005). Accelerated hunting pressure is discernible from reported changes in hunters’ behaviour in the species’ range countries. Thirty years ago, hunters in Ghana and Côte d’Ivoire almost always hunted only larger-bodied animals, but now they are mostly hunting smaller-bodied animals because of the depletion of large primates like C. vellerosus (Decher and Kpelle 2005, Gonedelé Bi et al. 2016). The region the species inhabits has a dense and rapidly growing human population; forest destruction and fragmentation have been extensive, and the hunting of wildlife is uncontrolled in most places, although at several sites the monkeys are held sacred (e.g., Kikélé sacred forest in Benin, Dinaoudi sacred grove in Côte d’Ivoire, Boabeng-Fiema Monkey Sanctuary in Ghana). Even in sacred groves, however, the future of this species is uncertain, because traditional beliefs are no longer well respected and habitat degradation is ongoing (S. Gonedelé Bi pers. obs. 2014). In both Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana, more than half of the closed forest in the forest reserves has been converted to plantation or farmland, or cleared and left bare (Bitty et al. 2015). In Comoé National Park in Côte d’Ivoire, several groups remain, but hunting pressure and mining occur although some patrol is in place. At the border of Benin and Togo, the proposed construction of the 147MW Adjarala storage hydropower station on the Mono River is threatening the future of this species in the Togodo protected area; approximately 2,315 hectares of the forest will be submerged under water
population:
In Côte d’Ivoire, surveys conducted in the last three decades indicate that Colobus vellerosus has been extirpated from almost all the protected areas where it formerly occurred (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2012) except the Comoé National Park in the northeast where several groups were observed in December 2018–January 2019 (S. Gonedelé Bi and R. Matsuda Goodwin pers. comm. 2019). This species also occurs in a community forest (Tanoé-Ehy swamp forest) and two sacred groves (Dinaoudi and Grébouo 1). In Tanoé-Ehy, a few groups were observed (S. Gonedelé Bi, pers. obs. 2018). In Dinaoudi and Grébouo 1, not more than 45 individuals in total remain.

In Ghana, more than 50% of protected areas that contained C. vellerosus in the 1970s no longer contain it. There has been on the average 87% reduction in encounter rates of this species in six forest reserves in the last 30 years, suggesting an equivalent reduction in population size. On the other hand, Boabeng-Fiema Monkey Sanctuary and its surroundings were home to 365 individuals in 2007 (Kankam and Sicotte 2013). Although no systematic census has been conducted since then, this population appears to be stable, while at least two groups of this species survive in Kakum National Park where law enforcement has been strengthened in the last 10 years (Wiafe 2016). Danquah and Tetteh’s (2016) survey in the Kwabre swamp forest in the southwest of the country in February 2009 reported the average encounter rates of 1.5 group/km (logged areas) and 1 group/km (unlogged areas) for C. vellerosus, but R. Horwich (pers. comm. 2015) reported that the species became much scarcer in recent years. In Mole National Park, the relative abundance of the species reported by patrol guards shows a 69% decline between 2001 and 2006 (Burton 2010). The continued occurrence of this species at Bui and Digya National Parks is uncertain given the fact that the former has been extremely deforested and there is no evidence of the bushmeat of this species sold in the markets near the latter park.

In Togo, this species occurs in Togodo protected area near the Benin-Togo border, Fazao-Malfakassa National Park, and the Yikpa-Dzigbe community forest where a few small groups at each site were observed; it has been extirpated from Missahohe (Kpalime), Assime Forest and Assoukoko forest (Segniagbeto et al. 2017).

In Benin, a habituated group of about 18 individuals and another unhabituated group of three individuals live in Kikelé sacred grove; the Lama forest has one group consisting of 10-15 individuals. Other forests where this species was once reported occurring are Mt. Kouffé, Pénéssoulou, Wari-Maro, Lokoli Forest, Bonou, Upper Ouémé River Forest and Boukou.

In Nigeria, although surveys at eight localities in southwestern Nigeria in December 2015-January 2016 found no individuals, small isolated populations may still remain in Old Oyo NP and Opara Game Reserve (Kazeem 2017).

Colobus vellerosus is probably extinct in Burkina Faso (Ginn and Nekaris 2014).

Overall, we estimate that only about 850-1,150 individuals currently occur at known sites. By including areas where surveys have not yet been conducted or incompletely performed, our estimate of the total remaining population size of this species is less than 1,500 individual
range: Colobus vellerosus ranges eastward from between the Sassandra and Bandama Rivers in Côte d'Ivoire through Ghana, Togo, and Benin to western Nigeria. Its current distribution is extremely fragmented and within the Bandama-Sassandra interfluvial zone in Côte d'Ivoire, Grébouo 1 sacred forest is the only site where this species still occurs (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2014). A few local biologists and forest rangers have recently reported that this species still occurs in the Old Oyo National Park and Opara Game Reserve in western Nigeria (Kazeem 2017), but this needs verification. A subpopulation that was once located between the Bandama and Sassandra Rivers, and sometimes referred to the subspecies dollmani, probably represented a hybrid zone with C. polykomos (Oates & McGraw 2009). Recent surveys in this interfluvial region indicate that “dollmani” has been extirpated and that the remaining population of the black-and-white colobus in that area is more similar to C. vellerosus, based on pelage patterns (Gonedelé Bi et al. 2014).
useTrade: Subsistence hunting for bushmeat occurs for this species (national rather than international commercial value).
conservationActions: C. vellerosus is listed as Class A under the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources and under Appendix II of CITES. Range countries should enact tougher laws against the hunting of threatened species and strictly enforce them. In order to more accurately grasp the size and density of populations of this species, systematic surveys should be conducted in Mole NP, Digya NP, Atewa FR in Ghana, and Old Oyo NP, Opara Game Reserve, and Kainji Lake NP in Nigeria. Currently, the Centre Suisse de Recherches Scientifiques en Côte d’Ivoire (Swiss Centre for Scientific Research)(CSRS) and the Action pour la Conservation de la Biodiversité Côte d'Ivoire (ACB-CI) in Côte d’Ivoire, and West African Primate Conservation Action (WAPCA) in Ghana have initiated conservation efforts for C. vellerosus and other threatened primates in Tanoé-Ehy Community Forest in Côte d’Ivoire and in the nearby Kwabre Forest in Ghana by involving local communities (Koné 2015). CSRS and ACB-CI are also currently conducting surveys in the Comoé National Park. In Togo, the Togolese Association for Nature Conservation (AGBO-ZEGUE) is making an effort to contribute to the preservation of the habitats of the species in Togodo National Park (G. Segniagbeto pers. comm. 2016). We recommend developing primate tourism in the Kikélé Forest (Benin) and Comoé National Park (Côte d’Ivoire). Because there are no ex situ conservation programs targeting C. vellerosus, we encourage the European Association of Zoos and Aquaria to establish a captive-breeding programme for this species

rationale: Piliocolobus tephrosceles is listed as Endangered under criterion A4bc. A decline exceeding 50% of the population is estimated for a time period that includes both the past and future (three generations; 30 years) based on past reduced density and encounter rates, reduction in area of occupancy, and reduction in habitat quality, and the threats have not ceased. Red colobus monkeys are poorly adapted to habitat degradation and their populations have been completely extirpated from several forests outside protected areas due to habitat degradation and loss. If as expected these processes continue, then all populations outside protected areas will likely be lost in the near future. Furthermore, substantial population declines have been documented in some parts of Kibale National Park and Gombe Stream National Park due to predation by Chimpanzees, with up to 89% declines recorded in group encounter rates. The vast majority of Piliocolobus tephrosceles reside in one location – Kibale National Park. Given that it's survival depends on a single location, the future of this taxon is tenuous, especially as there is already a high level of predation by Chimpanzees in some parts of this park.
habitat:
This species occurs in a wide variety of forest types, including riverine and gallery forest, forest-miombo savanna mosaic, old-growth lowland, mid-altitude, and montane moist rain forest, degraded secondary forests, and raphia palm swamps (Struhsaker 2010, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013).

In Kibale, P. tephrosceles is most abundant in moist, old-growth, evergreen forest with emergent trees reaching 50 m in height (Struhsaker 2010, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013, and references therein). It can persist in lightly logged forest as long as important food trees remain (Lee et al. 1988). Groups of P. tephrosceles average about 45–50 individuals in Kibale, and 55–59 individuals in Gombe (Struhsaker 2010, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013, and references therein). The mean group size recorded in Mbizi was 41 and in Mbuzi, 34 (Davenport et al. 2007).
threats: The main threat to P. tephrosceles is habitat loss through selective logging of mature forest for timber, conversion to agricultural land, the production of charcoal, and forest fires. To some degree, hunting for meat and skins remains a threat (e.g., around Mbizi; Davenport et al. 2007). The taxon also appears to be heavily predated by Chimpanzees. At Ngogo in Kibale National Park, the Colobus Monkeys live with the largest community of Chimpanzees recorded anywhere, which form huge hunting parties that result in the highest hunting success rate known for any large vertebrate predator (Struhsaker 2010). The population in Gombe Stream National Park appears to be seriously threatened with extinction because of predation by Chimpanzees and because of the very small size (ca 80 km²) and isolation of Gombe (Struhsaker 2005).
population:
Piliocolobus tephrosceles numbers at least 20,000 animals, with the largest and most viable population in Kibale National Park in Uganda estimated at ≥17,000 (Struhsaker 2005). Approximately 60% of the Kibale National Park represents suitable habitat for red colobus and published density estimates in this habitat range from 93 to 313 individuals/km² (Struhsaker 2005). Although Kibale would appear to have a healthy and viable population, long-term studies in two areas of the park indicate statistically significant declines in Ashy Red Colobus numbers. In one of them—the Ngogo study area—census data spanning nearly 33 years indicate an 89% decline in group encounter rates (Lwanga et al. 2011), mainly due to predation by Chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes). A similar long-term study focusing on the effects of logging and spanning 28 years at the Kanyawara study site, also in Kibale, indicated a 40% decline in Ashy Red Colobus numbers in old growth and protected forest, as well as in nearby selectively logged forest (Chapman et al. 2000). Red Colobus density in forest fragments on the western boundary of Kibale averaged 2.1 animals per hectare and ranged from 0 to 8.33 animals/ha (Chapman et al. 2006). However, a more recent assessment found that many of those fragments have either been eliminated or degraded by human activities and that the Red Colobus populations in them declined by 83% between 2000 and 2010 (Chapman et al. 2013).

Ashy Red Colobus numbers in Gombe Stream National Park also seem to have declined due to predation by Chimpanzees. Red Colobus group sizes have declined by nearly 50% over a 25-year period (Stanford 1998) and 16–40% of them are killed each year by Chimpanzees (Wrangham and Bergmann-Riss 1990).
range: Piliocolobus tephrosceles is present on the eastern border of the Rift Valley in western Uganda and western Tanzania (Struhsaker and Grubb 2013). Five distinct subpopulations are known in western Uganda in Kibale National Park, and in western Tanzania in Biharamulo on the southwestern shores of Lake Victoria, in Gombe Stream and Mahale Mountains national parks on the eastern shores of Lake Tanganyika, and on the Ufipa Plateau (Mbizi and Misheta) (Rodgers et al. 1984). However, recent surveys in Misheta found little forest of any consequence left in the area, and the Red Colobus population there has is probably been extirpated (Davenport et al. 2007). A subpopulation subsequently recorded in a forest patch near the village of Nsangu (post the surveys by Rodgers et al. 1984) is probably also now extinct (Davenport et al. 2007). Davenport et al. (2007) reported a new and previously unrecorded population of P. tephrosceles in Mbuzi forest. They also surveyed the Chala forest, which was in poor condition; no primates were seen, although it is not known if Red Colobus ever existed there. This species may be present in Burundi, Rwanda and eastern parts of the Democratic Republic of Congo, but its presence has not been confirmed.
useTrade: Bushmeat consumption is not common, although it does occur. Furthermore, Ashy Red Colobus are occasionally hunted opportunistically to feed dogs.
conservationActions:
This taxon is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

It is present in the Gombe Stream and Mahale Mountains national parks in Tanzania. It is also present in the 766-km² Kibale Forest National Park in Uganda, which may contain the only viable subpopulation; hunting by humans is virtually non-existent in this park (Struhsaker 2005). Long-term monitoring of the Ngogo subpopulation is required, as well as a comprehensive, long-term monitoring programme for the colobus throughout Kibale, as Kibale is the last hope for conservation of this taxon.

The southernmost population in the Mbizi forest should be protected, as this is the only remaining montane forest of any size in Ufipa, and the only source of water for Sumbawanga’s growing human population. There is also a need for immediate intervention if Mbuzi is not to be lost completely following the recent fate of both the Misheta and Nsangu forests. The forest patch is very small, isolated and has no protected status or management (Davenport et al. 2007).

The first conservation action plan for red colobus monkeys will be published in 2020. This plan identifies priority areas for conservation and recommends range-wide and taxon-based actions to prevent red colobus extinctions. The range-wide conservation priorities include actions that aim to improve government investment in wildlife conservation, expand and improve protected areas, determine taxon-specific distribution and abundance, engage with local human populations and involve them in conservation activities, remove barriers that prevent local access to human healthcare and family planning, and raise awareness of the plight of red colobus.

rationale: This species is assessed as Vulnerable due to a suspected past population rate of at least 30%, primarily due to habitat loss but also due to rapid habitat degradation. The Pará State in Brazil has lost 12% of its forest cover from 2000 to 2018 (Global Forest Watch 2020).
habitat: The species occurs in lowland primary and secondary terra firme forests (Costa-Araújo et al. 2019).
threats:
The area within the species' range has suffered extensive environmental damages due to illegal logging and agricultural expansion—this is happening even in federal protected areas and protected indigenous lands. This region is one of the main fronts of forest destruction in the Arc of deforestation, a region infamously characterized by fast, intense and disordered conversion of forests to pastoral and agricultural land and human settlements. In addition, there are four hydroelectric plants in the process of implementation in this region that will directly impact the habitat of the species.

Feeder roads of the Cuiaba-Santarem highway cut through the eastern border of the distribution of M. munduruku, resulting in considerable deforestation, including in protected areas. These roads also connect to the illegal alluvial mining areas in the Rio Crepori. There is extensive damage due to alluvial mining in the north eastern section of its range.
population: This is unknown regarding this species, but it is suspected that populations are in decline due to habitat degradation.
range:
Mico munduruku is endemic to the Amazonian forest of the southwest of Pará State, Brazil, occurring from the left margin of the Rio Jamanxim River, below the mouth of Rio Novo, possibly up to the right margin of the upper Rio Tapajós, below the mouth of the Rio Cururú (Costa-Araújo et al. 2019).

Based on specimens observed in the field, interviews with local inhabitants, specimens examined in museum collections and field reports, there are seven localities in the northern Tapajós–Jamanxim interfluve where the distinctive marmosets can be found, covering an area of approximately 55,000 km (Costa-Araújo et al. 2019). The state of Pará in Brazil has lost 12% of its forest cover from 2000 to 2018 (Global Forest Watch 2020).
conservationActions: Mico munduruku already faces the above-mentioned threats, and they will only increase as hydroelectric plants and complementary infrastructure projects as roads and transmission lines come to completion, inducing more intense settlement and forest reduction in the region. For these reasons, further research is urgently needed to better delimit the species’ range and to estimate population size and density, allowing for assessment of its conservation status and mitigate some of the projected impacts on its populations.

rationale: Sapajus apella is listed as Least Concern as the species is widespread and there are currently no major threats resulting in a significant overall population decline that would warrant listing in a threatened category or listing as Near Threatened. Although declines need to be considered over a period of 45 years (three generations), the species is more of a habitat generalist than other species with similar life-histories. However, the species is declining in some parts of its range, especially due to hunting and this combined with a reduced area of distribution.
habitat:
This species inhabits nearly all types of Amazonian lowland and submontane forest.

Capuchins are frugivores-insectivores, including a wide variety of fruits, seeds and arthropods, frogs, nestlings and even small mammals in their diet, supplemented by stems, flowers and leaves. They are extractive, manipulative foragers (see Struhsaker and Leland 1977, Izawa 1979). 

Mean group size is 18 individuals, with numbers of females exceeding the numbers of males (adult sex ratio of 0.85). Males disperse. Both sexes make up linear hierarchies, the top-ranking male being dominant to the top-ranking female. Subordinate males are often peripheral (Fragaszy et al. 2004).

Size: Adult male 1.35-4.8 kg (mean 3.05 kg); adult female: 1.76-3.4 kg (mean 2.4 kg) (Jack 2007).
threats: The species is hunted for food and for pets (among the most common primate kept as pets). The release of pet S. a. margaritae back into the wild is another threat for these primates (Martinez et al. 2000). Such releases must be considered in terms of the level of risk of disease transmission and hybridization. In Peru, Aquino and Encarnación (1994) reported that hunting has led to its extirpation in areas around human settlements. The species is threatened by habitat loss and fragmentation caused by urban/human population expansion.
population:
The species is widespread and common, though it is suspected that populations are decreasing.

Population density of the Margarita Island Capuchin has yet to be properly estimated. Results of an ongoing project about ecology and conservation of the Margarita Island Capuchin will allow the determination of densities in the near future. According to Sanz and Marquez (1994), total population is only 250-300 animals. Marquez and Sanz (1991) estimated between 0.02 and 0.23 groups/hours of observation in different forest fragments. Group size was 4.5 ind/group in average. During surveys conducted in 2007, group size varied between 2 and 15 individuals (N. Ceballos-Mago, direct observation).

In Tinigua National Park, Stevenson et al. (1992) recorded a density for Sapajus apella of 16 individuals/km² and, later Stevenson (2007) estimated a density of 27 individuals/km² (Stevenson 2007). 

Freese (1975, 1977) estimated the population density in the Manu National Park to be 36 individuals/km², and similar densities (40 individuals/km²) were found by Terborgh (1983, Terborgh and Janson 1985, Janson 1985a,b).

Further population densities estimates have been published as follows: Gallery forest in El Tuparro National Park, Colombia - 15-17 individuals/km² (Defler and Pintor 1985); Pacaya-Samiria, Peru - 8-10 individuals/km² (Soini 1986); Estación Biológica de Caparú, Colombia - 8 individuals/km² (Defler 2004); Río Puré, Colombia - 5.8 individuals/km² (Defler 2004); Samiria basin, Peru - 24 individuals/km² (Freese 1975, 1977). In Brazil, group size variesfrom 7 to  21 individuals (Peres 1988a, Izawa 1980). The following are density estimates in different sites: 14.6 ind/km² and 24.11 ind/km² in Carauari, AM; 0.71 ind/km² in Coarí, AM; 6.84 ind/km² in Tefé, AM; 6.73 ind./km² in Sena Madureira, AC (Peres 1988a); 8.62 ind/km² in FLOES do Antimary, AC and 8.95 ind/km² in Fazenda Bela Esperança, AC (Calouro 2005); 1.38 ind/km² and 8.18 ind/km² in Lago Mamori, AM and 6.61 ind/km² (Vulinec et al. 2006); 0.19 groups/10 km survey TI Campinas/Katukina (Calouro 2007), 0.27 groups/10 km survey Reserva Florestal Humaitá (Botelho et al. 2012).
range: This is a wide-ranging species in the lower Amazon. The species is found in Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Peru, Suriname, and Venezuela.
useTrade: The species is hunted for food and for pets (among the most common primate kept as pets). The release of pet monkeys back into the wild is another threat for these primates (Martinez et al., 2000). Such releases must be considered in terms of the level of risk of disease transmission and hybridization. In Peru, Aquino and Encarnación (1994) reported that hunting has led to its extirpation in areas around human settlements. The species is affected by illegal trade. In local markets in Amazonian Ecuador, a capuchin monkey could be sold in US$20-50 (J. Olalla pers. comm.).
conservationActions:
This species is listed on CITES Appendix II. This species occurs in numerous protected areas, many of which are very large.
